HEADLINE: Ex-Regulator Hired to Advise Bertelsmann 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
The German media company Bertelsmann has hired Joel I. Klein, the former head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, as a strategic adviser. He brings a prodigious set of connections at a time when the concern is poised for acquisitions.
 The efforts by Mr. Klein to strengthen the Justice Department's antitrust enforcement and its lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation made him a high-profile figure in the Clinton administration before he resigned in September. 
 Over the last three years, he also developed a close personal friendship with Thomas Middelhoff, the chief executive of Bertelsmann, as the media company expanded its holdings in the United States.
Mr. Klein said he never handled any matters involving Bertelsmann while working for the government. In fact, media companies fall under the jurisdiction of the federal government's other antitrust regulator, the Federal Trade Commission.
Bertelsmann's most high-profile recent deal -- the acquisition of Random House, the largest English language publisher, and its merger with Bertelsmann's Bantam Doubleday Dell -- was reviewed by the F.T.C., not Mr. Klein's division.
Bertelsmann will have ample use for Mr. Klein's antitrust expertise. In addition to his connections in the United States, Mr. Klein also worked closely with European antitrust regulators, who are often a bigger issue for Bertelsmann.
Bertelsmann is currently in talks to acquire the record company EMI, a deal that is likely to face the scrutiny of European regulators. Those regulators are also investigating the possibility of collusion on compact disc prices among European record music companies.
But Mr. Middelhoff said he hired Mr. Klein for his advice on strategy and for his public image as a vigorous regulator. "Joel is deeply connected with the Internet economy, and it is great to have him representing Bertelsmann's face to American society," Mr. Middelhoff said.
In addition to Random House, Bertelsmann owns the record labels Arista and RCA through its BMG music division along with many other book and music companies in the United States and overseas. In addition, the company owns book and music manufacturing companies, book and music clubs, the magazine publisher Gruner & Jahr, trade journals, and European newspapers and television stations.
It has embarked on an ambitious plan to sell its own books and music over the Internet, including starting the Internet retailer Bol.com, buying a 40 percent stake in the BarnesandNoble.com and investing in the digital music sharing Web site Napster.
The company is currently shopping for new acquisitions with a $12 billion war chest left over from the sale of its shares in America Online and other Internet investments.
Mr. Klein, 54, who was born in the Bronx, will assume the title of chief United States liaison officer to the parent company, Bertelsmann A.G. He will also become chairman and chief executive of Bertelsmann Inc., which handles real estate, financing, and other services for the company's North American divisions. He will not be responsible for Random House, BMG or any of the company's other operating divisions.
The new post is Mr. Klein's first job as a businessman after a career as a lawyer. After being a clerk for the Supreme Court, he became a public interest lawyer focusing on cases involving the mentally ill. He then practiced as a trial lawyer at a small, well-connected Washington law firm specializing in appellate and Supreme Court cases.
He took a leave in 1992 to help the Clinton administration nominate a justice of the Supreme Court and then worked in the White House counsel's office for about 15 months before moving to the Justice Department in 1994.
But Mr. Klein said his experience as an antitrust regulator educated him in business issues involving the convergence of digital technology and media. Some of those issues arose in the Microsoft case. "Joel has developed pretty good insights into the businesses he was regulating and a point of view on them, and I am pretty sure he will offer those up," said Steven Rattner, an investment banker who knows him. 
Mr. Klein also brings to Bertelsmann extensive connections with executives like Mr. Middelhoff at many of the companies he regulated. He met Mr. Middelhoff about three years ago, at a Washington dinner party at the home of the lawyer Vernon Jordan.
Mr. Middelhoff, a German who had recently been promoted to Bertelsmann's chief executive, immediately hit it off with Mr. Klein, both said. They began meeting for breakfast about twice a year at downtown Washington restaurants like the Four Seasons. "He was interested in learning about the U.S. and learning, obviously, about antitrust and competition policies in a general sense, although he didn't have anything before us," Mr. Klein said. "I found that learning from him about technology and e-commerce was very helpful." He said they never discussed specific regulatory issues.
In May 1999, Mr. Klein attended Mr. Middelhoff's 46th birthday party at the restaurant Daniel on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. In December, Mr. Klein also attended a meeting of Bertelsmann executives at its headquarters in Gutersloh, Germany, followed by a Christmas party at Mr. Middelhoff's home.
"Everyone loved him," Mr. Middelhoff said. "Late in the evening, when we made some funny jokes and so on, he was joking with us and he got it immediately -- I am very confident that he will fit it with Bertelsmann's corporate culture."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 2, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the appointment of Joel I. Klein as United States liaison officer at the Bertelsmann media company misstated the name and location of a restaurant in Washington where he had breakfast with Thomas Middelhoff, the company's chief executive. It is the Seasons restaurant at the Four Seasons Hotel, not the Four Seasons restaurant. And it is in Georgetown, not downtown.

HEADLINE: Medicine for the Economy 

 BODY:
It has been a rough few weeks economically. Americans have been receiving their sobering year-end 401(k) statements in the mail and reading about energy crises and layoffs at companies ranging from DaimlerChrysler to Amazon.com. Somber-looking politicians have taken to the airwaves to worry about a potential recession, a malady that the much-hyped "new economy" had supposedly rendered obsolete. It is no wonder that the index tracking consumer confidence in the economy's future has taken its steepest single-month nosedive in a decade. 
 Yesterday Alan Greenspan, worried about consumer expectations' nasty way of becoming self-fulfilling, delivered a needed pep pill to the nation in the form of a half-point cut in the key federal funds interest rate. His message: Relax, don't worry, and go out and spend some money so we can keep this economy growing. 
 With inflation no longer a threat, the Federal Reserve said it was engaged in a "rapid and forceful" response to the erosion in consumer confidence and stagnation in economic growth. The central bank had already cut rates by a half-point in early January. Mr. Greenspan hinted last week during his Congressional testimony that further cuts would be forthcoming when he noted that the economy may have ceased growing. Consumers and businesses can expect to borrow money more cheaply because of the move. 
Concerns about the economy were heightened yesterday when the Commerce Department reported that the economy grew in the final quarter of 2000 at an annual rate of 1.4 percent, the slowest in five years, and the Congressional Budget Office lowered its previous estimate of 3.1 percent growth for 2001 to 2.4 percent. Yet even as the short-term estimates worsened, the Budget Office boosted estimates of the federal government's likely budget surplus over the next 10 years by $1 trillion, increasing the threat that Congress will relax the fiscal discipline that played such a big role in generating the economic boom of the 1990's. 
Already Congressional Republicans are using the projected surplus to press for George W. Bush's 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut, and some Republicans believe the cut should be even larger. The Democrats are falling back, with some talking of accepting a cut as high as $1 trillion. But it would be a mistake to embrace deep, irreversible tax cuts on the basis of shaky surplus projections that may not pan out a decade hence. Recent history teaches that while monetary policy is the most effective short-term economic stimulus, fiscal discipline, and not an excessive tax cut, is the most effective long-term stimulus government can provide. 
Congressional Democrats should stand up for continued fiscal discipline by seeking to trim the scope of tax cuts and by insisting that they be phased in over the 10-year period, so that if the annual surpluses fall short of projections, the tax cuts can be curtailed. 
The projected surplus, it must be remembered, is not all that large compared with the demands that will be put upon it. Walling off the Social Security and Medicare components of the $5.6 trillion projected surplus over a decade brings the total of money potentially available down to $2.7 trillion. It would be reckless to commit well over half of this amount to a tax cut before Congress begins to address the host of important issues that will require new spending.

HEADLINE: FED CUTS KEY RATE BY HALF A POINT, CITING SLOWDOWN 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve today cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time this month, making clear that it intends to wage an aggressive battle against the growing possibility of a recession.
 Citing deteriorating conditions across the economy, the central bank's policy-setting committee voted for what it called "a rapid and forceful response of monetary policy" to breathe new life into the decade-long expansion. 
 "Alan Greenspan was blamed for one Bush recession," said Diane Swonk, chief economist at Bank One, referring to the economic downturn from mid-1990 to early 1991, when the current president's father was in the White House. "He doesn't want to be blamed for another."
While offering some reassuring words about the economy's prospects over the long run, the Fed also signaled that it would probably cut rates further in coming months, saying that "the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate economic weakness in the foreseeable future." 
Earlier today the Commerce Department reported that the economy expanded at a 1.4 percent annual pace in the last three months of 2000, well below what most economists had expected. Page C1. 
The Fed's rate cuts are traditionally aimed at stimulating economic growth by making credit less expensive, thus encouraging people to borrow and spend, particularly for homes, cars and appliances, three pillars of the economy. 
The central bank said it had reduced the main interest rate it controls, the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks, to 5.5 percent from 6 percent. It also reduced its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system to 5 percent from 5.5 percent.
"The message from this and the previous action is that the Fed is ready, willing and able to do what's necessary to head off a rapid decline in economic activity," said Richard D. Rippe, an economist at Prudential Securities.
The move led to an immediate reduction in the rates paid by consumers and businesses for some types of loans. Many of the nation's largest banks immediately cut their prime lending rate to 8.5 percent from 9 percent, a move that will affect some small business and consumer loans, including some adjustable mortgages. But borrowing costs for fixed-rate mortgages may not fall much in response to the move, since they are less affected by changes in short-term interest rates and they had already declined considerably in recent months.
In cutting its key rate by half a point, the Fed matched the expectations of most analysts. Mr. Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had signaled in testimony to Congress last week that a substantial rate cut was likely, saying that economic growth had declined to near zero.
But some investors had been hoping the Fed would cut rates by three-quarters of a percentage point, especially after a widely watched gauge of consumer sentiment, the Conference Board's index of consumer confidence, tumbled on Tuesday at a pace not seen since the last recession a decade ago.
As a result, investors did not respond today with anything like the exuberance that followed the Fed's last rate cut, on Jan. 3, when the central bank stunned the markets by cutting rates by half a point between scheduled meetings.
Stock prices fell in the minutes after the Fed's announcement at 2:15 p.m., but then steadied. The Dow Jones industrial index finished at 10,887.36, up 6.16 points. The Nasdaq index fell 65.62 points, to 2,772.73.
In explaining its action, the Fed described an economy that was slowing across the board. It noted that businesses appeared to be adapting faster than usual to slowing demand and dwindling profits because technology allows them to keep a finger on the nation's economic pulse with greater precision than ever before.
"Consumer and business confidence has eroded further, exacerbated by rising energy costs that continue to drain consumer purchasing power and press on business profit margins," the central bank said in a statement issued after the completion of its two-day meeting. 
"Partly as a consequence, retail sales and business spending on capital equipment have weakened appreciably," the statement continued. "In response, manufacturing production has been cut back sharply, with new technologies appearing to have accelerated the response of production and demand to potential excesses in the stock of inventories and capital equipment."
Economists said the statement showed that the Fed saw some glimmers of hope. Rising energy prices are likely to be less of a drag on the economy after winter ends. 
Capital spending, while down from its extremely high levels of the past few years, is not likely to collapse, given the pressure in nearly all industries to cut costs and improve quality. And the sharp, painful inventory adjustment being undertaken by many companies is likely to be completed relatively quickly, analysts said, allowing a return by mid-year to something approaching business as usual.
"It feels bad because it's so fast, but because it's so fast, it won't last that long," said William C. Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs in New York.
Economists at Credit Suisse First Boston said the economy appeared to be in a V-shaped cycle in which a stomach-churning downturn could well be followed by a rapid recovery.
In cutting rates twice this month by a total of one percentage point, the Fed put rates back where they were a year ago, when it was partway through a campaign to squelch what it saw at the time as growing inflationary pressure.
Analysts said any further signs of weakness would bring more rate cuts, perhaps even before the Fed's next scheduled meeting on March 20. 
"They're going to be driven by the data," Mr. Dudley said.
Among the indicators the Fed will be watching are consumer confidence and the stock market. Mr. Greenspan told Congress last week that the difference between a short period of painful adjustment to slower growth and a recession is often determined by how consumers respond.
Because the market's ups and downs can have a psychological impact even on people who are not investors, the Fed has a tricky job in dealing with Wall Street. A year ago, Mr. Greenspan suggested that interest rates might have to rise because the market was creating so much wealth that the economy was overheating. Now he would no doubt like to see the market rise gradually without getting out of hand.
There are also confusing signals about the degree of the economy's weakness.
Although consumer confidence is down, spending has held up relatively well. Declining long-term interest rates, driven by expectations that the threat of higher inflation has disappeared, have made mortgages more affordable, giving a boost to the housing industry. The Commerce Department reported today that sales of new homes jumped 13.4 percent in December, the biggest increase in eight years.
Yet manufacturers say business has stalled, and companies in many industries are laying off workers for the first time in years. Analysts expect the unemployment rate to begin creeping up from its current level of 4 percent.
"The G.D.P. numbers show a two-tier economy, with the manufacturing sector in recession and industrial production still declining, but the rest of the economy holding up reasonably well," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
The economy also seems likely to benefit later this year from the stimulus of a tax cut, particularly after Mr. Greenspan put his weight behind one last week. Economists said the combination of monetary and fiscal stimulus should ensure that the downturn, however steep it turns out to be, remains relatively short.

HEADLINE: This, It Appears Sure, Is the Year of the Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
After years in which Democrats blocked Republican tax-cutting efforts, President Bush now seems all but certain to shepherd a substantial tax cut through Congress this year.
 It is still unclear whether Democrats can contain the tax cut to something less than the 10-year figure of $1.6 trillion proposed by Mr. Bush, or whether it might grow even larger as some Republicans have suggested it should. 
 The composition of the tax cut is still very much up in the air as well, with Democrats intent on directing its benefits more to lower- and middle-income people than the Bush plan would. 
But the focus has shifted from whether to how much, how quickly and with how much bipartisan support.
"Clearly there will be a tax cut, and it will be a significant tax cut," said Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. "There should be a broad-based tax cut that affects all taxpayers."
Like most other Democrats, Mr. Baucus said any tax cut had to fit within a budget that provided sufficient money to deal with other needs, especially education, the long-term financial stability of Social Security and Medicare, and repayment of the national debt.
Moreover, Mr. Baucus said, the central element of Mr. Bush's plan, a reduction in all income tax rates, will have to be modified to make sure that the primary beneficiaries are not the wealthiest taxpayers but instead "working families, because they are hurting in many parts of the country."
But nearly all the defenses that allowed Democrats to hold back the Republican tax-cutting tide in recent years have been washed away.
With a Republican in the White House, Democrats in Congress no longer have a presidential veto to back them up; last year President Bill Clinton vetoed two tax cuts, both of which had passed Congress by comfortable margins.
In stating last week that the government could afford a large tax reduction without endangering its ability to pay off the national debt, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, undermined the Democratic position that a tax cut would be fiscally irresponsible.
The Congressional Budget Office's new, upwardly revised surplus projection to $5.6 trillion over the next decade makes it particularly hard for Democrats to sustain their argument that there is not room for a broad-based tax cut.
And the jitters over the nation's economic health -- which were underscored again today by the Federal Reserve's decision to cut interest rates for the second time in three weeks -- make it politically difficult for Democrats to oppose tax cuts that Republicans have artfully packaged as recession insurance.
"We now have what looks like pretty uniform agreement that we should have a tax cut and that we should have marginal-rate reductions," Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary, told reporters this week. 
The size of the tax cut, Mr. O'Neill said, is "a legitimate question," but not, he added, one that should unduly slow progress in getting legislation enacted. 
Should they choose to, Democrats could no doubt slow the tax-cutting effort. The party's more liberal members in particular find it hard to contemplate supporting anything like Mr. Bush's plan, which among other things would also repeal the federal estate tax.
But the changing landscape facing Democrats can be traced by looking at the tax cut proposals they have backed over the past year.
At the start of the presidential campaign, Al Gore proposed a tax cut of $250 billion over 10 years. By last summer, Mr. Gore was up to $500 billion.
This week, Democrats have been talking about a range between $750 billion and $1 trillion, and signaling that they are open to a deal with the White House. When Republicans in Congress sought a tax cut of that scale several years ago, it was derided by Democrats as fiscal folly.
Seeing their advantage, some Republicans in Congress have been trying to cast Mr. Bush's $1.6 trillion figure as a floor in any negotiations. 
The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, said he would like to add tax cuts for business and a reduction in the capital gains tax. Members of both parties are eager to expand the popular individual retirement account and 401(k) savings programs. An array of expiring tax breaks for individuals and corporations are likely to be extended.
With things going his way, Mr. Bush has indicated in the last several days that he would not object to Congress's taking the tax plan up in pieces if that would speed the passage of its main components.
As a first line of defense, Democrats are pushing to allocate the available portion of the federal budget surplus in equal thirds: to tax cuts, additional spending and a reserve that could go to debt reduction and shoring up Social Security and Medicare. They are also considering ideas like making any tax cut dependent on the surplus's actually materializing.
But they have yet to find the kind of roadblock to tax cuts that Mr. Clinton came up with three years ago when he challenged Congress to "save Social Security first" and keep the surplus off limits until then.
"It would be a mistake to play the game on Bush's terrain," said Will Marshall, president of the Progressive Policy Institute, a research group for centrist Democrats. "It's not fiscally responsible and certainly not a progressive way to go. If Democrats can't coalesce around a progressive alternative, that will provide opportunities for the White House to play divide and conquer, and will leave some Democrats fearful of missing the tax-cut train."

HEADLINE: Bush, in Outreach Bid, Meets Black Caucus 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
During his first 12 days in office, President Bush has swayed and prayed at a black church, stopped his motorcade at two predominantly black schools and advocated policies intended in part to rehabilitate black communities.
 He has surrounded himself with black advisers, talked with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and considered whether to make permanent President Bill Clinton's temporary appointment of the lone black judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va. 
 Mr. Bush received 8 percent of the African-American vote in November, the lowest level of black support for a Republican presidential candidate since Barry Goldwater ran in 1964. Several African-American members of Congress stormed out of the House chamber in early January when electoral votes giving Mr. Bush the presidency were tallied. 
But the new president has made a concerted effort to improve his standing among the nation's roughly 35 million blacks, an ethnic outreach effort that continued today as he met with a deeply suspicious Congressional Black Caucus.
"It was a freewheeling, blunt meeting," said Representative Melvin Watt, Democrat of North Carolina. "He spent 95 percent of the time listening."
During the campaign, and particularly at the Republican convention in Philadelphia, Mr. Bush showcased black supporters and advisers, which did little to attract African-American votes in November, but was seen as a signal of reassurance to white moderates that he intended to govern from the center.
Karen P. Hughes, a counselor to Mr. Bush, said he intended to be the president of all Americans, whether they voted for him or not.
"He's aware that he did not do well with the African-American vote but he's not going to let that stop him," Ms. Hughes said. 
Before Mr. Bush sat down in the Cabinet Room with about 30 black members of Congress this afternoon, Ms. Hughes acknowledged, "There are not a lot of supporters of his in that group."
But Mr. Bush's target audience extends well beyond the people in any given meeting.
"What Bush is doing is aimed as much at white people as black people," said David Bositis, an analyst of minority voting at the Joint Center for Economic Studies. "Bush is conservative, more conservative than the American public. By doing the things he's doing, he makes himself appear more moderate."
Mr. Bush opened the meeting with the black caucus, all Democrats, by saying he wanted to discuss his education proposals, some of which are intended to bring greater accountability to schools in poor urban areas. "While there may be some discussion about details," Mr. Bush said, "all of us, surely, believe the great hope for this country is to make sure every child -- I mean every child -- is educated."
The conversation turned quickly to a topic that is especially sensitive to Mr. Bush: the dispute over counting the votes, many of them in predominantly black areas, in Florida in the presidential election. 
Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, said before the hourlong White House meeting: "There's nothing more painful for blacks than our struggle for the right to vote. We're not getting over the pain we have from Florida."
Mr. Bush was ready to discuss the issue. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said before the meeting that the president believed there were numerous problems that the election highlighted beyond black voting, including difficulties with absentee ballots from overseas military personnel and news projections of the winners before the close of voting.
Chief among the 20 or so issues that arose at the meeting today was Mr. Bush's nomination of John Ashcroft, an outspoken conservative, as attorney general, an appointment vehemently opposed by many black political leaders and organizations. 
"That was the first thing that came up," said Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan. "We explained to him why we couldn't buy Ashcroft in 100 years."
It is unlikely that such opposition would be assuaged by the appointment of a black person as one of Mr. Ashcroft's deputies. Larry Thompson, a former United States attorney from Georgia, is a likely candidate, administration officials said. One appointment that would make at least some amends, black lawmakers say, would be to give Roger L. Gregory, whom Mr. Clinton last month appointed temporarily to the Fourth Circuit, a permanent post.
Mr. Bush's outreach toward blacks, who make up roughly 13 percent of the population, began shortly after he took the oath of office.
"While many of our citizens prosper, others doubt the promise, even the justice, of our own country," he said in his inaugural speech, remarks that aides said were intended, in part, for blacks. "The ambitions of some Americans are limited by failing schools and hidden prejudice and the circumstances of their birth. And sometimes our differences run so deep, it seems we share a continent, but not a country."
In the days since, Mr. Bush has spoken to traditional black leaders and sought to widen the circle to others more sympathetic to his approach.
He named three African Americans to high-level positions in his administration: Colin L. Powell as secretary of state, Roderick R. Paige as education secretary and Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser. And he surrounded himself with blacks at the White House while announcing his education reform plan and his initiative to prod more religious groups into delivering social services.
Mr. Bush also called Mr. Jackson soon after the civil rights leader acknowledged that he had fathered a child with a mistress. Mr. Bush said in the call that he was praying for Mr. Jackson, who has been outspoken in challenging the fairness of the vote-counting in Florida.
Last Sunday, Mr. Bush chose Lincoln Park United Methodist Church in Washington, which has a predominantly black congregation, for one of his first spiritual outings as president. He nodded his head to the chorus and swayed at the refrain, "I've got a feeling everything's going to be all right."
It is far from clear, however, whether the same can be said of his relations with African-Americans. Aides say that Mr. Bush had a dismal showing among blacks in his first campaign for Texas governor but rebounded four years later with about a fifth of the African-American vote.
Aside from the president's own aides, Mr. Rangel has been the black official who has visited most often with Mr. Bush, primarily because of his position as the ranking Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee. After three meetings in 24 hours, Mr. Rangel says he is still reserving judgment on whether the new president will aid African-Americans.
"We have not dealt with a single substantive issue in these meetings," Mr. Rangel said. "He's agreed with everything I've said. You can't come out angry when someone says, 'You're right. You're right. You're right.' "
As for some of the gestures the president has made, Mr. Rangel dismisses them.
"Passing out a couple dollars to ministers is not an overture to blacks," he said of the Bush initiative on religion-backed charity. "Visiting a black church is like me going to a cathedral in Paris to reach out to European Catholics. We have to deal with something of substance."

HEADLINE: THE LOCKERBIE VERDICT: THE OVERVIEW; 
LIBYAN CONVICTED BY SCOTTISH COURT IN '88 PAN AM BLAST

BYLINE:  By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: CAMP ZEIST, the Netherlands, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
A Scottish court today found a Libyan intelligence official guilty of murder in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 in 1988, when 270 died, but did not convict the second defendant and released him.
 The investigation into the bombing pitted Libya and its leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, against the West, with international sanctions costing Libya an estimated $30 billion before it finally handed over the suspects in 1999 under a diplomatic compromise that brought the trial to the Netherlands. 
 But the White House said today that the verdict would not end a ban on business deals with Libya or flights there by Americans, which has been in place since 1986. And President Bush said he would press Libya to apologize for the terrorism and compensate the families, many of whom watched the verdict in person or at closed-circuit broadcasts around the world, including New York and Washington. 
The verdict appeared to satisfy many families who lost members when Flight 103, on its way from London to New York, dropped out of the sky onto Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. They said it would help their civil case against Libya, which names Colonel Qaddafi as the chief plotter in the bombing, which took the lives of 189 Americans.
Bruce M. Smith, a retired Pan Am pilot whose wife, Ingrid, was killed, said he regretted that the trial had not been in an American federal court "so we could have gotten a death sentence." And Bryan Flynn, whose elder brother, J. P., was killed, said the verdict proved the bombing had been "an orchestrated strike against the Western world." He and other family members want sanctions renewed and Colonel Qaddafi tried as a war criminal.
The three judges, in an 82-page written decision, admitted that the prosecution's case had "uncertainties and qualifications," that key witnesses had repeatedly lied and that the prosecution had not explained how a bomb got aboard the plane. 
But they nonetheless unanimously concluded "there is nothing in the evidence which leaves us with any reasonable doubt as to the guilt" of the Libyan intelligence officer, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed al-Megrahi.
Mr. Megrahi's fellow defendant in the nine-month trial, Al Amin Khalifah Fhimah, a former airline manager, was told he was "discharged and free to go." Draped in a white toga and wearing a flat black fez, he rose to walk out a side door to freedom. His legal team stalked out the opposite door with curt bows to the judges.
Mr. Megrahi remained alone, slumped slightly forward, listening to his lawyer, who gave a brief, strained plea that Mr. Megrahi still maintained his innocence. He was told sentence would be passed after lunch, and Mr. Megrahi returned in three hours, looking stooped and wan, his toga hugged tightly around him. He was told that a life sentence was mandatory under Scottish law, and that the court, "in view of the horrendous nature of the crime," wished him to serve 20 years before any parole consideration.
Were it not for his age, 49, and that a Scottish prison will be foreign to him, Chief Judge Lord Ranald Sutherland said, the court would have recommended an even longer wait. Even so, Peter Lowenstein, father of a young American killed in the crash, said afterward: "Twenty years for 270 murders is less than a month per victim. It's just not right."
As the court attendees sat in stony silence while the clerk recorded the verdict, the public gallery on the other side of the soundproof glass was aflutter with nervous concern because Jim Swire, a tall, white-haired doctor who had sat through most of the trial and speaks for many of the British families, had suddenly gone pale and slid down his chair with his jaw agape. Ushers carried him out to an ambulance, but apparently he had only fainted from the tension.
United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan said after the verdict, "Justice has taken its course and the authority and legitimacy of the legal process must be respected." United Nations sanctions inposed on Libya in 1992 were suspended during the trial, but could be reinstated. 
Libya's ambassador to the European Union, Hamed al-Hudhairy, on hand for the verdict, said he thought there was "no possibility of sanctions being re-imposed." That threat was "something we have heard for a long time from the families," who he said were trying to "take the whole Libyan people hostage." 
Mr. al-Hudhairy called the verdict "a political decision," asking how it was possible to conclude that a defendant accused of arranging the bombing could be guilty if the defendant accused of helping him get the bomb aboard was innocent.
But the court did not conclude that Mr. Fhimah was innocent; it concluded that the prosecution had not proved beyond a reasonable doubt that he was guilty, though the court did not choose the "not proven" verdict available under Scottish law. 
The three judges did vote unanimously to find Mr. Megrahi guilty, which in theory reduces his chances of winning any appeal because in Scottish courts, a unanimous verdict tends to carry more weight than a split decision. The decision on Mr. Fhimah was also unanimous.
Although Mr. Megrahi was convicted, the court's written reasons (available at www.scotcourts .gov.uk/html/lockerbie.htm) show that it did not think the prosecution had proved all elements of its case.
The judges agreed that forensic evidence proved that the bomb, triggered by a Mebo MST-13 timer, was inside a Toshiba radio-cassette player in a brown Samsonite suitcase with clothing bought at Mary's House, a store in Malta.
But, they added, "the absence of any explanation of the method by which the primary suitcase might have been placed aboard KM 180 is a major difficulty for the Crown case." If there was an unaccompanied bag with a bomb on KM 180, an Air Malta flight from Malta to Frankfurt, there was evidence that such a bag could have moved through Frankfurt's airport to Pan Am Flight 103. 
The judges were scathing about two important witnesses: Abdul Majid Giaka, a Libyan secret service turncoat, and Edwin Bollier, an owner of Mebo, a Swiss electronics firm.
"Putting the matter shortly, we are unable to accept Abdul Majid as a credible and reliable witness on any matter except his description of the J.S.O.," the court concluded, referring to Libya's intelligence agency, the Jamahariya Security Organization, at which Mr. Majid had started his career as an auto mechanic. It rejected all his testimony about plastic explosives hidden in desks, conversations with the defendants about the Pan Am bombing and his claim to have seen Mr. Megrahi with a brown Samsonite.
Mr. Bollier, the court found, was an "untruthful and unreliable witness," and some of his testimony "belongs in the realm of fiction where it may be best placed in the genre of the spy thriller."
Tony Gauci, the owner of the clothing store in Malta, was "doing his best to tell the truth," the court found, and was believable when describing the clothes he sold. Of his visual identification of Mr. Megrahi, it said, "there are undoubtedly problems," because he had picked other people out of photo displays. 
Still, the court convicted Mr. Megrahi on several grounds: He was a Libyan intelligence agent "of fairly high rank" and traveled on a false passport. Libya bought Mebo bomb timers; he was in military procurement and had dealt with Mebo. Mr. Gauci identified him as the buyer of the clothing in the bomb suitcase, though it was "not an unequivocal identification." He was in Malta's airport at the time the bomb was presumably sent on its way. 
All in all, the court concluded, Mr. Megrahi's movements "form a real and convincing pattern."
The only evidence against Mr. Fhimah, the court found, were his diary entries about luggage tags and meeting Mr. Megrahi, and the prosecution conceded that it had not proved that he was a member of Libyan intelligence. Even if he gave Mr. Megrahi the suitcase tags, the court found, there was no evidence that he knew that doing so was part of a bomb plot, so he was acquitted.
At 6 p.m. today, Mr. Fhimah, bare-headed and in a denim shirt, left Camp Zeist in the back of a car, waving to the Scottish officers who had guarded him for two years.
A cousin, Ali Fhimah, using an Arabic expression for a family member, had said earlier: "We're happy that our son has been released, but we came here to see both of them let go. We believe that al-Megrahi is as innocent as our son, but we believe in Scottish justice and will continue to fight until he is acquitted, too."
Libyan television said today that Mr. Megrahi would appeal. In the Scottish courts, he has two weeks to ask permission from the same court, and six weeks more to file his reasons. If the court agrees, the appeal could be heard by at least five judges who would have to be appointed to hear the case. They would sit here, where Mr. Megrahi must be kept under the agreement with Libya until his conviction is final; if he waives his right to be present, they would sit in Edinburgh.
If his appeals fail, Mr. Megrahi is expected to serve his sentence in Barlinnie Prison in Glasgow.

HEADLINE: The Minimum Wage 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 During her confirmation hearing, Elaine L. Chao, who is now labor secretary, said President Bush wants states to be able to opt out of future minimum-wage increases (news article, Jan. 25). 
 If we allow such a change, the states most likely to do so would be those with the largest share of low-wage workers. 
Those states have a much bigger incentive to opt out, lowering the earnings of thousands of workers who would now be out of reach of the federal policy.
Furthermore, the economy in low-wage states has shown no negative effects of the last minimum-wage increase; to the contrary, the low-wage labor market has performed extremely well there. President Bush's idea would simply undermine a policy that has protected our lowest paid workers since its introduction in 1938.

JARED BERNSTEIN
Washington, Jan. 30, 2001

The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: Blustery, Independent Panel Chief to Hold Sway on Bush Economic Agenda 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 

 BODY:
The road to George W. Bush's economic agenda slashing taxes, shoring up Medicare and privatizing Social Security -- passes through the office of Representative Bill Thomas, where the ride could get bumpy.
 Mr. Thomas, the new chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is known for his sharp intellect and ability to finesse complex legislation, his independent streak and, especially, his quick temper. For years Mr. Thomas, a California Republican, was famous for interrogating administration officials and outside experts in the long debate over how to revamp the nation's health care system, reserving the brunt of his anger for those who arrived at the hearing room unprepared. 
 Last week, Mr. Thomas expressed enthusiasm for an across-the-board tax cut similar to the one proposed by President Bush. Now Mr. Thomas, who has a reputation for doing things his way, turns his attention to getting Mr. Bush's tax-cutting bill -- tweaked and rewritten, if necessary -- out of the House, where it will be acted on first, through the Senate and back to Mr. Bush for his signature.
"He's an ally and important friend for the Bush White House," said Representative Mark Foley, a Florida Republican on the Ways and Means Committee. "But they better be prepared for strong negotiations, spirited debates, and they better have the facts on their side before they expect him to march up a hill simply because the president asked."
Mr. Thomas, 59, has not said much publicly about how he intends to address tax cuts. But last week, in an interview, he seized on a particular chunk of testimony from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to say he would consider pushing for across-the-board tax cuts quickly, without packaging them with more targeted tax cuts that would benefit married couples and heirs.
Mr. Thomas said that he met several times with Mr. Bush in Austin, Tex., during the presidential campaign to discuss issues, including health care, and that he had managed to forge an easy relationship with the president. Already, he has been to the Bush White House several times, including today. 
But in many ways, the new president and the new chairman are polar opposites. While Mr. Bush prefers to be briefed on highly technical issues, Mr. Thomas prides himself on mastering the most arcane subjects and expects everyone else to be as well-prepared. After Mr. Thomas wound up on the Ways and Means health subcommittee, he immersed himself in Medicare minutiae for two years, rising at 4 a.m. to crack the books.
More pragmatic than ideological, Mr. Thomas is most at peace dismantling and reassembling old cars and clocks. He recently patched up a 1965 Porsche, then sold it right back at a profit to its original owner, who had given it up for dead.
"One of the things I tell people I do as a hobby is to trace electrical shorts in cars," Mr. Thomas said. "It's just a process of elimination, and you just have to start with a logical beginning. Figure out where the problems could be, see if that's where they are, and go through a sequence of decisions."
Legislation, he said, is no different. "It's the same, the same," he said. "Trace shorts. Find out what works, who is where, what is it we can do."
Mr. Thomas's depth of knowledge helped catapult him to the Ways and Means chairmanship over a more senior, more conservative member.
Few would have predicted it; a raft of conservative groups had rallied against Mr. Thomas, a supporter of abortion rights. And Representative Tom DeLay, the powerful Republican whip from Texas, threw his support behind Mr. Thomas's chief opponent, Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois.
Some said they believed Mr. Thomas's prickly personality would alienate people, a trait Mr. Crane tried to seize on in a letter to Speaker J. Dennis Hastert. "Never in my tenure in Congress have I allowed my temper to insult, berate or offend a colleague," Mr. Crane wrote.
But Mr. Thomas received a crucial endorsement. The vast majority of the panel's Republicans sent a private letter to Mr. Hastert supporting Mr. Thomas, a politically risky move had Mr. Crane won the job.
"That played into my decision," said Mr. Hastert, who skipped over his Illinois colleague and voted along with the steering committee to name Mr. Thomas to the chair. 
The personality issue was overshadowed by Mr. Thomas's legislative skills and political instincts.
"The House leader and the president have to ask that he deliver, not that he go to personality school," said Newt Gingrich, the former speaker.
Mr. Thomas has been a chairman before, over the House Administration Committee, a B-list panel responsible for overseeing the House's bureaucracy, but he wielded the gavel so effectively that many members say he empowered the committee and made a name for himself as an adept manager who can juggle many projects at once.
Even Democrats on the Ways and Means Committee said Mr. Thomas's selection was likely to reinvigorate the tax-writing panel, which had much of its power stripped away when Republicans took control of the House in 1994. Under Speaker Hastert, chairmen are just beginning to regain much of their old authority, and many House members expect Mr. Thomas to restore, at least in part, some of the panel's cachet under the legendary chairman Dan Rostenkowski. The panel, which oversees tax legislation and entitlement programs, is a powerhouse for corporate lobbyists, who gravitate to it like supplicants to Lourdes.
"The one thing he will do is bring back the prestige of the Ways and Means Committee," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, a senior California Democrat on the panel. "He doesn't roll over to anybody. That's probably his one weakness, that he always needs to have the last word. But he's strong and smart and he's formidable." 
Mr. Thomas acknowledges that he has a temper, but said that he unleashed it mostly on the deserving: those both ill-prepared and overly verbose. "People don't like it when I'm upset because somebody decides that they just thought about this for 10 seconds and they want to take two hours to dissect it," he said.
One of his most memorable clashes came in 1999 with Jim Nicholson, the Republican national chairman. Mr. Thomas publicly scolded Mr. Nicholson over redistricting in California, stunning some colleagues. When the dispute spilled over into letters, Mr. Thomas wrote one to Mr. Nicholson saying: "Thank you very much for your mucho carboned C.Y.A. letter. You seem to have the negative letter writing thing down pat." C.Y.A. is an abbreviation for cover your behind.
In 1995, a Florida Democrat, Representative Sam Gibbons, leapt for his tie in a hallway after a heated committee meeting.
But Mr. Thomas said his edges would not be as sharp as chairman. He wants to work with Democrats, he said, for the simple reason that it is easier to make law with them on his side.
"We can do some things partisan," he said. "It's just going to take longer and it's harder."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Chattering Objects That Need No Word for Art

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
"African Forms" at the Museum for African Art in SoHo is another outstanding exhibition from an institution that has made a habit of them since its founding 17 years ago. It hasn't hurt that the art of Africa is one of sustained and multifaceted excellence, or that research in this field has expanded exponentially over the last three decades.
 But success, at least on this level, was not preordained. Since its inception the museum has looked at the cultures of Africa through one lens and then another, delving into social, religious and geographical contexts, taking more purely formal tacks or pulling back to scrutinize African art's reception and interpretation in the West. Four exhibition titles indicate some of this breadth: "Art/ Artifact: African Art in Anthropology Collections" (1988), "Wild Spirits/Strong Medicine: African Art and the Wilderness" (1989), "Close Up: Lessons in the Art of Seeing African Art" (1990) and "Exhibitionism: Museums and African Art" (1994). 
 Alternating and often combining formal and contextual approaches, the museum's exhibitions have taken particular care to distinguish between aesthetic and spiritual power, between visual presence and cultural meaning, while encouraging the appreciation of both. 
Viewers have repeatedly been reminded that many African cultures do not have a word for art and that many objects were not meant to be looked at in a sustained way. A 1993 exhibition, "Secrecy: African Art That Conceals and Reveals," for example, examined how many sculptures and masks were visible only during ceremonies, and then sometimes only to the initiated.
A third approach has been emerging, one that considers decoration and daily use in addition to the more ascetic concerns of form and ritual. This was the case with the museum's exemplary "Hair in African Art and Culture" last year, and it continues with "African Forms," which has been organized by Frank Herreman, the museum's director of exhibitions, working with Marc Ginzburg, a founding trustee of the museum and longtime collector of African art. Most of the 400 works in the show are drawn from Mr. Ginzburg's collection. 
This effort is unusual for being almost entirely devoid of the figurative sculptures and masks that distinguish most exhibitions of African art. Instead, it presents, both in small clusters and large groupings of related objects, chairs and stools, neckrests, hairpins and hats, textiles and beaded aprons, jewelry and currency, bottles for snuff and kohl, ceramic vessels and baskets, flutes and other musical instruments, shields and weapons.
These objects are variously made of ivory, wood, straw, terra cotta, gourd, shells and animal hides, as well as brass, iron, silver and gold. The show concludes with a smattering of small religious objects, among them ornate bronze Ethiopian crosses and Muslim writing boards from Nigeria and Chad. But everything here feels subtly animated, if not inspirited, whether it is an elaborate knife sheath that suggests a little shrine or bowls fashioned from a large gourd incised with cosmological patterns.
Over all, "African Forms" asserts that with or without a specific word for art, few African peoples neglected the expressive opportunities implicit in the creation of handmade objects, no matter how basic.
As the wall texts indicate, many objects for daily use were produced by the same artists who were making masks and figures; they were usually commissioned and were owned and used by a single individual. Their forms adhered to local styles, like the low stools with three disclike legs of the Kamba people of Kenya. They communicated both cultural tradition and personal status. 
From raffia hats and cut-pile textiles to square-topped baskets (and the square-topped carved wood boxes modeled on them) and swords, the Kuba people's love of ornate patterning is evident. The two huge bright red berets near the exhibition's entrance, one made of human hair, the other of cotton, were specifically the accessories of married Zulu women.
This is a beautiful show, with much of that beauty emanating not only from the recurring elegance of the forms but also from the patina of human use, especially in the objects made of wood or hide. It suffers from a dearth of contextual information; it would be nice to illustrate, for example, how the beaded rectangular ear pendants of the Masai are worn.
But the groupings of related objects mostly compensate for the relative silence. A process of comparative viewing helped along by what labels there are reveals the diversity of sensibilities, technologies and materials. 
Certain Ethiopian people, for example, made the conical bases of their neck rests on lathes, while others preferred solid but delicately incised shaped blocks of wood. Still others, the Rendille, preferred a more free-form approach. Their headrests are pared-down sections of tree trunks that turn branches into legs.
As the objects talk effectively among themselves, they also speak frequently of other cultures. At least one of those exchanges is starkly concrete. 
The show includes a circular Ethiopian shield made of heavy hide decorated with radiating bands of silver, one of which has been engraved (presumably in London) with the following: "Taken from an Abyssinian Chief during the War in 1867 and given by Colonel Palliser to his cousin Sir Henry Charles Hardinge."
But in a more diffuse and elevated sense, the African influence on Western art, which has been widely acknowledged and detailed over the last 30 years, is as apparent here as in an exhibition of figurative sculptures and masks from the continent. Giacometti's "Spoon Woman" and Brancusi's "Endless Column" are two of the modern classics that may come to mind in these galleries. More interesting, the show, which is probably not the first to indicate that modern design has a similar debt to African art, confirms this repeatedly in the objects' collective emphasis on natural materials, elegant line and economy of form.
It is not by chance that Ray and Charles Eames were collectors of African objects of daily use, or that the introduction to the book by Mr. Ginzburg that accompanies the exhibition is written by the textile designer Jack Lenor Larsen. If the African influence on modern design is worthy of its own exhibition, so is an even more interesting cultural affinity suggested here: the one with the assiduously aestheticized objects of everyday use in Japan, which, to come full circle, also strongly influenced modern design.
In delineating a third path to African art, that of functional use, this show, like the "Hair" exhibition, more or less erases its tracks. It does this by revealing the overriding unity of visual material in most African cultures, the seamless progression from objects of physical adornment to those of mundane use to those of spiritual worship. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but in truth there is no low.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Objects that talk: Baskets woven by the Rotse people of Zambia. (The Museum for African Art)

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART; 
Unsold At Auction

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
Last week's old master paintings sales in New York followed what has become a familiar pattern this season. While Sotheby's and Christie's were able to sell some works for exceedingly high prices, a large percentage of material in each auction remained unsold. 
 Christie's sale included 175 works, of which 59 failed to sell. At Sotheby's, 219 paintings were offered and 84 never found buyers. 
 The same trend was seen last fall at the Impressionist and modern art auctions and at the American paintings sales: with the exception of a few top works, cautious buyers were scared off by high estimates. 
"It's a tricky market," said Anthony Crichton-Stuart, head of Christie's old master paintings department in New York. "Everyone's so aggressive to get property that sometimes you overreach and estimates are too high."
Christopher Apostle, director of Sotheby's old master paintings department in New York, said he believed that the high rate of unsold works reflected a sagging in the middle market. "I definitely have noticed a slowdown in more medium-level pictures," he said.
Still, a few museums gravitated toward some of the best paintings. 
While it can often be weeks or even months before museums announce their auction purchases -- curators must wait until the museum boards vote on the acquisitions -- three museums confirmed buying at last week's sales. 
The J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles bought Hans Hoffmann's "Hare in a Forest" at Sotheby's for $2.6 million. One of the only known oil paintings by the artist, it was commissioned in 1585 by the Hapsburg Emperor Rudolf II and is based on "The Hare," a 1502 watercolor nature study by Durer.
"We had been looking for early German paintings," said Deborah Gribbon, director of the Getty Museum. "We already have a group of works that are associated with the court of Rudolf II."
The $2.6 million paid by the Getty was well above the painting's $1.5 million high estimate. 
"A Hare in the Forest" failed to sell in 1990 at Sotheby's in London and again last year at the European Fine Art Fair in Maastricht, the Netherlands, where it was prominently displayed by the Maastricht dealer Robert Noortman. 
A Spanish bank, the Caja Madrid, bought Ribera's "Raising of Lazarus" (1613-1615) for the Prado Museum in Madrid at the Sotheby's sale. The bank paid $1.8 million for the work, just below its $2 million high estimate.
The painting, which depicts the figure of Christ wearing a red robe, is in a sense going home. It was listed in a 1686 inventory of the Spanish royal collection as being among the works in the Royal Chapel of the Palace of the Alcazar in Madrid. 
The third museum buyer last week was the Portland Art Museum in Oregon. It acquired Luca Giordano's "Battle of the Lapiths" for $248,000, well above the work's $150,000 high estimate. A bigger version of the composition is in the Hermitage. 
Museums did not snap up all the big-ticket paintings. Dealers also bought, though to replenish stock rather than for clients, they said.
Mr. Noortman bought Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Bearded Man, Bust-Length, in a Red Doublet" (1633) for $12.6 million. The seller, the casino owner Steve Wynn, paid $9 million for the work just two years ago at Christie's. 
In December Mr. Noortman bought Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Lady Age 62" for $28.6 million at Christie's in London.

Collection for Sale
The minute there is talk of a recession, top-flight dealers are offered collections that in more optimistic times would have found their way to the auction block. The latest example is a group of about 125 paintings, drawings, watercolors and prints by leading German Expressionist artists that experts say is worth about $50 million.
The collection belongs to Jan A. Ahlers, a German businessman who lives near Cologne and has been buying German Expressionist works for about 20 years. Mr. Ahlers recently decided it was time to sell and chose Mitchell-Innes & Nash, the Manhattan dealers, together with Christoph Graf Douglas, a Frankfurt art adviser, to handle the sale.
"The collection is as complete as it's going to get," said the dealer David Nash. "It would be too difficult to add more with today's high prices. So he's decided to sell the whole thing and concentrate instead on contemporary art."
Mr. Douglas and the dealers at Mitchell-Innes & Nash are all ex-Sotheby's experts who worked together for years. 
Among the collection's highlights are two paintings by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, one a depiction of the Brandenburg Gate and the other a portrait of a young Gypsy girl with her cat.

From Actors
John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson, who with Laurence Olivier were considered the Olympian stage actors of their generation, also happened to be friends who shared a passion for collecting. Now Sotheby's in London will be selling the Gielgud and Richardson estates in April. Gielgud, who died in May at 96, spent his last years South Pavilion, his 1690 home in Buckinghamshire, which was filled with furniture, paintings, silver, books and paintings.
"He tended to buy very decorative things," said Harry Dalmeny, deputy director of Sotheby's house sale department in London.
The sale, on April 5, includes a wide assortment of memorabilia, some of it personal, like Gielgud's Panama hats and cigarette cases. But there are also minor modern British and old master paintings, including a still life of flowers and fruit by Sir Matthew Smith and an 18th-century view of Venice by Giovanni Migliara.
Richardson, who died in 1983, and his second wife, the actress Meriel Forbes-Robertson, who died in April, were serious collectors of antiquities. Their sale, on April 27, will include a Hellenistic terra cotta female figure circa 300 B.C. and a first-century Roman bronze figure of a dancing satyr.
A label inside a wine pitcher bearing a Greek figure reads "26 July '78. Bought after lunch with Peter Hall," who was then director of the National Theater.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Getty has purchased "A Hare in a Forest" by Hans Hoffmann for $2.6 million. (Sotheby's New York)

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

ALHAMBRA, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400 or (212) 545-7536. Just over 500 years ago, before the Inquisition, Spain had a thriving Sephardic Jewish culture that created its own hybrids of European and Middle Eastern traditions. Alhambra, formed in 1981 to study and revive Judeo-Spanish music and to bring back that vanished culture, has delved into neighboring styles, ranging from those of North Africa to those of the Balkans. Sunday at 3 p.m. Admission: $21; $15 for World Music Institute members (Jon Pareles).

BLIND BOYS OF ALABAMA, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400 or (212) 545-7536. After more than 60 years as a group, the Blind Boys of Alabama are no longer boys but gray-haired pillars of gospel quartet singing. Led by Clarence Fountain, they proclaim their reverence in close harmonies and gutsy improvisations that leap heavenward. For this concert they will be joined by the St. Paul's Community Baptist Church Choir. Tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $26 (Pareles).

* ABRAHAM BURTON-ERIC McPHERSON QUARTET, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Once led solely by Mr. Burton, a saxophonist, this band now has equal leadership from Eric McPherson, one of the new young drummers changing the way rhythm sounds in jazz. It's a hot, loud, percussive band; James Hurt, who plays the piano like a huge set of drums, is part of the rhythm section. Nightly sets through Sunday are at 9 and 11, with 12:30 sets tonight and tomorrow night; the cover charge is $20, with a $10 minimum; $17.50 for Sunday (Ben Ratliff).

* DON BYRON, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 539-8777. Mr. Byron, a clarinetist who hates the tyranny of categories, has just issued his latest genre-smasher, "A Fine Line: Arias and Leider" (Blue Note Records/Capitol), which runs through popular music by Stevie Wonder, Roy Orbison, Stephen Sondheim, Puccini and Schumann as if these strands needn't ever have diverged. Tomorrow night at 8:30 he'll play music from the album, accompanied by the singers Patricia O'Callahan and Mark Ledford. Tickets: $20 (Ratliff).

* DU-TELS, Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3055. The Du-Tels' brand new album is called "No Knowledge of Music Required" (Shimmy Disc), a real howler from these masters of the thrift store songbook. Few musical pleasures compare with an evening with Gary Lucas on guitar and Peter Stampfel on vocals and whatever he decides to bang on. The virtuosity of Mr. Lucas, the axman, perfectly complements the joyful embodiment of Americana of the folk hero, Mr. Stampfel. If they take requests, be sure to shout for "Wisconsin Honeymoon" and "Bamboo." With Curtis Eller's American Circus, Sunday night at 10. Tickets: $8 in advance; $10 the day of show (Ann Powers).

CAJMERE/GREEN VELVET, Limelight, 47 West 20th Street, Manhattan, (212) 807-7780. One identity isn't enough for Curtis A. Jones. As Cajmere, he's a house-music disc jockey, producer and record-label founder whose "Brighter Days" became a dance-floor staple. And as Green Velvet, he's a cranky, hard-luck character bemoaning his latest mishaps to the blunt sounds of drum machines and cheap synthesizers. One or both will be the disc jockey tomorrow night, starting at about 10. Admission: $25 (Pareles).

MORRIS DAY AND THE TIME, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Clothes make the man about town in the Time, Morris Day's long-running Minneapolis funk band. Though Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis left the group to become full-time producers, Mr. Day still preens like a narcissistic Don Juan above the band's keyboard-driven funk, while his sidekick, Jerome, holds his mirror. Tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8 and 10:30. Admission: $35 (Pareles).

RAY DRUMMOND QUARTET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037. Since the late 1970's Mr. Drummond has been one of the hardest working musicians on the New York jazz scene, to the detriment of his own strengths as a composer. He's right in the middle of mainstream neo-bop, but he's also a bit of an Africanist, and he has often worked with the Senegalese percussionist Mor Thiam, who will join him this week. The pianist Stephen Scott and the drummer Billy Hart, who can both be excellent players, are on hand, too. Nightly sets through Sunday are at 9:30 and 11:30, with a 1 a.m. set tomorrow. Cover charge is $20; $15, Sunday; $10 minimum (Ratliff).

SNOOKS EAGLIN, Village Underground, 130 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 777-7745. The guitarist Snooks Eaglin rarely leaves New Orleans, and New Orleans never leaves him: it's in every syncopated chord he plays and in every growly, cackling note he sings. Mr. Eaglin has taken his whole band with him for this rare New York appearance, including the flamboyant pianist John McCleary, and he can draw on decades of repertory for his casually unerring revamps. Tomorrow night at 8:30 and 11:30. Admission: $20 (Pareles).

RICHIE HAWTIN. Twilo, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 268-1600. When he records as Plastikman, Richie Hawtin concocts techno at its most minimal: sparse combinations of clinical, inhuman sounds in ominous patterns. Behind the turntables, he ramps up the propulsion to push dancers into action. Tonight at 2 a.m. Admission: $25 (Pareles).

* ANDREW HILL SEXTET +11, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. The pianist Andrew Hill is one of the most mysterious composers of modern jazz, not just for his fraught harmonies and layered rhythms but for his periodic disappearances from the scene. But over the last four years or so, he has come back in a big way, gigging, hooking up with young performers who approach his music systematically and curatorially, even making a startling new record (last year's "Dusk," on Palmetto). This weekend is the world premiere of his 17-piece big band, put together with some of the enormous amount of money given to jazz last year by the Doris Duke Charitable Foundation. And some of the better musicians in town -- great fans of Mr. Hill's work -- are in the band, including the saxophonists Marty Ehrlich, Aaron Stewart and Greg Tardy; the trumpeters Dave Ballou and Ron Horton; the bassist Scott Colley; and the drummer Dafnis Prieto. Sets are tonight and tomorrow night at 8, 10:30 and midnight, with a $25 music charge for the first two shows and $18 for midnight; Sunday night sets are at 7 and 9, with a $18 music charge; $10 minimum on all nights (Ratliff).

* DAVID JOHANSEN AND THE HARRY SMITHS, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. David Johansen's latest genre excursion heads for the recorded roots of American music: the blues, ballads, country and gospel songs, full of murder and adultery and hope for redemption, that were collected by Harry Smith for his "Anthology of American Folk Music," a foundation of the 1950's folk revival. Although Mr. Johansen is a master of irony, he sings the songs as straightforward folk with a touch of rock, making the old narratives sound current. Tomorrow night at 7:30 and 10:30. Admission: $20 (Pareles).

* LUNA, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Embracing the legacy of two-guitar New York bands from the Velvet Underground to Television, Luna applies the dynamics of strum, drone and build to Dean Wareham's tales of longing and decadence. As Mr. Wareham sings about high-toned parties, aimless road trips and creeping paranoia, the songs start out cool, but the writhing, swelling guitars reveal the obsessions within them. The band is about to release a long-awaited live album. Tonight and tomorrow night at 10, with Joy Zipper opening tonight and the morosely tuneful band Clem Snide opening tomorrow. Admission: $15 (Pareles).

CHARLES McPHERSON QUINTET/JAMES CARTER SEXTET, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. Mr. McPherson, a saxophonist, has been associated with two other Charlies: Mingus, in whose band he played during the 1970's, and Parker, whose style he fully absorbed to become one of the best interpreters of bebop we have. James Carter, on the other hand, is an eclecticist whose tastes range from Ben Webster to Sun Ra to Django Reinhardt, whose music he covers on a lively recent album, "Chasin' the Gypsy" (Atlantic); this weeklong gig will focus on the Reinhardt material. Double sets tonight through Sunday, at 9 and 11:30; $30 music charge and $5 minimum. (Ratliff).

"MODE FOR JOE: THE MUSIC OF JOE HENDERSON," Birdland, 315 West 44th Street, Clinton, (212) 581-3080. Mr. Henderson's influence as a record maker has endured into the 90's, but he's rarely celebrated as a composer, despite having written tunes like "Recorda Me" and "Blue Bossa," classics of the 1960's Blue Note Records era. This ad hoc band addresses Mr. Henderson as a writer. It includes Javon Jackson, the tenor player who probably sounds most like Mr. Henderson today, as well as the trombonist Josh Roseman, the drummer Lenny White and others. Sets are tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and 11. Cover charge, $25; $10 minimum (Ratliff).

OTHER DIMENSIONS IN MUSIC, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. One of the best things to come out of the resurgence of interest in good old-fashioned free-jazz energy music is this working quartet, whose members (Roy Campbell, trumpet; Daniel Carter, saxophones; William Parker, bass; Rashied Bakr, drums) lean on little motifs to guide their bursts of inspiration.Sometimes the results are messy, but this band tries to mirror the emotions, and sometimes emotions are messy. Sets tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 9:30; cover charge, $10 (Ratliff).

JEB PATTON AND PERCY HEATH, Kaplan Penthouse, Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500. Mr. Patton, a fluid young bebopper who plays in the Heath Brothers band, will perform duets with the bassist Percy Heath, he of the melodic lines, beautifully economical swing and a tone to die for. Because he's a rhythm-section player and not a bandleader, Mr. Heath hasn't received the distinction as a national treasure that he deserves; his appearance at the big John Lewis concert a few weeks ago at Lincoln Center was a Top 10 moment if there ever was one. The concert is tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $45 (Ratliff).

VERNON REID AND MASQUE/CHURCH OF BETTY, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. From hard rock to harmolodic jazz to hybrids of hip-hop and jungle, the guitarist Vernon Reid has delved into all sorts of sharp-edged music. He brings fast fingers, a taste for experimental structures and a fearless ear for noise to his projects. Chris Rael, who leads Church of Betty, is determined to mesh East and West. Collaborating with downtown New York musicians who'll take on anything, he mixes pop and ragas from India with funk, rock and hip-hop, coming up with a hybrid that radiates optimism. Tonight at 7:30 and 10:30. Tickets: $20 (Pareles).

HEADLINE: My Student Loans 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As someone from a working-class family who financed her education at Yale University and Stanford Business School with a combination of scholarships, loans and jobs, I think Princeton's decision to compete for students by not requiring them to borrow money is a bad idea (news article, Jan. 28).
 Education is an investment. 
This is especially true for Ivy League graduates, as they have the best opportunities to get high-paying jobs. 
 It would be far better to offer loan payments spread over a longer time, lower interest rates or a well-designed program to forgive loans if graduates go into lower-paying lines of work like academia or public service.
Having paid my loans, and having tried to be generous in gifts to my universities, I see little justification to give the best and the brightest a free ride.

NANCY C. LANGWISER-KEAR
Wellesley, Mass., Jan. 29, 2001

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Dow Closes at 4-Month High on Hope for More Rate Cuts

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks posted their highest close in more than four months yesterday as expectations that the Federal Reserve would fire off another round of interest-rate cuts to pump up the economy overshadowed fears that the nation was teetering perilously near to recession.
 The Dow Jones Industrial average jumped 96.27 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,983.63, its highest close since Sept. 14. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 10.1 points, or 0.4 percent, to 2,782.79. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 7.46 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,373.47. 
 "In the short run, bad news is good news for the market," said David Sowerby, market strategist for Loomis Sayles. "We don't wish for a recession, but at least the weakness just further reinforces that the Fed has, in my opinion, another full percentage point to give us in lower interest rates."
Driving the Dow were gains in Merck and Intel. Both were added to UBS Warburg's list of favorite stocks. Merck rose $2.30, to close at $84.48, and Intel added 81 cents, to $37.81.
Also in the Dow, the local and wireless telecommunications company SBC Communications gained $2.20, to $50.55. I.B.M., another Dow component, added $2.05, to $114.05.
The market was held back through most of the day by news of a slowdown among United States manufacturers.
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of manufacturing activity slumped in January to its lowest level since March 1991, when the United States was last in a recession.
The association's index fell to 41.2 in January, well below the 43.6 reading expected by Wall Street, from a revised 44.3 points in December. A number below 50 denotes a contraction in the sector.
On Wednesday, the Fed cut its key federal funds rate by half a percentage point, to 5.5 percent, saying the economic slowdown called for "rapid and forceful action," and indicated it would cut rates again if necessary.
To underscore its message, the Fed also cut its discount rate on direct Fed loans to commercial banks by a half-point, to 5 percent.
The economy is now "awfully close" to a no-growth scenario, Norbert Ore, a senior official at the National Association of Purchasing Management, said. 
"The overall economy could certainly still be growing, but that would be a maximum of 0.6 percent, so it is still coming awfully close to that no-growth scenario," Mr. Ore said. --------------------

Treasuries Are Higher
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday on expectations that a report that said that manufacturing activity was near a 10-year low would help prompt policy makers to cut interest rates further.
"The economy is slowing to a point where the Fed is afraid it's slowing too much, and there's no reason for them to stop" lowering interest rates, said Todd Abraham, who helps invest $1.5 billion in bonds at Federated Investors in Pittsburgh.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 8/32, to a price of 105 2/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.07 percent from 5.11 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 28/32, to 111 23/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.44 percent from 5.50 percent on Wednesday.
