HEADLINE: Caught in the Electrical Fallout 

BYLINE:  By Gary Locke; Gary Locke, a Democrat, is governor of Washington.

DATELINE: OLYMPIA, Wash. 

 BODY:
If pragmatic action isn't taken soon to fix the broken electricity market threatening the economy of the West, our national prosperity could be seriously harmed. And the federal government -- not just California and the neighboring states now finding themselves forced to share its problems -- must be involved in the solution.
 In the State of Washington, we elected not to deregulate our retail electric power industry. We continue to expect utilities to serve their customers with low-cost power while earning a fair rate of return. But now, caught in the fallout of California's energy meltdown, we, too, are facing potential shortages, skyrocketing prices and escalating debt. 
 We are on the same electric grid -- regional power market and transmission system -- as California. (More than a dozen Western states are on this grid.) Usually this helps everyone: Washington sells power to California in the summer, for example, helping it keep its air conditioners running, and buys from California in the winter to keep our homes warm.
But the current unexpected and serious power generation shortage in California drives prices through the roof for us, too, affecting our utilities, businesses and citizens. Some utilities in Washington are now paying more than 10 times what is normal for power at this time of year.
Adding to Washington State's burden is an unusually dry winter. Too little rain has fallen to fill the reservoirs behind our dams. In some areas, like Lake Roosevelt, behind the Grand Coulee Dam, we haven't seen water levels this low for 25 years. Even if we get normal rainfall for the rest of the season, this year's mountain snow pack -- which melts to feed our reservoirs in spring and summer -- will be at 50 to 70 percent of normal. And if we divert too much water from our rivers for power generation, we use supplies needed for migrating salmon and agricultural irrigation.
The utility that serves Tacoma has instituted a 50 percent surcharge for power, and the one that supplies Seattle has passed 28 percent price increases. Customers north of Seattle face a 35 percent rate now and probably another increase later. The impact of these rising prices ripples through our economy: industries have already curtailed operation because of these rising costs. And Washington is not alone. The Idaho Power Company recently announced it may increase prices 24 percent, and some utilities in Utah and Arizona also expect sharp increases.
Independent power producers bought many of the generating plants that California's deregulation required its utilities to sell, and these producers were expected to build new plants to keep pace with demand. The legal obligation of regulated utilities to serve, however, does not transfer to the independent, competitive generators. This market structure provides inadequate incentives to construct new plants -- or, worse, perverse incentives not to generate electricity, since if supplies stay short, prices will stay at high levels. Independent power producers are realizing huge profits in this West Coast crisis and stand to continue to do so, at the expense of the region, through the summer and perhaps into the next year or two.
Both political parties and both state and federal governments had a hand in creating the deregulation that has disrupted our power market, and government at all levels must set aside partisanship as we confront the results. The Bush administration must help solve the crisis or risk letting it spin out of control. This is not a "normal" market where the integrity of price signals needs to be protected. This is a highly distorted market where intervention is needed. And because interstate commerce is involved, only the federal government can supply this intervention.
President Bush and his energy secretary, Spencer Abraham, should put pressure on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to stabilize the market immediately by putting temporary price controls on wholesale electricity. They should also ask Congress to expand the federal assistance that helps low-income people pay their electric bills. 
California, of course, must work to solve the debt problems of its utilities and renew the financial integrity of its system. But as it struggles to restore stability, our entire region needs protection.
Washington State is doing its part. I have issued an energy supply alert that mandates a 10 percent reduction in energy consumption by all governments in the state. I've asked for the same reduction by citizens and businesses. The energy alert also allows companies to fire up their own diesel generators now, with the requirement that they offset additional particulate emissions with investments in clean air contributions later.
We in the Northwest cannot protect ourselves from a crisis we did not cause and a deregulation experiment we did not want. Even the most fervent free-market advocates should recognize that there must be short-term steps taken now to stabilize the market. And only the federal government can provide the immediate help we need.

HEADLINE: Fed Noted in December That a Cut Was Needed 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers agreed at their meeting in December that they might have to cut interest rates sharply, but they were not prepared to do so at the time, minutes of the meeting showed today.
 Members of the Federal Open Market Committee felt they lacked enough evidence to lower rates in December, but by Jan. 3 they agreed unanimously that "prompt and forceful policy action sooner and larger than expected by financial markets" was needed, according to minutes from the Dec. 19 policy meeting and a Jan. 3 conference call. 
 Even though a few members of the committee wanted to cut rates right away, "they could accept a delay in light of prevailing uncertainties about the prospective performance of the economy," the minutes said. 
As usual, the minutes did not specify how many or which members of the group -- which includes the five executive governors and presidents of regional Fed banks who vote on a rotating basis -- were pushing for an immediate rate cut.
In the end, the Fed held rates steady in December but issued a clear warning in its so-called statement of risks that an excessive slowdown was the main risk, a sharp shift from its previous stance that inflationary overheating was the key threat to the record expansion, now in its 10th year. The revised statement of risks "could strengthen expectations regarding future monetary policy easing to an extent that was difficult to predict and could generate sizable reaction in financial markets," policy makers agreed in December.
On Jan. 3, the Fed cut its target rate on overnight loans between banks a half percentage point in a relatively rare intermeeting move -- the first since late 1998 --that surprised global markets and briefly sent stocks soaring.
The January move was followed by an additional half-point cut on Wednesday, which lowered the key federal funds rate to 5.5 percent from 6 percent. The Fed continued to stand by its warning that it was ready to cut rates further if necessary.
At their December session, the policy makers noted the economy had slowed significantly, albeit from an "unsustainably high" and potentially inflationary pace earlier in 2000.
That had helped keep inflation in check, a factor that Fed policy makers agreed would ease the path toward swift interest-rate cuts if the economic picture continued to darken.

HEADLINE: Factory Index Shows Output At Its Lowest In a Decade 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
American manufacturers cut production sharply in January, sending an index of their activity to a level not reached since the recession of a decade ago, a trade group reported yesterday.
 The report by the trade group, the National Association of Purchasing Management, was released two days after another group, the Conference Board, said its measure of consumer confidence in December had its largest monthly decline in more than a decade. Such signs of a slowing economy led the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates twice last month, most recently on Wednesday, to try to bolster consumer spending. 
 While personal income grew rapidly in December, Americans remained cautious about spending, the Commerce Department said in a separate report yesterday. That was one reason the economy grew at its slowest rate in five years in the last three months of 2000. But with little serious threat of inflation, economists said consumer confidence, and eventually the broader economy, might improve now that the Fed has lowered its benchmark interest rate. 
"Monetary policy tends to have a fairly long lag," said Calvin Schnure, senior economist for J. P. Morgan Chase. Still, "there could be some immediate effect on confidence."
The purchasing managers' index fell below what that trade group termed the break-even point, the level below which the drop in manufacturing would hurt the economy as a whole, for the first time since 1991.
The index stood at 41.2 for January, its lowest point since the 40.8 recorded in March 1991 and down from an adjusted 44.3 in December. A reading above 50 would indicate increased activity by industrial companies and suggest growth in manufacturing. The index has not been above 50 since July.
The group's report suggested that production, new orders, employment and exports were contracting while the prices of raw materials were increasing, a development that would worry economists more if inflation was seen as a bigger threat.
"This is the sixth month that manufacturing has failed to grow, which technically by our numbers would indicate a recession," said Norbert J. Ore, chairman of the committee that publishes the report. "It brings to an end the longest economic run of growth that we've seen in history."
The purchasing-managers index has fallen steadily since late 1999 as manufacturing, which accounts for about a fifth of the economic output in the United States, has been hit with higher energy costs and a stronger dollar, which in turn, hurts exports. This came as corporate earnings, stock prices and most economic indicators were faring well. 
The production component of the overall index fell to 37.9, its lowest point since the 37.2 reported in May 1982, when the economy was struggling to emerge from a recession.
"One of the reasons we're less likely to go into a recession is that inventory buildup has not been as great," said David Huether, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers, another industry group. Increased efficiency in purchasing methods has curtailed unintentional inventory buildup, Mr. Huether said.
An unprecedented 10-year economic expansion fueled by business investment is not over, he said, but "those lower interest rates probably aren't going to spill over to the economy for another four months or so."
Heartened by their new-found ability to refinance loans, consumers could return to buying durable goods like refrigerators and cars, items that are easy to put off buying when times are hard. Many people avoided such purchases in December, according to figures released yesterday by the Commerce Department.
Personal income increased $36.6 billion, or 0.4 percent, in December, while personal spending rose $19.4 billion, or 0.3 percent. Personal spending has risen at the same rate for three months, but is down from an 0.8 percent pace in September.
Interest rate cuts alone will not necessarily inspire consumer confidence, economists said. Low inflation and a steady stock market will also play a role, they said.
Consumer confidence has also been hurt by corporate efforts to increase investor confidence.
Even though businesses slashed costs and consumers cut back, construction spending rose 0.6 percent in December, to an annual rate of $811.5 billion, compared with a 0.2 percent gain in November, the Commerce Department reported. But government spending contributed to much of this increase.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Economic Mood Brightens In Europe as It Sours in U.S.
Even as the economic mood of Americans has shifted almost overnight from exuberance to anxiety, Europe has emerged as an oasis of tranquillity and prosperity.
 Europe now stands a good chance of outpacing its economic rival by a significant margin. Consumer confidence is running at nearly record levels across most of the Continent and European unemployment, stuck for much of the decade above 10 percent, is now at its lowest level since 1991. Page A1. 

Verizon and Sprint Post Results
Verizon Communications said that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 1.3 percent while Sprint reported an 11 percent decline in profit. Verizon, which spent more to add long-distance customers in New York and sell more data and wireless services, met Wall Street expectations. Sprint, which was hurt by a decline in long-distance sales, exceeded analysts' estimates. Shares of Verizon rose 5 cents, to $55, while Sprint fell 25 cents, to $24.55. C5.

California Power Plan Approved
The California Legislature narrowly approved a $10 billion plan to let the state buy power on long-term contracts, a first step toward stabilizing its troubled utilities. A13.

Chief Resigns at Terra Lycos
Robert J. Davis, who took Lycos from a university project to the fifth-most-popular Web site in the United States, resigned as chief executive of Terra Lycos. C4.

Senate Panel Hears About Air Woes
A Senate committee hearing on the proposed purchase of Trans World Airlines by American Airlines strayed into a discussion about frustrations over high fares and delays. C3.

Stocks Rise on Rate-Cut Fever
Blue-chip stocks rose on expectations that the Federal Reserve will continue to lower interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 96.27 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,983.63. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 10.06 points, to 2,782.79. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.46 points, to 1,373.47. C5.

Manufacturing Index Shows Decline
An index of United States manufacturing fell in January to its lowest point in almost 10 years, according to a survey of industry executives. Another report showed that construction spending increased 0.6 percent in December, and a third showed that personal income increased 0.4 percent in December, while spending rose 0.3 percent. C2.

Japan Banks Told Not to Expect Aid
Hakuo Yanagisawa, the head of Japan's Financial Services Agency, said that banks and their corporate customers should not expect additional government aid. "People who say we need to inject more public money to boost the banks' capital bases do not understand the situation at all," he said. "The problem Japan is facing is not an issue of the balance sheet, but rather it is a problem of profits and losses." World Business, Section W.

British Steel Maker to Cut Jobs
The Corus Group, a leading European steel maker, said it would cut 6,050 jobs, a fifth of its work force. World Business, Section W.

$120 Million Deal for ReplayTV
SonicBlue, an Internet media company, agreed to buy ReplayTV, a troubled competitor, for $120 million in stock. C4.

HEADLINE: Report on States Finds New York Is Not Stacking Up the Way It Used To 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New Yorkers still smarting over being trounced by Maryland now face another blow to their battered pride: evidence that other states are beating out New York on a host of nonfootball measures, economic and social.
 Georgia's population and economy have been growing far faster than New York's. In Texas, earnings have been rising faster and taxes falling faster, too. Connecticut has a better-educated population, California residents receive more patents and Massachusetts has far fewer people without health insurance. 
 All this information was compiled by the Citizens Budget Committee, a nonpartisan New York civic group that compared New York with the nine other most populous states (New York is No. 3), as well as Connecticut and Massachusetts. 
What it found was "a mixed picture, but not as bright as anyone expected," said Charles Brecher, research director for the group. "There were some bright spots, but a slightly greater number of not-so-bright spots."
Gov. George E. Pataki's administration criticized the report as misleading. 
"It's out of date and very emphatically a shoddy piece of work," said Stephen Kagann, the governor's chief economist. "It completely mischaracterizes the state of the economy." For example, the report used 1988 data on the growth of the state economy, he said, but more recent estimates would show New York's growth far above the national average. 
The Empire State still rules in some areas: its very low rate of crimes against property, its steep drop in violent crime and its increasing attractiveness to foreign tourists. (If you count those who arrive at Newark International Airport, as well as at Kennedy and La Guardia, New York actually had more international visitors than California in 1999.)
As Governor Pataki likes to point out, New York has slashed its state and local taxes; its 11 percent drop between 1993 and 1998 is second only to Texas's, according to the report. But as the governor's Democratic rivals in the coming election will stress, the state and local tax burden in 1998 was still the heaviest of any rival state and far above the national average.
Quite a few of the results were just plain bleak. In 1999, New York had the highest percentage of people living in poverty and the highest percentage of families receiving welfare, and was second only to Connecticut in the increase of those without health insurance over a five-year period. Electricity was more expensive in New York than in the other states, at least as of 1998, and construction of everything except housing was the least robust.
Most striking of all is what has happened to the state's population, according to the census estimates cited in the report. Far more residents have left New York than any other state in the group -- twice as many as left California in 1998 and 1999, for example -- and on a percentage basis, New York's losses are the steepest, at almost 6 percent over the five years ending in June 1999. California's domestic migration, as statisticians put it, was a loss of about 3 percent during the same period; Georgia, meanwhile, gained more than 5 percent.
That matters, in part because "In a nation where people are free to move, perhaps the most intuitively sensible indicator of an area's competitiveness is its population size," the report said. "If many people want to live in a place, it must be doing something right; if few people choose to live there, then it is, by definition, unattractive."
Of course, New York also attracted immigrants from overseas, at rates second only to California's. Almost 104,000 people from abroad moved to New York in the 12-month period ending with June 1999; in the five years ending with June 1999, overseas immigrants added 3.2 percent to the state's population, according to census estimates. That, along with births that outnumbered deaths, helped increase New York's population by 0.2 percent; the only state that fared worse was Pennsylvania, which lost population.
To be sure, data from the 2000 census suggests that the state's population problems may have been overstated in the report. Detailed breakdowns of domestic and international migration are not yet available. But broadly, the census found that over the last decade, the state's population had grown 5.5 percent, rather than the 1.1 percent increase the census bureau estimated in 1999.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 6, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a report that New York had fallen behind other states on a range of economic and social measures misstated the date for figures about the growth of the state's economy. It was 1998, not 1988. The article also misstated the name of the nonprofit group that prepared the study. It is the Citizens Budget Commission, not Committee.

HEADLINE: Brooding Over Its Homeless, Japan Sees a Broken System 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: OSAKA, Japan, Jan. 26 

 BODY:
Down and out, in Japan?
 Dressed in stained sweaters and tattered parkas, the men began milling in the hangarlike building well before dawn, smoking and stamping their feet on the ground against the biting cold. 
 A few hours passed. No construction vans in sight. For most of the graying, ill-shaven men waiting around the city welfare office, it became grimly apparent that this day had brought no better luck than the last, the last but one and several more before that.
Homeless, the dozens of men who gather here each day -- more out of routine than in hope -- will soon begin to fan out across Osaka, Japan's second-largest city, collecting cans and other garbage to sell, or simply head back to their tents in city parks to sleep until soup kitchens open in the evening. 
"I've been able to survive as a day laborer for 13 years," said Isamu Sato, "but in the last two years, there just haven't been any more jobs." Mr. Sato, 53 and homeless, wore a short towel in lieu of a scarf and had on a flimsy blue jacket and baseball cap. "Now I am living in a city shelter, and am down to two meals a day. People think there is something wrong with us, but if there were work we would do it. With nothing to do, all that's left for us is to wander around."
Through 10 years of economic ills, Japan has clung tightly to a number of cherished national myths, from the idea that an economy that rose to greatness so quickly after World War II couldn't possibly be fundamentally broken, to the notion that all Japanese people are essentially middle class.
In Osaka, where the number of homeless -- the largest in Japan -- is increasing swiftly, belief in those myths is becoming strained. The homeless are taking over public parks and straining the prefectural budget to the point where officials who put the number of city homeless at 10,000 -- modest by the standards of some American cities -- recognize that the real figure may be much higher.
Even by official data, the number of makeshift tents for the homeless in the city's largest park alone rose to 458 last summer, from 159 a year earlier.
Citizens' groups, meanwhile, have been protesting about the problem, demanding that Osaka clear the homeless out of public areas and protect people better against a population viewed as dirty and dangerous. Many of these groups have also campaigned against having public shelters in their neighborhoods.
"People are always complaining, why don't we find a vacant lot to house these people in far away from the city center, or why don't we just keep them all by the port," said Yukata Izumi, an official in the Osaka Welfare Bureau. "We have replied that the homeless have a right to a proper living area of their own, too, and have begged for the public's comprehension. 
"These people have become economic refugees, and the basic problem is that when the economy is bad, there is no work, and people without work will eventually become homeless."
According to government data released this week, the monthly unemployment rate in 2000 was 4.7 percent, tying a record set the previous year. 
Layoffs as a result of Japan's prolonged economic downturn have hit middle-aged men particularly hard. In a society where lifetime employment was the postwar standard in many industries, the loss of a job at that stage of life leaves people with little chance of starting over.
Osaka may have the largest number of homeless, but they are present and visible these days in every major Japanese city -- from Tokyo, where they sleep under bridges or build cardboard hovels along riverbanks, to Yokohama, Nagoya, Kobe and Kyoto. According to city estimates, there were 5,700 homeless in Tokyo as of late last year. But people who work with the homeless say their true numbers are most likely twice or even triple that.
The reaction of Japan's local and national governments clearly betrays their inexperience in dealing with the issue.
Pressed into action late last year by angry citizens to remove the tents of homeless people from Osaka's biggest park, Nagai Koen, the welfare bureau built a state-of-the-art shelter within the park. But the shelter's presence in the huge wooded site, which contains ponds, museums and sporting areas, quickly became an issue itself. The city government, under duress, promised to remove the glistening new shelter within three years, and not to allow the homeless to return.
But even as they repeat that pledge, city officials remain at something of a loss to explain how they will fulfill it.
A watchman guards the entrance to the shelter, an impressively neat collection of brushed aluminum structures on the edge of the park. 
Takafumi Katagiri, the deputy director, explains that the 250-bed center opened in December and began filling up quickly until it reached about half capacity. Since then, new arrivals have just about matched departures.
The center offers spotless living quarters with showers, televisions and laundry areas that would be welcomed in many an American university town. 
There is even a kennel where the residents can keep their pets. Still, many of the homeless living in the park remain suspicious of the program, and say they cherish their independence most of all.
In theory, Mr. Katagiri said, the homeless residents can save enough money from their odd jobs to move out eventually and find homes of their own. 
"The one thing that is sure is that this is a temporary structure, and after three years it will be removed," he said. "We are hoping they will find alternatives; otherwise they will back on the streets. But we have promised the neighbors that they won't be back in the park, and if need be, we will stop them from putting up tents."
So far, Kitashiro Naomichi, a 55-year-old homeless man and longtime resident of the park, has resisted the calls to come live in the new shelter. Just five minutes away by foot, the place he calls home is a jumble of heavy blue plastic sheeting thrown up against a park wall and anchored with old car batteries. He has also built a small wooden home for his two large puppies, who tussle with each other aggressively, paying little heed to a stranger.
"If I had a job, I wouldn't be here," said Mr. Naomichi, who warmed himself by a fire made from trash as a university track team jogged by in the stiff morning cold. "But I make a living O.K. collecting things that other people have thrown away, and it suits me here just fine."
More than social welfare, Mr. Naomichi indicated that he craved the consideration of others, all the more since he lost contact with his family several years ago because of their deep and mutual shame over his condition.
"I realize that many people worry about us being in the park," he said. "But some people have been very friendly nonetheless, offering me money and clothes, and sometimes food for my dogs. I would really like to speak to my family, but whenever I make up my mind to call them, as soon as I hear a voice on the other end, I hang up."

HEADLINE: As American Economy Slows, Europeans Suddenly Feel Flush 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Even as the economic mood of Americans has shifted almost overnight from exuberance to anxiety, Europe has emerged as an oasis of tranquillity and prosperity.
 After years of lagging far behind the United States, Europe now stands a good chance of outpacing its economic rival by a significant margin. Consumer confidence, which has plunged to its lowest level since 1993 in the United States, is running at nearly record levels across most of the Continent. European unemployment, stuck for much of the decade above 10 percent, is now at its lowest level since 1991. 
It is not a boom, at least not yet. What constitutes a wonderful year in Europe -- growth of 3.4 percent for 2000 and overall unemployment down to about 8.7 percent -- would not long ago have been considered mediocre if not depressing in the United States, where annual growth has averaged about 4.5 percent the last several years and joblessness is now only 4 percent. 
But mood is largely a matter of perspective, and the contrast could not be more stark. While many Americans fear their spectacular boom may be ending, most Europeans feel they are finally shaking free of their doldrums.
European markets have become more open and competitive and European companies have emulated many American practices to help deliver better performance. State-owned monopolies have been privatized and stripped of their protections. Governments are lowering taxes, at least modestly. Wage increases have slowed to a crawl and labor markets have become more flexible, as companies skirt traditional job-protection rules by hiring part-time and temporary workers.
Yet even as the United States struggles with a slowing economy, few experts believe Europe can jump in to fill the gap for the global economy. Most economists believe Europe's long-term potential growth is still significantly lower than that of the United States. And neither European consumers nor corporations have the same lust for imported goods that helped pull Asian countries out of crisis two years ago.
"If we were to get into a global recession, I do not think Europe would be strong enough to play the consumer of last resort," said Christel Rendu, who analyzes European business-cycles for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "I doubt that it could pull the world out of a recession."
At the same time, Japan remains mired in a decade-long slump that shows no signs of ending, and the rest of Asia, while on the rebound from its financial turmoil of a few years ago, is not strong enough to keep growing without a healthy American economy.
Indeed, many business executives here base their current optimism on the assumption that the American economy will start recovering by the second half of this year.
"The United States is the only real consumer market," said Wolfgang Ley, chief executive of Escada, which designs and sells fashion clothing around the world. "No other country can pull itself out of a recession as fast as America."
Many European companies, in fact, have more reasons than ever to worry about the United States, not because of exports but because they have bought major American companies. From DaimlerChrysler and British Petroleum to Unilever, European companies have spent hundreds of billions of dollars buying American corporations the last few years. For companies like DaimlerChrysler, which lost about $1.7 billion at Chrysler last year, America means heartburn. But over the longer term, many economists argue, Europe's underlying potential for growth will remain lower than that of the United States.
For one thing, Europe's population is not growing, which means comparatively fewer consumers and workers. And even though unemployment is still a major problem, many countries have acute shortages of skilled workers and some are short workers in all fields.
Beyond that, productivity growth has been slower in Europe than in the United States, in part because European investment in new factories and technology has consistently been more cautious.
"The big difference is that the potential growth of the United States is higher than that of Europe," Philippe d'Arvisenet, director of research at BNP Paribas, one of France's biggest banks, said. "In the U.S., because you have had 10 years of very dynamic investment, you have a great deal of added capacity. As a result, the potential growth ishigher than in Europe."
But given how dark the mood has long been in Europe, the current pace feels just fine to a lot of people. It may or may not be a coincidence, but Mr. Ley of Escada said that European women had abruptly lost their interest in fairly cheerless, minimalist clothing.
"There is a comeback in flamboyant colors, rich materials that have the feeling of luxury," he said. "It might be an expression of new excitement."
To Mr. d'Arvisenet, the new excitement is evident, too. "What we experienced in Europe for two-thirds of the last decade is a rate of growth of about 1.5 percent," he said. "Coming from 1.5 percent to 3 percent, suddenly everything is fine," creating, he added, "a big difference in climate."
Perhaps the most important reason for the shift has been a significant change in labor markets. Europe suffered from double-digit unemployment and generated almost no additional jobs for seven long years, from 1993 until June 1999. Since then, unemployment has dropped to 8.7 percent and is now at the lowest level since 1991.
Much of the reason is that Europe's once-powerful unions have become weaker and settled for wage increases that are actually lower than the rate of inflation. Equally important, employers have been able to escape the rigidity of the tough European job-protection rules by hiring temporary and part-time workers.
Ms. Rendu, of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, argued that these changes had fundamentally changed the hiring equation in Europe. By 2007, she predicted, joblessness in Europe could drop as low as 5.7 percent.
European analysts and government leaders believe that growth across the 12 nations that have adopted the euro will slow from 3.2 percent last year to about 2.5 percent or a bit less this year. Countries like Germany and Italy, which depend heavily on exports outside Europe, are more likely to be hit harder than others. But analysts here expect a gentle dip rather than a full stop in growth as in the United States.
"The United States is slowing down after a very long race of spectacular growth," said Carlo Monticelli, co-head of European research at Deutsche Bank. "In Europe, we are in a situation where the good phase is just starting."
The contrast between prospects in Europe and the United States was highlighted today by the European Central Bank, which decided against following the Federal Reserve's move on Tuesday to reduce interest rates in the United States. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, told reporters at a news conference here today that conditions in Europe remained "broadly favorable" and that European economic prospects would mainly be determined by "domestic factors."
Stefan Bergheim, who follows European economics for Merrill Lynch in Frankfurt, said Europe differed from the United States in several basic ways right now. The first is that both consumer and business confidence are running at nearly record highs across Europe. Even in Germany, which depends heavily on exports of industrial goods and was severely set back by the Asian financial crises in 1998, recent surveys show that confidence is running far above normal levels.
Many European companies believe they can shrug off an American downturn, as long as it is relatively short. Exports to the United States account for less than 3 percent of Europe's annual economic output, a smaller share than the value of exports to Central Europe and Russia. And many manufacturers here are convinced that their real growth markets are elsewhere.
Consider the case of Heidelberger Druckmaschinen of Germany, the world's biggest manufacturer of large printing equipment. In the six months ended last September, exports to North America accounted for about one-third of total sales.
But by far the biggest source of growth came from the Asia Pacific region, where sales soared 57 percent to more than $400 million. Orders from within Europe jumped nearly 40 percent in the past year, one of the biggest increases in that region in years.
"We think we are in a moment of special momentum in Europe," Herbert Meyer, the chief financial officer of Heidelberger, said. "As long as we can expect a soft landing in the United States -- growth higher than 2 percent -- we expect this momentum can be maintained."
But Mr. Meyer also added a crucial caveat: if the United States goes into a severe downturn, exports from Asian countries to American consumers will plunge and European countries will not be able to escape the downturn.
"Due to better and better working of the European common market, Europe is a bit better protected from heavy shocks from outside," Mr. Meyer said. "But if you have a big recession, Europe would not be able to compensate."

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Optimistic After Powell's Meeting With Congo President 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
The new, young leader of the war-shattered Congo, Joseph Kabila, did the rounds of Washington today, a face among many at a Congressional prayer breakfast, a supplicant at the headquarters of the World Bank and the guest of corporate investors disappointed at the ruin of his country. 
 The main event of his crowded day was a scheduled session with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. But there was a surprise too: an impromptu, face-to-face meeting with his rival, the Rwandan leader, Paul Kagame, whose troops continue to occupy the eastern part of his country and whose support he must win if there is any chance of peace. 
 As he moved through his appointments, Mr. Kabila, 29, appeared to be a quiet figure, and in contrast to his corpulent father, Laurent Kabila, of modest build and demeanor. 
Mr. Kabila, who came to Washington after stopping in Europe, is making his first trip abroad as president, evidently trying to improve Congo's image in the West and around the world. Some diplomats said it was rather brave of him to leave his capital, Kinshasa, so soon after the turmoil of his father's death, but said he must have felt relatively confident of his support.
Wherever he went officials said he spoke of peace and an interest in reviving accords calling for the departure of the armies of five African countries that have taken sides in the two-and-a-half-year Congo conflict. Such words had been heard before from his father, who was assassinated last month, after spending his last year blocking a cease-fire agreement, known as the Lusaka accords. 
But after his 30-minute session with General Powell, a senior State Department official expressed optimism anew. The Congolese leader had "expressed a conviction to start the dialogue, carry out the Lusaka accords and then rebuild democracy," the official said.
In reply, General Powell stressed that Mr. Kabila needed to meet with other African leaders to build an atmosphere of trust and security that would permit the occupying armies to withdraw, the official said.
In his only public address of the day, Mr. Kabila spoke at a reception attended by executives of mining and mineral companies given by the Corporate Council on Africa, which promotes business ties between the United States and Africa.
In clear English, Mr. Kabila -- who grew up in Tanzania, where English is spoken -- promised to clear up past "misunderstandings" and appealed to business to return.The economy would be liberalized, he said, and he spoke of human rights and due process. But his huge country is without a functional government and basic services. 
Seasoned hands at the reception, including Maurice Tempelsman, one of the leading American investors in Congo for several decades, until the early 1990's, received Mr. Kabila with warmth but with some warnings for him. "A businessmen is always accountable for the safety of his people and the security of his investments," Mr. Tempelsman said in a subtle message to Mr. Kabila.
Neither standard has existed in Congo in recent years, and the International Rescue Committee, a nongovernmental group working in Congo, says the war has resulted in 1.7 million deaths in two years. 
On his visit, Mr. Kabila was accompanied by the governor of the Central Bank of Congo, Jean-Claude Masangu. They met with top officials of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The Congo has among the highest arrears to the fund, with $510 million in overdue debt, a spokesman said. At the World Bank, the Congo owes $288 million and has not received loans going on a decade, a spokesman said. 
No new commitments were made at the international financial institutions, the spokesman said. 
At the Congressional prayer breakfast this morning, Mr. Kabila shook hands with Mr. Kagame, and they later met at a Washington hotel.
Mr. Kabila will attend the Security Council of the United Nations Friday. 
Mr. Kabila was trained in the Ugandan Army and then went to China for further training, an American diplomat said. He is believed to have met Mr. Kagame in 1997 when Mr. Kagame temporarily joined forces with Laurent Kabila.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
2 Rental Projects Near South Orange Train Hub

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. 

 BODY:
The first two upscale rental developments in a dozen years are under construction near the heart of this compact suburb's reviving downtown and a block from its New Jersey Transit train station.
 One, with 200 apartments, is rising on a 4.7-acre site on Third Street and will be called Gaslight Commons, after the type of street lights that predominate in the 2.7-square-mile township. The other, Church Street Commons, is taking shape in two 25-apartment phases around the corner on Church Street. 
 The larger development replaces a car dealership that formerly stood on the site. It will have 200 one- and two-bedroom apartments with 771 to 1,282 square feet of space each. The apartments will include washers and dryers, high-tech wiring and balconies or patios. Some will also have dens and fireplaces. 
The apartments will be in two four-story brick buildings, each of which will wrap around an interior courtyard. One courtyard will feature a garden, the other an outdoor swimming pool, according to the developer, LCOR Inc., which is based in Berwyn, Pa., with offices in Jersey City. There will also be a health club and a 180-car garage as well as surface parking for 158 cars at the complex. LCOR's financial partners in the project are Key Bank and Lehman Brothers.
Gaslight Commons, the developer said, will capitalize on the absence of new upscale rentals in the township as well as in surrounding communities and the project's closeness to the train station. South Orange's attraction for commuters to Manhattan has been enhanced since the introduction in 1996 of an express service directly into Penn Station, called Midtown Direct, that shaved about 15 minutes off the previous 45-minute trip. 
"With the labor market tight and roadways congested, being able to offer good train access and a convenient commute is a major draw," said Anthony Marchetta, a vice president at LCOR. Another appeal is that the project, designed by Humphreys & Partners Architects of Dallas, is in a reviving downtown, he said.
Efforts to turn around the township's 12-block business district that began seven years have paid off in the last two years, said John O. Gross, South Orange's administrator. 
Some of the projects, including the rehabilitation of the 1916 Sloane Street Station and the string of stores adjoining it, were done in cooperation with New Jersey Transit, the overseer of the state's transit system. In 1999, the area around the station was one of five such areas designated as "transit villages" as part of a state program aimed at attracting private investment and spurring mixed-use development within walking distance of transit hubs. 
Projects are in various stages of development in the four other designated towns: Rutherford, Pleasantville, Morristown and South Amboy. Among them is a 226-apartment rental on a three-acre site across Lafayette Avenue from the train station in Morristown. Construction of that project, Lafayette Commons, is to start in September, according to the developer, a partnership between the Roseland Property Company of Short Hills and Woodmont Properties of Parsippany.
Two blocks from the train station in South Amboy, work is under way on Lighthouse Bay, made up of 115 town houses and 70 one-family detached homes. Sales are to start this spring at the project, said the developer, Baker Residential of Pleasantville, N.Y.
Jeffrey A. Warsh, New Jersey Transit's executive director, described the transit village program in South Orange as "a model for the state." He added, "A project to restore blighted storefronts served as a catalyst for subsequent improvements." 
Other downtown projects include a $10 million art center that is to contain five cinemas, a 350-seat theater for live performances and a community room. Construction of the center is to begin this spring. 
The strong demand for and limited supply of rentals helps Gaslight Commons and Church Street Commons, Mr. Gross said, noting that they are "certainly the first such upscale developments since the 1980's."
Roy Scott, who runs Re/Max Village Square Realtors, a realty company in South Orange, said there would always be people who "are not prepared to or choose not to buy." But many potential tenants were not drawn to the older rentals in town because they lacked amenities, he said, adding that "people wound up renting elsewhere."
Mr. Marchetta said his company bought the car dealership site late in 1999 after it secured all approvals and the township rezoned the parcel for housing. As part of the downtown redevelopment, property taxes on the project are reduced for 30 years, he said.
Mr. Marchetta said the units would be marketed mainly to empty nesters as well as young professionals who live in the area or elsewhere in New Jersey and work in Manhattan. Tenants relocating from Manhattan are another potential audience, he said, adding that monthly rents are expected to range from $1,400 to $2,000. Leasing will begin by September with initial occupancy to start four months later, he added.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: A rendering of Gaslight Commons, a 200-apartment complex under construction in South Orange, N.J. (Humphreys & Partners Architects)

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS; 
How 'Miracle on Ice' Helped Restore Faith

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
After the 52 Americans who were held hostage in the United States embassy in Tehran were released on Jan. 20, 1981, they were shown an hourlong video that summarized the world events they had missed during their 444 days in captivity.
 The tape, made by the State Department, ended with the stunning 4-3 victory by the United States men's hockey team over the powerhouse Soviet Union/Red Army squad in the semifinals at the 1980 Winter Olympics in Lake Placid, N.Y. 
 The group, which flew to the United States Air Force hospital in Wiesbaden, West Germany, where it viewed the video, applauded the most for the hockey team. "Here I'm exposed to this wonderful sight of Americans going crazy over a hockey game," Barry Rosen, one of the hostages, said. "I wish I had been there; that was my only regret." 
Rosen tells the story at the end of yet another finely made HBO documentary, "Do You Believe in Miracles?" (Monday at 10 p.m. Eastern time), which puts the Feb. 22, 1980, victory over the Soviets (and the gold medal won by the United States two days later against Finland) in the context of America's crisis of confidence.
"Besides the cheers on the plane leaving Iran, I don't remember cheering as much for anything else as I did for the hockey team," Rosen, now the head of public affairs at Teachers College, said Wednesday night after a screening of the film.
After being freed, Rosen got on with his life, and had not thought much about the Olympic hockey saga and its meaning to the hostages until he got a call last year from Brian Hyland, the documentary's producer. Hyland was not seeking any more than Rosen's views on the turmoil in Iran.
"I laughed," Rosen said. "He said, 'Would you be interested in talking about the Iranian situation, and I said, 'What?' But during the interview, things came out. It was natural." He recalled for Hyland how he learned about the United States hockey team's victory, which occurred 11 months before his release.
"If I had been able to read about the hockey team, it would have been a great thing to talk about, but it would not have had as great an impact if I were free," Rosen said.
Rosen said that HBO's use of the United States-Soviet game to symbolize how Americans started feeling better about themselves is not a stretch -- especially in what was a post-Vietnam period marked by runaway inflation, soaring interest rates and the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan.
"That game may have been the moment when Americans starting feeling pride again," Rosen said. His wife, Barbara, added: "People were looking for something to hold on to. Things were so bad for so long."
Indeed, much like the event itself, "Do You Believe in Miracles?" is a feel-good work that takes viewers from how Coach Herb Brooks utilized motivational techniques, many of them shamelessly manipulative, to bond the team, often against him, and to prepare his players to play the mighty Soviets.
It builds the story effectively, then intercuts action with interviews to capture the tension of the games against the Soviets and the Finns.
The documentary is rich with game and training film, and enlightening interviews with United States and Soviet players, as well as remarks from people like Rosen, former Vice President Walter Mondale, and Al Michaels, who called the game for ABC.
Vladislav Tretiak, the peerless Soviet goalie who was pulled by Coach Viktor Tikhonov after giving up two goals in the first period of the game, said: "They were just students. We played as professionals and students came out to play against us. Simply, we did not respect that team and you can't do that in hockey."
Tretiak, and his teammates Boris Mikhailov and Zinetula Bilyletdinov, as well as the Soviet reporter Igor Kuperman, offer candid commentary about their formidable team's Olympic demise. Inevitably, Tretiak was asked if he believed in miracles.
One Soviet holdout from the documentary was Tikhonov, who is still coaching hockey in Russia. Hyland might as well have asked the late Leonid Brezhnev for a sitdown.
"I was escorted into this dark office that looked like the opening scene from 'The Godfather,' " Hyland said. "He said, 'Nyet.' He said more than that, but my translator was so afraid of him, he told me, 'He said no. Now let's get out of here.' "

Althea Gibson's Voice
In ABC's "Raising the Roof" (tomorrow 1-2 p.m. on Channel 7), a report that celebrates Black History Month and looks at black managers, black quarterbacks and Magic Johnson, remarks from the ailing Althea Gibson are read by an actress, Novella Nelson. It's an unusual but effective device to learning something about the reclusive 73-year-old tennis icon.
In melancholy words, Gibson says, "I want people to remember me as I was: strong, vibrant and athletic, not as I am now." About her career, in which she faced racism in tennis and golf, she added, "It has been a bewildering, challenging, exhausting experience, often more painful than pleasurable, more sad than happy."

Airwaves
ABC will experiment with a new technology capable of tracking players' on-ice speed and the distance they cover during Sunday's National Hockey League All-Star Game (2:30 p.m. on Channel 7). The Trakus system will use transmitters the size of credit cards fitted inside four players' helmets. It will send data to antennas around the rink that will send the information to computers. . . . Channel 5 has agreed to renew its deal to carry 50 Yankees games this season for a small increase above the $18.5 million fee that it paid in 2000.

HEADLINE: Energy, in the Arctic and California 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "California's Golden Dream Goes Dark," by D. J. Waldie (Op-Ed, Jan. 28):
 This energy crisis has been caused not so much by tremendous economic growth and prosperity as by the ineptitude and lack of vision by the utility companies, former Gov. 
Pete Wilson and the Legislature. They enacted the flawed deregulation system. 
 In the next few years, with the right vision and political will, there is no reason California cannot develop an energy system that can be a model for the rest of the states. And yes, we're going to keep our hot tubs.

RICH WILLIAMS
Petaluma, Calif., Jan. 28, 2001

HEADLINE: Power Supplier Shifts Its Clients 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Enron Energy Services officially notified many large business customers today that, as reported, it would no longer supply them with low-cost power because of the turmoil in California's electricity market. 
 The businesses will be switched to Pacific Gas and Electric, which is in such financial distress that the state has been forced to buy some of the power needed to supply its customers. 
 Enron's move was another sign of how soaring wholesale electricity prices and power shortages were forcing more private companies from the country's largest energy market and sending ripples through the economy.
But Enron officials said the company had decided that it would absorb any increases in power rates for these customers. One person close to the company estimated that the increases could be as high as 35 percent over the prices in the long-term contracts with these businesses.
While it appeared that the decision could cost Enron, a huge Houston-based energy concern, tens of millions of dollars, if not several hundred million dollars over the next several years, it would allow the company to maintain good relations with the business customers, a company official said.
Peggy Mahoney, an Enron spokeswoman, said that the costs would not be so large that they would stop the company from meeting its overall earnings forecasts. Enron Energy Services is a subsidiary of the Enron Corporation that helps businesses save money on their energy needs.
Under California's deregulation plan, companies like Enron negotiated contracts directly with big businesses, in this case companies like Cisco Systems, Kaiser Permanente and Genentech, and sell them power at a discount from what Pacific Gas and Electric would charge.

HEADLINE: Starting Race for Governor, McCall Focuses on Pataki 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Accusing Gov. George E. Pataki of "aimless lethargy" and "detachment" in office, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, announced last night that he will run for governor in 2002, kicking off what promises to be one of the longest and most bitterly contested races the state has seen.
 Mr. McCall, a Democrat, is the only black person ever elected to statewide office in New York State and the first black person ever to be regarded as a serious contender for the governor's office. 
 At a fund-raising dinner at the Plaza Hotel that his aides said took in more than $1 million, Mr. McCall answered the supporters who have been shouting, "Run, Carl, run" for almost a year. "You don't have to chant any more," he said. "I am here to tell you tonight, I am running."
With 21 months to go before the election, the events of this week mark the earliest start to a statewide campaign that political professionals can remember, yet Mr. McCall was not even the first big-name candidate to declare his entry into the race.
That distinction went to another Democrat, Andrew M. Cuomo, the former United States secretary of housing and urban development and son of the former governor, who told his backers on Monday that he planned to run.
But Mr. McCall ignored Mr. Cuomo, who promises to be a strong primary opponent, and trained his fire on the even more formidable Republican incumbent, Mr. Pataki, who enjoys great popularity and is a potent fund-raiser.
"The governor has done nothing to improve our public schools, he's shortchanged our public universities, he's ignored the upstate economy," Mr. McCall said. "He's failed to lead."
"It's time to turn around the aimless lethargy of this administration," he said. "It's time to replace detachment with determination."
Mr. McCall's comments signaled his intention to make a campaign issue of the governor's laconic public persona and often low public profile.
But Mr. Pataki has proved to be a fierce, often nimble political battler, and his office was ready with a reply to Mr. McCall before the comptroller had stopped speaking. "Carl McCall's political ambitions have apparently made him overlook the fact that Governor Pataki has cut more than $100 billion in taxes, helped create more than 780,000 new jobs, provided record school aid increases, improved health care and our environment, and brought our crime rate and welfare rolls to record lows," said Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the governor's office. "All of which explains why the governor enjoys such tremendous support from the people of New York State."
This week's two Democratic coming-out parties stood in stark contrast to each other. Mr. Cuomo's announcement Monday came in an unorthodox setting -- a shoe store owned by Kenneth Cole, a brother-in-law of Mr. Cuomo's -- and drew an unorthodox crowd of 200, some of them political veterans, some of them famous, but few who are currently fully engaged in politics.
Mr. McCall's party was more in the mold of a classic political gala, held in an ornate hotel ballroom. Among the 600 people in attendance were many of the power players of Democratic politics -- Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, Representatives Charles B. Rangel, Jerrold L. Nadler, and Gregory W. Meeks, and dozens of state legislators, City Council members and party leaders. Three of the four Democratic candidates for mayor of New York City attended; two, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, and Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, who have endorsed Mr. McCall, and a third, Mark Green, the public advocate, who said he was only "here as a friend." Missing was the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone.
Even the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, who has had a strained relationship with Mr. McCall and is expected to remain neutral in the primary, felt compelled to make an appearance and greet Mr. McCall, though he did not stay for dinner. Almost as striking was the number of upstate officials present to support Mr. McCall, a Manhattan resident.
The fundraiser also drew a celebrity element, with the likes of Bill Cosby, Shirley MacLaine and Vernon Jordan in attendance. Ms. MacLaine captured some of the evening's confident, almost giddy air, calling it "the loosest coming-out party I've been to in 5,000 years."
Invoking Bella Abzug, the late congresswoman, Ms. MacLaine said, "I haven't endorsed or supported anyone since Bella, and I talked to her last night."
Mr. McCall's supporters readily acknowledged that he faces an uphill fight -- a tough primary against Mr. Cuomo and then, should the comptroller win, a battle as a decided underdog against Mr. Pataki. "Whether he can beat George Pataki or not, I don't know," said Mel Miller, the former Assembly speaker who is now a lobbyist. "George Pataki is very popular."
But Mr. McCall's backers consider him a strong candidate, and one they can support enthusiastically. And for black supporters, there is a sense that his run represents a coming of age. "We've been planning for a long time to get here," Mr. Rangel said.

HEADLINE: Strength of January Vehicle Sales Surprises Automakers 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
Americans snapped up new cars and sport utility vehicles last month as though the economy were booming and layoffs were far from their minds, surprising and even mystifying auto executives worried about plunging consumer confidence and an economy that has slowed almost to a standstill.
 Automakers sold cars, vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 17.2 million vehicles in January, far better than the pace of 15.4 million vehicles set in December. The auto industry considers anything above 16 million to be a strong month. 
 Sales were down 6 percent from those in the month a year earlier, when the industry was enjoying an extraordinary boom. For all of last year, automakers sold 17.4 million cars and light trucks, their best year ever by a wide margin. 
Good weather and large shipments of cars to corporate and government fleets probably played some role in the rebound in sales after December, said George Pipas, Ford Motor's director of United States market analysis, adding that the true strength of the market was probably between the December and January levels. "We're very pleased with January's results, but as far as I know, I haven't heard any Champagne corks pop at Ford headquarters," Mr. Pipas said.
Jamie Jameson, the vice president for marketing and sales at the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler, said that the Federal Reserve's first cut in interest rates a month ago may have increased sales slightly even though most economic models suggest that movements in interest rates take many months to have an effect. As automakers' own borrowing costs declined after the rate cut, they began offering lower interest rates to consumers on discounted loans in late January, Mr. Jameson said. Chrysler, for example, reduced interest rates on Monday for loans on Jeep Grand Cherokees and Dodge Durangos.
The Fed is cutting rates in an effort to stimulate the economy and keep it from heading into a recession. The auto sales figures were released on the same day as a report showing that United States manufacturers cut their production sharply in January. Page C2. 
Enduring or not, the auto market's strength last month produced one immediate benefit for the economy in the Midwest: no automakers announced further cuts today in their targets for production in the first quarter after doing so repeatedly in December and early January. General Motors, Ford and Chrysler officials did say today that they would idle several factories for a week or two this month but added that these production cutbacks were part of plans set in early January to reach the first-quarter targets rather than a further retrenchment.
G.M., Ford and Chrysler have been idling factories for a week or two at a time and furloughing the workers. Chrysler announced on Monday that it would reduce its work force by 26,000 people over the next three years, partly by laying off up to 7,100 people in the United States and Canada and 3,100 in Mexico and South America. These steps have caused ripples across the upper Midwest, as auto parts suppliers have also begun closing factories temporarily, prompting economists to warn that consumer spending and confidence in the region might be so damaged as to push the region into a recession.
The auto industry directly and indirectly accounts for about a quarter of the economic output of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana, according to an analysis a few years ago by the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
G.M.'s sales fell 5.1 percent last month, while Ford's dropped 11.6 percent, and sales at Chrysler tumbled 16.2 percent. G.M. prospered partly because of enormous shipments of cars to fleets; Paul Ballew, executive director of market analysis at General Motors, said that the company's extra fleet sales alone had increased the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales in January by 200,000 vehicles.
He also cautioned that January and February are weak months for auto sales, making it hard to draw conclusions. 
But G.M. also did extremely well in selling full-size sport utility vehicles, which are mostly sold at high profits to families and not to fleets, which typically buy unpopular models available at deep discounts. G.M.'s sales of full-size sport utilities jumped 18 percent even as Ford's sales of them dropped more than 20 percent. Mr. Pipas said that Ford's main full-size sport utilities, the Ford Expedition and Lincoln Navigator, were not selling as well as a year ago because they are now in the last year before a redesign.
The sharp drop in Chrysler's sales was in line with expectations, said Gary Lapidus, an auto analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
Dieter Zetsche, the former Mercedes executive sent from Germany two months ago to become Chrysler's chief executive, said in a statement today that uncertainty preceding the layoffs announced on Monday had hurt the company's sales last month.
Foreign automakers had a mixed performance last month, as some benefited from new models and from the strength of the dollar against the yen and euro, which made it much cheaper to import cars and car parts to the United States.
Mitsubishi's sales leaped 15.2 percent, Honda's sales rose 11.1 percent and BMW's climbed 9.8 percent. But Nissan's sales dipped 4.4 percent, the Mercedes unit of DaimlerChrysler had a 7 percent drop and Toyota's sales were down 11.4 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Said to Approve Anti-Hussein Funding 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 

 BODY:
An Iraqi opposition group said today that it had been given permission by the Bush administration to begin American-funded activities within Iraq in an effort to undermine the government of President Saddam Hussein.
 The group, the Iraqi National Congress, said through a Washington spokesman that it would be the first time that the United States had provided funding for opposition activities inside Iraq since 1996, when the assistance was suspended. 
 "In that sense, it is a big deal, a pretty substantial departure" in American policy, said Francis Brooke, the American adviser to the London-based dissident group. 
He said the Bush administration's decision to let the group tap a multimillion-dollar fund established last fall by Congress "portends a more serious approach to the problem" of confronting Mr. Hussein. 
A State Department spokeswoman would not comment on a report in The Washington Post that disclosed the administration's decision to grant a one-year license allowing the money to be used inside Iraq.
Although the Clinton administration had set in motion the plan to help opposition groups re-establish activities inside Iraq, it was often tepid in its support for the opposition. President Clinton signed a law in 1998 authorizing $98 million in military aid and equipment, but in the end his administration provided very little assistance and explicitly refused to provide weapons. Senior Clinton administration officials warned that Iraqi opposition groups were too weak and fractious to pose a serious threat to Mr. Hussein and could embarrass the United States.
Mr. Brooke said the Bush administration decision would allow the opposition group to use American money to collect information about human rights violations, breaches of United Nations resolutions and other political intelligence. "We operate in Iraq anyway," he said. "The significance is that we're going to be able to operate inside Iraq with overt American assistance."
The new administration had signaled its intent to increase pressure on Iraq, both through reinvigorated economic sanctions and support for the opposition. The administration includes senior officials, notably Vice President Dick Cheney and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, who directed the 1991 war against Iraq.

HEADLINE: Giuliani, Thinking of the Future, Celebrates a Book Deal That Has City Hall Abuzz 

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Edward I. Koch landed a $100,000 advance for a book he wrote while still mayor. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo drew less than $20,000 for a collection of his best-received speeches. But when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani went to the literary market, he set a City Hall record, drawing an advance of nearly $3 million for a memoir and a less juicy how-to guide on managing an unmanageable city.
 The deal elicited a quick celebration Wednesday night at Gracie Mansion with his publisher, Talk Miramax Books. But by yesterday, the size of his advance had the mayor answering questions about any possible conflicts it might present, given that Talk Miramax's corporate parent is the Walt Disney Company, the entertainment conglomerate that bases many of its operations in New York City. 
 Disney officials and the mayor said yesterday that the deal did not pose any conflicts. Miramax, they noted, is an autonomous subsidiary. And any major publisher the mayor might have picked would have a sizable presence in New York City and occasional interaction with City Hall, Mr. Giuliani added.
"There are no issues," the mayor said, after giving a broad outline of his two books, the first of which will focus on his professional and personal life and the second of which will be a sort of manual on managing mammoth organizations like New York City.
To ensure that no ethical questions surface, the mayor said, he will stay away from matters related to Disney.
Disney has extensive operations in New York City. Though based in Burbank, Calif., it has several thousand employees in New York, working at places like ABC Inc., WABC-TV, WABC-AM, WPLJ-FM, ABC News, ABC.com, and on such programs as "The View," "Good Morning America" and two soap operas.
In addition, the company's retail presence includes ESPN Zone and several Walt Disney stores. Miramax Films is based in TriBeCa, and Disney's theatrical division operates the hugely popular Broadway shows "The Lion King," "Aida" and "Beauty and the Beast."
In past years of Mr. Giuliani's administration, Disney or its subsidiaries have benefited from a range of city assistance, including $26 million in sales-tax abatements and other aid to keep its ABC television network based in New York, and more than $20 million in state and city loans to rebuild the New Amsterdam Theater at Times Square.
"I've given similar help to The New York Times, given similar help to CBS, NBC, the New York Stock Exchange, the New York Yankees and the New York Mets," Mr. Giuliani said, after a speech in Times Square. But he added that from now on when it comes to Disney, "I will stay out of any decisions about them."
Mr. Giuliani's decision to write the book, in fact, puts him in a league with an increasing number of public officials who have decided to mix their political careers with the literary life. But others, including many members of the Clinton administration, waited until they left office to start work on a book.
Asked why he chose to start writing the book now, the mayor said he had been contemplating such a project for about 15 years and had already made several false starts. And why did he not wait until the end of his tenure to sign a deal? The mayor said he was eager to figure out what he would be doing with himself starting next year.
"I have got to find a way to make a living next year," he said. "I want to do something interesting, I want to do something that is creative, I want to do something that is fun, I want to do something that is enlightening."
The advance offered to Mr. Giuliani -- who has 11 months left in office -- would be prohibited if he were a member of the United States House of Representatives. But there is no city ethics law that bars such advances, said Gene Russianoff, senior attorney at the New York Public Research Interest Group.
Even so, Mr. Russianoff and Fred Wertheimer, president of Democracy 21, a nonprofit Washington organization that advocates campaign finance and ethics reform, said yesterday that they were disturbed by the deal. The mayor, they said, should not have accepted a large advance, or he should have waited until he left office to sign such a lucrative contract.
"There is bad judgment here," Mr. Wertheimer said. "It is ethically questionable and certainly insensitive to the larger public interest concerns."
Beside the big-ticket economic assistance the city has provided to Disney or its subsidiaries, topics related to the company routinely involve City Hall or the mayor. When Time Warner last year shut off ABC's signal on its cable television system, Mr. Giuliani came to ABC's defense. When Disney wanted a festive premiere for its "Pocahontas" film, it negotiated a deal with the city to show it in Central Park.
Disney officials said that nothing about the company's relationship with New York City would change.
"Obviously the fact that the mayor has a book contract with Miramax will not have any influence on our interactions with the city, or business decisions we would consider regarding the city or the state," said Christine L. Castro, a Disney spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: Expert Says Car Weight Was Key in Tire Failures 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
Firestone tires have been failing on Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles because of a combination of factors, especially the vehicle's weight, according to a report issued today by a professor retained by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc.
 Sanjay Govindjee, an associate professor of civil and environmental engineering at the University of California at Berkeley, said in his report that tire inflation pressure, hot weather and vehicle speed had all played a role in causing a fraction of 1 percent of Firestone tires to lose their treads during highway driving. But he said that the most important single factor in determining how quickly cracks spread through the tires was how much weight they were carrying. 
 "The variable that seems to be most important is the load on the tire -- that is, the weight of the vehicle itself," Mr. Govindjee said in a conference call with reporters . 
Mr. Govindjee, an expert on how rubber and other elastic substances behave when subjected to stresses, declined to discuss whether the Firestone tires had been the right tires for the Explorer, sticking to the results of laboratory and computer analyses while offering few opinions.
Bridgestone/Firestone, a unit of the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, recalled 6.5 million tires on Aug. 9 after the Ford Motor Company determined that the tires had an above-average rate of failures causing deaths and injuries, especially since 1997. Federal regulators had received unconfirmed reports of 148 deaths linked to Firestone tires by Dec. 6, the last time regulators released a tally.
Ken Zino, a Ford spokesman, said today that the problem was that the tires were unusually sensitive to the loads on them, and not that the Explorer was too heavy for its tires. "We have studied that, and there's nothing unusual in the Explorer as far as loads," he said.
The completely redesigned 2002 Ford Explorer, which goes on sale later this month, uses larger tires that are capable of carrying more weight. Ford also announced in November that it would begin providing customers with more information on how much weight their vehicles could safely carry.
Current owners' manuals in Explorers suggest customers have their empty vehicles weighed at weighing stations along highways or at shipping companies. By subtracting this number from the recommended maximum weight of the vehicle when fully loaded, found on the inside of the pillar behind the driver's door, the payload can be calculated. The typical Explorer can safely carry slightly less weight than a Ford Taurus sedan, according to Ford and tests by Consumer Reports magazine.
Ford manufactures the Explorer by bolting a large, heavy passenger compartment onto an underbody originally designed for the Ford Ranger pickup truck, a much lighter vehicle.
Mr. Govindjee's report did not address the stability of the Explorer, an area outside his expertise.
A computer analysis last fall by The New York Times of a federal database of all fatal crashes nationwide found that 97 percent of all tire-related deaths in Explorers during the 1990's also involved rollovers, compared with 84 percent for all other sport utility vehicles and 38 percent in cars. Tire problems were a factor in roughly one-tenth of the rollover deaths in Explorers during the 1990's, an unusually high proportion at a time when tire-related deaths were a tiny and dwindling share of traffic deaths.
A mention of warranty claims in Mr. Govindjee's report attracted considerable attention today among personal injury lawyers and consumer activists. Mr. Govindjee said that the rate of warranty claims for some recalled Firestone tires was the same as for some Firestone tires that had not been recalled.
The brief statement on warranty claims in the middle of the highly technical report today prompted Joan Claybrook, the president of Public Citizen, the consumer safety group in Washington, to call for a wider recall.
Firestone has recalled all ATX tires of the P235/75R15 size, but only recalled Wilderness AT tires of this size that were made in Decatur, Ill. Firestone has not recalled Wilderness tires made at its factories in Joliet, Ill., Quebec and Wilson, N.C. The ATX tires have been made since 1990 and the Wilderness tires since 1996.
Mr. Govindjee said in his report that the frequency of warranty claims for Wilderness tires varied little by where they were made. All of them had warranty rates that were somewhat above the average for all Firestone tires made in the late 1990's, but considerably below the average for all Firestone tires made in the early 1990's. The Wilderness tires had much lower warranty rates than ATX tires produced since 1996.
Greer Tidwell, Firestone's director of manufacturing, said that Wilderness tires had a better design than ATX tires. He said a recall of all Wilderness tires would be unnecessary.
Firestone paid for Mr. Govindjee's report and provided him with the laboratory results that he used for his computer analyses. But Mr. Govindjee said in the telephone interview that Firestone had not tried to steer his research.
A table in today's report showed that rubber tests from Firestone's own laboratory produced results that were consistently a little less favorable to the company than an independent laboratory's tests on identical rubber. Mr. Govindjee attributed the discrepancy to differences in test methods.
The report today comes as lawyers continue to file tire-related lawsuits. A few are suing automakers other than Ford, and representing clients in hot-weather places outside the United States.
Firestone and General Motors were sued on Wednesday in Nashville by the family of three citizens of Mexico , one of them pregnant, who died in a crash in Mexico a year ago. The lawsuit asserted that the family's 1997 Chevrolet Suburban crashed because a Firestone tire failed. Firestone and G.M. officials said that they had not yet seen the lawsuit, which was reported today by NashvillePost.com, a business news Web site.
