HEADLINE: Energy Secretary Rejects Request to Cap Electricity Price 

BYLINE:  By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 2 

 BODY:
Spencer Abraham, the federal energy secretary, rejected a plea from several Western governors today for the federal government to impose temporary price caps on wholesale electricity, after listening to their concerns that "exorbitant" and "out-of-control" electricity costs were spreading economic havoc across the region.
 "I have great concerns about that, and the president has expressed concerns as well," Mr. Abraham said in response to the request from at least eight Western governors, including those of the three West Coast states, California, Oregon and Washington. 
 "At a time when demand is a very serious challenge for us this summer," Mr. Abraham said, "anything that puts disincentives in place, that would work against reducing demand, I think has to be looked at very closely." 
Several of the governors, especially the Democrats, denounced the Bush administration's unenthusiastic response.
"I'm very disappointed by the secretary's statement that the administration does not support even temporary, quick price caps," said Gary Locke, the Democratic governor of Washington. "They're really leaving all the people of the Western United States out in the cold and on their own for many years."
"This is a growing crisis that's going to sweep across the United States," Governor Locke said, "and that's why the Bush administration needs to get involved now and has to provide some immediate relief and stabilize the situation."
The meeting here in Portland was called by the Western Governors' Association and held under the polite billing of an "Energy Policy Roundtable," but there was no mistaking the tension as elected leaders struggled with the economic and political fallout of the turmoil in the region's electricity markets. And Secretary Abraham was not the only official on the hot seat during the event.
A leader who many governors felt had some explaining to do was Gov. Gray Davis of California, the state where the electricity crisis began and the one that has been widely blamed by its neighbors for creating supply shortages that have driven up electric rates by 10 percent to 80 percent in some Western cities.
Governor Davis, a Democrat, cited the bill he signed on Thursday in Sacramento that would allow the state to buy as much as $10 billion worth of power through long-term contracts to try to stabilize its electricity market. He promised his fellow governors that California would move at "warp speed" to build new power plants, after more than a decade in which not a single major plant had been built in the state, and he managed to defuse some of the anger directed at him and his state with his description of the conservation measures that he said California was undertaking.
The California conservation plan, to reduce demand by as much as 20 percent, includes a requirement that retail businesses curb their outdoor lighting and take other measures to cut power consumption.
Secretary Abraham, who was sworn into office barely a week ago, praised the electricity bill signed by Mr. Davis. He cited it and the conservation measures in explaining why he did not believe that significant federal intervention in the electricity crisis, including price controls, was needed right now.
"I think Governor Davis proved that California can stand on its own with the actions they've already taken," Mr. Abraham said at a news conference. "They've made the progress they said they would make, and I commend them."
Despite his opposition to price caps, Mr. Abraham said he was open to more suggestions from the governors, and he noted that President Bush had convened a task force on the electricity problem, with Vice President Dick Cheney as chairman.
The issue of price caps was contentious even among the governors, as at least three -- Dirk Kempthorne of Idaho and Jane Dee Hull of Arizona, both Republicans, and Tony Knowles of Alaska, a Democrat -- announced their opposition and thwarted a forceful effort by the three West Coast governors to forge a unanimous resolution in favor of capping prices.
Such controls could, indeed, stabilize electricity bills in the short term by limiting what large power generators could charge utilities. But critics say the measures are an artificial and dangerous tinkering with normal market forces and could exacerbate problems in the long run by discouraging development of new sources of electricity.
The issue is further complicated by the fact that some Western states are net exporters of power, and price caps are bitterly opposed in those states by power industry leaders, who say curbs will produce a net loss for the states, even if consumers temporarily benefit.
The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which oversees the wholesale electricity markets, has so far turned back pleas to use its authority to impose the caps, saying it can do so only if it finds evidence of collusion by power companies to drive up prices. Although wholesale rates for electricity have soared at times to 10 times and even 100 times their normal rates in the recent crisis, the regulatory commission has said it does not believe that industry officials have manipulated the market.
The commission's chairman, Curt Hebert, repeated Secretary Abraham's comments in opposing price controls.
"Caps are completely contrary to everything the FERC is trying to accomplish" in creating competition and alleviating the Western power shortages, Mr. Hebert told the governors today, using the acronym for his agency. He said the caps would also reduce incentives to conserve electricity.
The governors did agree today on a number of short-term and long-range strategies to help ease the crisis, including increasing conservation, in part by exploring ways of billing consumers that encourage them to use significantly less electricity during peak demand hours, which is when rolling blackouts, which have already hit California, are most likely to be imposed. And they pledged to work on speeding the construction of new power plants. But Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon, a Democrat, pushed for an extensive expansion of conservation efforts, warning against simply trying to "dig, drill and burn" a way out of a crisis.
Also at the meeting were leaders of several Indian tribes, who repeatedly expressed concern that the electricity problems could unravel federal laws and programs protecting salmon and other migratory fish that must navigate the huge network of federal hydroelectric dams in the Northwest.
"Salmon did not create the current crisis, and the Columbia River cannot continue to be run on their backs," said Antone Minthorn, chairman of the Confederated Tribes of the Umatilla Indian Reservation, in northeastern Oregon.

HEADLINE: Bush, the Conciliator, Meets With Democrats 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 

 BODY:
President Bush ventured into enemy territory today, meeting with Senate Democrats to outline his hopes for his first year in office.
 Later in the day, in a speech to Republican members of Congress at a retreat in Williamsburg, Va., he vowed to make the case for deep tax cuts "over and over again" until Americans were convinced that his plan would help the middle class and act as a remedy for economic slowdown. 
 Mr. Bush's spokesman said the Democrats, who met Mr. Bush behind closed doors, listened politely but were "tentative and silent" during his 12-minute speech, which was followed by a brief question-and-answer period. But after they emerged from their own strategy sessions, the Senate Democrats warmly praised Mr. Bush for the gracious gesture of showing up. 
The Republicans, not surprisingly, were basking in the glow of the legislative possibilities ahead, and talked openly about tax cuts that are even deeper than what Mr. Bush proposed in his campaign.
"I come from the school of thought that by cutting marginal rates for everybody who pays taxes is a good way to help ease the pain of what may be an economic slowdown," Mr. Bush told the Republicans, brushing past Alan Greenspan's warning last week that by the time any tax cut would be passed and take effect, it would probably be too late to correct the current slowdown. "And we'll make that case over and over and over again until we get a bill through." 
At both the Democratic and Republican gatherings, Mr. Bush turned on his charm -- and repeated some well-tested laugh-lines -- to show that he was at ease in his new setting and confident of legislative victory. He told House and Senate Republicans, who went to Williamsburg with their spouses, that he would invite them all to the White House.
"Just don't take any silverware," he said, to much applause.
Mr. Bush was not specific today about his tax proposals, but his spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said the bill he would propose next week would closely mirror the $1.6 billion tax cut he proposed in the campaign. That plan seemed a long shot a few months ago, but today, with the economy slowing and new estimates of the federal surplus rising, it is clear that Mr. Bush will almost certainly get a huge tax cut through Congress.
Democrats are trying to limit any cut to $750 billion to $1 trillion over the next 10 years -- far larger than the tax cut Al Gore ran on in his campaign -- while some Republicans are talking about Mr. Bush's proposal of $1.6 trillion as a floor, not a ceiling. 
The result is a predictable rush among Washington lobbyists to get their favorite tax provisions included in the legislative language, with everyone from high-tech corporations to automakers arguing that after years of higher productivity, they now need a break. 
Mr. Bush discussed none of that today. But he did warn Republicans that "it's important for us not to let the tax relief debate fall into a class warfare debate," arguing, as he did during the campaign, that even a single mother making $22,000 a year would benefit.
"It seems like to me the fair way to do things," he said, "is if people pay taxes, they ought to get tax relief."
The White House has set aside next week as its tax-cut week, just as last week was devoted to education reform and this week to helping religious organizations perform charitable work. And once again, the White House is choreographing events to keep its agenda on television and the front pages.
On Monday, Mr. Bush is planning to bring four families to the White House to talk about how his tax cuts could aid them; on Tuesday he is to visit a small business, and on Wednesday he plans to hold a reunion of families he met on the campaign trail to humanize his tax proposals. On Thursday, he is to send his tax legislation to Capitol Hill.
The size and composition of the tax legislation, however, will be the subject of a protracted struggle. So Mr. Bush took the unusual step of appearing at the annual party retreat of the Senate Democrats, at the Library of Congress, as a sign that he wanted to reach across the aisle.
While he stayed for under an hour and did not get into detailed discussions of policy, Democrats called Mr. Bush's very appearance before them an unusual gesture of good will and said it the first time a president of the opposition party had appeared at the strategy sessions that have been a staple of party politics since the 1980's.
Mr. Bush expressed the hope that the parties could reach compromises on education, tax cutting and Medicare prescription drug coverage, the lawmakers said. And there was no discussion of the confirmation battle just past over John Ashcroft.
"I give him very high marks for being there," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said, "I thought that his remarks were very conciliatory. He indicated an interest in working with us and reaching compromise on issues."
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware called the visit to the Democratic gathering a "good gesture," but cautioned that the president might have a hard time pulling the parties together. 
"Where are the compromises?" Mr. Biden asked. "Bipartisanship doesn't mean we just like each other. I mean, we do like each other. But it means how does that translate? Are you really going to have compromises on issues? He said he thought we could."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 5, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Saturday about President Bush's appearance at a closed-door meeting with Senate Democrats included an erroneous phrase from a pool news report of the event. A spokesman for the White House said afterward that the Democrats had been "attentive and silent," not "tentative and silent."
The article also misstated the size of Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut. It is $1.6 trillion over 10 years, not $1.6 billion.

HEADLINE: Set the Alarm for 2011 

BYLINE:  By Adam Garfinkle; Adam Garfinkle is a senior fellow at the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia.

 BODY:
 WHILE AMERICA SLEEPS
Self-Delusion, Military Weakness,
and the Threat to Peace Today.
By Donald Kagan
and Frederick W. Kagan.
Illustrated. 483 pp. New York:
St. Martin's Press. $32.50.
 A clarion call, a sounding of the tocsin or a plea to heed history's dire warnings -- all are fair ways to describe "While America Sleeps," an unflinching polemic nested in the language of historical research and contemporary strategic analysis. A father-son duo -- the former a renowned professor of history and classics at Yale, the latter a professor of military history at the United States Military Academy -- Donald Kagan and Frederick W. Kagan adjure us to wake up lest America after the cold war repeat the grave errors of Britain after World War I. 
Britain's position then and America's today, they insist, are analogous. And both countries' leaders are guilty of the same mistakes, which are, in ascending order of severity: trusting expressions of good will, international organizations and arms control agreements to keep the peace; allowing one's credibility to be eroded by a supine diplomacy; and letting one's military might decay to a level far below that required to consummate one's commitments.
The book is divided into a short introduction that both makes the case for its organizing analogy and sets its mobilizing tone; a lengthy chronicle of Britain between the world wars; a slightly shorter discussion of American post-cold-war policy; and a brief conclusion that restates, with the confidence of explication behind it, the claims laid out in the introduction. 
Does this straightforward thesis, embedded in this parsimonious presentation, work? Well, no -- not unless the reader, already persuaded of the authors' point of view, reads in search of self-referential support. For everyone else, there are problems. One of them concerns the Kagans' use of their core analogy. The introduction, though badly written, nonetheless leads us to expect close correspondences. But in the 11 chapters on interwar Britain that follow, except for one offhand reference to a "revolution in military affairs," no analogies to the American present are suggested. These handsomely fashioned chapters stand alone as monographs, but that is precisely the problem: they are not supposed to stand alone. In the section on post-cold-war America, we do occasionally encounter a claim for a strict analogy: the end of the Persian Gulf war is like the defective Versailles Treaty; the 1994 Agreed Framework arrangement with North Korea resembles the pusillanimous conclusion to the 1923 Corfu crisis; and a few others. But then, upon reaching the concluding section of the book, the reader is told: "It has not been the purpose of this work to draw precise parallels. . . . The analogy is much broader and more fundamental than that. It is the similarities between the strategic positions of England and the United States with respect to the rest of the world and, above all, in the general pattern of self-deluding pseudoengagement that both countries pursued."
It is not clear, then, what the Kagans claim for their approach. If close correspondence is not intended, then why the eye-straining detail, taking the reader through the Chanak crisis of 1922, the Corfu affair of 1923, the approach to the Locarno peace conference in 1925 and the debilitating aftermath of that unfortunate promise to defend France and Belgium, through to the rape of Abyssinia in 1935 and the German remilitarization of the Rhineland in 1936? It is, after all, not an obscure story. But if the drawing of parallels is loose and episodic, then what justifies the conclusion that the strategic positions of Britain and the United States with respect to the rest of the world are similar, and that both are guilty of "self-deluding pseudoengagement?" Is America today "in danger of suffering a fate similar to that which befell Britain in the 1930's," as the Kagans believe?
It is true that liberal great powers are prone to sentiment and distraction when pursuing long-term strategic ends. It is also true that a mismatch between military capabilities and political commitments is a dangerous thing. And it happens to be true, as the Kagans nicely observe, that the first serious challenge to Britain after World War I and to America after the fall of the Berlin Wall arose in Iraq. But beyond that, the claims for an British-American analogy, and for fearing that America is engaged in "self-deluding pseudoengagement" -- activism without strategic purpose -- are slightly preposterous.
To take only the most obvious points, Britain vastly expanded the territory it literally had to garrison after World War I, and did so in the face of wrenching economic strictures. With the threat of nuclear war much reduced and that of a major European war eliminated, America in the 1990's had less to do, and less to do amid an economic expansion without parallel in the country's history. Moreover, Britain was an empire in the classical sense: it conquered territory and faced other empires cheek by jowl around the globe. America's imperial career is far less concrete and narrowly self-interested in character. (Why men of conservative mien like the Kagans would want to contribute to effacing this distinction is baffling.) Finally in this regard, Britain's main challenge after World War I was to deal effectively with a defeated major power, Germany. America's main challenge is to integrate other powers who wish to enter an international mainstream of which the United States is simultaneously champion and chief beneficiary.
Further, there is a dispute over how irresponsible Britain and France really were after World War I. Even the Kagans regard the two countries' confusion and timidity as having been far more significant than their military weakness -- though to accuse them of "withdrawal into isolation" seems a bit much. They also stress that it was the Great Depression that made all the difference, "that brought the most serious dangers into being" while it simultaneously "helped to undermine the leading power's will and ability to respond to those dangers." And who, at the time of Locarno, say, could have -- or should have -- predicted the Great Depression?
More to the point, however, is whether the United States has been engaged in "self-deluding pseudoengagement" these last 10 years. The Kagans think so. They regret that the United States did not take Baghdad and oust Saddam Hussein, and that it did not use decisive military force early on in the Balkans. They regret the 1994 agreement with North Korea, chalking it up to a failure of will based on too frail a military posture. They criticize the Clinton administration for a legacy of half measures in diplomacy and for an irresponsible diminution of American military clout. They cannot identify the next threat -- they can see no parallel to a Japanese invasion of Manchuria or any Hitler coming to power in some parallel to Germany -- but they are sure that the erosion of American credibility and interventionary reach will call forth such a threat in due course.
Credibility and power are important, and the world is still a dangerous place. But the Kagans seem concerned not at all about the consequences of American overextension, pretension or failure to set priorities and limits -- difficulties that have plagued great powers in history as often as timidity and weakness. The United States spends more on defense than at least the next half dozen countries in the world combined, and conducts nearly 80 percent of the world's military research and development. By most measures, American military (and economic) superiority has grown relative to others over the past decade. The United States stations troops permanently in a dozen countries overseas; its military reach is fully global. The United States dominates most relevant international institutions and is the policy-active center of global finance. This is weak pseudoengagement?
Does all this mean, then, that all is well, and that the Kagans are crying wolf? Not exactly. Their realist instincts are sound even if their analysis isn't. In a sense, they miss their own best historical point. What most threatens American security and the present relatively benign international order is not the prospect that the United States will not hold up its end of a balance of power. It is that a rogue event like the Great Depression will undermine the capabilities of American leadership, and others' confidence in it, just as it generates defections from the present normative order and multiplies challenges to it. If the American economy should go seriously into the tank after more than a decade of accelerated international economic integration, relative stability could deteriorate very fast. It could make the sorts of threats the Kagans fear seem tame by comparison. 
But who today can, or should, predict that?

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sunset Park, Brooklyn; 
Historic Character and Foreign Accents

BYLINE:  By JOYCE COHEN

 BODY:
IT took two years of looking before Nicholas and Jill Benz Malter found a house.
 The couple, who had previously rented in Windsor Terrace and Park Slope in Brooklyn, settled on a two-story brick row house in Sunset Park, arriving in late summer with their 3-year-old son, Teddy. 
 "We wanted a nice house, something sturdy, with some historic character," Mr. Malter said. "Jill and I did a lot of legwork. We either drove or walked up every block from 40th to 60th Streets and went to dinner in the neighborhood on Saturday nights." 
Sunset Park, saddled by crime and poverty in the 1980's, has been on an upward track for a dozen years. It has always been a magnet for immigrants and is now attracting home buyers priced out of other parts of the city.
"Yesterday, I stepped outside and saw a guy riding his bike, and thought, 'This guy is scoping out houses,' " Mr. Malter said. Sure enough, the bicyclist stopped to inquire about the neighborhood.
"He asked where I used to live," Mr. Malter said, "I said, 'Park Slope,' and he laughed and said, 'Me, too.' "
Mr. Malter, a former photographer who is now a firefighter, runs or bikes the three and a half miles to Ladder Company 113 in Flatbush. His wife takes the subway to freelance editorial assignments in Manhattan. Their goal was a place both livable and affordable. "You have everything you need; the shopping is good; and we are central to a lot of Brooklyn," Mr. Malter said.
"We realized we were not moving to a gentrified yuppie neighborhood with a coffee bar and a Barnes & Noble. The services are a little bit different. Sometimes when you go into stores on Fifth Avenue, you feel like you are in a foreign city. You go into a Mexican cafe, and they don't speak any English."
The housing stock in Sunset Park is uniform: Rows upon rows of attached two- and three-family homes, most built at the turn of the century. The entire area from Fourth to Seventh Avenues and 38th to 64th Streets, though not a city landmark, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Houses currently sell for $275,000 to $400,000, real-estate brokers say, with brick or frame houses on the low end, and brownstone or limestone houses on the high end. Most homes have finished basements and yards; hardly any have driveways.
PRICES surged two to three years ago but are now steadying and even sinking a bit, said Jeannette A. Fasino, a broker at E.R.A. Okelly International Realty. "In 1998, nothing was selling," she said. "In 1999, everything just jumped. A house would be $250,000 and had to go up $50,000 because we had people fighting over the house." 
Though the bidding frenzy has quieted, "as soon as we put a house on the market, somebody is putting an offer on it, even if the house is priced high," she said.
Buyers in Sunset Park "are not picky," Ms. Fasino added. "All they want is a two-family under a certain amount, and they are happy with it."
Many homes have lovely interior details, said Delvis Valdes, owner of the Clarimar Realty Corporation. "They have all the antique woodwork and moldings, working fireplaces and old bathrooms with clawfeet tubs and pedestal sinks." 
Sunset Park also has a scattering of mid rise apartment houses of eight units or more. A one-bedroom goes for around $800, Mr. Valdes said, with a nice one-bedroom in a private home costing around $1,000.
Crime peaked in the early 1980's, said Mr. Valdes, whose parents, Clara and Mario, ran Brooklyn's Clarimar Supermarket chain. "It was really rough. Gangs were prevalent. When crime went down and the economy picked up, Sunset Park started getting the benefit of Manhattan becoming too pricey. You are getting a lot of Manhattan push outs, so-called Anglos. Come the 1990's, it became a more pleasant area to work and live. It's a nice revival."
That also goes for the area's businesses. There are just a handful of vacant storefronts along the main commercial strip, Fifth Avenue, compared with dozens when the Sunset Park Fifth Avenue Business Improvement District was organized six years ago, said Renee Giordano, the executive director.
Except for a few national chains -- McDonald's, Burger King, Radio Shack, Rite-Aid -- Fifth Avenue is crammed with mom-and-pop places: restaurants, food markets, nail salons, beauty shops, hardware stores, furniture stores and clothing stores. There are plenty of five-and-dimes and even some tattoo parlors.
The Business Improvement District collects garbage, decorates for the holidays and helps to finance building renovations. Most recently, it ran a "Keep Sunset Park Clean" poster contest for local schoolchildren.
One big effort, begun three years ago, is graffiti removal. "We were one of the most graffiti-scarred communities," Mrs. Giordano said. "It was on lampposts, fire hydrants, call boxes, gates, buildings, everything. You feel really defeated when you have somebody writing on your property."
She and her husband, Tony, who have five children, have lived in Sunset Park since 1978. "Now, we have a lot of owner-occupied properties," she said. "Many block associations don't have to meet any more because there don't seem to be the problems they had. People are hard-working and really want the community to look nice."
The area's other commercial strip, Eighth Avenue, is the centerpiece of Sunset Park's Chinatown. "Eighth Avenue is up and coming," Mrs. Giordano said. "When I moved here, it was almost all abandoned." 
Chinese immigrants like Sunset Park because housing prices are lower than in Manhattan's Chinatown or in Flushing, said Vicky Tse, a broker at LCCW Realty, where about 85 percent of the clientele is Chinese. "When they come, their relatives are here and they take care of each other," she said. Chinese immigrants often work in Sunset Park or take the N train directly to Manhattan's Chinatown.
The area, settled by the Dutch, was farmland until Brooklyn's street grid was laid out in the 1830's. First, Irish immigrants streamed in, followed by Scandinavians, Poles and Italians. After World War II, there was an influx of Latinos. Since the 1980's, immigrants have primarily been Asian. There are also Arabs, Turks, Indians, Greeks and Russians.
A century ago, industry thrived at Bush Terminal, built in the 1890's by a man named Irving Bush and covering 200 waterfront acres from 32nd to 41st Streets. The 97-acre Brooklyn Army Terminal, which opened in 1919 between 58th and 63rd Streets, was one of the primary departure points for United States troops and supplies during World War II. Today, both are urban industrial parks belonging to the Southwest Brooklyn Economic Development Zone. 
Currently, the public has access to the waterfront only at the Brooklyn Army Terminal's 58th Street Pier, where the Sea Streak ferry docks. (The one-way 12-minute ride to Wall Street costs $5.)
In 1941, the Gowanus Expressway went up, roofing Third Avenue and attracting drugs and gangs. Today, it remains a "physical and psychological barrier that separates the waterfront from the upland," said Jeremy Laufer, district manager of Community Board 7, which includes Sunset Park.
"If you have no other dealing with Sunset Park, the impression you get is there are all these sex-related businesses, because, from the expressway, you have these neon signs in your face," he said. There is talk about replacing the Gowanus with a tunnel, though it is unclear when, or whether, that would happen.
Sunset Park was once considered part of Bay Ridge, but in 1969 it was given federal money for revitalization and renamed for the 25-acre park at its center.
ITS large immigrant population makes it one of the city's finest areas for ethnic restaurants and markets, said Myra Alperson, editor and publisher of a quarterly print newsletter called NoshNews.
"It's an amazingly rich place," said Ms. Alperson, who devoted an issue of NoshNews to Sunset Park. "It has tremendous personality."
She enthuses about the Mexican, Ecuadorean and Dominican restaurants on Fifth Avenue and the Asian ones along Eighth Avenue. The park itself, which Ms. Alperson termed "stunning," is on a rise, offering a lovely, faraway vista of Manhattan, as well as a closer view of the egg-shaped dome atop St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church. The park has a recreation center and an outdoor swimming pool.
Nearby is the huge and historic Green-Wood Cemetery, opened in 1840. Some real-estate agents refer to the area just east of the cemetery as Green-Wood Heights.
Most of the neighborhood children are zoned for Community School District 15, whose superintendent, Francis J. DeStefano, resigned last month amid allegations of financial mismanagement. Overcrowding and large class sizes are a problem in the district, with all of its schools "at a minimum of 125 percent utilization," said Patricia Lawrence, the district's chief executive for operations.
"The schools are on an upward line in terms of academic achievement, but still have a very poor immigrant population," Ms. Lawrence said. "We are teaching children who don't come in speaking English."
The area's three parochial schools, which teach children through Grade 8, are St. Agatha's, St. Michael's and Our Lady of Perpetual Help. Sunset Park currently has no public high school but plans have been approved to build one on Fourth Avenue between 37th and 38th streets.
The Sunset Park Public Library, expanded and renovated three years ago, is heavily used. It stocks materials in Spanish and Chinese, and it holds after-school programs for children.
In the very long term, proposals are in place that would reinvigorate the waterfront and open it to the public, said Mr. Laufer of the community board. A 40-year plan for the waterfront includes a 24-acre park in its first phase.

Mr. Zammit, a former bookbinder, lives there with his mother, Josephine, and his dog, Sandy. He was so grateful for surviving bladder cancer in 1982 that he "made a promise to God" and created a sort of shrine with decorations that he changes for each holiday. The display is filled with signs, pictures and assorted flotsam, some of it donated. It includes a nativity scene that stays up year-round, plus assorted stuffed toys -- Raggedy Ann, Tweety Bird, Bugs Bunny. Mr. Zammit, 65, said his favorite holiday display was Halloween, which takes him three weeks to set up. Everything is buttressed from behind with milk crates, chicken wire and duct tape. "People take pictures all the time," Mr. Zammit said. One Valentine's Day, "someone proposed to his girlfriend here. They used to live on the block. Now they have a son." Map of Brooklyn shows the location of Sunset Park.

HEADLINE: What's doing in Rio 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER; LARRY ROHTER is chief of the Rio bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
Rio de Janeiro is always alluring and exhilarating, but never more so than in the weeks leading up to Carnaval. As the annual bacchanal draws closer, the easygoing, relaxed rhythms of a Southern Hemisphere summer -- lying on the beach, quaffing ice-cold beer and chatting at a seafront cafe -- begin to wane and the city pulses with anticipation.
 This year Carnaval in all its excess and baroque splendor will run from Feb. 24 to 27. At weekend rehearsals that are open to the public, the 14 samba associations competing for the title of best in the city are putting the final touches on their lavish presentations. In fact, the intrepid visitor, foreigner or Brazilian, can even get fixed up with a costume and parade along Avenida Marques de Sapucai at the Sambadrome with some of the better-known "schools." 
 Though Carnaval usually gets all the publicity, the Lenten period following may be one of the best times of year to visit. The weather is still warm and the beaches inviting. But Cariocas, as the city's residents are called, have gone back to work and school, so the attractions are much less crowded than in December or January, and some hotels lower their rates accordingly. 
A decade ago, Rio had a reputation as unsafe. Things have improved markedly in recent years, thanks in part to a stepped-up police presence in tourist areas such as Copacabana and Ipanema. Nevertheless, Carnaval is a time of jostling and often-raucous crowds; people tend to lower their guard, drink a lot or go long periods without sleep, thereby offering chances galore for pickpockets and thieves. Visitors should remain as cautious as in any other large city.

Events
Tickets to the two nights of formal Carnaval parades, on Feb. 24 and 25 at the Sambadrome, are snatched up far ahead, and at this late date can be acquired only from scalpers or as part of a package tour purchased from travel agencies in Brazil or the United States. But the samba schools open their pre-Carnaval rehearsals to the public, and it is a favorite Rio pastime to visit the principal associations to gauge their chances of winning. The oldest and most traditional school is Estacao Primeira de Mangueira, which performs Saturdays at 9 p.m. at Rua Visconde de Niteroi 1072 in the Mangueira neighborhood. Tickets are $5.25, or $32 for a table for four, at 1.90 reals to the dollar. Call (55-21) 567-4637.
In addition, local samba groups called blocos participate in free smaller parades in neighborhoods ranging from Ipanema to Vila Isabel, scheduled so that they do not conflict with the samba competition. Check with a hotel concierge for details. 
A glimpse of the African influence on Brazilian culture will be on display in an exhibition of paintings by Rubem Valentin at the National Museum of Fine Arts, Avenida Rio Branco 199, from March 20 to April 24. Most of his work is concerned with the themes of religious and cultural syncreticism, such as the Afro-Brazilian religion called Candomble. The museum, which also has a wide-ranging permanent collection of Brazilian art, is open Tuesday to Friday 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. and on weekends 2 to 6 p.m.; $2.10; (55-21) 240-0068.
The chaotic manner in which Cariocas drive suggests that their favorite sport other than soccer may well be automobile racing. The real thing, in the form of the Formula Indy, can be seen, with several Brazilian drivers competing, at the Nelson Piquet Autodrome, Rua Embaixador Abelardo Bueno in Jacarepagua, on March 25. Grandstand tickets: $24 to $37, with a garage pass costing $95; information (55-11) 3819-0054.
Once Carnaval is over, Canecao, at Avenida Venceslau Bras 215 in Botafogo, next to the Rio Sul shopping mall, once again becomes the focus of the city's musical life with its mix of diverting samba, pop and rock shows. This fall, programming at Rio's premier music hall includes the reggae-samba band Cidade Negra from March 2 to 11 and Rita Lee, the godmother of Brazilian rock, March 15 to 18. But the highlight of the season promises to be the joint performances by Gilberto Gil and Milton Nascimento, two of the country's biggest stars, April 19 to 29. Tickets: $8 to $26; (55-21) 543-1241
Classical music also comes into its own at the elaborate, French-inspired Theatro Municipal, at the Praca Floriano in the downtown area known as Cinelandia, in the weeks after Carnaval. The Orquestra Sinfonica and its chorus will feature a Verdi Gala, with selections from some of the composer's best-known operas, March 16 to 18, and performances of "Simon Boccanegra," April 20 to 29; (55-21) 262-3935.

Sightseeing
The 100-foot-tall statue of Christ the Redeemer atop Corcovado (Hunchback) Mountain offers one of the most spectacular vistas of the city. The statue itself faces east, overlooking Guanabara Bay and the mountains ringing it, from a height of 2,300 feet, but the view from the pavilion is 360 degrees of sheer pleasure. Accessible by train from Rua Cosme Velho 513, from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily; $8; (55-21) 558-1329.
The Tijuca National Park, Estrada da Cascatinha 850, in Alto da Boa Vista, surrounds Corcovado and is a cool oasis in a city that regularly suffers temperatures of 100 degrees or more this time of year. Accessible from many parts of the city, it includes a tranquil tropical forest with nature trails, waterfalls, museums and restaurants. Free admission; (55-21) 492-2253.
There is no more relaxing way to spend a Sunday than strolling the Ipanema or Copacabana beach front or around the Lagoa Rodrigo de Freitas, the lagoon that separates the beach-front neighborhoods from the mountains. The three eastbound lanes of the main waterside boulevard are closed to vehicles and become the domain of skaters, courting couples, residents walking their dogs and music groups of all styles. 
Though the hundreds of squatter shantytowns perched on mountainsides above some of Rio's most exclusive neighborhoods have fascinated visitors since the movie "Black Orpheus" of 40 years ago, they have always been considered too dangerous to visit. But several companies now offer guided tours of Rocinha, the largest settlement, with the residents' cooperation. Jeep Tours' three-hour visit is $30 a person. Call (55-21) 3890-9273 or 3476-3510.

Where to Stay
Rates have zoomed in the past two years, as oil and telecommunications executives have flocked to the best hotels for dealmaking; many establishments are also abandoning the tradition of including breakfast in the rate. So it pays to shop around. With few new hotels being built, bargains are increasingly harder to find. 
The Rio Atlantica Hotel, Avenida Atlantica 2964 in Copacabana, (55-21) 548-6332, fax (55-21) 255-6410, www.rioatlantica.com.br, is one of the city's newer and more conveniently situated hotels, with 228 rooms designed in cool pastels with minimalist furniture. Doubles without a sea view from $170. 
Perched on a promontory overlooking the sea, the Sheraton Rio Hotel and Towers, Avenida Niemeyer 121, (55-21) 274-1122, fax (55-21) 239-5643, www.sheraton-rio.com, on the outskirts of Leblon, is somewhat isolated, but has the advantage of what amounts to a private beach. All 559 rooms have at least a partial ocean view; the best boast spectacular panoramas. Rates from $225. 
Budget: A traditional favorite of economy travelers is the 230-room Hotel Novo Mundo, Praia do Flamengo 20; (55-21) 557-6226, fax (55-21) 265-2369, www.hotelnovomundo-rio.com.br. Built in Art Deco style and a popular haunt of politicians back when Rio was still Brazil's capital, it is convenient to downtown and has recently been remodeled, with some rooms offering great views of Sugar Loaf Mountain and Guanabara Bay. Doubles: $75, with breakfast. 
Luxury: The Copacabana Palace Hotel, Avenida Atlantica 1702, (55-21) 548-7070, fax (55-21) 235-7330, or copacabanapalace.orient-express .com, was the obvious choice to serve as the backdrop for some of the most romantic scenes in Bruno Barreto's recent comedy "Bossa Nova." Built in ornate French style in 1925, the Copa is both a symbol of everything that is most elegant about Rio and a favorite of celebrities, with prices to match. Its 226 rooms were completely remodeled in the 1990's. Doubles without an ocean view begin at $425. 
The 221-room Caesar Park, Avenida Viera Souto 460 in Ipanema, (55-21) 525-2525, fax (55-21) 521-6000, www.caesarpark-rio.com, is convenient to shops, night life and restaurants in the trendiest neighborhood in Rio. The beach-front location is complemented by a security force that keeps an eye on guests on the beach. Doubles with a partial ocean view start at $300.

Where to Eat
Antiquarius, Rua Aristides Espinola 19 in Leblon, (55-21) 294-1049, fax (55-21) 512-5756, is a standout for traditional Portuguese cuisine -- fish and poultry with sauces that are hearty but not heavy -- in a tastefully subdued atmosphere. In fact, many food writers say it is Rio's best restaurant. The only disadvantage: just one card, Diners Club, is accepted. Dinner for two with a bottle of sparkling Portuguese wine: $125. 
At Satyricon, Rua Barao da Torre 192 in Ipanema, (55-21) 521-0627, fax (55-21) 287-7010, freshly caught fish on ice beckon at the entrance. The menu is Italian (although there is also a sushi bar), portions are generous, and service is attentive. Risottos are a specialty, as is a juicy whole fish baked in salt. Dinner for two with South American wine: $100. 
Just down the street at Rua Barao da Torre 368, (55-21) 522-3730, fax (55-21) 247-6153, is Gourmet, the restaurant of the moment. The best dishes are tropical variations on French or Italian recipes, such as a vichyssoise made from hearts of palm, coquille St. Jacques served with Thai sauces, and Amazon-fruit sorbets. The setting is agreeable, with a simple all-white decor. Dinner for two with wine: $90. 
Rio abounds in restaurants serving grilled meats in an all-you-can-eat format, with waiters continually coming to the table with choice cuts until the customer is sated. One of the best is Marius, at Avenida Atlantica 290A in Leme; telephone and fax (55-22) 542-2393. Next door, Marius Crustaceos, (55-21) 543-6363, recently opened with an interesting new twist on the concept: platter after platter of shrimp, lobster, mussels, squid, clams, sea bass and salmon, along with various cold seafood salads and hot soups. Dinner for two with Belgian beer: $60. 
Rio's "food by the kilogram" restaurants continue to be the best source of a good cheap meal, especially for those in a hurry. For lunch try Estacao, in the heart of the Ipanema shopping district at Rua Visconde de Piraja 572, (55-21) 512-3230, or Terra Brasilis, at Rua Humberto de Campos 699 in Leblon, (55-21) 274-4702, which specializes in regional cuisine and rich desserts. Meals at either place cost about $4 a pound; wine and beer available.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER; 
Peeling the Layers of History in Berlin

BYLINE:  By DAISANN McLANE 

 BODY:
MY plane landed smoothly at Tegel Airport in Berlin, but I didn't. Emerging from the gate with the other passengers, I soon found myself in the airport's main terminal. But what about immigration? I walked on, a bit nervously, eyes peeled for the official checkpoint I must have missed. Surely some security guard would notice me and steer me in the right direction before I did something illegal. 
 But no one approached. Finally, I spotted an information desk and went over to ask where I should present my passport. 
 "No problem," said the clerk. "You came in on the flight from Amsterdam? You don't need to show your passport." 
Once you enter the European Union, as I had in Amsterdam the previous week, you can travel freely among its member nations without formalities. And some part of me did know this. But I spent my early childhood watching the cold war on TV, and I had memories, grainy, in gray and white: Khrushchev, pounding his shoe on a table at the United Nations, and John F. Kennedy proclaiming, "Ich bin ein Berliner." 
The child of the cold war, arriving for the first time in one of that era's hot-button capitals, was incredulous that she could stroll into Berlin straight off the plane. The adult traveler, on the other hand, was pleased there was an airport bus at curbside, which, for about $1.85, at 2.15 marks to the dollar, transported her to the center of town, two blocks from her hotel, in only 20 minutes. 
I spent four days and nights in Berlin in early December, taking advantage of low-season air fares that got me a round trip from J.F.K. in New York with a stop in Amsterdam, for only $402. Normally, Berlin is a much more expensive ticket, because there is no direct flight from the United States (a situation that will change next month when Lufthansa inaugurates nonstops from Dulles Airport outside Washington). Like so many of Berlin's quirks, the logistical difficulty in getting there from North America is a cold war legacy. Because it was divided between the West and the Soviet bloc for more than 40 years, Berlin doesn't have a single huge airport -- instead, it has three modest-sized ones, including Tegel, the hub for most commercial flights within Western Europe. 
Four days and nights was not enough time to peel the layers of a city that I found completely absorbing, like a history book or a complex novel that one couldn't put down. Since the Berlin Wall came down more than 10 years ago, the city has undergone an enormous transformation as, reunited, it takes its place once again as Germany's capital city. And there's more to come, as evidenced by the Berlin skyline's most dramatic feature: a bumper crop of spiky steel construction cranes stretching as far as you can see. 
The usual sightseeing routine in other European capitals is to visit museums by day, then recover from art and culture overload by, perhaps, sitting in a cafe, or strolling along a charming street in some quaint quarter. While Berlin has some terrific museums, it is no museum piece. History spills into the streets here, dramatically and sometimes unsettlingly. A short walk in Berlin can take you past pompous Nazi-era buildings, or sleek modernist apartments designed by Bauhaus architects, through blocks still bullet scarred from World War II into glittery -- some would say tasteless -- steel-and-glass shopping complexes. 
There is an English-language map of the city called "Walk the Wall," on sale at most newsstands for $2, that superimposes the outline of the former Wall on contemporary Berlin, and details suggested self-guided tours. Cynically, I applauded the clever Berlin entrepreneur who'd probably made a small fortune from American tourists with this map. And then I bought one.
Map in hand, I forged through changing neighborhoods in the former East and West. My wheels spinning, I kept it up until my legs gave out. (A word of warning: Berlin is a city of sprawling neighborhoods, like London, and the walking distances between U-Bahn stops and notable sites is often 15 minutes or more.) By 7 or 8 p.m., I was usually ready to collapse. But my Berlin collapses were stylish ones, cushioned by fluffy comforters and nice cotton sheets. 
Among the city's many changes is one that's good news for the budget traveler. The boom in real estate in the former Eastern section has encouraged small, inexpensive and offbeat hotels in the $60-to-$100 range. Neither of the places I stayed in, the Sorat Art'otel or the Kunstlerheim Luise, existed in their current form five years ago. 
Both caught my interest because each is part of a novel hotel concept, flourishing in Berlin, called the art hotel. On the Internet and in guidebooks I found several listings for art hotels, so called because they feature rooms and common areas designed by local artists. The concept was handled differently in the two I was able to sample: the Sorat Art'otel used a single artist's designs in all the rooms, while each of Kunstlerheim Luise's 30 rooms is a commission from a different artist. However, in both cases I retired each evening to personality-filled chambers in which I was surrounded by (in one case, literally embedded in) original artwork. This European city is worth a visit for the art hotel experience alone. 
For symmetry's sake, I'd booked two nights at the Sorat Art'otel, just off Kurfurstendamm (Ku'damm), in the former West, and two nights at the Kunstlerheim Luise, in Mitte, in the former East. There was no particular reason for starting my stay in the West, but, looking back, I am glad I did. The neighborhood around the Sorat, Charlottenburg, was Berlin's main tourist destination before the Wall came down. The Ku'damm is a broad boulevard of wide sidewalks and pricey shops, Berlin's answer to Madison Avenue. 
Strolling up and down the familiar environment along the Ku'damm, as I did my first afternoon, was a good way to warm up and get oriented to the city. It also gave me my first opportunity to jump on the Euro-bargain bandwagon. In Amsterdam, I'd been dismayed at the lack of major-league shopping opportunities. But on the Ku'damm, the designer boutiques all had big signs saying "Reduziert." In an hour, I'd managed to find a new down coat from the Italian designer Max Mara -- the first such garment that didn't turn me into a ringer for the Michelin Man. Originally $600, with "reduziert" by 40 percent, and a refund on the V.A.T. tax, which ended up being about 10 percent, it was $300. 
Returning to the hotel along Ku'damm, I passed a window filled with gingerbread, strings of twinkling lights and a jaw-dropping spread of cakes, candies and cookies. Walking into this gingerbread house, I made a dangerous discovery -- Leysieffer Confections sells the most delectable butter cookies imaginable, at $4.60 a bag. (Worse news, at least for those who are trying to avoid the Michelin Man look: Leysieffer's has branches throughout Berlin.) 
Back at the Sorat, which reminded me a lot of the Paramount Hotel in New York, I munched cookies and took stock of my art room. Small, with twin beds and a sleek, modernist bathroom, it radiated a tasteful Philippe Starck-inspired sensibility of geometric shapes and soft shades. In the bright white-tiled bathroom -- shower, no tub -- was the steel cone-shaped sink that is becoming the ubiquitous signifier of the postmodern. Considering the size of the room, I wondered if the Sorat was really a good value at $107 for a single. The next morning over my (free) breakfast in a huge, sunny dining room, spread with a lavish buffet of meats, smoked fish, salads, cheeses, eggs, breads and pastries, I decided it definitely was. 
Having a big breakfast in the hotel turned out to be a good thing, since sightseeing became so absorbing that I tended, like some absent-minded professor, to forget about eating. Climbing up the spiral ramp in the spectacular new Reichstagskuppel, Sir Norman Foster's gleaming glass-and-steel addition to the top of Germany's capitol building, I became entranced watching the amazing view of the city, and the reflection of my fellow sightseers in the surfaces of the structure's centerpiece, a funnel made of broken mirrors. I stopped in the dome's pleasant rooftop cafe for coffee and apple cake. Returning to the ground floor, I was amazed that I'd spent nearly three hours in the dome, symbol of the new Berlin. 
I spent nearly as much time in another new architectural landmark, equally stunning: Daniel Libeskind's Jewish Museum. The museum's exhibits, which will chronicle the history of German Jews from the Middle Ages to the present, will not go on display until September; however, more than 340,000 visitors toured the empty building in the past two years. (Earlier this month, the museum was closed to the public until September.) Fashioned to resemble a shattered Star of David, it is designed to provide a symbolic experience of German Jewish history. 
I walked, disoriented, through corridors that turned at unexpected, irregular angles, then climbed a steep, ever-narrowing staircase that rose as if to heaven (according to a short documentary film I viewed in the museum, it symbolizes Jacob's ladder). Passing through a garden of white pillars, each one topped by an olive tree, I lost my footing on the pebbled ground. Laughing, the guard informed me that was the point -- the base of the garden is tilted at about 13 degrees. The off-balance feeling is designed to evoke the emotions of the German Jews who fled before World War II, and found themselves adapting to foreign countries and cultures. 
The last room was the most evocative. With the help of the guard, I pulled open a heavy door and entered a dark chamber. As my eyes began to adjust to the dimness, the door slammed shut with a loud thunk behind me. For an instant, surrounded by blackness, I felt a cold panic -- exactly as the architect had intended. 
THE Museum Haus am Checkpoint Charlie offered insight into another Berlin era, albeit in a more conventional setting. Situated directly above the infamous passage point between East and West Berlin, the private museum holds a collection of ephemera, and documentation of the hundreds of escape attempts and escapes made during the 30 years of the Wall -- everything from hot-air balloons to hand-dug tunnels to specially fitted Volkswagens that could hold "passengers" in a hidden compartment behind the engine. Leaving the museum, I walked freely back and forth past the "checkpoint," just to shake off the feeling of confinement and claustrophobia. 
An even better remedy for bad Wall flashbacks is a stroll through the gallery district of Mitte, ground zero of Berlin's art and fashion scene. If the Ku'damm is Madison Avenue, Mitte is SoHo, circa 1979, chockablock with young artists and designers and those who follow them like heat-seeking missiles. Dozens of small private galleries (mainly showcasing contemporary artists and photographers) line the narrow streets behind the Hackescher Markt -- Sophienstrasse, Auguststrasse and Oranienberger Strasse.
As in SoHo, the galleries have attracted the fashionistas, and there are almost as many boutiques as galleries now. I enjoyed poking through both -- savoring an exhibit of vintage Berlin photographs, then popping in to look at funny felt jackets and foot-tall egg cozies shaped like witches' hats at the shop Hut Up. In these corners of the avant-hip, Berlin's recent past fades away -- almost. (It surfaces again when you notice that many of the shops and galleries are run as collectives, or pop into a Chinese cafe for a plate of fried rice on the run and discover that your host came to Berlin as an exchange student from Laos.) 
Staying at Kunstlerheim Luise, as it turned out, was an excellent way to get into the Mitte spirit (and, at $69 a night for a room without private bath, an economical one). When I arrived in my room, my initial reaction was to laugh out loud for five minutes. I had been assigned the Hundezimmer, or Dog Room. It was papered on one wall with a design from Disney's "101 Dalmatians" and decorated on another with plastic dog dishes, which unexpectedly created a late-60's Pop Art atmosphere. I noted that the bedside table had been fashioned from a stack of large dog-food cans topped with glass, and that the pillows on the queen-sized bed had been puffed to look like pointed ears. 
What I did not notice, until I awoke on my last Berlin morning, was that the bed itself was a giant wicker dog basket. The clever artist behind this room (identified only as Odin) had transformed me into the "hund" of this "zimmer." 
Yawning in my basket, I thought about how to spend my last few hours in Berlin. Easy decision. The Tiergarten, Berlin's Central Park, was a short U-Bahn ride away. I rolled over, jumped up and took myself out for a walk. 

Stops on a walking tour
I spent an average of $118 a day for accommodation in stylish hotels, lots of museum hopping, food and local transportation, with an exchange rate of 2.15 marks to the dollar. 

Hotels
At the Sorat Art'otel, Joachimstaler Strasse 29, (49-30) 884470, fax (49-30) 88447700, www.sorat-hotels
.com/artotel-berlin, my sleek little room had twin beds, each with a padded gray-green headboard, TV, phone and sparkling bathroom with a shower. The room, which I booked on the hotel's Web site, cost $107 a night (singles now start at $123); the price included a sumptuous breakfast buffet served in the downstairs dining room.
At the Hotel Kunstlerheim Luise, Luisenstrasse 19, (49-30) 284480, fax (49-30) 2844 8448, on the Web, www.kuenstlerheim-luise.de, each of the hotel's 30 rooms is an installation, commissioned to a single artist. My room, the Hundezimmer, or Dog Room, cost $69 a night; the spotless dorm-style bath with shower stalls, sinks and toilets was down the hall. The price included a cold Continental breakfast of croissants, cereal and coffee. One drawback: the hotel is right next to the S-Bahn (overhead train) line, and some of the rooms can be noisy. 

Restaurants
Trying to pack as many of Berlin's sights into four days as possible, I didn't spend much time planning when or where to eat -- and in Berlin, you have to plan, since restaurants seem to fill up by 6 p.m. and stay that way until closing. I tended to pop into any place that looked halfway good and that was open and handy when I got hungry. 
Mahachai Thai, Schluterstrasse 60, (49-30) 313 0879, tucked near the S-Bahn stop Savignyplatz, was a lucky find -- a serenely decorated Thai restaurant with fresh, authentically spiced dishes. I had an excellent chicken curry, with rice, beer, Thai salad and shrimp chips, for $23. 
Oxymoron, Rosenthaler Strasse 40-41, (49-30) 2839 1886, turns into a disco at 5 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday and at 11 p.m. Friday and Saturday; I didn't know that, nor would I have guessed it from the look of the place, which reminded me of a casual SoHo bistro. The early supper menu was a good value. I had a plate of garlic-sauced linguine and a glass of pinot grigio, for $9.25.
At Kafer im Reichstag, Platz der Republik 1, (49-30) 2262 9933, the restaurant adjacent to the new dome in the Reichstag, coffee and apple cake came to $5. 
Leysieffer's, Kurfurstendamm 218, (49-30) 885 7480, also on Friedrichstrasse around the corner from Galeries Lafayette, sells exquisite cookies. 

Museums
The Museum Haus am Checkpoint Charlie is at Friedrichstrasse 43-45; (49-30) 253 7250; museum-haus-am
.checkpointcharlie.org. Open 9 a.m. to 10 p.m. daily; admission $5.60.
Though the Jewish Museum, at Lindenstrasse 9-14, (49-30) 2839 7444, www.jmberlin.de, is not yet open, it will be a must-see when the collections are installed in September. 
The Reichstagskuppel (Dome of the Reichstag), Platz der Republik 1, (49-30) 227 0, is free and open daily from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. 
The Brohan Museum, Schlossstrasse 1A, (49-30) 32690600, www.broehan-museum.de, is a little jewel of a place, filled with extraordinarily beautiful examples of German, French and Dutch Art Deco objects and furniture. Open 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Closed Mondays; $3.70. 

Transportation
From Tegel airport, I caught a bus to Berlin Zoo, near the Sorat Art'otel and Ku'damm, for about $1.85. 
The Berlin transit network (www.bfg.de) is very user-friendly. I found it easiest to buy a day pass, or Tageskarte. The card is good for all U-Bahn, S-Bahn and bus rides within the city center, and costs $4 a day. 
Returning, I took a taxi from the Kunstlerheim Luise hotel to the airport; the fare was $12. 
 DAISANN MCLANE

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 1302 words

HEADLINE: FILM; 
The Rare Producer Honored for His Art

BYLINE:  By DAVID THOMSON; David Thomson is the author of "A Biographical Dictionary of Film."

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
IT'S very interesting," says the filmmaker James Toback. "I have known Ed Pressman since school. We were at Ethical Culture and Fieldston together. We grew up in the same building, the Majestic, on Central Park West. He's like my oldest friend. He's always been there. And now he's become really very important and very powerful. And I don't see any change. As a kid he always had the best toys, and he'd share them. And now he's involved on maybe half -- or more -- of the best films. But it's still Ed -- quiet, shy, bookish Ed -- trying to help and please the wilder kids, the ones who try to make movies."
 Mr. Toback ("Black and White") isn't far from those wilder guys, but the director Abel Ferrara, who even sounds as if he staggered, wounded, from one of his bloodiest scenes, may even be closer. "His legacy," he says of Mr. Pressman, struggling to describe this renowned producer, "the strangest films -- all leading back to him. He's very up front. He's there for us to be what we can be. Yeah, that's it. And behind closed doors, he has his moments. Don't let appearances fool you." 
 I have to admit that finding a serious appreciation of a producer in the American press is not a common experience. The impresarios of theater, the museum world, or opera and popular music have their place. But in film the producer is almost invariably cast as the heavy in the story of art versus commerce -- whereas any number of encounters in Hollywood will confirm that there are few people as money-minded as some of our directors, and that few are as devoted to making good, different pictures as Edward R. Pressman. As a measure of that, on Friday, the Brooklyn Academy of Music will begin a 25-film retrospective of the career of this man who is still only 57.
Ed Pressman has his name on, among other films, Terrence Malick's "Badlands." I could stop there, because if you directed or produced "Badlands," you are home. But the list goes on: "Sisters" and "Phantom of the Paradise" (both by Brian De Palma); "Despair" (by Rainer Werner Fassbinder, from Nabokov, with Dirk Bogarde); "The Hand" (Oliver Stone's debut); "True Stories" (David Byrne); "Good Morning, Babylon" (the Taviani brothers); "Blue Steel" (Kathryn Bigelow); "To Sleep with Anger" (Charles Burnett); "Reversal of Fortune" (Barbet Schroeder's von Bulow story); "Bad Lieutenant" (Mr. Ferrara); "Hoffa"; "City Hall"; "Two Girls and a Guy"; "Plenty"; "Wall Street"; "American Psycho."
Not that every one those films has to be your favorite, or one you'd want to see again. But think of them as they must have begun -- fever dreams in the minds of their makers. Consider how far-fetched, how outrageous or disgusting they seemed. And then ask yourself what the tradition of independent film in America would mean without most of them. And if you point out to Mr. Pressman that people like Mr. Ferrara and Mr. Toback, or Mr. Stone and Mr. De Palma, are larger than life, hard to control, tricky in a deal sometimes, dangerously unpredictable and hardly the sort of people you might think of offering to a band of sober investors, he grins, and says, "Well, I've always been drawn to vivacious people."
He was the son of Jack Pressman, who started a toy company in the 1940's, cornered the marble business and made America crazy for Chinese Checkers. Ed, the oldest son, was supposed to take over -- Jack died when Ed was 16 -- but somehow, with his mother, Lynn Rambach, running the business, Ed went away, to Stanford University and the London School of Economics, so that he ended up asking his kid brother, Jimmy, to run the company. Ed would take some money out of the toys and branch out.
A turning point came at the Fieldston School, in the Bronx, where he'd had a teacher who taught modern history using Siegfried Kracauer's "From Caligari to Hitler" and showed pictures like "M" and "The Blue Angel." Suddenly, horizons defined by Edward G. Robinson and George Raft lifted. A few years later, Mr. Pressman was a devotee of the French New Wave -- the age when the rules about how to make a film began to seem fatuous or suspicious. When he went to England, he met Paul Williams, a young American with wild ideas. "To me," Mr. Pressman says, "he was Orson Welles, and I'd be Louis B. Mayer -- and that's how we did "Out of It" and "The Revolutionary,' " with Mr. Williams directing and Mr. Pressman producing.
This is not a common fantasy. Mr. Mayer is one of the more odious villains in film history, while Welles was a genius, a bon viveur, one of the greatest storytellers and tragic heroes ever made. So many kids grow up wanting to be Welles -- or just behaving like him. Mr. Pressman recognizes his own perverse streak. He thinks it was due in part to his love of business, that family influence. But it also came out of his objective, philosophical stance. From early on, he liked to observe the differences in people and how they might be helped to fit together. But there was also some profound shyness, some feeling that he was not attractive or spectacular enough to be a famous leader (though Mr. Toback recalls that in school Mr. Pressman was a brilliant quarterback). It was more something he felt about himself than what others noticed. And to this day he has never wanted to be a director himself -- no matter that he's seen directors make mistakes that he could have avoided.
"With Paul, at the beginning, I totally loved getting behind his vision," he says. Mr. Pressman's wife, Annie, an actress, adds this: "Eddie once said, 'You have to be a very quick thinker to be a director.' And he likes to take his time. He could have been a professor. But once he makes up his mind -- the perseverance!"
SOME projects take 10 years before the script is right, or the several small pieces of money fall into place. And Mr. Pressman is not wild with money ("He's ingeniously tight," says one agent), even if he has gone beyond family loans to lines of credit with banks. Over the years, he has had big hits, "Conan the Barbarian" and "The Crow," though many predicted disaster for both. He has had great moments, as when "Badlands" delighted the 1973 New York Film Festival. But there was a preview screening of "Paris by Night" (1988) in Seattle when he and its director, David Hare, had to reckon that the film was doomed.
He is bright-eyed about the future -- these are the prize marbles he shows you: Tamara Jenkins is working on a biopic of Diane Arbus. There is another chapter in the Crow saga to come, with the hip-hop artist DMX in the lead. He has the rights to the David Begelman story, with a very good script by Michael Thomas; Nick Broomfield, the provocative English documentarian, is lined up to direct. And he has fun thinking about the roller-coaster career of an establishment figure like Begelman, the onetime producer and major studio executive who went from check forging and ignominy to resurrection and then suicide.
There is also a film about gambling, from the book "No Limits," to be directed by Richard Kwietniowski, who made "Love and Death on Long Island." And there is Mr. Toback's next film, "Harvard Man," as well as the chance of Sean Penn and Nick Nolte doing "The Monkey Wrench Gang" from Edward Abbey's novel about terrorists acting to protect the environment.
Not every one of those dreams is guaranteed. But securely based in New York and Los Angeles, with Annie and their 13-year-old son, Sam, Ed Pressman shows no sign of relaxing. He's also invested in the future of digital film and is continuing to push the limits of bad taste (as in "Bad Lieutenant" and "American Psycho"). Most of all, he sees a kind of business flux ahead in which only producers -- independent, courageous but experienced -- are likely to guard movies against the drab, merchandising hand of intergalactic conglomerates.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Gathered Vestiges of a Covered-Wagon Diaspora

BYLINE:  By JOSHUA BROCKMAN; Joshua Brockman is freelance writer who until recently lived in Santa Fe, N.M.

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M. 

 BODY:
ALMOST everyone is familiar with the entrance of Jews to America through Ellis Island, but few people have heard of a smaller but nevertheless important Jewish migration westward to New Mexico by wagon train along the Santa Fe Trail. Their number was not great -- by 1917, fewer than 1,000 called New Mexico home -- but these Jews helped shape the economy, culture and political landscape of the region.
 Today, their story is being told through the art, memorabilia and family histories of the Ambergs, Bibos, Floersheims, Herzsteins, Ilfelds, Spiegelbergs, Uhlfelders and Zeckendorfs, among others, in a rich display of pioneer life at the Palace of the Governors of the Museum of New Mexico. The exhibition, "Jewish Pioneers of New Mexico," opened in October and will remain at the museum for five years. 
 The first to settle in New Mexico were Ashkenazic immigrants from German principalities. They moved west from the East Coast beginning in the 1840's, caught up in the sentiment of Manifest Destiny to populate the vast western territories. Putting down roots in this arid and mountainous landscape, where Spanish and American Indian dialects were spoken and justice was often carried out through gun fights or public hangings, was no easy task, particularly for foreigners. Yet these Jews moved into isolated areas, lived among the Indians, established community institutions and formed synagogues where none existed. 
The travails of life in the West paled in comparison to the persecution and second-class citizenship these Jews would have continued to face had they remained in Europe. And, unlike much of the eastern United States, the West remained full of opportunities for entrepreneurs and was largely free of anti-Semitism and religious divisiveness, mainly because Anglos there needed one another to survive.
The exhibit, the museum's first examination of the New Mexico Jewish diaspora, spans the years from 1821, when the Santa Fe Trail opened, providing a trade route from the East, through 1917, when the flow of immigration was slowed by the United States' entrance into World War I. The show looks at the contributions made by Jewish merchants, bankers, miners, ranchers, soldiers, sutlers and traders throughout the region.
It is organized along four themes: immigration, occupations, social and family life, and religion. Elegantly displayed using panels of scanned photographs and documents alongside artifacts, the exhibit is largely based on loans and donations from families in New Mexico (an estimated 15,000 Jews live here today) and descendants of Jewish pioneers now scattered across the nation.
The flow of heirlooms has continued even after the opening, said Thomas E. Chavez, director of the museum. Among them are a number of steamer trunks, one of which traveled by boat over the Atlantic and then by wagon train over the Santa Fe Trail.
"I look at a trunk and I imagine where it's been and the people packing it," Mr. Chavez said. "Those trips seem even a little bit risky today."
The show's curator, David H. Snow, schooled as an archaeologist and anthropologist, said preparing the exhibit had felt like an excavation. "I might just as well be out there with a trowel again, digging up roots," he said.
Jewish pioneers were mostly young single men like Solomon Jacob Spiegelberg, who left Westphalia as a teenager in search of a better life. Spiegelberg settled in Santa Fe in 1846. He was the first German Jewish merchant to live in this Western outpost along the Santa Fe Trail, where he established the Spiegelberg mercantile business and became sutler to Fort Marcy, keeping it supplied with provisions.
Like other young Jewish entrepreneurs who came West, he was also an ambassador for the region, persuading his family in Germany to join him. One by one, six Spiegelberg brothers immigrated to New Mexico between 1844 and 1861 as part of a first wave of Jewish immigrants to the territory. Once here, their first goal was to find a place in Southwestern society rather than create a religious and ethnic niche for themselves.
The idea for the exhibit came from Spiegelberg descendants -- Susan and Felix Warburg, guest curators and principal donors -- after a Spiegelberg family reunion in Santa Fe in 1988. Mr. Warburg's family donated their Fifth Avenue mansion in New York City to the Jewish Theological Seminary in 1944 to house the Jewish Museum. Mrs. Warburg is the great-granddaughter of the Jewish pioneers Wolf (Willi) and Flora Spiegelberg. Willi, the youngest brother of Solomon, learned to speak Spanish, English and four Indian dialects and ultimately became the probate judge, or mayor, of Santa Fe County in 1884. 
"They wanted to create a new world and they had to reinvent themselves," Mrs. Warburg said of her pioneer ancestors. "They were highly respected because of their ability to adapt."
Religion and culture also traveled over the dusty trails. The museum display includes a 200-year-old Torah used by the first synagogue in New Mexico, an 1870 piano and the Uhlfelder family Bible printed in 1786 with Hebrew, German and Latin texts. Handwritten notations listing birth dates of family members inside the Bible provide something of a genealogical road map. 
Many of the first Jews who immigrated were cousins. In many cases they became further connected in New Mexico through marriage. By 1860, half of the Jewish population in the territory was related, the museum says. But there was also intermarriage with the local Hispanic and Indian populations.
Of all the members of the Bibo clan -- children of a cantor in Brakel, Westphalia -- who immigrated to New Mexico, Solomon Bibo immersed himself the most in American Indian life through marriage and his involvement in tribal government. In 1885, after establishing a trading relationship with Acoma Pueblo and learning its language, Keres, he married Juana Valle, the granddaughter of the tribe's governor. In the late 1880's Bibo was chosen as governor of Acoma Pueblo, a title he held again in later years.
Before 1870, there were no banks in New Mexico, so merchant families functioned as financial institutions by holding deposits, extending credit and even mortgages. The role of Jewish merchants as bankers is documented by a fine example of scrip issued in 1863 by Spiegelberg Hermanos, the Spiegelberg Brothers.
Ushering in a new era, the railroad arrived in Las Vegas, N.M., in 1879 and in Albuquerque in 1880. New cities emerged including Clayton, Deming and Tucumcari. East Las Vegas and New Albuquerque also sprouted up, mirroring the adjacent established towns. In response, Jews relocated to seize opportunities. By 1880, half of the original Jewish pioneers had left New Mexico, but a Jewish population of about 200 grew during the next two decades, bolstered by a second wave of Jewish immigrants who arrived with the railroad. Most businesses became more specialized because goods could be carried swiftly and in greater quantities to distant locations.
Meanwhile, Charles Ilfeld and his family presided over the expansion of what would become the state's largest mercantile business. Their company grew from its original retail location in Las Vegas to wholesale branches throughout New Mexico. The Ilfelds established themselves as a precursor to Wal-Mart with their slogan, still painted on the side of the Ilfeld building on the plaza in Las Vegas: "Charles Ilfeld Company Wholesalers of Everything."
Despite the civilizing effect of the railroad, which began to transform New Mexico from a frontier into a marketplace, Jews were not immune from the lawlessness that was part and parcel of Western society. Levi Herzstein discovered this when he came face to face with one of the West's most notorious gangs -- the "Black Jack" Ketchum gang. In 1896 the Herzstein store and post office was held up by these outlaws. Levi, who was summoned to Liberty in the early 1890's to help run the family store by his older brother Morris, pursued the gang and was killed in a shoot-out.
The Herzstein business later moved to Clayton and ultimately into the Texas panhandle. This expansion is captured by the inscription on a shoe brush: "Herzstein's Clayton, New Mexico -- Dalhart, Texas. If it's from Herzstein's it's correct."
"There was kind of a Jewish telegraph through the Southwest, and my grandmother and the family knew all of the Jews in Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona and western Texas," said Mortimer H. Herzstein, 74, who was born in Trinidad, Colo., and is a descendant of two Jewish pioneer families.
"Jewish Pioneers" presents a balanced picture of Jewish life, blemishes and all. A prison portrait from 1901 shows Jake Gold, who by 1882 established Gold's Old Curio Shop, one of the first stores to sell American Indian crafts, with a number pinned on his suit: he served time in the New Mexico Territorial prison for abandoning his wife.
Before synagogues, Jews maintained civic affiliations through membership in the Order of Masons, the Independent Order of Odd Fellows and the Germania Club and as founders of the Historical Society of New Mexico.
As Reform Jews, these pioneers were initially satisfied with private expressions of their faith. The first synagogue, Temple Montefiore, in Las Vegas, was founded in 1884, well after the first pioneers arrived. The first Jewish cemetery followed in 1888. A synagogue did not exist in Santa Fe until 1953.
Although the exhibit focuses predominantly on men, one woman who stands out is Yetta Kohn. She came across the Santa Fe Trail in the mid-1860's and became the matriarch of a ranching dynasty, known today as the T-4 Cattle Company, in Montoya. The family has operated the business since 1902.
Despite their small numbers, Jewish pioneers and their descendants rose to prominence in New Mexico territory and after it became a state in 1912. Towns and railroad sidings were also named for Jewish pioneers, although these names have largely vanished from maps.
In assembling the shards of Jewish life, "Jewish Pioneers" reveals an enduring legacy of Jews in New Mexico and their successful efforts to blend into the landscape and culture. 
"They made every effort to fit in, and that applies not only economically but politically," said the historian Henry J. Tobias, author of "A History of the Jews in New Mexico." "It's part of the heritage they left. In some ways you might think of them as part of the glue that held society out here together."

GRAPHIC: Photos: William Ilfeld's powder flask, 1870, and the interior of Gold's Old Curio Shop in Santa Fe, N.M., in the 1880's. (Museum of New Mexico); (Royal Hubbell/Museum of New Mexico)(pg. 37); Dancers and chorus at Acoma Pueblo, 1883. Solomon Bibo, a Jewish pioneer to New Mexico, is standing beside the drummer. (Ben Wittick/Museum of New Mexico)(pg. 41)

ORGANIZATION: MUSEUM OF NEW MEXICO 

PERSON: BROCKMAN, JOSHUA 

GEOGRAPHIC: SANTA FE, NM, USA (95%) NEW MEXICO, USA (99%) UNITED STATES (99%); GERMANY (79%); EUROPE (79%) NEW MEXICO
