HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
There's a Method to This 'Choral Miracle'

BYLINE:  By CORI ELLISON; Cori Ellison is the dramaturg at the New York City Opera.

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM 

 BODY:
AN icy December wind chills Sweden's temporarily sunless capital. But inside the torchlit portals of Berwaldhallen, a 1979 concert hall carved into a granite hillside in Stockholm's green Djurgarden district, the 34 members of the Swedish Radio Choir are working up a sweat. They bray incantations from "Curse Upon Iron" by the Estonian composer Veljo Tormis: "You flesh eater, gnawer of bones, spiller of innocent blood!" Tonu Kaljuste, their departing music director, jerks about, smacking a tambourine against his flank like a mad shaman. Is this any way for good Lutherans to behave?
 Forgive them: they're celebrating the 75th anniversary of their elite squad. Their hearty encore piece capped a gala program including a gospel-style "Hallelujah," folksy numbers by the native sons Alfven and Stenhammar, blockbusters by Schubert and Poulenc, and premieres of specially commissioned works by Sven-David Sandstrom and Esa-Pekka Salonen. It's all in a day's work for this incarnation of the "Swedish choral miracle." 
 The Swedish Radio Choir will continue its jubilee celebration in New York. On Friday, it will team up with the Eric Ericson Chamber Choir, conducted by its namesake, for a program of 20th-century a cappella works presented by Lincoln Center's Great Performers series at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. And next Sunday the two choirs will join the Swedish Radio Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall for a performance of the Verdi Requiem, led by the orchestra's vibrant new Austrian maestro, Manfred Honeck.
On close scrutiny, the Swedish choral miracle turns out to be less mysterious than methodical. In the last century, Sweden has produced a prodigious quantity of first-rate choral music and the stellar choirs to perform it, an achievement that has much to do with hospitable soil: a small, largely homogeneous population of 9 million, one-sixth of which is clustered around Stockholm; periodic upsurges of nationalism, expressed notably in choral singing; the legendary Swedish team mentality; and what Mr. Sandstrom, since 1999 a professor of composition at Indiana University in Bloomington, calls "the melody of the Swedish language."
It also has to do with fertile seeds, embodied in a group of gifted, zealous individuals whose rise to leadership positions in Sweden's musical life transformed the nation's musical tastes and standards. In 1944, the Monday Group, a gaggle of young Stockholm Conservatory students fed up with the National Romanticism of Alfven and Stenhammar, began studying privately with the modernist Hilding Rosenberg and meeting to discuss and study the music of Bartok, Hindemith, Schoenberg, Stravinsky and others.
The group comprised two instrumentalists, three musicologists, five composers and a choral conductor, Mr. Ericson. In 1945, Mr. Ericson enlisted 16 conservatory friends to sing through Renaissance madrigals and motets, music they had read about but never heard. Though their plans had not included performing, they ended up presenting a meticulously prepared program, billing themselves as the Stockholm Chamber Choir (later, the Ericson Chamber Choir). Once they had developed a blooming sound and technical proficiency, they proceeded to tackle the heady works of Brahms, Reger and the Swedish Romantics, eventually moving on to Bartok, Martin, Milhaud, Schoenberg and Stravinsky.
Mr. Ericson insists that it is a choir's repertory that shapes its technique and sound. "The pieces we did early on that seemed difficult tonally and rhythmically became less and less so," he said over coffee in a Stockholm hotel. "Certain pieces were like rungs on a ladder, pieces by Lidholm, Stravinsky, Nono and Dallapiccola, perhaps most of all. This is how we really learned to read notes and rhythms. When you come out on the other side of such pieces, you're a better musician, a better singer, maybe even a better person."
By the 1950's, Mr. Ericson's efforts had spawned a new breed in Sweden: the professional choir, musically confident and vocally secure. Swedish composers were inspired to write for this unique, flexible instrument, ready and able to brave new choral techniques and harmonic languages. The ensuing flood of commissions and premieres yielded, to Mr. Ericson's mind, 10 or 15 true classics, including several works by Ingvar Lidholm and Mr. Sandstrom.
Swedish composers so eagerly embraced choral music because most of them were enthusiastic choral singers themselves. Lars Edlund, Eskil Hemberg, Thomas Jennefelt and Lars Johan Werle all sang in Mr. Ericson's choirs, and Mr. Sandstrom was a tenor in the Hagersten Motet Choir for two decades.
But there has been no closer connection between conductor and composer than the fruitful alliance of Mr. Ericson and Mr. Lidholm, another member of the Monday Group. Mr. Lidholm's "Laudi," evoking both Palestrina and Stravinsky, was given its premiere in 1947 by Mr. Ericson's choir. The first masterwork of modern Swedish choral music, it is one of many repertory staples by Mr. Lidholm. His heavily chromatic, chant-infused "Libera Me" will highlight the choirs' program on Friday.
In 1952, Mr. Ericson was recruited by the Swedish Broadcasting Company to revamp its Swedish Radio Choir. The choir and its sister orchestra were spinoffs of the post-World War II orchestras and choruses established in Western Europe to bolster the cultural programming of national broadcasting corporations. Blessed with far-reaching airwaves, luxurious rehearsal periods, a mandate to nurture native and contemporary music and ample subsidies from the arts-friendly Social Democratic government, the radio orchestra and choir would revolutionize Swedish music.
One of Mr. Ericson's first official acts was to insist that at least 75 percent of the radio choir's repertory be a cappella. "A cappella singing is the only way to establish high choral standards of intonation, balance and listening," the 82-year-old maestro said.
Led by executives devoted to contemporary music (including Mr. Lidholm, who was director of chamber music from 1956 to 1965), the Swedish Radio afforded significant opportunities to musicians hungry to catch up with international musical developments after their World War II isolation. Mr. Ericson enjoyed exhilarating associations with Luigi Nono, Karlheinz Stockhausen, John Cage, Terry Riley, Witold Lutoslawski, Krzysztof Penderecki, Mauricio Kagel, Morton Feldman and Pauline Oliveros, all of whom visited Stockholm to conduct or discuss their works.
BEGINNING in 1959, Gyorgy Ligeti regularly visited Stockholm. His Requiem, commissioned by the Swedish Radio, was given its premiere by the choir and orchestra in 1964, and his 16-part "Lux Aeterna," which the choirs will sing on Friday, inspired a wealth of large-scale "symphonic" choral pieces. His signature tone clusters and micropolyphony began to crop up in Swedish choral music of the 1970's.
In the 1960's, the Ericson Chamber Choir began a collaboration with Nikolaus Harnoncourt and his period-instrument ensemble, Concentus Musicus Wien, which resulted in recordings of Monteverdi's Vespers, Purcell's "Fairy Queen" and Handel's "Jephtha" and "Belshazzar." Mr. Ericson's growing reputation in Europe led, in 1971, to a major project for EMI: a four-LP album, "European Choral Music of Five Centuries," featuring the radio choir and the Ericson Chamber Choir.
The groups, combined as an oratorio choir, became much in demand. During the 1980's, they began a series of collaborations with the Berlin Philharmonic, resulting in recordings of Mozart's Requiem with Riccardo Muti, Haydn's "Creation" and Beethoven's "Missa Solemnis" with James Levine, and Brahms's "German Requiem" with Claudio Abbado.
Mr. Ericson loves to tell how Mr. Muti once panicked to hear that his Verdi Requiem choir would comprise a mere 66 souls. "I told him, 'Trust me,' " Mr. Ericson said. "You should have seen his face when our choir sounded loud and clear over the Berlin Philharmonic's brass."
By the time of Mr. Ericson's mandatory retirement from his radio choir post (a civil service job) in 1983, the ensemble had established a seven-concert subscription series, four or five annual collaborations with the radio orchestra and about one commission per season. Though their hours have increased to half-time and their wages have steadily improved, the choristers, who supplement their incomes with church and teaching jobs, still aspire to parity with the orchestra.
Yet there is little turnover, with only two or three new choristers joining the ranks annually. Those chosen few must pass rigorous auditions, singing rangy, tricky choral parts, chromatic and whole-step scales and crescendo and memory exercises. Once accepted, the choristers must reaudition every three years (and after the age of 50, annually).
Mr. Ericson has hardly been idle since leaving the radio choir. Until 1990, he continued teaching choral conducting at the Stockholm Conservatory, where he trained virtually all of Sweden's choral conductors for four decades. He also went on leading a men's choir, Orphei Drangar, in Uppsala until 1991. He has taught master classes worldwide and conducted choirs including the BBC Singers, the Vienna State Opera Chorus, the Netherlands Chamber Choir and the Groupe Vocale de France. He also continues to conduct the Ericson Chamber Choir.
The radio choir has since been directed by the Baroque specialist Anders Ohrwall; Gustaf Sjokvist, an Ericson protege; and Mr. Kaljuste, an Estonian and the first non-Swedish leader. In 2002, the Swede Stefan Parkman, the principal conductor of the Danish Radio Choir and another Ericson associate, will take charge.
Mr. Ericson has so dominated Swedish choral life for so long that the waning of his career seems to cause an unspoken malaise. Yet his legacy is so tangible -- in Sweden's vital choral repertory; in its "pyramid" of more than half a million regular choral singers, from beginners to virtuosos; in its army of impeccably trained conductors -- that there seems little cause for worry.
Still, Sweden's recent economic slowdown, high unemployment rate and shift away from the welfare-state model make its arts organizations understandably nervous. A full 70 percent of the radio orchestra and choir's $10 million budget is direct government subsidy.
Perhaps Mr. Ericson's greatest but least tangible legacy is the legendary Scandinavian choral sound. It's a sinewy, lean sonority, less expansive than that of a Slavic, German or Italianate choir. For the rest, one can only itemize the qualities of great choirs the world over: purity of tone and pitch, an impeccable unison, perfectly blended partials, rhythmic precision, unanimity of diction, stylistic versatility and finely modulated dynamics, from diaphanous piano to bracing forte.
The definition of the elusive "Scandinavian sound" was one topic addressed at an informal symposium before the radio choir's jubilee concert. Mr. Lidholm defined it as "an absolutely even, equalized sound, in which every singer consents to relinquish his or her own personality in favor of the choir's."
Mr. Ericson admitted to a paradox. "The secret is solo-quality voices," he said. "In an orchestra, any violinist could step out and play the Beethoven Violin Concerto. Why shouldn't one of the sopranos in a good choir be able to step out and sing Mozart's 'Exsultate Jubilate'?" And indeed, over the decades, the radio choir has included Kim Borg, Nicolai Gedda, Kerstin Meyer, Anne Sofie von Otter, Erik Saeden, Elisabeth Soderstrom and Ingvar Wixell, among others.
Mr. Salonen waxed typically poetic: "Their sound is like the northern light, and to get it, you must know what it is to live without sun."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Eric Ericson, who leads the Swedish Radio Choir and his Chamber Choir in New York. (Lena Koller)(pg. 29); Members of the Swedish Radio Choir, which sustains the glory of its formative era under Eric Ericson. (Andreas Carlsbecker)(pg. 35)

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
What Is 'Black Dance'? A Cultural Melting Pot

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER REARDON; Christopher Reardon's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the choreographer Doug Varone.

 BODY:
IF things had gone according to plan, Salia Sanou would be earning a decent living these days as a police inspector in Burkina Faso, the tropical West African country where he was born and reared. After passing the police exam, Mr. Sanou was on the verge of getting his badge in 1991. Then, in a final fling with dance, which he had studied since childhood, he went to an audition that turned his world upside down.
 Seydou Boro showed up, too. Not unlike Mr. Sanou, his compatriot, he had pursued a respectable career working with computers. His dream, though, was to perform in films and on stage. The audition helped it come true. 
 Today Mr. Sanou and Mr. Boro are widely regarded as two of West Africa's most inventive dance makers, right up there with Beatrice Kombe from Ivory Coast. Proteges of the French choreographer Mathilde Monnier, they performed at last summer's Lincoln Center Festival in her postmodern retelling of Sophocles' "Antigone." 
Later this month they will return to New York to present one of their own works, called "Taagala." The title means "traveler" in Bambara, a language spoken in parts of West Africa, and the two choreographers give it an expansive reading. The 50-minute piece, which will be staged on Feb. 21 and 23 at the Harvey Theater at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presents an expressionist vision of the itinerant life familiar to both sub-Saharan nomads and jet-setting artists. 
"Taagala" comes as part of "Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation," an annual series of performances, discussions and master classes presented by 651 Arts, a community-based organization that rents office space at the theater. The series will run from Feb. 15 through Feb. 24, offering recent works by the African-American choreographers Abdel R. Salaam, Bebe Miller and Ronald K. Brown.
An opening-night celebration will honor 14 black dancers and choreographers who have advanced the art form, among them Katherine Dunham, George Faison, Diane McIntyre and Eleo Pomare. There will also be a screening of an excerpt from "Free to Dance," a new documentary that chronicles the contributions that black artists have made to modern dance in the United States. Produced by the American Dance Festival, it is to be broadcast nationally by PBS in April as part of its "Dance in America" series.
"Black dance" has always been a problematic term, not least because of enduring conflicts over race and the body. Adding to the confusion is the facility with which black dancers and choreographers have absorbed and spread cultural influences.
Last year, 651 Arts underscored this propensity by presenting a slate of emerging choreographers whose work defied any neat distinctions between black and white dance. (One choreographer took some of her inspiration from video games, another from circus tricks.) Similarly, this year's lineup stresses the long tradition of transformation.
"We need to recognize that tradition is something that is created," said Mr. Salaam, 50, a native New Yorker who worked his way up through the Chuck Davis Dance Company before starting his own troupe in 1981. "It's constantly evolving and constantly developing."
Mr. Salaam's reverence for traditional African dance is matched only by his willingness to use it as a springboard for experimentation. That hasn't always been a safe position. When he began to meld traditional and modern steps 16 years ago, he came under fire from both camps.
"It was very controversial," he said. "These two didactic languages were bumping up against each other, and they were seen as philosophically incompatible. Now everybody's doing it. Finally there's this understanding that culture is organic, that it has deep roots to nourish it and branches spreading in different directions."
Mr. Salaam's troupe, Forces of Nature Dance Theater Company, traces that growth in "Rhythm Legacy: The Living Books." Almost biblical in scope, it starts with the discovery of rhythm in Africa and ends with its second coming in America. Along the way, it traces the evolution of many traditional African dances, like a mating dance that originated in Senegal and took on new meaning among the Gullah people on the Sea Islands off the coast of Georgia.
Dance transforms itself on African soil, too, a process that seems to keep pace with globalization. Another reason, though, is support for creative partnerships and international tours through programs like Africa Exchange at 651 Arts and L'Afrique en Creations in Paris. Mr. Sanou and Mr. Boro, both in their early 30's, have benefited from each of these programs. Yet their passion for experimentation goes back much further.
One of Mr. Sanou's mentors was Germaine Acogny, a Senegalese choreographer who has worked closely with Maurice Bejart and Susanne Linke. (Ms. Acogny's company, Jant-Bi, performed Ms. Linke's "Coq Est Mort" ("The Rooster Is Dead") last summer at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Massachusetts.)
Mr. Boro, on the other hand, got his early movement training on the soccerfield, and later he joined a theater company in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso.
They caught the eye of Ms. Monnier when she went to audition dancers and musicians for "Pour Antigone," her update of the Greek tragedy, which she planned to set in Africa. (Raised in France and Morocco, she presaged the recent boom in crosscultural collaboration.) Ms. Monnier chose five artists to work with her in France. 
For Mr. Sanou, the experience was an epiphany. "I was trained in African styles by the older men in the village," he recalled in a 1999 interview, "but I never imagined that I could make a career of it, or that I could dance in silence, without music. Abroad, I discovered the music in me."
After finishing "Pour Antigone," he and Mr. Boro stayed with Ms. Monnier's company at the national choreographic center in Montpellier, France. Even so, they returned often to their families in Burkina Faso.
Once known as Upper Volta, the country now takes its name from a phrase in two local languages, Moore and Dioula, that means "land of upright people." Nevertheless, it has experienced five military coups since winning independence from France in 1960. The most recent one, coming with the assassination of Thomas Sankara in 1987, gave a haunting subtext to "Pour Antigone." Like Polyneices in the ancient play, Sankara was never given a proper burial.
Ouagadougou's flourishing film and theater industries have inspired Mr. Sanou and Mr. Boro to press ahead with plans to open a choreographic center modeled on the one in Montpellier. The project began to take root in 1996, when they established a troupe, Compagnie Salia Ni Seydou and created their first dance together, "Le Siecle des Fous" ("The Century of Fools").
Mr. Boro took the lead in choreographing their next piece, which was called "Figninto" (Bambara for "blind"). After winning prizes in Angola and France, it edged out "Pour Antigone" and "Le Coq Est Mort" to win the people's choice award at the 1999 International Festival of New Dance in Montreal.
Audiences in Ouagadougou were cynical at first. Several years ago, Mr. Sanou heard a viewer there remark, "They spend six months in France and voila! they dance like fools to please the whites." Now the prevailing view is more receptive. One explanation for the changed attitude lies in the dancers' physical artistry.
"Salia has a coiled kind of energy, like a cricket that flies up with explosive force," said Nena Gilreath Lucas, co-director of Atlanta's Ballethnic Dance Company, which gave the two choreographers a residency last summer. "Seydou is more like an albatross. His arms are so long, and he's so tall. It gives his movement a smoother quality, full of breath and air."
Joining them in "Taagala," their third production, are two other dancers and a pair of traditional musicians from Burkina Faso. Shrouded in a linen sheet, the dancers evoke a sense of dislocation and loss of identity that sometimes comes with a life spent in constant motion.
Travel is a recurring theme in this year's "Black Dance" series. Mr. Brown, 34, takes a sanguine view of migration and immigration in his new work, "High Life." Born in Brooklyn, he said the first act grew out of his sense of wonderment at the Great Migration, when millions of blacks moved north and created a new hybrid culture. The second act is set in West Africa after independence and was inspired by several recent trips to Ivory Coast to work with the choreographer Rokiya Kone. (Through Africa Exchange, she has also come to New York to work with Mr. Brown's company, Evidence.)
"I don't want to bastardize traditional dance, but when I go into the studio I'm trying to physicalize an emotion," he said. "I don't worry about how I do it, or whether I'm drawing from capoeira, modern dance, traditional or what I might do in a club."
Ms. Miller, also Brooklyn-born, shares Mr. Brown's expansive reach, if not his every aim. A postmodernist known for the intimate tenor of her musings on cultural identity, she deftly probed the dynamics of race, class and gender in "Going to the Wall," which was seen last spring at the Joyce Theater.
The casting for her newest dance, "Verge," might suggest a return to those themes. (Ms. Miller, now 50, described it as a quartet with "two men, two women; two whites, two blacks.")
Cultural factors are still present, but her main interest was in exploring the more primal, animalistic properties of touch. She began working on the piece two years ago during a residency in Portland, Ore.
"One of the first things we did was go to the zoo and watch the primates and the blind mole rats to get a different sense of the body and moving in your skin," she recalled. "The next day we went downtown to Pioneer Square, where all the grunge kids hang out. We sat for an hour watching them. It soon became clear that they had their own economy and their own social rules, a lot of which was manifested through touch."
BACK in the studio, she and her dancers began developing new movement vocabulary through a series of structured improvisations. One day they formed a pile of bodies on the floor in an effort to "resensualize" themselves.
"It was one of the most lovely things I've ever done," Ms. Miller said.
"I found myself at one point with someone's chin underneath my chin in a way I'd never felt before. It was nothing very interesting to look at, but it short-circuited all of my physical and emotional impulses. It felt amazing to be there wondering: what's in contact here?"
Her question, asked of cultures as well as chins, is an apt catch phrase for the "Black Dance" series.

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT; 
New Liaison to Gay Residents: From Rabble Rouser to Bureaucrat

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA ROWE 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
UNTIL last month, Joseph DeFilippis had spent his adult life as a rabble-rousing advocate for gays and lesbians, lobbying government officials and writing angry letters. Now he has switched sides.
 Mr. DeFilippis is Westchester County's new full-time liaison to the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender community. 
 He was persuaded to make the leap into government because of what he sees as the clear commitment of County Executive Andrew J. Spano to better serve the so-called "L.G.B.T. community."
The acronym stands for lesbian-gay-bisexual-transgender and is the current, politically correct catchall phrase. But Mr. DeFilippis hates it.
"It sound like you're ordering a sandwich," he said. "This is going to be an adjustment for me, working in the political arena. I tend to shoot from the hip."
During an interview at his new office, Mr. DeFilippis, 33, was just moving in -- trying to find a stapler that worked and figuring out exactly what a community liaison does. 
He is the former coordinator of the Queer Economic Justice Network, which he founded in 1999 to alert government to the effects of welfare reform on gays and lesbians. He also worked on behalf of elderly gay people as the director of Sage, a community organization in Queens. Gay seniors are particularly isolated, he said, because they are less likely to have children to provide for them and are routinely turned away from nursing homes that will not admit their partners.
"There's a myth that we're all white, educated, affluent men. I don't think the gay agenda is just getting into the military and getting married," said Mr. DeFilippis, who did, in fact, marry his partner, David Koteles, seven years ago. The couple live together in northern Manhattan.
A native of Queens, Mr. DeFilippis is the son of immigrants whose dinner table arguments focused neither on political parties nor lifestyles but on a kind of one-upmanship over how left-leaning one could fairly claim to be. He found his calling after college when he went to work for the New York Foundation and saw that activism could actually make a difference.
"That's where I decided that fighting over the dinner table wasn't really a sufficient contribution," he said.
But how, exactly, will Mr. DeFilippis fill his days in Westchester? 
He plans to spend much of his time educating employees in schools, hospitals, clinics and senior centers on how to be sensitive to gay and lesbian clients. He will also create an advisory board -- like the county's African-American and Latino boards -- to advise Mr. Spano, and he plans to hold community forums to gain a better sense of the needs of gays and lesbians in Westchester.
"We have a large lesbian-gay community here," Mr. Spano said. "And we thought its needs would be better served if we had a designated person who could respond. I expect Joseph to be our eyes and ears, to investigate charges of harassment or discrimination and to refer people to our Human Rights Commission, if need be, on matters of sexual orientation. That's a full-time job."
Mr. DeFilippis is not the first person to hold the post. Mr. Spano's predecessor, Andrew P. O'Rourke, created the position as a part-time job. Mr. Spano has expanded it to 40 hours a week, with a salary of $65,235 a year.
The last person to hold the job was Dr. Zelle Andrews, who left almost a year ago. The county does not have any other liaison positions.
Depending on whom one asks, gays and lesbians make up 5 to 10 percent of the general population. But in Westchester they may be particularly hidden, said Laura Newman, executive director of the Loft in White Plains, a lesbian and gay community services center with 2,200 people on its mailing list.
"It's not like living in New York City or the Village with people waving flags all the time," she said. "One of the reasons that people are particularly closeted up here is that they may not be sure this is a friendly climate."
For good reason. Two years ago, when the county was forming its Human Rights Commission, the attempt to include language about sexual orientation in its charter brought a firestorm, Ms. Newman said.
"I saw a lot of extremely bigoted people who were quite outspoken about not accepting lesbian and gay people or families," she said.
With the hiring of Mr. DeFilippis, Mr. Spano is trying to address that. Last month, he also introduced legislation that would create a domestic partnership registry, so unmarried couples in a long-term relationship could qualify for legal protection and benefits.
More evidence, Mr. DeFilippis said, of the county's commitment to this population.
"That's what got me to schlep up here every day from Manhattan," he said. "The feeling that I am going to work with an administration that's truly open to this."

After years of lobbying for gays and lesbians, he will be their advocate within the county government. "This is going to be an adjustment for me," he said, "working in the political arena." (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Billion-Dollar Expansion Plan for High-Tech Center

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR 

 BODY:
FROM the outside a cluster of buildings along Route 1 here looks more like a 1950's high school than a repository of high-technology research and development of the sort that takes place inside the Sarnoff Corporation, which pioneered such innovations as color TV and high-definition television as well as the infrared camera. 
 Now, the company is planning to transform its 600,000-square-foot headquarters into a 3.5-million-square-foot technology campus that, like Sarnoff itself, will marry technology and research with commerce. In partnership with the Advance Group of Bedminster, the company plans to build the $1 billion project in stages over the next 10 to 15 years, with the first 610,000-square-foot phase expected to start in 2003. Stubbins Associates of Cambridge, Mass., designed the master plan for the project and is its architect with Rothe-Johnson of Edison. 
 The plan still must navigate the approval process. But it has already drawn both applause for the jobs it could generate and criticism for the disruption in the quality of life it could cause when added with other projects planned along the Route 1 corridor, from New Brunswick to Trenton. 
The technology campus is to comprise as many as 22 buildings with laboratories, offices and hotels as well as such services as a day care center and health club. Its anchor is to be a 750,000-square-foot headquarters for Sarnoff, including incubator space for its spinoffs. There are also plans for satellite campuses of Stevens Institute of Technology of Hoboken and the New Jersey Institute of Technology of Newark. 
The buildings, along with deck parking garages, will be clustered on 89 acres in the middle of the 336-acre property. Beyond the existing buildings, the site is a tangle of woods and fields between Washington Road and the Millstone River. 
"We're not just going to build more buildings, but create a center with national focus," James E. Carnes, Sarnoff's president and chief executive, said. The project could attract 10,000 jobs, he said. 
Over the years Sarnoff, which creates and commercializes electronics, biomedical and information technologies, spurred similar companies to locate along Route 1, helping to make it a high-tech corridor. Now, with its proposed campus, Sarnoff hopes its own facilities will be attractive to scientists that it is recruiting as well as to technology-related companies.
In many ways, Sarnoff's decision to develop its site has as much to do with changes in the information economy as it does with changes in the company itself.
The company was started in 1942 as the nonprofit research arm of RCA by Gen. David Sarnoff, RCA's chairman. Its complex here was built by 1965, when Route 1 still passed potato fields, cow pastures and hardwood forest -- not office parks. 
In 1986 RCA was acquired by the General Electric Company, which had its own research arm, making the complex redundant. It was sold in 1987 to SRI International, a nonprofit company in Menlo Park, Calif., and became a for-profit subsidiary. 
SINCE then Sarnoff, no longer reliant on its parent for financing, worked for industry and government clients under contract or for royalties on products made from its discoveries. In 1992 Sarnoff started to spin off start-up companies -- 19 of them so far -- to bring its technologies to market, and it expects to profit by selling all or part of its stock in the companies when they eventually go public or when the start-up company is acquired by another concern. (Orchid BioSciences, which works on genetics-based technologies, is its only fledging to go public, and Sarnoff's stake was worth $1.2 million at the time of the offering last May. The VideoBrush Corporation, a spinoff whose product enables several snapshots to be combined into one, was sold in 1999.)
Meanwhile, Sarnoff, which employs 750, realized it needed to expand and update its buildings to remain competitive, Mr. Carnes said. To do so "without draining our investment in our technology" meant leveraging other assets, including real estate, he said, adding that the new headquarters would help with recruiting because "it will provide a flexible and collaborative environment." 
That Sarnoff is the sponsor and anchor of its 336-acre park in West Windsor makes it distinct from the three technology research parks already in the state. Two of them are along the Route 1 corridor. They are the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center in Plainsboro and South Brunswick and the 50-acre state-sponsored Technology Center of New Jersey in North Brunswick. The third is the 50-acre University Heights Science Park in Newark's Central Ward, sponsored by four institutions of higher education.
Dean Lundahl, regional managing director at Advance, said the Sarnoff park planned to attract established as well as emerging companies. He said -- and early proponents agree -- that the park would help the image of New Jersey as a high-tech state and Mercer County as one of its silicon corners.
"Sarnoff is an icon of New Jersey's transition to the New Economy," said Stephen R. Sasala II, president and chief executive of Prosperity New Jersey, a public-private nonprofit partnership created by the state to attract high-tech concerns. 
Science- and technology-oriented companies are considered a growth engine for New Jersey, which has more scientists per capita than any other state. It also has more than 10,000 high-tech companies, putting it fourth in the nation in the number of such concerns, according to Prosperity New Jersey.
Mr. Lundahl said that because the project is along Route 1 and near a train station, it conforms with a goal of the state Development and Redevelopment Plan to concentrate development near highways and mass transit. He also said the project's proposed 3.5 million square feet is less than the 4.5 million feet that could be developed on the site under current zoning.
Carole Carson, the mayor of West Windsor, said the project "is well-designed, well-thought out" and "in an appropriate place" for growth. It is also important, she said, that the company stay in the township.
Still, challenges exist, including environmental concerns involving the nearby Millstone River and traffic issues. A proposed bypass on Route 1 near the Sarnoff site is under review by the state's Department of Transportation. The developers support the bypass, which will parallel Washington Road, as a way to keep cars moving along the highway and to their park. 
Meanwhile, some critics of the way development along Route 1 is evolving say that improvements along the heavily traveled highway, including the proposed bypass, have not kept pace with the growth and that more should be done before the next round of projects, like Sarnoff's, moves forward. Among them is George Hawkins, executive director of the Stony Brook-Millstone River Watershed Association, an environmental preservation group.
"Sarnoff's decision to develop its site makes sense in isolation," he said, noting, however, that if land-use decisions continue to be made piecemeal, "the collective consequences from the potential development will be calamity." He said that under present zoning some 10 million square feet of commercial space could be added to the corridor over time. 
Mercer County Executive Robert D. Prunetti acknowledged that "the livability of the county is dependent on striking a balance between growth and conservation." He called the Sarnoff project reasonable.
The developers say they expect to address concerns about the project. Its cornerstone will be Sarnoff's new 750,000-square-foot headquarters, which will be created by demolishing 350,000 square feet of its existing complex, renovating the remaining 250,000 feet and adding 500,000 square feet of space. About 150,000 square feet will be an incubator for start-ups. 
Mr. Lundahl said the hope is that as those companies mature, they will want to stay close to Sarnoff and its resources and take space in the rest of the technology park.
The other 21 planned buildings include two hotels, a health club and a day care center. Others will contain the 2.2 million square feet of research laboratory and office space, most of which will not be constructed until after a significant amount of space is preleased, Mr. Lundahl said, noting that rents will be competitive. Mr. Lundahl and brokers in the area all said that offices of the sort planned for the complex would currently charge rents in the low to mid $30's per square foot per year. 
With such a "long-term project there will be ups and downs in the economy," Mr. Carnes said, adding that the key is "to re-evaluate and respond to the market."

HEADLINE: The Enforcer; 
As Mrs. Whitman Begins Her New Job, There Is Debate Over Her Commitment to the Environment in the Past

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
THERE was Christie Whitman, canoeing down a pristine stream in the interior of New Jersey. This was not a tourism advertisement, but rather a back-to-nature touch strategically inserted into the governor's State of the State address several weeks ago.
 And this was not just any governor, but the woman who had just been chosen by President-elect Bush to head the nation's Environmental Protection Agency. As the state's own Senator Robert G. Torricelli put it, "There are few training grounds that could better prepare someone for this position than the governor of New Jersey." 
 But as Mrs. Whitman begins her new career, there is some debate over the depth of her concern for the environment. Her efforts to preserve open space and to protect the coastline have received high marks from nearly every environmental group. But the governor's overall record -- particularly in her first term, when "open for business" was a campaign theme -- has another side. Faced with a deep economic slump, Mrs. Whitman took office pledging to slash not only taxes but regulations that stood in the way of business. 
"She is certainly good on open space," said Edward Lloyd, a professor at Columbia University Law School and a former director of the Rutgers Environmental Law Clinic. "That is what she is best known for in the environmental area. On the regulatory side, there is a very different story to tell."
Indeed, in her last address as governor, Mrs. Whitman cited her program to protect a million acres of woods and farmland from development, and used the speech to unveil a new effort to improve state parks.
"Even as the state has been growing, our air and water are cleaner, with fewer days of high ozone and carbon monoxide and far fewer beach closings," Mrs. Whitman said. "All policy is personal, and for me few policies are more personal than our efforts to preserve open space in the Garden State. Raised on a farm, I want every New Jersey child now and in the future to enjoy the character of the state that I have always loved."
The reality is far more complex.
For instance, the State Department of Environmental Protection was one of Governor Whitman's first targets. She clearly intended to shift the organization and philosophy of an agency long viewed as an enemy of business and developers. In her first budget, Mrs. Whitman cut more than 200 positions from the department, an action that included transferring the Board of Public Utilities to the Treasury Department.
When environmental groups and public employee unions strenuously protested, the governor was unmoved, saying increased regulation was not the best way to get a cleaner environment.
The cuts Mrs. Whitman proposed for later budgets were so deep that they drew opposition from her own party. In May 1996, some state senators including John O. Bennett, the majority leader from Little Silver, said Republicans would oppose the governor's budget unless she restored money for environmental programs.
"The proposed budget would require dramatic reductions in scientific, technical and human resources," Senator Bennett and six other senators wrote in a letter to the governor. "We feel strongly that the proposed layoffs of D.E.P. personnel will negatively impact the department's ability to effectively safeguard the environment and protect public health."
In subsequent years, Mrs. Whitman restored much of the agency's financing -- though her budget allocations did not reach the 1994 level until the fiscal year 2000.
In a recent interview, Eileen McGinnis, the governor's chief of policy and planning, said that although some of Mrs. Whitman's policies in her first term were a response to the state's economic problems, the changes at the Department of Environmental Protection were not among them.
"The department needed a more focused mission," Ms. McGinnis said.
In many ways, the Whitman administration marked a deep change for New Jersey's environmental policies -- from a trend toward greater regulation and control to a more cooperative relationship with industry and developers. While her predecessors created large blocks of rules to shape the environment -- the Byrne administration's creation of the Pinelands commission, the financing of municipal sewage plants in the Kean years and the Florio administration's stringent pollution regulations -- Mrs. Whitman concentrated on adjusting existing rules rather than creating new ones.
Ms. McGinnis said the intent was not to simply cut down on regulation, but to replace a thicket of confusing requirements with clear timetables and concrete goals. She said the plan was to maintain strict environmental standards while eliminating the creation of what some considered unneeded regulations.
"I would say sensible regulation," Ms. McGinnis said.
But the definition of sensible can vary depending on one's agenda, and that change in philosophy is controversial to this day. Many of the steps taken by Mrs. Whitman still rankle environmental groups in the state, including these actions:
*Elimination of the Office of Environmental Prosecutor and the office of the Public Advocate and the creation of the Office of the Business Ombudsman.
*Downsizing the Department of Environmental Protection, which saw its staff drop to a low of 3,022 in 1998 from 3,729 in 1994.
*Elimination of the Department of Environmental Protection lab.
*Support for the expansion of controversial highways and such developments such as Merrill Lynch's corporate park in Hopewell.
*Reduction in both staff and financing for the state's parks.
*Elimination of more than 100 stations that monitor water quality.
*Removal of more than 1,000 chemicals from a group of hazardous industrial chemicals, called the right-to-know list, that are subject to state inspection.
David S. Pringle, the campaign director of the New Jersey Environmental Federation, a private watchdog organization, maintained that Mrs. Whitman's policies had a drastic effect. Although he was quick to credit the governor's efforts to preserve open space, he said she had been "exceedingly poor on enforcement and regulatory funding."
"There was a 20 to 30 percent cut in funding for environmental programs," Mr. Pringle said. "There was a two-thirds cut in the toxic right-to-know list. All of these had the cumulative impact of sending a message to polluters that they could get away with significant compromises to environmental and public health."
Other critics pointed to a sharp drop in money collected in fines and penalties for environmental violations in the seven years Mrs. Whitman held office -- as much as 80 percent in some of those years. In addition, the number of inspections conducted by environmental regulators dropped to 23,686 in 2000 from 27,826 in 1994. In 1999, the inspector general of the federal agency that Mrs. Whitman would later inherit issued a report critical of the state's water-monitoring program for failing to meet federal guidelines. Ultimately, the environmental agency suspended some financing because the state did not file its water-quality reports on time.
Not surprisingly, Whitman administration officials disagree vehemently with the critics. Cathy Tormey, an assistant commissioner at the state Department of Environmental Protection, attributed the drop in the number of inspections to a change in the inspections themselves rather than a lax attitude.
In addition, Ms. Tormey said the number of legal actions taken against major polluters remained virtually the same after Mrs. Whitman took office in January 1994. She said that the federal environmental agency assessed penalties of $225 million in 2000, with New Jersey collecting $12 million in fines.
"We are out there and we are assessing penalties against people who are violating environmental laws," Ms. Tormey said. "We do have a strong enforcement program and it does respond with penalties."
On the other hand, critics say the $12 million collected by the state pales in comparison with $26 million in fines collected in the last year of the Florio administration. While Ms. Tormey and others in the Whitman administration contend that the amount of the fines has little to do with environmental quality, critics insist it is an important measure of the state's aggressiveness in sanctioning polluters. If the state is not willing to punish violators, they say, then it naturally follows that more companies are willing to take risks.
"That has bad consequences because people don't try to comply until they are caught," Mr. Lloyd said. "It sounds good to say we want to assist, we want to foster compliance. But the question is what happens in the field. It makes a difference when you have the hammer."
Before Mrs. Whitman took office, the willingness of state environmental regulators to use an enforcement hammer had long been a complaint of industry. Businesses -- particularly those in heavy industry and land development -- often found themselves at odds with state officials.
"There was a command and control atmosphere in Trenton, and businesses were viewed not as friends but as enemies," said Joseph Gonzalez, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, the state's largest private business advocacy group.
And while business did not always agree with Mrs. Whitman's approach -- the two sides fought bitterly over the state's sewer rules -- Mr. Gonzalez said the governor was always willing to work with industry, particularly in shortening the time needed to receive environmental permits.
"We have seen real improvement in that across the board," he said.
Critics, on the other hand, said that Mrs. Whitman's concern for economic growth caused problems for the administration in several cases.
One example often cited is the controversial Merrill Lynch office park in Hopewell, a rural town in Mercer County. Faced with the prospect of the investment company moving 3,500 jobs out of state, Governor Whitman stepped in with more than $100 million in incentives to persuade the company to stay. The project, a sprawling office development with the potential to house more space than the World Trade Center, was seen as a betrayal by town residents, particularly in light of the governor's support for open-space preservation.
"The state capital is eight miles away, and they are building this giant office building in a cornfield, while Trenton is going begging for jobs," said Mayor Marylou Ferrara of Hopewell Township. "The state gave them subsidies and tax breaks like you can't believe. They made it more attractive to build in a soybean field than a city."
Then there was the state energy efficiency fund, with nearly $1 billion that was supposed to pay for renewable energy and heightened efficiency. Environmentalists contend that the state Board of Public Utilities has dragged its feet and has spent none of the money, even though the first $128 million has been available for nearly a year. Utility companies have fought for control of the funds, while environmentalists argue that the money should be disbursed by the state or by a combination of industry and environmentalists.
"There has been no articulation of an energy policy," said Curtis Fisher, legislative director for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.
Mr. Fisher, whose group successfully pushed for the money as part of the 1999 energy deregulation bill, said recent problems in California underscored its importance. New York recently doubled available funds for energy efficiency, he said, while New Jersey had been slow to move. "So far they have refused to move forward with this money, and it is critically needed," he said.
Even more embarrassing for the Whitman administration was fallout from a settlement between state regulators and a large cranberry grower over accusations that the company's operations had expanded into the state's wetlands. Under the proposed agreement, A. R. DeMarco Enterprises said it would turn over another large parcel of land to the state to settle any complaints lodged by New Jersey environmental regulators.
Critics raised an outcry, pointing to a longtime friendship between Garfield DeMarco, the company's president, and Robert Shinn, the commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection. Although Mr. Shinn said he had recused himself from the settlement, Governor Whitman requested an investigation by the state inspector general.
In November, the inspector general criticized the regulators' actions, saying the settlement was flawed for several reasons. And although he found no improper actions by the commissioner, the inspector general said Mr. Shinn did not totally shut himself out of the process.
"The appearance of impropriety coupled with an inappropriate enforcement process leads the office of inspector general to conclude that it would not be in the public interest to finalize" the agreement, wrote Edward M. Neafsey, the inspector general.
The Department of Environmental Protection is still working on a final settlement based on the guidelines recommended by the inspector general, a spokeswoman said last week.
Despite the criticism of her stewardship of the state's natural resources, the Whitman administration's response has been consistent: Look at results, not at regulations.
"Is the air and water cleaner?" Ms. McGinnis asked. "That is where the focus should be."
To be sure, many environmental groups credit Mrs. Whitman with improving the state in several areas. Her most ambitious effort was the plan to save a million acres of open space and the protection of Sterling Forest on the New York State border.
Even so, aides to Mrs. Whitman acknowledged that the loss of open space in New Jersey -- the nation's most densely populated state -- actually increased during her terms in office.
In addition, the beaches are much cleaner than they were as recently as 10 years ago, when the sight of medical waste and industrial sludge washing up on New Jersey's beaches was not unusual. Indeed, there have been no beach closings in recent years.
"Our program is one of the best in the nation," said Cindy Zipf, executive director of Clean Ocean Action, a private environmental advcocacy group.
Ms. Zipf said Mrs. Whitman led the effort to stop the dumping of toxic harbor sludge off the New Jersey coast, and was a strong proponent of the state's beach-monitoring programs. And though Ms. Zipf said her organization would like to see even tighter regulation of pollutants in the water, she conceded that under Mrs. Whitman, "the ocean experience has been a positive one."
In other areas, the record seems to be more mixed. A report prepared for Governor Whitman by an aide concluded that water quality had improved in some areas but worsened in others. According to the memorandum, 42 percent of streams and rivers were identified as polluted in last year's water-quality report as against 33 percent in 1994. But the memorandum also said that the number of streams identified as severely polluted dropped to 1 percent in 2000 from from 5 percent in 1994.
Air quality is better since Mrs. Whitman took office, according to reports filed with the Environmental Protection Agency by state regulators, with lower levels of such pollutants as lead, sulfur and airborne particles. Critics of Mrs. Whitman acknowledged that she took a strong position on reducing the amount of pollution emitted from power plants and praised her for sticking with her program to toughen emissions testing for vehicles despite the political fallout from a disastrous and costly implementation.
Still, critics contended that the improvements in air quality were part of a trend that had begun in the 1970's with passage of the federal Clean Air Act and the banning of such pollutants as leaded gasoline. In addition, they said that in recent years, improvement in the air quality had flattened when compared with the strides made in previous decades.
"We should have been a lot better," said John Paul Guinan, a staff attorney for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. "Our technology has improved, but the results have plateaued."
While supporters and critics alike agree that it may be too soon to evaluate Mrs. Whitman's performance on the environment, Assemblyman Leonard Lance, a Republican from Flemington, says that overall, "the record is strong, particularly in the second term."
Speaking in defense of her checkered record, Mr. Lance said Mrs. Whitman did not have the ability to finance many of her environmental initiatives until the state's economy rebounded at the beginning of her second term, and that programs like the 10-year open-space plan would bear fruit many years in the future.
On the other hand, Mr. Fisher of the public interest organization said that many of the programs that have helped to clean up the state's air and its beaches were begun by Governors Kean and Byrne, and that the results of Governor Whitman's efforts might not become apparent for some time. 
"Environmental policies take years to see all of the positives and negatives," he said. "It will take years to know exactly, but the early indication is there is damage that needs repair."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Learning the Hard Way in Camden

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CAMDEN 

 BODY:
ONE indication that Annette D. Knox was the right choice for superintendent of schools here is that on the day after her first school board meeting, which went on until 2:30 in the morning, she was able to describe the event as "mild."
 Another good sign was that no matter how confrontational some speakers became during Monday night's marathon meeting, Ms. Knox kept her cool. While dozens of people approached the front of the room to question numerous items in Ms. Knox's first round of proposed changes, the new superintendent stared intently over the top of her rimless glasses, soaking up what the speakers had to offer, and occasionally responding, always politely and confidently. 
 "I learned over the years that you have to be calm and listen to what people have to say," said Ms. Knox. "The people here have a history with the city and the schools that I don't have, and they have their stories to tell. I have to know that history and where people are coming from. I may not always agree, but I need to know it." 
Perhaps that's a lesson that should have been reviewed when Ms. Knox first took over on Jan. 1 as superintendent of the largest and poorest school district in southern New Jersey.
On her first day on the job, the 54-year-old administrator made an indelible mark when she requested resignation slips from all 200 employees in the district's central administration office. The intent was not a wholesale firing of all district employees, Ms. Knox said, but to provide a tool for evaluating the organization to ensure that workers' skills matched their jobs and to give her some options.
But the damage was done. Teachers, administrators and union officials immediately perceived the action as a threat, and although Ms. Knox dropped her request for resignations, people remain cautious.
"I'm trying to be neutral and diplomatic, but her actions did not fare well with our members," said Claraliene Gordon, president of the Camden Education Association, which represents 3,100 of the district's 4,000 members. "I hope her intentions are honorable, but there's a process. That's what's in question, not her ability, not her plan."
In hindsight, Ms. Knox recognizes that she could have handled things differently that first week.
"I might have talked to more people about it, gotten more views," she said, adding, "I don't think it ended up badly. Some people may hold on to it, but I think we've moved around it as an organization."
Despite some ruffled feathers, Ms. Knox has not slowed down. In a city where the unemployment and crime rates are three times higher than the state averages, with a school district where 88 percent of the students qualify for subsidized lunches and 50 percent drop out before graduating from high school, time is a luxury that she does not have.
Filling a position that had been vacant since April 1999 has meant Ms. Knox had to hit the ground running. In her first month, she has proposed developing a uniform curriculum for all schools, privatizing the food service program, consolidating six school buildings that currently serve from 21 to 274 students each, reorganizing the district and creating a strong literacy program and a comprehensive summer school program. These and other proposals were included in her report to the board last week, but by the end of the meeting some items had to be tabled because of resistance.
In a highly politicized system, where a former school board president was convicted of spending school funds on personal meals and vacations, and the last superintendent resigned after repeated clashes with the board, part of what Ms. Knox is up against is the fact that she is the first woman and the first outsider to run Camden's 32 public schools serving 19,000 students. The president of the school board, Philip E. Freeman, said it was exactly that outsider status they were looking for when they narrowed their time-consuming search to five finalists, and then to Ms. Knox. 
"She brings a fresh perspective to the district that lends itself to being fair and unbiased," said Mr. Freeman. "She's apolitical, she's not connected to the system, doesn't have any special interest groups she's representing. She's someone who's open and honest and can promote her program to all the different factions with integrity." 
Before coming to Camden, Ms. Knox was regional superintendent of 23 public schools in Cleveland, where she was brought in to help restructure the school system that had just come out from under state rule. Most of her 31 years in education were spent in the New York City school system, where she started out as a first-grade teacher and worked her way up to principal in public schools throughout Harlem. She said she first got a taste for education as a young girl in the town of Washington, N.C.
"Growing up, I never really wanted to be a teacher," said Ms. Knox, who wears her hair in short, neat cornrows and dresses in black and neutral tones accented by native prints. "I had four aunts who were teachers, and we all lived in the same neighborhood, so I'd go to them whenever I needed help. Later I realized that those aunts had a lot more impact on me than I thought."
Ms. Knox said she was attracted to Camden because she always wanted to be superintendent of a district where she was really needed and her skills could be tested. This weekend she planned to move into her new home in Camden, just around the corner from the district offices and in view of the new baseball stadium under construction.
"Some districts are just matched to your personality," said Ms. Knox, who has signed a three-year contract at a salary of $160,000 a year, making her one of the highest-paid superintendents in the state. "I feel I'm matched to Camden. I'm a fighter. I'm a person who never gives up. I believe in always being prepared at all times, and if I'm not prepared, developing the skills and tools I need to be."
And fight she will have to, not only against the special interests of unions looking to protect members, but also against a system in which giving pupils a substandard education is so ingrained. Students describe the high schools as places where kids spend most of their days trying to figure out how to cut classes, where broken windows are standard and where fights can break out in the hallway at a moment's notice, where passing gym merely requires one to change into and out of uniform, and where students routinely fall asleep in class while teachers gossip with security guards. 
As the district where the 1981 class-action lawsuit of Abbott vs. Burke originated, Camden forced the New Jersey State Supreme Court and the state Board of Education, after several years of wrangling, to guarantee the same level of financing to poorer urban school districts as that provided by taxpayers in richer districts. To that end, Camden is one of the state's 30 special districts and receives $240 million of its $247 million budget from the state. But money is not always the answer. Camden spends $10,792 a year on each student -- far higher than the state average of $9,505 -- yet pupils' test scores fall far below average, a situation that has led to the state's oversight of the district for the last two years.
While educators point to everything from poverty to the high percentage of foreign-speaking students to inadequate resources as reasons for the schools' failures, Ms. Knox has been visiting classrooms in recent days, talking to students to find out what they feel is lacking in their schools.
"Students are able to tell you what they need," she said. "They see it at other schools, and they know that the experiences they're having here are not the same as those other students. Every child in this world starts out with the same intellectual capacity to learn. It is how we engage them in the school environment that will determine whether they can compete in this world."
Along with her critics, several people who spoke at the board meeting offered to lend their support, reminding Ms. Knox that she could not do it all alone. The next morning, Ms. Knox said she received several phone calls from well-wishers telling her they were praying for her and telling her to be strong. She says the welcome she has received from the community has been tremendous and that she feels the city is ready for the change she represents.
"There's a level of expectancy, that we're going to be moving ahead and people are wondering what's next," Ms. Knox said. "There's anticipation but I think it is positive. I've always been working my way toward a Camden, N.J.. I believe this is the place where I can make a difference. I have no fears."

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Bitter Pill For Local Druggist

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN MILLER 

DATELINE: WANAQUE 

 BODY:
The signs are everywhere, though you have to slow down to see them.
 "For Rent" notices pepper a stretch of Ringwood Avenue in the Haskell section of this Passaic County town. And between sagging storefronts, another establishment announces that it sells "Used Junk." 
 Then there's a sign across the street: "Over 53 Years and We're Staying," in red letters in the window of Kressaty's Pharmacy. 
The reason for the sign's insistence is a proposal before the town planning board to allow a business on a vacant lot down the street from Kressaty's where a CVS pharmacy wants open. Borough officials contend that the depressed Haskell section desperately needs an anchor, something like a CVS, to attract new businesses. But the plan puts the officials in the uncomfortable position of threatening one of the town's few successful businesses -- and the kind of place where customers linger, talk about family, tell jokes.
"Our customers are more worried than we are," said Fred Kressaty, the 80-year-old pharmacy owner, who has encouraged visitors to sign a petition asking local officials to block the "unnecessary introduction" of chain stores.
"The arrival of chain stores is one sign of progress," the petition reads, "but the price of progress should not be the loss of people and institutions, whose dedication to the community is beneficial and long-standing."
Nearly 500 people signed the petition in the first week alone, and now there are more than 1,000 signatures, Mr. Kressaty said.
That still has not kept CVS from making an offer to buy out the pharmacy, thoughMr. Kressaty said he turned it down.
So far, the town has received about $1 million from the state to help build a "town center" for Haskell, complete with old-fashioned lights, brick crosswalks and a clock tower. Housing for 2,200 elderly residents has also been approved.
Indeed, there are already sections of Wanaque that have been visited by the mixed blessing of gentrifrication. Professionals are moving into the area, and homes that sold for a song are fetching more than $200,000. Passaic County Community College opened a campus in Wanaque last year. And a consulting firm is marketing the town to businesses. But none of this has done much for Haskell, and to make the area come alive, supporters of the CVS say new retail businesses have to be encouraged to come here.
"You can't invite merchants to come into a town that looks like the South Bronx," said Lorraine La Neve, a longtime resident and former president of the borough's Chamber of Commerce. 
Officials here envision restaurants, boutiques and business offices lining Ringwood Avenue, and it is a vision that many of them are excited about.
"Many towns will have these plans," said the borough administrator, Tom Carroll, "but it won't happen. Here, it will happen." 
Mr. Kressaty -- though his business is imperiled -- insisted that he was not opposed to competition. But Barbara Offner, a nurse who was shopping at the pharmacy, complained about the long lines and unfriendly service at chain stores.
Whether to accept the CVS is a tough decision, said Robert Rizzotti, a planning consultant who conducted an economic development study for the borough.
What's more, Mr. Rizzotti said that approval of the CVS must come quickly to assure the success of the redevelopment effort.
"It's an unfortunate situation in some instances, because businesses will be hurt," he said.
But James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University, said Mr. Rizzotti might be overstating the case. 
"Any one store," Mr. Hughes said, "I don't think you could say the whole plan would hinge on it." 
But he did note that when local stores are pushed out, it's a loss of something less tangible than simply one business.
"Those pharmacies," he said, referring to chains like CVS, "can destroy the fabric of the community."
They can also offer discounted prices and wider selections, undercutting the smaller, locally owned businesses.
Todd Andrews, a spokesman for CVS, which is based in Woonsocket, R.I., disagreed with the notion that the chain would treat customers impersonally.
"That is a misconception," Mr. Andrews said. "Our pharmacists are professionals, and look after our patients with the same care and professionalism that other pharmacists would."
Moreover, the introduction of big pharmacies does not necessarily mean the death of smaller ones. Mr. Rizzotti's report, citing the Bergen County town of Waldwick, noted that two major chains had opened in the past few years -- including one near Waldwick Pharmacy..
"You have to be creative, flexible," said Bill Brown, who has owned the pharmacy for 28 years.
For Mr. Brown, the answer is a hometown feel, competitive pricing and innovative products like the throat lozenges he sells under the store's own label.
Despite such assurances, the concerns here are palpable. John Soojian, a 45-year resident of neighboring Pompton Lakes, who is the owner and developer of the CVS site, said he feared vilification.
"I'm damned if I do, I'm damned if I don't," Mr. Soojian said.
And Mayor Warren Hagstrom, who was born and raised here and has a seat on the planning board that will hear the CVS proposal, said he had been lying awake at night thinking about the plan for the last several weeks.
"I can't hurt them," Mr. Hagstrom said of the Kressaty family. 
But the Kressatys -- Fred and his wife, Claire and their daughter Terri, 44 -- insist that they will stay. Fred and Claire own the building and live above the store.
"I wouldn't consider closing at all," said Terri Kressaty, who stands to inherit the business. "There is absolutely nothing that will shut us down."

HEADLINE: THE CAPITOL; 
A Feud Brewing Over Family Leave

BYLINE:  By ABHI RAGHUNATHAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
The usual marriage of convenience in which Republicans and business interests are joined in a common purpose -- is showing signs of strain.
 Blame the paid family-leave bill. 
 In fact, the attempt to grant all workers a paid leave of absence when they become parents has brought together legislators of both parties, though not the special interest groups that historically back them.
Labor groups and women's organizations claim that no one should have to choose between a paycheck and a child, which is why they support legislation that would allow employees with newborn or newly adopted children to collect up to 12 weeks of unemployment compensation while taking a leave from work.
Business groups see things differently.
They contend that such a bill would devastate companies by forcing them to seek new employees. Moreover, they say the money available to the state should be used for unemployment compensation, not financing a new government program that could lead to higher tax rates. 
Business groups were not pleased when the New Jersey chapter of the AFL-CIO, along with the state chapter of the National Organization for Women and more than 20 other advocacy groups announced last Monday that they were forming a coalition to lobby for the paid family leave bill.
"This bill is long overdue," said Assemblywoman Arline Friscia, Democrat of Middlesex, a sponsor of the measure who complained that parents no longer have time to spend with their children because most families now depend on the incomes of both parents.
Karen Jarrett of Newark, who spoke at the AFL-CIO's announcement of support for the measure, said that financial problems compelled her to return to her job counseling young mothers three weeks after adopting her 18-month old nephew.
"I just couldn't afford it," Ms. Jarrett said. "We don't need or ask for much help, but we could have used 12 weeks of help a few years ago."
Now, a parent of a newborn or newly adopted child can take up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave. Businesses that employ 50 or more people are required to hire the person back at the same or an equivalent job. A temporary disability program also provides some pay for women on maternity leave, the length of which is determined by a doctor.
The proposed bill would replace the current law by allowing workers to draw up to 12 weeks of pay from the state's Unemployment Insurance fund. In addition, in a move that would make New Jersey the first state to adopt such a regulation, businesses that employ 50 or more people would be required to take back employees at the position they held when they left, or an equivalent one.
In the Assembly the bill was also sponsored by Charlotte Vandervalk, a Bergen County Republican. In the Senate Jack Sinagra, a Republican of Middlesex, and John Lynch, a Democrat of New Brunswick, sponsored the legislation.
The measure is before committees in both houses. The likelihood of the measure becoming law is very doubtful, however. Rae Hutton, a spokeswoman for the acting governor, Donald DiFrancesco, said that the governor liked the idea of the bill but was reluctant to support it without the backing of business interests in the state.
In opposing the bill, the South Jersey Chamber of Commerce called it disruptive to the workplace and said it would cripple small businesses. The New Jersey Business and Industry Association, which represents more than 16,000 businesses, had a three-person delegation fan out on Monday afternoon among the newspaper offices in the State House, where they spelled out how the bill could drain the state's unemployment fund.
The state now has a balance of $3.158 billion in the unemployment fund, which comes from taxes collected from workers and employers. Under the terms of the measure being considered, the commissioner of labor could deny aid if more than $130 million was spent on paid-family leave to prevent the fund from shrinking too rapidly.
Though workers pay a fixed rate, each business pays a different amount based on such factors as the number of people laid off and the amount of money in the unemployment fund.
Gregory Williams, a research analyst for the Office of Legislative Services, said the fund would have to dip at least $650 million before businesses would be pushed into a higher tax rate.
The New Jersey Business and Industry Association said the cost of the bill could run as high as $260 million a year if all the people eligible to do so took off 12 weeks, though the Office of Legislative Services placed the cost at about $100 million.
One businessman, Lou Roth, president of Wats Room Inc., a market research company with 300 employees in Rochelle Park, said the bill would force him to spend $8,000 to find and train about 20 new workers.
Mr. Roth also questioned the fairness of using funds intended for the unemployed to help those who just had a child.
"It's a personal issue to have a child," he said. "There's no reason why they should be funded by unemployment insurance funds which are paid by employees and employers."
Nonetheless, Assemblywoman Vandervalk said there was time to get some business groups to support the measure, suggesting that the state incorporate a tax cut for business, or decreasing the amount of paid leave that workers should get.
"We have to talk," she said. "There is still room for negotiation."

The next day, Donald DiFrancesco, the acting governor took his place there. (Photographs by Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; 
Micheaux Film at Newark Museum

BYLINE:  By Margo Nash 

 BODY:
 Just a few years after D. W. Griffith made "Birth of a Nation" in 1915, the African-American filmmaker Oscar Micheaux, a former coal miner and Pullman porter, started making films. In them, African-Americans are portrayed with dignity in roles of authority in contrast to the typical stock characters of the day. 
Micheaux's genres included drama, musicals and films about social themes, and he directed over 40 films between 1918 and 1948. On Saturday Feb. 10 at 2 p.m. the Newark Museum will screen, one of Micheaux's silent films, "The Symbol of the Unconquered" (1920). The drummer Max Roach will provide the percussive accompaniment to the film he performed once before on television. Pearl Bowser, co-author of a book about Micheaux published last fall, "Writing Himself Into History: Oscar Micheaux, His Silent Films, and His Audience," (Rutgers University Press) will also be there to discuss Micheaux and sign copies of her book. In her book, Ms. Bowser wrote that "The Symbol of the Unconquered" reveals the economic underpinnings of the Ku Klux Klan. Michele Parchment, manager of public programs, who also coordinates the Newark Black Film Festival, said of Micheaux, "He is one of our silent heroes when we are dealing with African-American history." Margo Nash
