HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
Waiting at theGate For Trade With Cuba

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
THE Havana harbor has been a forbidden port of call for American ships since the United States imposed its economic embargo on Cuba in the early 1960's, and not much was expected to change after Congress enacted a law last fall lifting the embargo just enough to allow the first sales of food and medicine. The new law imposed such severe restrictions on financing that nobody expected any deals.
 But the law, to take effect in a month, may allow American companies to sell a surprising variety of products to Cuba, ranging from fertilizer and cigarettes to washing machines and live sheep. And some deals may be small enough so that the Cubans can afford to buy the products without borrowing, which would bypass the financing restrictions. 
 There's a catch -- two actually. One is the Bush administration, which will draft the final regulations to carry out the law and has a much tougher view of Cuba than the Clinton administration did. Second is Cuba itself. Cuba officially views American products as symbols of oppression and has vowed not to buy so much as a grain of American rice or a single box of Rice Krispies. 
As a result, the diplomatic and commercial tug of war between Washington and Havana will largely determine the extent to which American companies can break into the market that Canada, Mexico and other countries have had to themselves for 40 years. 
The effort to punch a hole through the embargo has as much to do with commercial interests as with politics. American farmers and food producers pushed for an end to the sanctions and want government agencies to interpret the new law as broadly as possible. They hope that even with the financing restrictions, the United States will gain a toehold in a market worth $1.6 billion a year in sales of food and medicine. 
But the Cuban government is upset by financing restrictions added at the last minute by Representative Lincoln Diaz-Balart, a Republican from Miami, and other legislators who opposed weakening the embargo. The restrictions prevent American companies and banks from extending credit directly to Cuban buyers.
"Our country will not acquire one penny worth of food or medicine in the United States," said an editorial in Granma, the official newspaper of Cuba's Communist Party. The financing conditions were called humiliating and unjust and the government convoked more than half a million people in Havana to protest.
Still, American food producers are trying to persuade the Cubans to make some purchases and prove that the country is a viable market; otherwise, the producers say, support for lifting the embargo completely will shrivel.
"We're working very hard to get a shipment into Cuba this year," said Audrae Erickson, a trade policy specialist at the American Farm Bureau Federation in Washington, which represents the big grain growers in the United States. "We believe we can do cash transactions with Cuba if we can resolve some of the outstanding political issues that Cuba has." 
BUT Fidel Castro is known for contrariness concerning the embargo, which he has used for decades to fan resentment against Washington. 
Pamela S. Falk, a trade expert at the City University of New York School of Law who is advising several companies interested in doing business with the Cubans, said Mr. Castro might feel threatened by the partial lifting of the embargo. Economic necessity may force him to do business with the United States, she said, especially because Cuba has trouble with other suppliers. 
Ms. Falk noted, for example, that Cuba's wheat-for-sugar barter arrangement with France had faltered because of Cuban credit problems, which could lead Mr. Castro to seek an alternative. France has decided to withhold $160 million in credits for the purchase of wheat and flour until Cuba repays millions in debts. 
American producers may also be able to make offers that the Cubans find hard to refuse. Cuba's proximity to the United States means that transportation costs would be far less than for shipments coming across the Atlantic. For example, the Agriculture Department estimates that Cuba will buy more than 450,000 tons of rice this year. American rice producers, who are expected to be first in line to complete deals, have said they could sell rice to Cuba at about half the price it pays to buyrice from Vietnam and China, two of Cuba's biggest suppliers.
If the Cubans buy, the range of goods they may choose is much broader than the term "food and medicine" suggests. John S. Kavulich II, president of the U.S.-Cuba Trade and Economic Council, a business group that focuses on Cuba, said that despite appearances, the legislation represented a real loosening of the embargo. "By anyone's definition, the commercial landscape between the two countries has radically changed."
The law lifts sanctions on sales of food and medicine not only to Cuba, but also to Iran, Libya, North Korea and Syria. The president can decide to lift financing restrictions on the other four countries, but not for Cuba.
Under the law, American companies may sell food and medical supplies to anyone in Cuba -- including government agencies and tourist hotels. But the financing restrictions mean that business must be done in cash or with financing provided by a bank in a third country. The law prohibits the United States government from extending export credits to Cuban buyers, and no American company or bank may provide financing.
Supporters of the restrictions called them necessary to protect United States banks from Cuba's bad credit risk. Over the last few years, Cuba has not paid some debts to European creditors. "We're talking about what is essentially a deadbeat country," said Thomas M. T. Niles, president of the U.S. Council for International Business, a business organization in Washington.
But the Cuban-American congressmen who led the effort to impose restrictions also believed they would be so onerous that the embargo, in effect, would remain intact. 
That may not be the case. The final regulations, still under discussion, may permit foreign subsidiaries of some American banks to extend credit to Cuba. However, they are unlikely to be permitted to work hand in hand with their affiliates in the United States. 
Last month, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, and other senators introduced a bill to lift the financing restrictions and encourage greater sales of food and medical products to Cuba. 
Regulators are using a broad definition of food that includes not just grains, but also livestock, meat, fish and a long list of other products derived from basic foods. These may include beer, wine, cigarettes, seeds and fertilizer. The list is expected to exclude pesticides, agricultural equipment and bottled drinking water, which is not considered an agricultural product. 
Processed foods like snacks, cookies and breakfast cereals are expected to be permitted. Because these goods tend to be shipped in smaller quantities than grains, Cubans may be more likely to pay for them in cash and not need financing. 
Despite the dire condition of the Cuban economy, the country does have limited access to dollars. The 1.4 million people of Cuban origin in the United States send $500 million to $800 million a year to relatives in Cuba, and those dollars enter the Cuban economy. Cuba's growing tourism industry also gladly accepts dollars as payment.
"We actually believe Cuba will be a good market for consumer products, especially snack foods, breakfast cereals, sodas and things like that," said Sarah A. Fogarty, director of international trade at the Grocery Manufacturers of America. "We believe we will be selling more to the market, but under some limited conditions, and we'll be looking to the new Congress for a bit more." 
THE definition of medicines and medical supplies is interpreted broadly under the new law. It includes all pharmaceutical drugs, as well as ambulances, operating tables and the institutional washing machines used in hospitals. It excludes desks for doctors and other furniture that could be used outside a hospital, as well as vitamins and supplements.
The definition, however, leaves room for confusion. For example, it is unclear whether the Cubans can buy surgical gowns, which may be classified as clothing, not as medical equipment.
Shipping is another confusing issue. The new law does not address older laws that prohibit any vessel that calls on a Cuban port from entering a harbor in the United States for 180 days. The shipping restriction currently can be waived by the Treasury secretary, and many food producers believe those same waivers can probably be applied under the new law. But until the regulations are published, they cannot be sure. 
Writing regulations for a federal law is always complicated. But it is especially so in this case, because it involves sanctions and coincides with a change in administrations with differing views.
Former President Bill Clinton favored at least a partial lifting of the ban on American trade with Cuba that was first imposed by President Dwight Eisenhower in 1960 and tightened by John F. Kennedy in 1962. During the presidential campaign last year, Mr. Bush took a hard line on Cuba, saying in a speech in August that until it "frees political prisoners, and holds free elections and allows free speech, I will keep the sanctions in place." 
Mr. Bush, however, has said he intends to pay more attention to Latin America than did Mr. Clinton. And his new attorney general, John Ashcroft, was one of the principal sponsors of the law lifting some of the sanctions on Cuba.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MARINE PARK; 
They Dislike a Tract's Weeds, But Oppose Shops Even More

BYLINE:  By HOPE REEVES 

 BODY:
If there's one thing everyone agrees on, it's that the tract isn't pretty. But what should be done with the patch of ugly weeds and scattered trees at the intersection of the Belt Parkway and Flatbush Avenue?
 "The last thing we need is another mall," said Dorothy Turano, district manager of Community Board 18, about possible commercial development. "There is no way our community could withstand the extra traffic and pollution." 
 But a shopping center seems to be coming. Philips International, developers, has teamed up with Toys "R" Us and Kristal Automall to build Shoppes at Mill Basin, several acres of one- and two-story businesses that will include a chain bookstore, restaurant and office supply store.
A contract with the Economic Development Corporation, steward of the city-owned land abutting Four Sparrows Marsh and the Gateway National Recreation Area, has been drafted and should be signed within the next three weeks, said Renee Sacks, a Philips spokeswoman. "It's going to be a very high-class, Long Island-looking" place, she said. "It will have all the amenities." The plan also calls for various traffic measures, like the addition of a new laneto Flatbush Avenue's three lanes and more traffic lights.
The development corporation confirmed it was negotiating with Philips but would not comment further.
"You can't just come into the community without talking to us about it," said Mike Steffens, president of the Friends of Marine Park, a nonprofit group. "We're the ones who are going to have to deal with this thing. We've just planted a couple hundred trees there. It should be green space, not concrete."
Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern said his agency was negotiating with the development corporation to create a buffer zone of trees and shrubs to protect an ecologically important marshland that adjoins the site.
Even if a shopping center is built, Mr. Steffens doubts that it will succeed. "The community has said it doesn't want it," he said, "and there are almost the exact same stores at Kings Plaza, less than half mile away." HOPE REEVES

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Susanne Connolly Brian Kanaga

 BODY:
For many couples, choosing an elopement over a big, splashy wedding offers certain pluses. For instance, there's no need for a cake or to emulate the stiffly dressed plastic couple perched atop it. Elopements also promise a certain simplicity -- a simplicity that nonetheless managed to elude this couple. 
 When Susanne Marie Connolly and Brian W. Kanaga of Narberth, Pa., were married on Friday in the Manhattan chambers of Justice Stephen G. Crane, a State Supreme Court judge, they did so without informing their families. But part of their plan was a Saturday surprise reception for everyone at Astra, a Manhattan restaurant. And luring their families to Manhattan without telling them the reason proved to be extraordinarily complicated. 
 Ms. Connolly, 33, who will keep her name, is an associate at Salvo, Russell, Fichter & Landau, a law firm in Blue Bell, Pa. She graduated magna cum laude from Colgate and received her law degree from New York University. She is a daughter of Elizabeth Freeman of West Yarmouth, Mass., and John Connolly of Staten Island. 
Mr. Kanaga, also 33, is a quantitative researcher at the Susquehanna Investments Group, an options trading firm in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. He graduated summa cum laude from Johns Hopkins and received a master's degree magna cum laude in economics from Princeton. He is the son of Linda Elliott of Colorado Springs and Robert Kanaga of Fort Worth, and the stepson of Dixon Elliott. 
Ms. Connolly and Mr. Kanaga met in August 1997 on a blind date. By August 1999, the couple had decided to marry, but they didn't buy an engagement ring or tell anyone, Ms. Connolly said, "because then, people would start asking when we'd be getting married." She added that they thought "a sort of a reverse surprise party" would be fun. "We're old enough that our parents shouldn't have to be involved in planning our wedding," she said.
The couple's plans to marry privately were made with the best of intentions, but uncovered a minefield of unexpected events. At most surprise parties, the guests must keep the secret and only one cover story must be concocted, for the guest of honor. Turning the concept on its head was no simple matter. 
It was easy to keep the plan from the bridegroom's far-flung family. "Because I'm so busy with work, they're used to fitting in with my schedule," said Mr. Kanaga, whose previous marriage ended in divorce. 
But how to keep the secret from the bride's tightly knit gregarious family while ensuring they would all be in the same place at the same time? To further thicken the plot, Ms. Connolly's brother, John, had already learned of the elopement (his wife is the best friend of one of Ms. Connolly's best friends). "I grilled him every week to make sure he's not leaking information," Ms. Connolly said, with a laugh. 
As the couple's plan went into high gear, they needed a whole slew of stories to ensure that the couple's family members would not make other plans for the weekend. They had the best friend of Ms. Connolly's father invite him to a wildly expensive dinner on Feb. 2 at Alain Ducasse, the Manhattan restaurant. Ms. Connolly's sister, Cathy Ehrreich, and her husband, who live in West Yarmouth, were invited for a weekend visit with the couple in Manhattan. For an aunt and uncle who live in Florida, she first reserved their time by telling them she was going to visit them. Other plans -- also worthy of a 30's screwball comedy -- were concocted for Ms. Connolly's mother. 
Everything was going well until Ms. Connolly's sister called the aunt and uncle in Florida.
"My sister didn't understand how I could be in two places at once," Ms. Connolly recalled. "She didn't understand why I had invited her to New York when I was going to be in Florida." 
Adding another fictional tale to the mounting pile, the sister and brother-in-law were told their uncle had the dates wrong, Ms. Connolly said. She then told the aunt and uncle that the "real" reason she wanted to see them was for a surprise engagement party -- to be held, by the way, in New York. She bought them tickets and begged them not to tell anyone. 
Closer to their wedding weekend, the couple began to reel out the engagement cover story to the family. Each was told to keep the news a secret from the others. But with every turn, the risks of someone inadvertently revealing their plan grew. 
"I still keep a place in Manhattan, and my father occasionally stays there," Ms. Connolly said. "The wedding band called and left a long detailed message on the answering machine there." Fearful that her father would intercept one of these calls, she said, "I began checking my messages faithfully every three hours." 
She added, with a note of exhaustion, "It was more complicated than I thought."

HEADLINE: A True Depression Doll 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Latest Economic Indicator: A Depression Doll Is Hot" (Jan. 7). Flossie Flirt, a doll whose eyes moved sideways as well as up and down, was given to me on my sixth birthday in 1931. Several months later, my dad's company folded and like millions of other breadwinners during the Depression era, he was unable to find employment. 
 With rapidly dwindling savings and no job prospects, my parents decided we would have to drive back East to live with my 81-year-old grandfather in Lancaster County, Pa. Flossie, our clothing and the few small personal effects that could be squeezed into a beat-up Ford went with us.
We moved from a bungalow with all the modern conveniences of that day to a 100-year-old farmhouse with no indoor plumbing. From attending Minneapolis's Tuttle School, featuring progressive education, I went to a one-room schoolhouse with a single teacher for eight grades.
Within the next five years, we shuttled back and forth between small apartments in Lancaster and my granddad's home in Washington Borough. My dad had several short-term jobs as a timekeeper for W.P.A. roadwork crews and surveying gullies for the C.C.C. Mostly, he had no employment.
The only constant in my life was Flossie. By the time I was 12, Flossie had no hair and the enamel on her face had cracked from hundreds of washings. I still adored her.
As of 1937, my dad had a good job in New York and we were renting a house in Forest Hills for $32 a month.
A 12-year-old child whose constant companion was a raggedy doll must have been an embarrassment and a worry for her parents. At my dad's gentle but firm insistence, we wrapped my Flossie in tissue paper and placed her high on a shelf in my bedroom closet.

NANCY FINLEY
Brooklyn

HEADLINE: SENIORITY; 
Talking BackIs Good Medicine

BYLINE:  By FRED BROCK; Fred Brock is an editor at The Times. His column on the approach and arrival of retirement appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: fbrock@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TWO years ago, Esther Weiss traveled from her home in Encino, Calif., to her hometown of Kansas City, Mo., to help celebrate her sister's 90th birthday. Upon arriving, she found that her older sister was suffering from painful, and untreated, gastric distress after eating.
 So Mrs. Weiss, now 79, recalled confronting her sister's doctor about the problem: "He said to me, 'Well, what do you expect at her age?' I told him I had read about this problem and some possible treatments on the Internet. He told me I shouldn't read so much. I went ballistic. I know people who are 90 and don't have this problem. I demanded they find out what was wrong. So they did some tests, discovered my sister had acid reflux and put her on the proper medication. After that the problem was under control." 
 That doctor's attitude toward Mrs. Weiss and her sister may not represent that of a majority of physicians. But it does point to an issue that is troubling to many older people: doctors who may be dismissive toward the elderly and their problems.
Well, such doctors had better brace themselves, because the baby boomers, the oldest of whom are now turning 55, are on the verge of becoming the latest crop of older patients. Dr. Richard W. Besdine, the director of the Center for Gerontology and Health Care Research at Brown University, calls the boomers "very demanding, with high expectations of being continuously informed in achieving their goals of optimum health."
"Doctors who don't like questions," he added, "ain't seen nothing yet!"
And in about a month, the pharmaceutical giant Pfizer will put into the hands of many older patients a tool that will make life a bit more difficult for dismissive physicians. It is a series of lists of very specific questions for elderly patients to ask their doctors about common illnesses.
The lists are a result of a three-year study by Pfizer and the Rand Corporation aimed at improving the quality of care for older Americans. The questions will cover 12 conditions, including hypertension, diabetes and pneumonia, and will be contained in pamphlets that doctors can display in their offices. The questions will also be on a Pfizer Web site (www.pfizerforliving.com); some pamphlets will be mailed to patients. Doctors are receiving detailed, technical fact sheets on conditions covered by the study.
The consumer pamphlet on hypertension, or high blood pressure, for example, explains the disease and possible treatment. Then it lists questions that a patient should ask his or her doctor, including these: What is my blood pressure? What should it be? How often should I have it checked? Should I buy a home blood pressure monitor? If taking medication, what should I do if I miss a dose? Are there any side effects I should be aware of? If I take other medications, are there any drug interactions I should be aware of?
The questions from the pamphlet on diabetes include these: How can I know I'm controlling my blood sugar correctly? Are my kidneys O.K.? Am I supposed to be on a medicine to help protect my kidneys?
ROBIN P. HERTZ, an epidemiologist at Pfizer and director of the study -- called Acove, for Assessing the Care of Vulnerable Elders -- said she hoped that encouraging older patients to ask questions would not irritate too many doctors.
"Doctors and managed-care organizations are requesting the fact sheets from this study," she said. "So far, 900,000 have been distributed to the medical community. It's a real major step toward improving the care of older people. But we are trying to smooth out the program so it doesn't take the physician by surprise."
She also echoed Dr. Besdine's remarks about the baby boomers, and emphasized that older patients made up a big part of most doctors' practices.
It remains to be seen how effectively patients will use the questions. Mrs. Weiss, for instance, says many older people are just not as aggressive as she is. "They grew up in an era when the doctor was God," she said. "Well, he's not. So I think a list of questions could be very helpful."
Sidney Reznick, 81, a comedy writer who lives in West Hollywood, Calif., and has worked for the likes of Jackie Gleason and Johnny Carson, describes himself as an introvert who would be helped by a list of questions. "The problem with some doctors and institutions is that they treat old people like a cliche," he said. "They figure you're over the hill. They don't listen. This might get their attention."
Dr. Hertz said the Pfizer-Rand study does not in any way direct doctors or patients toward drugs made by Pfizer. Dr. Besdine, 60, who is an unpaid member of the study's advisory board, agreed."I don't think Pifzer has gotten any more noble," he said. "It's just that they know that most health care professionals, as well as the public and the media, are very savvy when it comes to reading between the lines when something is a commercial message. Trying to push their drugs would undermine their primary goal of being recognized as a drug company that cares about the health of older people. They're smarter than that."

GRAPHIC: Photo (Daniel Vasconcellos)

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Will Doctors Make Your Credit Sick?

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
KATHLEEN McNALLY knows a thing or two about bad credit. She is vice president for financial literacy at the National Foundation for Credit Counseling, an association of 1,500 agencies that help people with financial problems.
 But even she was taken aback when a second notice from her family doctor was a letter threatening to turn over her bill to a collection agency. She would have paid the first bill, she said, but decided to wait because there was confusion over whether her insurance company had yet paid its portion. After she learned that she was responsible for the amount, she said, "I paid that bill that very night." 
 Back in the quaint old days -- say, five years ago -- when one person in the doctor's office pecked out a handful of notices a day, an unpaid bill was handled a bit more delicately. There were phone calls and there was gentle hectoring, much of it directed at the insurance companies.
But doctors, hospitals, laboratories and other providers are taking tougher approaches to seeing that bills are paid. Tired of waiting for insurance companies to cough up and angry that their office workers have taken on piles of bill-collecting paperwork, many of them are now turning to collection agencies. 
"Without a doubt, an increasing amount of claims from providers are going to collections," said Robert Perez, senior vice president of RevCare, which manages health care claims. His company, in Cypress, Calif., tends to go after insurance companies. Mr. Perez estimates that 25 to 30 percent of his business is "insurance follow-up"; five years ago, it was closer to 10 percent. But many agencies, he added, are also leaning increasingly on patients. 
"Ten years ago, these claims never came to us," Mr. Perez said. "But now, with managed-care companies using every excuse to delay the adjudication, there is frustration." Companies like his also take the paperwork load off of doctors' clerical workers, he said. "Providers figure they need to concentrate their people because they are not staffed to work 10,000 claims per month," he said. 
The American Collectors Association says that far more health care providers are turning over their accounts to agencies 30 to 60 days after a missed payment, instead of the customary 150 to 210 days.
Often, the notices go to patients, and their credit can be tainted in the process.
Unlike car payments, health care claims are rarely straightforward. Medical providers and insurance companies argue over coding and other technicalities that can hold up payments for months. Hospitals lose payment records. Laboratories do not have insurance information on file. Patients and their insurers disagree about what services are allowed, and haggle for months while the collection agencies swoop down. And, yes, patients sometimes feel a moral right to ignore bills that they feel their insurance company should have picked up, even when it is clear that the company will not.
Chat rooms and consumer-advice columns in local newspapers are full of stories of this sort: A woman has a Caesarean section and cannot understand why her insurance company finds anesthesia optional for the procedure. While she argues, she watches the notices pile up.
Some states have laws regulating how long insurance companies may wait before making a payment; others protect consumers from having their credit reports tainted by unpaid medical bills.
New York State, for instance, has the "prompt pay law," which requires insurance companies to pay undisputed claims within 45 days. Since the law was signed in 1997, the state Department of Insurance has fined 30 insurance companies a total of almost $1 million for failure to comply.
California requires insurers to pay interest on late payments. "Prompt payment laws are becoming more prevalent," said Allen Briskin, a health care lawyer at Davis Wright Tremaine in San Francisco. 
HERE is the advice of the professionals like Ms. McNally: Understand what your health plan covers before you go into the hospital; this should prevent unpleasant surprises. If you are fighting a claim with an insurance company, let your doctors know immediately, so they will not submit your bill to an agency. Answer letters from collection agencies promptly with phone calls and letters that will go on file as contested, and do the same with any tainted credit report. In New York and most other states, doctors are not permitted to bill a patient if the H.M.O. does not pay up. 
And check your credit report annually. Credit counseling services like the Incharge Institute can advise you how (www.incharge.org). "There is a tendency with doctors to sell their debts quicker as they look at shorter-term bottom lines," said Tim Raftis, vice president of Incharge. "But that can damage consumers' credit reports. Sometimes they are unaware because they are not monitoring their report all the time."

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
Eight Million Stories in Dodge City (Jury Dodging, That Is)

BYLINE:  By LAURA PEDERSEN 

 BODY:
ASK New Yorkers anything about jury duty -- how one gets picked, how to be excused -- and you'll get a hundred different survivalist stories.
 There is certainly plenty of raw material. Each day computerized summonses from the State Supreme Court land in city mailboxes, 10,000 a week in Manhattan alone, "inviting" recipients to show up on such-and-such a date, followed by bright red letters that threaten: "Willful disobedience of this summons is a criminal contempt of court and is punishable by a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both." 
 Many New Yorkers, their Filofaxes and Day-Runners bulging at the seams, would move heaven and earth to get out of this job. 
I was a 19-year-old innocent when I received my first court communique, in the mid-80's, after having moved to Manhattan from upstate. The summons so intimidated me that I arrived early at the courthouse on Centre Street and was directed to a cavernous waiting area. 
There seemed to be two factions. The first was abuzz with how to get on a jury. Naively, I insinuated myself into this group because they seemed so cheery. They had brought along breakfast, newspapers and sewing projects. They were mostly Civil Service employees, teachers, retirees and young women who made no secret that they lived on welfare and wanted the stipend, then $15 a day. 
But when my new cohorts spoke wistfully of friends who had managed to be empaneled an entire year, I shuddered. I had a new job as a trading floor clerk at the American Stock Exchange and attended New York University at night. I now glanced at the other group, surly and melancholic, weighed down with armfuls of reading material, lining up at the pay phones. One of my people waved at them and said: "Oh, they're just trying to get off. And they will."
Whoops! As nice as my new friends were, given my schedule, I was clearly in the wrong pew. So I scampered over to the disgruntled group. They weren't welcoming, least of all the men who were converting their benches into work stations. One man had even brought along his secretary, for dictation. 
Now, 16 years later, hard-driving New Yorkers are still resisting the call of the jury. But the rules of the game have changed, thanks to some mid-90's initiatives by the New York State chief judge, Judith S. Kaye. Jurors who are not paid by their employers now receive $40 a day. Better yet, prospective jurors are now guaranteed a first postponement by phone, may be able to get more in person, and are even asked to choose a convenient time to serve.
Also, the sources used to find jurors have been broadened to include not only voter and car-registration lists -- the main sources previously -- but also tax returns and public-benefit records. This change has enlarged the jury pool and lengthened the minimum interval between summonses, from about two years to about four.
But gone are the exemptions for doctors, lawyers, politicians, embalmers and the self-employed. Even mayors must serve, as Mayor Giuliani did in a personal-injury case in 1999. 
In fact, there are only two exemptions left besides a medical disability (and be aware that many show up, usually in vain, with bad-back X-rays and Prozac prescriptions). You can claim financial hardship -- mere loss of income doesn't fly -- if you bring in tax returns and documentation of employment status. Or if you can prove that you are the primary caretaker of small children or of an incapacitated relative.
These changes have challenged the ingenuity of many ambitious New Yorkers. Consider my old colleagues, the Wall Street traders, whose livelihood depends upon being there from opening to closing bell.
I remember a clerk named Roy, who earned about $30,000 to wait in line for all of us at the Department of Motor Vehicles and the post office, and was even sent out to videotape missed Little League games. Of course that was all legal. But at times Roy was also sent out for someone's jury duty. This was not legal.
 REMINISCENT of the old Civil War dodge -- back then, draftees could pay others to take their place in uniform -- this tactic may be more tempting under the new jury rules. And the fact is that no one checks your ID at the courthouse.
But you are under oath when you state your name and address. "It's perjury and a misdemeanor punishable by a hefty fine or jail" to lie in that situation, said Brian Maxey, director of the Citizens Jury Project, a court monitoring group. In 1994, one bond trader, Andrew Levinson, was sentenced to 500 hours of community service for trying to have his auto mechanic replace him for jury duty. 
"We hear this a lot," said Mr. Maxey of people's pleas to let them pay others, or pay higher taxes, to skirt jury service. "But it doesn't work, because by narrowing the pool in this manner, then it's no longer a jury of your peers." 
A television news anchor has used a different approach for years. Once he was excused during voir dire for interrogating the lawyer and being "generally obnoxious," he said. Another time he arrived in an N.Y.P.D. T-shirt carrying a beach chair and a radio. He told the clerk he would be outside and just to holler if he was needed. He was not needed.
Still, outlandish props like the Mr. Peanut suit, the bizarre religious rituals and the hemorrhoid pillow -- all real examples -- seldom work, said one trial lawyer. What succeeds most, he said, is saying that you feel you must follow your conscience and not the law.
A stockbroker said he had had success over the years by telling the judge how much he looked forward to serving. "Because from working on Wall Street," he would say, "I have the ability to tell when a person is guilty by looking at his eyes. People with shifty eyes are always lying." The broker was never given the chance to test his theory.
Peter LaBadia, a retired stockbroker, accidentally stumbled into his escape from jury duty. His handwriting was simply awful and his completed jury questionnaire was always returned. Finally, after some years, believing that English was not Mr. LaBadia's primary language, the court clerk offered to send an interpreter. Mr. LaBadia replied, in his usual handwriting.
Then comes the throwaway strategy. I remember a trader who tossed her summons into the garbage. "I've been deep-sixing them for 10 years," she blithely announced. "How are they going to prove I received it? It's not registered mail." 
Right she was. She is not alone. Eight to 10 percent of those who receive a summons in Manhattan are no-shows. Still, you are taking your chances with such behavior. Every Friday there are hearings at the courthouse at which people who have ignored three consecutive summonses can be fined from $5 to $250.
"You tend to be fined on the lower end if you sign a promise to serve at a later date," Mr. Maxey said. "But if you're indignant and stress how important you are, then you tend to get fined the full amount."
I know what you're thinking. What if I don't show up for the scofflaw hearing either? If not, the court imposes a $250 lien against you. Now just try getting a mortgage.
And what about that threat of prison? Vincent Homeneck, chief clerk of the jury division of Manhattan State Supreme Court for the last seven years, could not recall any no-show who had gone to jail. But he remembered one sitting juror who was sentenced to 10 days for chronic lateness at a 1996 murder trial.
 WHERE is the guilt and the shame? After all, jury duty is "the essence of democracy," said Julia Vitullo-Martin, who is a founder of the Citizens Jury Project and is writing a book about jury duty. "Serving on a jury is to judicial process what voting is to the executive process." 
Perhaps in a freewheeling economy in which time is precious, we view the summons as we would a call at 3 a.m. from the Transportation Department saying, "O.K., it's your turn to plow the roads." 
Still, a duty is a duty. When Andrew Schwarz, a partner in a Wall Street trading company, got the call about three years ago, he had every intention of sidestepping jury service.
"Then the judge gives this speech about how he fought for this country and a lot of his buddies didn't come back and he hopes we'll all take the time to do our duty," Mr. Schwarz said. "He was right. After that I was prepared to stay nights and weekends."

HEADLINE: Here Come the Kids: Gen Y Invades the Workplace 

BYLINE:  By NELSON MUI 

 BODY:
THE other night, I went to a party with a 22-year-old colleague. We were covering the celebrity-happy event for our online news service, Fashion Wire Daily. After surveying the crowd, my co-worker asked what she should do next.
"There's Bret Easton Ellis, and he's alone," I said. "You can start by talking to him."
 She looked puzzled. "Who's Bret Easton Ellis?" 
 "You remember -- the book and the movie 'Less Than Zero?' "
Her face remained blank. After I mentioned "American Psycho," the movie made last year from Mr. Ellis's 1990 novel, she muttered, "Oh." She passed up the chat with him.
Amused, I later regaled a few office mates with our colleague who had never heard of Mr. Ellis, the onetime literary enfant terrible and gossip-column fixture -- but I got the same blank stares. Then it dawned on me: at 30, I am a different generation from half my office. We have a full-time columnist who is barely out of her teens, and one of our junior editors could not rent a car for a weekend trip to Boston because at 24 he is a year too young. 
I often find myself explaining pop references from the not so distant past. When hits from Depeche Mode or New Order come on the radio, someone always asks, "Who is this?" Curiously, there is only selective ignorance of the 80's. The happy, bubblegum music of Banarama and Duran Duran remains popular with 20-somethings, as the forerunners of singers like Britney Spears. Angst-ridden groups like the Smiths or Nirvana will apparently have to wait for a VH1 "Behind the Music" special for resurrection. 
Interacting with younger colleagues has made me realize that I am not, and never will be, one of the self-assured, relentlessly sunny, multitasking young people labeled Generation Y. 
While marketing gurus and management experts have begun studying this wave as it enters the workplace, I have been living it -- at the forefront of the latest generation gap. I'm seeing everything that has been predicted about Generation Y: the warp-speed processing of information, the need to speed through careers, the self-esteem on steroids.
As each generation misunderstands the next, the flashpoint today is the belief among many managers of my generation, Generation X, that these happy, glib youngsters are arrogant and entitled. "They often act as if they're doing you a favor by working for you," said Jason Lundy, 31, a marketing director in New York. Jill Mittelhauser, 30, a communications executive in Boston, called some young people she works with "brazen." 
For their part, Generation Y'ers who have reached the workplace often say their immediate elders are needlessly downbeat. "They don't want to be associated with X'ers," said Neil Howe, the author with William Strauss of "Millennials Rising" (Vintage Books, 2000), a study of the young people whose formative years were the 1990's. "They decry their next elders as the most selfish and complaining generation and the least heroic, and a bunch of slackers." 
Mr. Howe and Mr. Strauss define the youngest Americans reaching adulthood, whom they call millennials, as those born since 1982, not yet out of college. Others date the generation from 1977, when births began climbing after a decade of declines. In either case, a generation is shaped more by cultural experiences than strict demographics, and it is clear in many offices that those under, say, 25 represent a different wave. Last month, the Army changed its recruiting slogan after 20 years from "Be All You Can Be" to "An Army of One," to appeal to the individualism of the younger generation. 
Jokes about Gen Y in the workplace are surfacing, including some on a Web page (http://members .home.net/j2cbat/ritalin.html) that offers tips for "dealing with the Ritalin generation." These include posting "speed limits in hallways" and "preparing for vacation time to be accrued in nanoseconds." 
"Be flexible," managers are cautioned. "Attention levels in the Ritalin generation may be so vastly improved that psychic abilities might be awakened. Don't be surprised if your assistant asks you to sign a letter to someone you don't know, dated months in advance."
It is easy to divine the roots of the divide: while Gen X'ers came of age in an era of soaring national debt, predictions of Social Security apocalypse and a bleak job market in the recession of the early 90's, the younger set mostly has memories of economic expansion. Add to this that their parents, the baby boomers, were obsessed with child rearing and car-pooled their progeny to soccer games, tutoring and community service projects to beef up college resumes, and self-esteem, and you have a generation that expects the world at 22. 
For many 30-somethings in a position of managing the new kids on the block, there is wide resentment. Mr. Lundy, who is the executive director of marketing and strategic planning at Esquire, remembers the recession years, when Gen X'ers took dead-end McJobs, or were grateful for any entry-level professional work. He is surprised to see young colleagues bristle at small tasks. 
He recalled asking an assistant to walk a few blocks to deliver vital documents to a client, but the assistant refused. "It was extremely urgent that the client got it right away," Mr. Lundy said. "We're at 55th and Broadway, and the client's office was at 49th and Sixth. When I asked my 22-year-old assistant to run over there, she responded, 'Why are you asking me to do this?' "
Mr. Lundy continued, "After some further prodding, she whined, 'But it's cold out.' " He ended up walking the papers over himself. He has since found a different assistant. "It's great that Gen Y thinks all is right with the world -- it makes for a nice positive attitude," he said. "The problem is these are people who've often had it easy, and it shows."
Susan Portnoy, 35, a publicist in New York, said that while Gen Y'ers are very ambitious and motivated from the start, they also end up seeming extremely impatient. "A lot of them are bald-faced," Ms. Portnoy said. "It's like, 'I haven't done it before, but I want to do it right away.' " She recalled one young woman she hired who asked for a plum assignment within days of starting her job. "She came to me and said, 'I want to be the one who walks Madonna,' for this magazine's launch party," Ms. Portnoy recalled. "I was like, 'No, you're just lucky you get to go to the party.' "
Deborah Rothstein, the executive director for career services at Columbia University, said: "I think there's a general sense of entitlement among Gen Y'ers, which comes from them knowing it's the strongest job market -- they know that if they don't get a job they want, they'll go freelance. A lot of the kids come to me and say, 'I'd like to be making six figures within six months.' They all want to be challenged immediately and expect opportunities for international travel -- within two months of starting work. 
"I've been dealing with this every year for eight years, and it's kind of a shock to see the attitude in recent years. Sometimes you just want to sit them down and give them a reality check."
Perhaps reality is on the way in the form of the first economic downturn in 10 years. If the corporate layoffs making headlines and the Nasdaq collapse lead to full-blown recession, Generation Y may receive its comeuppance, and many members of Gen X will be quietly smirking. 
But so far, the latest dip seems not to be denting Generation Y's optimism or sense of entitlement. Despite a drop in general consumer confidence, unemployment remains at a three-decade low, and last week the Congressional Budget Office predicted 10 more years of economic growth. 
"I think we have a lot more opportunities than the preceding generation," said Tiffany Williams, 18, a student at Baruch College in New York, who works full time as an administrative assistant. Ms. Williams started working at 13 and by 16 "moved on to the office-administrative thing," she said. "Our lives start so much earlier than older peoples' lives -- the minute you graduate from a high school, you can be recruited by a firm and make much more money than the older crowd ever did at our age. The world opens up to us so young -- we network in class, we network at the coffee shop."
Bruce Tulgan, a management consultant who is writing a book to be called "Managing Generation Y," described the youngest members of the work force as "superhigh maintenance" and a generation that is "on fast forward with self-esteem." 
"Young people are given an unprecedented amount of responsibility at an early age," Mr. Tulgan said. "It's a common conflict when young people overestimate themselves, and because they have high expectations, they're going to be a nightmare to manage."
His advice to older supervisors is to try a "coaching style of management." "You'll have to be rigorous with your feedback," he added. "If they say, 'I want to do this big project,' then you'll have to come back and give them a smaller goal, set a deadline, let them tackle it and give them feedback and increasing levels of responsibility."
One difference, and source of potential conflict, is that Gen Y expects office cultures to adapt to them, rather than the reverse. A senior manager in local government in his 40's expressed surprise at his new analyst, 22. "She said she preferred to work in a different way and said she wanted her assignments on short deadlines, as if it were homework," the manager said. "She wanted to recreate her college experience of doing last-minute term papers. It used to be that in the past, incoming employees would try to figure out what the organization wanted and how it functioned."
According to Mr. Tulgan, members of Gen Y view Gen X'ers with a "healthy contempt" as well as a lot of "healthy respect," but also "think they're a little too edgy." A poll conducted for "Millennials Rising" showed teenagers had negative perceptions of Gen X by 2 to 1. 
In that book, Mr. Howe and Mr. Strauss theorize that the differences between the two youngest American generations to come of age trace not only to economics, but also to cultural influences. Raised in the 1970's, Gen X'ers are, Mr. Howe said, children of the "consciousness revolution," a time when Americans were distrustful of institutions, and children were often neglected at the expense of parental self-fulfillment. Gen Y, by contrast, is the "baby on board" generation, raised by prosperous, increasingly conservative, childcentric parents. 
"These kids are happier, and they don't mind talking about it," Mr. Howe said. "They're collectively optimistic about the future -- they think they have a destiny as a generation and think they will play a role in shaping the future. Gen X'ers, however, were collectively pessimistic but individually optimistic."
Stacy Garrick, 23, a graduate of the University of California at Los Angeles who works in a nonprofit organization, said: "I think we're more free spirited than the X'ers. I certainly wouldn't consider myself a cynical person, and I don't think there's much of that in my generation."
She added that there was a downside to the extraordinary pressure to focus on careers at an early age. "At U.C.L.A., there was a big sense of competition, of people who were on track the whole time they're in school," she said. "I know I was concerned about my resume. Even the parents are more involved. They help plan and track their kids' career plans. Perhaps because of all this work, most of the people I graduated with expect to make quite a bit of money. Most of my friends are making in the 40's and 50's already."
For those X'ers and boomers who feel Generation Y might be skipping paying its dues, both Mr. Tulgan and Prof. Jay Conger of the London Business School, another management specialist, advise: get over it. "The older crowd paid their dues at a different kind of country club," Professor Conger said. "It's much more of a free-agent, market-oriented workplace now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jason Lundy, the 30-something director of marketing and strategic planning at Esquire, and Nia Tahani, his new 20-something advertising sales assistant. Gen X and Gen Y coexist warily in the workplace. (Barbara Alper for The New York Times)(pg. 2) Drawings (Robert Zimmerman)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Gladly Taking Criticism, Instead Of Obscurity

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
IT does not bother Steve H. Hanke that he has been called a hustler, a charlatan and a snake-oil salesman. But being referred to as obscure -- that has the power to sting.
 Mr. Hanke is the Johns Hopkins University professor of applied economics who rose from, well, obscurity in 1998 to international recognition as the man who counseled President Suharto on the mechanics of setting up a currency board to stabilize the rupiah, Indonesia's volatile currency. 
 Mr. Suharto never enacted Mr. Hanke's ideas, but for a few months the odd relationship between the dictator and the professor receoved attention around the world, and most of it was negative. Several accounts of Mr. Hanke's forays into Indonesia described him as "an obscure economics professor." Paul Krugman, a well-known economist (and now an Op-Ed page columnist for The New York Times) called him "a snake-oil salesman" and a "rupiah Rasputin."
"I've got to admit, it's a good line," Mr. Hanke said during an interview last week on the Johns Hopkins campus in Baltimore, where he has been a faculty member for 31 years. The battering that he and his reputation took during the Indonesia episode "left a little scar tissue," he said. But it was worth the effort because it focused so much attention on the issue of currency boards, which he refers to as "the cause."
A currency board is a way to stabilize economically shaky nations. Like the old gold standard, it backs up a local currency with reliable reserves. But instead of using gold, a country guarantees its own currency with United States dollars, German marks or some other strong monetary unit.
The boards were first used in English colonies in the 19th century but fell out of favor. Mr. Hanke says he did not know anything about such boards until another Hopkins professor mentioned the idea more than 15 years ago. Since then he has written several books about the boards and has become a monetary Roto-Rooter man, flying off to help far-away countries with big economic problems.
He obviously relishes the role of globetrotting academic. On the day of the interview, Mr. Hanke, 58, wore a white shirt, a paisley ascot and a navy blazer with a large gold stopwatch chain attached conspicuously to his lapel. The chain dangled in the breast pocket of his jacket, without a watch. "It's being cleaned," he explained.
Mr. Hanke said the name-calling and other ridicule of the last few years had not weakened "the cause." Today he is meeting with the president of Montenegro, who has come to Baltimore to discuss currency.
"Since 1849, there's never been a problem with one of these currency boards," he said. "All the academic critiques are about as phony as a three-dollar bill."
Still, the critiques far outnumber the defenses. Most economists view currency boards as last-ditch efforts that can do more harm than good. They say the economic problems in Argentina, for example, are the fault of its currency board system, which pegs the peso one-to-one to the dollar, thus making Argentine exports uncompetitive.
Mr. Hanke, who has advised Argentina's government, contends that its economic woes have nothing to do with the board. "In Argentina, if the weather is bad, critics will blame it on the currency board," he said.
Mr. Hanke says he enjoyed hunting when he was growing up in Iowa, and he still takes a shotgun approach to issues on his hit list. Among his favorite targets are the International Monetary Fund, which he considers incompetent, and the Federal Reserve System, which he thinks should be dismantled. 
If he has been ejected from the club of economists, that's all right with him, because he never considered himself as an economist in the orthodox sense. He stumbled on economics at the University of Colorado and did his doctoral dissertation on measuring the demand for water in municipal systems. Even today, while he holds an appointment in the economics department at Johns Hopkins, he keeps his office in the department of geography and environmental engineering, where he has worked since 1969.
Lately, Mr. Hanke has had to accept the limitations of "the cause" as struggling countries skip the boards and instead adopt foreign currencies to strengthen their economies. Last year, Ecuador and El Salvador did just that with the dollar.
"Economists are debating whether this should happen, but it's already happening," he said, confident in the rightness of his position and the wrongness of others'. He believes that the fuss over his role in Indonesia drew attention to the merits of strong currencies for weak countries, and that this could lead to the day when there are only a handful of currencies in the world. "The best thing about all that's happened to me," he said, "is that the cause is still alive."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: Hedging Your Bets? Look Homeward, Investor 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN David Bowers arrived in New York from London early last year as the new chief global investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, he set about to shake up the firm's view of the world. But he was not prepared for the change he would usher in after months of crunching numbers and examining the interplay of Wall Street and foreign stock markets.
 What he and his colleagues concluded in September -- and announced to little fanfare in November -- was that investing abroad for Americans is nowhere near as good an idea as conventional wisdom dictates. Within days, Merrill Lynch advised its wealthy private clients to limit the foreign stocks in their portfolios to about 5 percent. That is down from the 35 percent recommended by Merrill's previous chief investment strategist, Charles I. Clough Jr. 
 "We have to come to grips with not how we think the world should be, but with how the world works," said Mr. Bowers, who as a British citizen found it difficult to turn his back on foreign stocks. "This is not a negative call on international equities. But we think it's prudent to make the change to a lower international exposure." 
Prudent investors are always trying to balance risk. To hedge against a market downturn in the United States, money-management mavens have long suggested diversifying by sprinkling investment portfolios with overseas assets. Buy Sony, Alcatel or BP Amoco, they have recommended. Then, presumably, as one market or stock goes down, another will go up. 
But Mr. Bowers and other strategists have found that there are better ways to reduce risk -- namely, by choosing industry sectors or other markets, like bonds, that are less in sync with the United States market.
Among those coming to the same conclusion is Nicholas P. Sargen, global market strategist for private clients at J. P. Morgan, now part of J. P. Morgan Chase, who recently lowered his allocation guideline for foreign stocks to 10 percent to 15 percent. "We overrode models that suggested more," he said. Rosemary Sagar, head of global investments at the United States Trust Company, said money managers there were lightening up on international stocks to improve risk reduction.
And while James W. Paulsen, the chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management, which manages money for institutional investors, has not changed his foreign guideline, now around 15 percent, he is watching. If the decline in the benefits of overseas diversification "persists for a period," he added, "it will affect us."
IF American investors heed the new advice, they will buy fewer foreign equities and, in all likelihood, take a new approach to the international equities they do buy. Likely casualties are investment vehicles that became popular in the 1990's: mutual funds that focus on specific countries.
Instead, active money managers and mutual fund managers who apply the sector approach may attract a bigger share of investors' money. If Americans pull back overseas, the impact is likely to be greatest on smaller countries, especially those in emerging markets that hunger for foreign capital. 
The reason for Merrill's about-face is hardly a mystery: nowadays, the performance of foreign stocks is much more highly correlated to that of Wall Street. Since the 1980's, the economic policies of Western nations have been more aligned than ever before. Global barriers against trade and capital flows have fallen. Central banks agree that inflation is the No. 1 enemy, and they are determined to fight it. And the introduction of the euro in 1999 has given Europe a homogeneity it never had. 
In the corporate world, foreign companies watched for years as their American counterparts enjoyed greater prosperity and created more jobs than they did. Now companies everywhere are imitating American management -- cutting costs, increasing productivity and putting profits first. And because of mergers, many more companies, in the United States and abroad, have a global reach.
Just think: Ten years ago, how many Americans had ever heard of Nokia? It was a Finnish phone and electronics company. Now its cell phones blanket the world, and its fortunes rise and fall on global trends, not Finnish ones.
Americans, in truth, have always fallen short of meeting conventional money management guidelines: that they put about 25 percent to 40 percent of their equity portfolios into stocks outside the United States, or 15 percent to 30 percent of their entire portfolios (including bonds). At the end of 1999, for example, American pension funds had 11 percent of their investments abroad, including stocks and bonds, according to the InterSec Research Corporation, while individuals had just 2.3 percent of their money abroad. Many of Merrill's own clients, Mr. Bowers said, do not even have enough foreign stocks to reach its new, lower guideline.
Yet the shift in strategy at Merrill and other brokerage firms -- and the change that it reflects on Wall Street and in the money management business -- is turning decades of conventional wisdom on its head.
It is also a gamble -- and not every brokerage firm or analyst is in agreement. Some argue that the reduced benefits of foreign diversification may be temporary, more a product of the surge and then the fall in technology stocks than of a fundamental change in the way a more global world works. And the move toward sectors, while beneficial, is as much a new marketing tool for Wall Street and mutual funds as it is a fashionable way to pick stocks.
STILL, as the numbers are currently being crunched, there is little question that much of the advantage in investing overseas has been lost, as world markets follow American markets more closely than ever.
"It is very comforting when there is a crash and you have something that isn't going down in another market," said Jeremy J. Siegel, a finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and the author of "Stocks for the Long Run." "But foreign equities won't give you that."
The change has been so abrupt that Mr. Siegel said he would cut his foreign-investment guideline in the newest edition of his book, due late this year. "Correlations have gone up, and I don't think the returns from abroad have gone up enough to compensate for that," he said. The second edition of the book, in 1998, advised that 25 percent of a stock portfolio be invested outside the United States; the new version will recommend no more than 20 percent.
The change is also remaking Wall Street firms, turning their research focus from countries to global sectors like technology, pharmaceuticals and energy.
"If all these countries are looking the same, I have to latch on to something else to differentiate between stocks," said Stefano Cavaglia, head of equity strategy at Brinson Partners in Chicago. "We used to have all our analysts organized on a country line. That's gone. Everything is organized on an industry basis, and all of the country directors have been reassigned." 
Putnam Investments, the mutual fund company in Boston, has also shifted its approach away from concentrating on countries as a stock-picking tool. "Sector is the biggest driving force," said Omid Kamshad, chief investment officer for international core equities at Putnam.
If investors and fund managers no longer pick Germany or Japan as a year's winner, and then buy stocks in that market, they will have to look for winners in, say, banks and autos. They would look globally for the best companies in those sectors, no matter where their headquarters are.
"A company's market capitalization, or the fact that it is part of the technology sector, for example, will become a more significant differentiator than whether the company is listed on the Norwegian or British stock exchange," said Ms. Sagar, another advocate of the sector approach.
New mutual funds based on worldwide sectors are popping up all over. Some 24 global funds were created in 2000 alone, most of them centered on technology, telecommunications, the Internet and health care, according to Strategic Insight, a mutual fund research company. Just two were started in 1999 and nine in 1998. 
Mr. Sargen said the J. P. Morgan Private Bank created global technology, global health care and global financial sector funds last year for its private clients. 
The companies that build indexes, like Morgan Stanley Capital International and Dow Jones, are shaping new sector benchmarks as fast as they can. Morgan Stanley now has 10 global sector indexes for developed markets -- including utilities, telecommunications, consumer staples, health care, industrials and energy. Two weeks ago, it introduced a new group of all-country sector indexes that include emerging markets.
Dow Jones Indexes has had its own global sector indexes since 1994. But Sheldon Gao, its senior director for strategic development, said that "nobody paid attention to our sector indexes at the time." Now interest is so strong that Dow Jones next week will introduce its Global Sector Titans -- 18 indexes, each with the 30 biggest companies worldwide.
EVEN so, some analysts contend that there is no reason for Americans to cut back their investments abroad. They acknowledge that winning the argument may be difficult; after all, over the last six years, the United States stock market has risen 190 percent while those of the rest of the world, taken together, have climbed just 37 percent. 
But these analysts, noting that half of the world's market capitalization is outside the United States, assert that not looking abroad means forfeiting many opportunities.
"I adamantly believe that there are benefits from international diversification that have not been fully appreciated," Mr. Cavaglia said. 
Roger G. Ibbotson, a finance professor at the Yale School of Management and the chairman of Ibbotson Associates, also advises against cutting back -- mostly because Americans have so little invested overseas to begin with. "Correlations have gone up, but nowhere to the extent that we should do less" investing abroad, he said.
Still, the numbers appear to reveal some perils. Not only do foreign markets take many more of their cues from the American market, but they also tend to follow it more closely when Wall Street is declining. And such times are precisely when American investors want diversification protection the most.
When statisticians measure correlations, a "1" is a perfect correlation between two trends, while a "minus 1" is a perfect inverse correlation. A zero means no relation whatsoever. So the closer that the correlation of two markets is to 1, the less the diversification benefit of investing in the two markets.
In the fall of 1993, the correlation between the performance of the American market and the rest of the developed world's markets was as low as 0.145, according to Merrill Lynch. That was the smallest correlation since 1979, when it was as low as 0.07.
The figure moved generally higher, however, later on. In 1995, it was more than 0.3, and in 1997, more than 0.5. Then the correlation surged, to 0.787 by the end of last year, the highest level since the mid-1970's.
Ibbotson Associates, using a slightly more conservative approach than Merrill, put the correlation between the United States and the rest of the world, including emerging markets, at 0.765 at year-end.
Both firms calculated the correlations in dollar terms, incorporating the effects of currency fluctuations on investors here. In any given year, such movements can greatly affect profits or losses for American investors in foreign markets.
Correlations are also rising between the United States market and those of specific regional groups. Consider emerging markets, once regarded as a perfect place for diversification. The Ibbotson data shows that the correlation between emerging markets and the American market rose to 0.66 at the end of last year. It had been as low as 0.18 in 1992 and 0.19 in 1993.
The correlation between European and American markets has been higher over time, and has risen again recently. At the end of last year, it was 0.687, up from 0.451 in mid-1997 and an average of 0.418 in 1981. 
Japan, the major market that has often had least correlation to the United States, has also shown a mini-trend toward following Wall Street's lead. Its correlation was 0.49 at year-end, compared with an average of 0.18 in 1982.
Although these numbers alone undermine the argument for overseas diversification, a recent study adds fuel to the flame. Conducted by Kirt C. Butler, associate professor of finance at Michigan State University, and Domingo Castelo Joaquin, assistant professor of finance at Illinois State University, it shows that when the United States stock market goes into a tailspin, the rest of the world is even more likely to follow.
"An internationally diversified portfolio becomes riskier in bear markets because of higher volatility and greater correlation among national equity market returns," according to the study, which was published last March. In other words, when Wall Street is in a decline, American investors are getting even less risk protection than they thought from buying foreign stocks.
THESE new thoughts about diversification come at an interesting juncture. After the decline in world markets last year, as most followed the United States downward, investors may be more interested in managing their risk.
And that is precisely why Merrill lowered its guideline for foreign stocks to a range of zero to 5 percent for their least aggressive investors. The guideline is 5 percent to 10 percent for their most aggressive investors. In the three categories in between, the guideline is 5 percent.
Instead, Merrill says that an American investor, based on current analyses, can get much better risk reduction by diversifying into the domestic bond market. Based on the Ibbotson data, the correlation between stocks and government bonds has reversed in the last four years. In 1997, the average correlation was 0.49, near its high in the 1970's. At the end of last year, it was 0.12, with an average for the year of 0.17.
Merrill is also sending clients into private equity funds, which often involve venture capital investments. The correlations of those funds to the stock market are also very low, although this avenue of diversification is open to relatively few individuals because of the high minimum investments required.
Mr. Cavaglia of Brinson Partners had another suggestion for individual investors: Look for active money managers "who know that country and sector factors are important." An investor who buys a mutual fund that invests by geography, not sectors, "is not getting the full benefit of the international game," he said.
Putnam, which made the switch to a sector focus in 1997, has not "completely killed off country factors," Mr. Kamshad said. For example, investors who want to buy a foreign utility -- in Spain, for example -- would still have to pay much attention to local economic factors, he said. 
Nonetheless, investing in different sectors provides more diversification benefits, according to analysts who favor a sector approach. Mr. Cavaglia's analysis shows that the correlations among major sectors like technology, health care, energy and financials were down to 0.33 by last August. Although the sector analysis is done differently and is therefore not directly comparable to the correlation of United States and foreign markets, the industry correlations are well below those of a similar analysis he did for countries.
As the new analysis sinks in, the big losers may be funds that focus on a single country.
SOME of the first country funds were closed-end funds, which have a limited number of shares whose price rises or falls in part with shifting demand for those shares. The price also moves, of course, with the direction of the underlying foreign stock market.
Because the performance of a closed-end country fund depends on investors' interest in that country's stocks, there is a premium or a discount in the price of the shares, compared with the value of the underlying stocks. A big discount means that investors do not find the closed-end fund or the country -- or both -- very attractive.
The net assets of closed-end country funds have dropped from a peak of $16.7 billion in 1996 to $10.3 billion last year, according to Michael T. Porter, the country-fund analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. The number of these funds, meanwhile, has declined to 63, representing 27 countries, from 84 in 1995. And they traded at an average discount of 23.9 percent at year-end.
But not everyone is turning against foreign stocks. Mr. Butler, the Michigan State University professor, said his own work had not made him alter his portfolio; it is heavily weighted toward foreign equities. He has held his ground because the rise in correlations between United States and world markets had much to do with the recent rise in market volatility, he said. If that volatility subsides with the bursting of the technology bubble, correlations may fall again.
Mr. Bowers of Merrill Lynch also acknowledges some doubts. He knows that market relationships can change quickly, just as they did in the last few years. "Is this the start of a new world order, or is this just the time to get into international stocks?" he asks.
Then the moment passes, and he heads out to sell his new view of the investing world.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
In Technology, Caution Is Still the Better Part of Wisdom

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
NOW that technology stocks are humming again, investors are settling back into their comfort zone. The tech wreck of 2000 is receding into the mists of distant memory as investors focus on earnings in the second half of 2001 rather than the gloomy here and now. 
 Technology bulls think that earnings declines through June of this year will give way again to growth, albeit anemic, in the third and fourth quarters. According to First Call/Thomson Financial, which tracks analysts' prognostications, earnings among technology companies are forecast to fall by 10.7 percent in the first quarter, compared with a year earlier, and by almost the same amount in the second quarter. But current estimates for the whole year expect 0.7 percent growth. 
 This is a far cry from the 26.4 percent earnings growth that these companies showed in 2000. But shrewd investors know that was yesterday's news. The question today is this: Should investors jump back into technology stocks in anticipation of an earnings rebound? 
Tobias Levkovich, an equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, thinks not. He suspects that capital spending on technology will be slower to recover than many people think, even if the Federal Reserve Board's medicine puts the United States economy back on its feet. 
Mr. Levkovich argues that capital spending programs typically rise and fall with corporate profit margins. In recent years, profit margins were high and technology spending went vertical. But because he expects margins to be under continued pressure throughout the year, he thinks that technology spending will remain desultory. 
"Now you have three different pressures on margins: a slowing economy, high wages and energy prices," he said.
As a result, he thinks that consumer spending, not capital expenditures, will drive any economic re-acceleration that 2001 may bring.
Mr. Levkovich saw another reason for continuing weak demand for technology. The urge among traditional companies to embrace the Internet, he said, is not as primal as it was during the last two years.
"Traditional industry players felt they had to do something with the Internet," he said, "or they'd be the old-economy dinosaur put out of business by the new-economy asteroids." So they threw money at anything Internet. 
Now that the Web has lost some of its wonder, it is no longer quite the spending priority among traditional companies. A result will be a delay in increased demand for technology. 
Mr. Levkovich has surveyed leading telecommunications companies, brokerage firms and cable concerns for their technology spending plans in 2001. He estimates that telecommunications companies, whose capital spending has tripled in the last few years, will spend 5.2 percent less on technology this year than last. While brokerage firms will increase their technology spending this year, they will do so by only 8.2 percent, less than half their rate in 2000. And growth in cable capital expenditures is expected to fall to 8.9 percent this year, from 79 percent last year. 
Nevertheless, investors are fairly optimistic about earnings for technology companies in the second half. Too optimistic, in Mr. Levkovich's view. He said he would not be surprised if earnings guidance from companies becomes more conservative in coming weeks. 
"We just had a pretty good decade for technology," Mr. Levkovich said. "Tech spending went from 3 percent to 5.7 percent of G.D.P. But technology spending is cyclical. And these stocks do need earnings to do well."
