PERSON: Lori Appelbaum 

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
Finding Skeletons in Bank Closets

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
THEY call her the Credit Queen. 
 When corporate bankruptcies started to escalate last year, Lori Appelbaum, the bank-stock analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company, was ready. With contacts and skills gathered a decade ago when she was a loan officer at Chemical Bank, Ms. Appelbaum has been publishing estimates showing which banks hold how much in troubled loans. 
 It is not information banks tend to make public. While banks must disclose the overall size of their loan portfolios, they never divulge the names of borrowers, citing client confidentiality.
But Ms. Appelbaum is not afraid to snoop around and name names. In chatty e-mail messages to clients, she has published lists of banks owning the loans of troubled companies like Sunbeam, Finova, Owens Corning and Xerox. Last summer, she assembled a watch list of corporate America's sick and dying, and she actively monitors the loans of 200 or so companies.
Knowing which banks had large exposures to loans was useful information for investors last year. In the case of Sunbeam, the housewares maker, Ms. Appelbaum sent a note to clients on Oct. 23 describing the company as a "potential problem" for three banks that had lent it a total of $1.7 billion: First Union, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America. 
Three weeks later, when Bank of America and First Union filed their third-quarter earnings reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, they disclosed that by year-end they might be classifying a loan to a large borrower as "nonperforming" -- a euphemism for delinquent.
While neither bank would identify the borrower, it was widely acknowledged to be Sunbeam. As analysts learned of this unpleasant surprise, prices for the shares of both banks fell sharply.
A spokesman for Bank of America and a spokeswoman for First Union declined to comment on Ms. Appelbaum's research. But Thomas Finucane, a manager of the John Hancock Regional Bank fund, said, "She's done a lot of work establishing who's got the hot potatoes." 
Ms. Appelbaum is not always predicting doom for her banks: when problems surfaced at Xerox, for example, she noted that even under the worst circumstances, the company's lenders would likely get all of their money back.
Ms. Appelbaum is clearly relishing the chance to put some rather obscure skills to use, including poring over the terms of dense loan contracts between banks and borrowers. 
"This is my shining moment," she said in an interview last week. "I know just how long a bank can keep a company afloat before it just dies."
Remarkably cheerful for someone who studies companies on life support, she chuckles as she remembers the leveraged-buyout surge of the late 1980's. Fresh out of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, she worked on financing deals at Chemical Bank, only to watch borrowers default on their debts within months.
One of her earliest financings was for Doskocil, a meat processor that in 1988 got into a bidding war for a rival, Wilson Foods. Thanks to a $133 million loan from Chemical, Doskocil won Wilson. But 16 months later, the company was in bankruptcy.
"They had all sorts of excuses," Ms. Appelbaum said of Doskocil, which quickly began missing its earnings targets. "First they said people didn't eat as much pork over Christmas; then, in the spring, they said people were eating more chicken at picnics. It was just endless."
As Doskocil and other Chemical customers missed loan payments, Ms. Appelbaum moved to a group that provided secured loans to keep bankrupt companies afloat as they reorganized.
By 1993, as the economy began to rebound, Ms. Appelbaum decided to get out of lending and into equity research. "I'd really get to know these companies, but I'd go to credit meetings at the bank and nobody cared," she explained. "All they wanted to know was whether they'd get back their interest and principal."
After working for two years as an assistant to the bank-stock analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, Ms. Appelbaum landed at Goldman, where she is senior analyst covering the banking industry. 
In gathering intelligence on banks' troubled loans, Ms. Appelbaum's biggest advantage comes from within Goldman, one of the largest traders of distressed bank loans. She also talks to industry analysts at the firm, and consulted with Goldman's building-materials analyst when several companies in the building industry were overwhelmed by the threat of litigation relating to asbestos claims.
Ms. Appelbaum also pores over loan agreements filed by companies with the S.E.C. as exhibits to their annual reports. 
With the banks keeping silent, Ms. Appelbaum's work often amounts to educated guesses, but she is not afraid to update her e-mail reports as she receives more information. 
On Jan. 5, amid rumors about possible bankruptcy filings by California's two biggest utilities, Ms. Appelbaum sent out a note estimating that Bank of America had committed as much as $700 million to them. But two hours later, she sent an update pegging the bank's exposure at $400 million after doing more research.
Even though her insights into rising loan losses have brought Ms. Appelbaum much attention in the banking world, in December she began to look beyond the trouble, anticipating that the stocks of banks hit hardest by credit problems could get a boost once the Federal Reserve cut interest rates.
By lowering rates, the Fed reduced banks' costs, making lending more profitable. Lower rates also strengthened prices in the market for loans made to many of the most troubled companies by 10 percent, reducing the losses that banks might encounter on some of their poorest-quality debt.
"To Lori's credit, she didn't get stuck on her focus on credit," said Ronald Temple, who follows financial services stocks for Deutsche Bank Asset Management. Bank stocks are up 7 percent since the Fed first lowered rates on Jan. 3, according to the Philadelphia Stock Exchange/Keefe Bruyette & Woods index.
Ms. Appelbaum is not throwing away her list of troubled companies any time soon. "I don't think we're out of the woods on credit issues," she said, but lower interest rates will help make bank stocks more attractive. "Investors can see the light at the end of the tunnel."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lori Appelbaum's cheerful demeanor belies her analytic specialty: poking around among sick and dying companies. Ms. Appelbaum is the senior Goldman, Sachs analyst for the bank industry. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Short Circuit; 
Deregulation: A Movement Groping in the Dark

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
THIS bit of gallows humor has been making the rounds of the electricity industry: The British decide to switch drivers from the left to the right side of the road, just like the rest of Europe. But the queen worries that making the changeover all at once will be too complicated.
 So she decides to institute a monthlong transition period. Cars will switch sides in January. Trucks will wait until February. 
 Welcome to the era of electricity deregulation.
Five years after states began giving up their control over the power industry, power prices have soared in both California and New York, two of the states where deregulation is furthest along. Last month, rolling blackouts hit California, prompting Gray Davis, the state's governor, to label deregulation there "a colossal and dangerous failure."
Over the last two decades, the gospel of deregulation has spread from Washington to London to New Delhi, from trucking to banking to telecommunications to electricity. The United States, which embraced deregulation earlier and more thoroughly than the rest of the developed world, grew almost twice as fast as Europe and nearly three times as fast as Japan in the 1990's.
"Letting market forces work, letting competition work, is better for consumers, better for investors and better for the overall economy," said Philip Hoffman, chief economist of PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh.
Now, however, and possibly for the first time since deregulation began in earnest, this dogma faces a serious real-world failure. 
Despite this, many economists still think that electricity deregulation will work. A product is a product, they say, and competition always works better than state control.
"I believe that premise as a matter of religious faith," said Philip J. Romero, dean of the business school at the University of Oregon and one of the architects of California's deregulation plan.
Optimists like Mr. Romero say the current period is merely an ugly transition, not yet even true deregulation. Power costs would have risen anyway, they say, because the price of natural gas, which is used to generate electricity, has soared.
In addition, California has been slow to allow building of new plants. That has left power in short supply, causing prices to rise. As new supplies becomes available, prices will fall, Mr. Romero said.
Also, California made a crucial mistake when it capped the rates consumers could be charged, while removing controls on the wholesale price of power, said Stephen Slifer, the chief American economist at Lehman Brothers. The caps prevented the state's utilities from passing their costs on to ratepayers, creating no incentive for consumers to conserve, Mr. Slifer said. 
However, a growing chorus of dissenters worries that the recent price spikes are not an aberration. The way electricity is produced and priced gives too much clout to the power generators, they say.
To economists, prices serve as crucial signals to producers and consumers. In a regulated market, the state sets prices high enough for private companies to cover their costs and earn a guaranteed profit for their investors. But in a deregulated market, prices should vary with demand and supply.
If prices rise, companies will see the opportunity for profit and make investments to meet that demand. Also, high prices tell consumers that supply is scarce and give them an incentive to conserve.
Sounds good. But building power plants is a slow process, so supply shortages can last several years. Also, electricity is the kind of product economists call "demand inelastic," because it is vital for both consumers and businesses. That means its price must go way up before people will use less of it.
IN other words, once the supply of power gets tight, generators gain almost unlimited power to set prices. As a result, prices can stay high for far longer than is necessary to signal the marketplace that a new supply is needed. Making matters worse is the fact that electricity cannot be stored, so users cannot build inventory to protect themselves.
The way electricity is priced in deregulated markets only adds to the problem.
Because of the physics of power transmission, producers and utilities must work together to keep power flowing across the electric grid. So New York, California and other states that have deregulated have set up nonprofit "independent system operators" to control their transmission grids.
Every day, the I.S.O.'s set the price for the power, using so-called reverse auctions. (California's system works slightly differently, but the effect is the same.)The I.S.O.'s receive offers to produce electricity from generators. Then they pick as many plants as they need to keep the lights on, choosing the lowest bid first, then the next lowest and so on. Once the demand for power has been met, the highest bid accepted sets the price that every generator receives.
In theory, the system should encourage generators to bid no more than the cost of running their plants, because, if its bid is accepted, it will break even; then, if a higher bid is accepted, the generator will get that price and automatically make a profit.
But because I.S.O.'s hold new auctions every day, generators can manipulate the system to raise prices, said Richard Schuler, an economics professor at Cornell University who is a member of the board of the New York I.S.O. For example, a generator with several plants in a state could bid the output of one of its plants at a very high price, to see if it can drive up the overall price of the auction.
ALL those factors combine to give suppliers too much control over prices, said Richard Rosen, executive vice president of the Tellus Institute, a Boston environmental research group, and a longtime critic of deregulation. 
Dr. Rosen is not optimistic that new supplies will solve the problem. For electricity markets to work, there must be a significant excess of supply even at peak periods, he said. But because electricity cannot be stored, having a lot of extra plants simply means some plants won't run, so why would power companies build or maintain them? 
"There's a very good reason this industry has been regulated for 100 years," said Dr. Frank Wolak, an economics professor at Stanford University and chairman of the market surveillance committee of the California I.S.O. "This is an industry that's extremely susceptible to market power."
Deregulation's defenders say that will change as new plants are built. But this winter's price spikes have been so severe, and electricity is so important, that they do not have much time to prove their point. On Friday, the governors of eight Western states, including five Republicans, called for at least temporary controls on the wholesale price of power.
Deregulation promised much, but at least in California, it hasn't yet delivered, and people lose patience very quickly when the lights go out. As S. David Freeman, general manager of the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, said, "What is the purpose that's being served by going to a system of higher prices, other than satisfying people who believe that the marketplace is better?"

HEADLINE: The Mystery of Economic Recessions 

BYLINE:  By Robert J. Shiller; Robert J. Shiller is an economics professor at Yale and author of "Irrational Exuberance."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
A great embarrassment for modern macroeconomic theory is that it has never achieved any consensus on the basic questions of what makes the stock market rise or fall and what ultimately causes recessions.
 Today, there is great debate over whether a recession is in the offing -- and if there is a recession, how long it will last. Already, signs of an economic downturn are all around -- a depressed stock market, layoffs in several business sectors. That's why many Americans looked with relief toward Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve Board, which last week cut the benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point for the second time in a month. But will the Fed's action prevent a recession? It's difficult to tell. 
 Economists know what economic indicators correlate with recessions -- stock market declines often precede them, for example. And we know that most movements in the stock market haven't made any straightforward sense as a rational response to interest rates or to news about future profits or dividends. But we have not been able to pinpoint what ultimately causes recessions -- probably because the causes are psychological and thus intangible.
The renowned British economist A. C. Pigou wrote in 1929 that psychological factors account for about half of fluctuations in industrial production: he spoke of "psychological interdependence," "sympathetic or epidemic excitement" and "mutual suggestion." His judgment seems about as good today as in 1929 -- and the factors he described are still not easily measured.
Absent any scientific consensus about the ultimate source of economic fluctuations, oversimplified theories abound. Today's example is the popular theory that the Fed controls everything -- that the raising or lowering of interest rates alone causes the economy's ups and downs. The record 14 percent one-day increase in the Nasdaq index on Jan. 3, after the Federal Reserve Board made its first half-point cut in interest rates this year, suggests how strongly some investors buy into this theory.
Of course, the Fed's management of interest rates does have an important role in the way recessions play out, but it would appear unlikely that anything the Fed actively chooses to do will actually disrupt the economy. Something else is driving the periodic recessions.
A recession is generally related to a decline in confidence, a decline that makes consumers less willing to spend and businesses less willing to invest and to employ workers. Eventually we see layoffs and rises in unemployment. The recent string of layoffs and the January decline in manufacturing employment are ultimately due to a decline in confidence.
There are some efforts to measure confidence systematically, notably the Consumer Confidence Index published by the Conference Board. It is based on answers to just five survey questions, about respondents' assessments of business and employment conditions, now and in six months, and of the likely family income in six months. Surely many respondents to these surveys are reflecting what they hear on the evening news, rather than probing their inner psyches.
The index, as simple as it is, however, has been shown in a number of studies to contain valuable information for forecasters. A decline in confidence is a useful predictor that consumer spending will drop. And in the past few months, the index has had its greatest decline since the recession in 1990 and 1991. This suggests some trouble ahead.
Part of our confidence in the past few years has been an exaggerated national faith in Alan Greenspan. This faith may have grown up in part because of the success of the interest rate cuts that he undertook to support the stock market just after the Oct. 19, 1987, crash. It may also stem from the 1998 interest-rate cuts after the Long Term Capital Management debacle, in which the failure of a big hedge fund threatened to cause a chain reaction of bankruptcies. Mr. Greenspan has come to symbolize support for the new economy, and he is an essential part of the current story.
But public confidence based on belief in the acumen of one 74-year-old man cannot be secure. Many critics, in fact, are now going far in the other direction, viewing Mr. Greenspan as the principal cause of the current downturn because of the Fed's persistence in raising interest rates until well into 2000.
Solid confidence is ultimately based on knowledge, on an understanding of underlying mechanisms and a mental accounting of the reasons for security. The problem today is that the economy is in such a cockeyed and unusual situation that it is easy to imagine that confidence could soon erode a great deal.
After 1982, the Nasdaq stock price index moved in a smooth upward arc, rising at a higher and higher clip, until March of last year, and since then it has fallen roughly in half -- as classic a bubble-and-burst pattern as there ever was.
Broader stock-price indexes have followed a similar, though less dramatic, ascending arc since 1982, and real estate prices are also inflated. There have been no bursts yet, but these situations, too, look so much like bubbles that it is hard to imagine how confidence could be secure going forward now.
So are we likely to have a recession?
Some factors suggest that we might. Our economic expansion of the past 10 years has been fueled by some trends that may not be sustainable. One is a historic decline in the average rate of personal savings, from more than 8 percent of income saved each year in 1991 to no saving at all in December 2000 -- in fact, to households' spending more a year than their income. Another is high borrowing. The debt burden of the average American household (especially mortgage debt) has risen to record levels.
 The problem for forecasters is that we are, by these measures, largely out of the range of our historical experience. When we are out of range, past examples cannot be reliable guides to the future. 
Lacking an established theory of the ultimate causes of economic fluctuations, forecasters tend to rely on simple extrapolation of trends or on assumptions that past patterns will repeat themselves. But we are in a moment when confidence and market psychology are changing fast. Surprises -- perhaps a serious recession -- could be in store for us.

HEADLINE: Of Offers and Counteroffers 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "An Offer You Can't Refuse. Well, Maybe" (The Right Thing, Jan. 21), in which Jeffrey L. Seglin discussed the ethical problems of accepting a job offer, then changing one's mind because someone else offers a better deal: 
 The column did not address the flip side of the issue. At least once a month, I receive an inquiry from a distraught, soon-to-be former executive who accepts a position from a new company and then puts her current employer on notice. Then, before the official start date, she is informed by the new employer that the job is no longer hers. Without a written, signed employment contract for a defined period of time, the executive is left hanging in the wind. All too often, the old employer has already accepted the resignation and won't reverse its decision. The executive usually has no legal recourse -- and because she has left her job voluntarily, she cannot receive unemployment benefits, either. 
The reasons the new employer gives for revoking the offer range from "we rethought the position's requirements, and decided you are not the best candidate" to "we have to scale back and reduce head count." Perhaps the executive has a claim of fraud or detrimental reliance, but without a written contract, such claims are nearly impossible to prove.
Most employers, however, do not offer such contracts. So why is it an ethical faux pas for an employee to change his or her mind (which I admit is problematic) yet it is not even an issue for the new employer to wreak havoc on a person's personal, financial and professional life?

JONATHAN SACK
New York City, Jan. 21

The writer is an employment lawyer.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY; 
Suit Challenges Buyout That Won Fed Approval

BYLINE:  By Robert D. Hershey Jr. 

 BODY:
Has the Federal Reserve, which administers consumer protection rules in addition to conducting the nation's monetary policy, approved a plan that victimizes minority shareholders in a buyout? At least one lawsuit contends just that.
 At issue is the price that the Bank for International Settlements, the Swiss body that functions as central bank for the world's central banks, will pay for privately held B.I.S. shares representing a 13.73 percent minority interest. 
 In September, the bank decided that the existence of a few shareholders other than central banks was no longer "in line" with its international role and development and proposed to pay 16,000 Swiss francs for each of the 72,648 privately held shares, roughly double the then-current market prices. 
This price was calculated with help from the French unit of J. P. Morgan, which said that low liquidity and lack of voting rights meant that the shares were worth 45 percent less than the B.I.S.'s net asset, or intrinsic, value.
One of the most vociferous objectors is Jean-Marie Eveillard, co-president of two First Eagle SoGen mutual funds managed by Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder in New York. First Eagle SoGen has accused the B.I.S. of "fraudulent, deceptive or manipulative" actions in a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in New York.
"We'd get about one-half the amount that the bank itself says is the true value," Mr. Eveillard complained, calculating that the funds' 130,000 shareholders stood to lose a total of about $100 million.
Last month, the B.I.S. board unanimously approved the buyback at the price of 16,000 Swiss francs, meaning that neither Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve who attended in place of Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, nor William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, objected.
A Fed spokesman declined to comment. "The matter's in litigation," he said. Robert D. Hershey Jr.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
After an Unforeseen Injury, Help That Lifts the Spirits

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
A year ago Joycelyn Brathwaite was happily employed as a home health aide. She worked four to six hours a day, six to seven days a week, earning about $7 an hour.
 Then one day she slipped on a carpet in the home of the elderly woman in Bedford-Stuyvesant that she was taking care of, fell and could not get up. She was rushed to the emergency room and released after several hours. 
 "It was a sharp pain," Ms. Brathwaite said. "When I laid out at night and I wanted to turn, I felt the pain in my back and all the way down to my legs."
The pain would not go away, and every time she thought about returning to work, it got the best of her.
Ms. Brathwaite, 62, an immigrant from Trinidad who worked for years as a baby-sitter and housekeeper, applied for the first time in her life for unemployment benefits, and later for workers' compensation. 
But while she was waiting for the benefits to come through, she had no income, and no savings, because most of her money had been going to rent and food, and to her parents and other relatives in Trinidad.
After two months of unemployment, she had trouble paying her utility bills and the $509 monthly rent on her one-bedroom apartment southeast of Prospect Park in Brooklyn. 
An official from the health workers' union that Ms. Brathwaite belongs to told her that perhaps she could get help from the Community Service Society of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
She spoke with Jennifer Antoine, a social worker for the agency who specializes in helping people apply for public benefits.
Ms. Antoine immediately gave Ms. Brathwaite a $56 voucher so she could buy food, and followed it up with another two weeks later. 
Next, she secured a six-month grant for Ms. Brathwaite of $294 a month that helped pay the rent. The remaining $215 of her rent was paid by the city and state as a form of welfare called a shelter allowance.
Echoing comments that have been made by the leaders of the other social service agencies that the Neediest Cases Fund supports, David R. Jones, the chief executive of the Community Service Society, said that the agency had been receiving more requests for help from families and individuals who are struggling to make ends meet despite having jobs that pay more than minimum wage. 
"These are the kinds of critical interventions where not-for-profits and resources like the Neediest Cases Fund make it possible for working people who are playing by the rules to have some kind of modicum of a decent life," he said.
Ms. Brathwaite said that when she lost her job she would have considered moving to a less expensive apartment, but that she did not think she could find one.
Ms. Antoine agreed. "Who's going to find an apartment that's less than $500 a month?" she asked.
Mr. Jones said that as rents in New York City had gone up across the spectrum of economic strata, those on the low end had suffered the most, with rent demanding a greater percentage of their incomes.
"About 10,000 apartments below the $800 mark leave the market each year," he said. "Because of the increases in things like the high cost of living in the city of New York, she'd have real difficulty replacing that apartment."
Ms. Antoine said Ms. Brathwaite was fortunate that just as the six-month grant for her rent ran out, she began receiving public benefits, the vast majority of which go to paying her rent. 
Ms. Brathwaite had arranged those benefits with the help of Ms. Antoine. She is also hoping to start receiving food stamps.
Perhaps more important than the financial help was the relief Ms. Brathwaite felt once she got in contact with Ms. Antoine, whom she called "the best social worker ever."
"When you know organizations like this will help you," she said, "it lifts your spirit up."

HEADLINE: Immigrants Provide Employee Answer for Long Island Mailing Company 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: EDGEWOOD, N.Y. 

 BODY:
There is a one-story building in the back of an industrial park here with a roof the size of eight football fields. There, companies' financial statements are prepared and shipped to investors across the country by Investor Communication Services, the nation's largest provider of such services, which expects to send a billion pieces of mail this year.
 The company has one problem: employees. "We can't find enough of them," said Judy M. Winter-Giella, director of human resources. 
 The solution is immigrants. "We know what the job market is and we've found a work force that is eager to work and eager to learn," Ms. Winter-Giella said.
The work force at the I.C.S. center here on central Long Island is about 90 percent foreign born, company officials estimate: about 85 percent Hispanic and 5 percent Haitian. Though they work with mail written in English, most of them cannot speak or read the language.
Like much of the country, Suffolk County is experiencing an unprecedented labor shortage. With unemployment hovering around 2 percent here, there are not enough people to fill all the low-level, low-paying jobs available. 
It is not unusual for large companies to turn to recent immigrants to close the gap. But I.C.S. has come up with a way to keep the workers it has, while helping them toward jobs with better pay and a future: it pays workers to attend courses on English as a second language. Classes are held twice a week in the company break rooms. Each two-hour class averages about 20 people.
The company says employees with English skills work more efficiently and provide a pool of candidates for higher-level jobs. "If you want to sort mail written in English, if you want to get ahead, then you have to learn to read and speak English," Maggie Rajotte, the language teacher, told a dozen Hispanic men in the break room after work.
During the busy season from March through May, the company, a division of New Jersey-based Automatic Data Processing, will take on 1,300 temporary workers to augment its full-time staff of 700. These people will work as much as 84 hours a week in 12-hour shifts, Ms. Winter-Giella said.
Wages start at $6.75 an hour, and few skills are needed to load envelopes and reading material into a machine.
"The truth is, the new people are hungry," Ms. Winter-Giella said. "We've found they will work 54 days in a row. We depend on them to tell their friends and relatives that there is good work here."
Nadeshda Sosa found work here. She walked in the door four years ago as a temporary sorter and is now a line supervisor earning about $15 an hour. 
Ms. Sosa, who fled the civil war in El Salvador, now owns a home nearby in Brentwood with her husband, a day laborer, and two children. She speaks excellent English.
"I came from a war, and now I have a home," Ms. Sosa, 26, said as she wandered among the sorting and stamping machines. "The language classes, they're a good thing. The company is teaching people to be part of society, not hidden laborers."
The Census Bureau estimates that more than 850,000 immigrants came to the United States between July 1998 and July 1999. But some economists believe that the number of illegal aliens is woefully underestimated and that the actual number could be as much as three times that. 
There is a strong demand for people to fill laborious and dirty jobs that pay $8 an hour or less -- about 25 percent of all jobs in the country. And Suffolk County has a large population of new immigrants -- 3,040 in the year that ended in July 1999, according to the Census Bureau. Most of them are from Mexico or Latin America, and many are here illegally.
At I.C.S., workers are required to offer proof that they can work legally in the United States: a Social Security card and a picture ID. But counterfeits are easily obtained and workers readily admit that they work under false names. Workers also must pass a drug test and a criminal background check.
Employers can be fined for knowingly hiring illegal workers, but they also risk being sued for discrimination if they challenge documents that on the surface seem authentic, Ms. Winter-Giella said. 
"If the documents appear real, we accept them as such," she said. "We can't afford to mistreat people."
The Social Security Administration makes only random checks once a year for numbers that fail to match legitimate accounts or repeat themselves in different locations.
The workplace is clean and well kept at I.C.S. The overtime is plentiful, the paychecks steady. And the technology is state of the art.
"The hardest part of the job is the ink and the paper cuts," said Luis Morales, 32, a Mexican who works under another name. "It doesn't pay much, but it's warm work for the wintertime. When May comes, I'll go back to landscaping. That pays $15 an hour without taxes."
While they have found work on the farms and in the factories, new immigrants have not found a welcome mat in Long Island. Groups of Americans routinely protest the presence of day laborers who loiter on their streets while waiting for work. Recently two Mexican men were abducted by two white men and stabbed and beaten with gardening tools in Suffolk County. The motive was hate, the police said. 
There is a housing shortage that the county is unable to solve. Immigrants routinely live in toolsheds and auto garages. "Speak English!" is the battle cry in the suburban parking lots.
But Mr. Morales is unfazed. "It doesn't bother me to hear that racism," he said. "I say, 'How are you going to get your mail without me?' "

HEADLINE: Bronx Journal; 
Residents Seek Shelter From Thriving Motels

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

 BODY:
On some mornings, Joseph Allen emerges from his home in the Fish Bay neighborhood of the northeast Bronx to find a condom or two lying in the street. Once, he looked down and saw a pair of women's underpants just past the gutter. Another time, a line of men were urinating outside his home.
 "It's that motel," Mr. Allen said, nodding in the direction of the Crown Motor Inn, a squat cement structure on Boston Road that shadows Mr. Allen's two-story brick home just around the corner, on Pearsall Avenue. "I don't think a motel like that belongs in a residential neighborhood like this." 
 Nearly everyone who matters in New York City's government professes agreement with Mr. Allen -- the mayor, the Bronx borough president, the planners and the police -- and yet the hourly-rate motels that dot a three-mile stretch along Boston Road continue to flourish. According to the police, many of them are used by prostitutes and drug addicts, and are sometimes the scene of robberies and other crimes. 
In December, after years of complaints from local residents, city officials offered a proposal that would have blocked any future motels on Boston Road -- and many other types of commercial activity as well. Area merchants banded together to defeat the plan, saying it would have flattened the economy along much of Boston Road, which runs from the New York Botanical Garden to the Westchester County line. 
That left residents in the surrounding neighborhoods -- Fish Bay, Williamsbridge and Eastchester -- back at square one. City officials say they are trying to come up with another plan to limit the so-called hot-sheets motels. But the prospects seem less than certain. Local leaders worry that the issue has already become entangled in this year's mayoral election. Others say that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's administration, despite its much-publicized crackdown on sleaze and crime in other parts of the city, has missed its chance in this corner of the Bronx.
"They cleaned up 42nd Street, why not here?" said John Barr, a Fish Bay resident since 1969. "We've become a dumping ground."
The fight over the Boston Road motels has been brewing for years. The northeast Bronx is hardly a mecca for tourists, yet in the last several years one hourly-rate motel after another has popped up. There are now about a dozen, and they are permitted under the commercial zoning rules that apply for much of the area.
Residents were further frustrated by the construction two years ago of the Crown Motor Inn, at 3320 Boston Road.
The motel sits next to a residential neighborhood and across the street from SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic School, an elementary school. Residents of Fish Bay demonstrated against construction of the motel and filed a lawsuit accusing it of several things, including inadequate parking, but the motel won and was awarded a certificate of occupancy. 
It was then that the City Planning Commission came forward with a plan to remake Boston Road. Under the proposal, new businesses would have been limited to retail shops and other types of businesses deemed more compatible with a residential area. Existing businesses, including the motels, would have been allowed to stay, but not to expand.
Although some residents welcomed the proposal, many merchants did not. Besides the motels, Boston Road has dozens of auto-related businesses, including dealerships, repair shops and car washes. Under the city's plan, most of those businesses would also not have been able to expand, and no new ones would have been permitted.
Bernie Landau, who owns a used-car dealership and several other businesses along Boston Road, said the city's plan would have forced several people to seriously consider relocating. Mr. Landau, who has done business in the Bronx for 46 years, says he is proud that the Boston Road commercial strip and the neighborhoods around it remained vibrant when much of the borough declined in the 1970's and 80's. 
"When the business community starts going down, the neighborhood starts going down," said Mr. Landau, the president of a local merchants organization. "If I can't do business here, I'll go somewhere else."
The city decided to withdraw its plan last month after it was rejected by Community Boards 11 and 12 and the Bronx Borough Board. 
Some local leaders say they fear that city politics -- specifically, the well-known animosity between Mayor Giuliani and the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer -- is the major reason that the city has not dealt with the residents' concerns.
Mr. Ferrer, who is running to succeed Mr. Giuliani as mayor, forwarded a proposal to the Planning Commission last year that would have required future hotels or motels built anywhere in the city to be within 1,000 feet of an entrance to a major highway. That, he said, would prevent them from being located in residential neighborhoods. 
The City Planning Commission, 7 of whose 13 members are appointed by the mayor, rejected Mr. Ferrer's plan as too sweeping. 
"We believe New York does not have enough hotels," said the commission's executive director, Andrew Lynn. 
The Ferrer and Giuliani camps have lined up on opposite sides of the issue. The lawyer for the Boston Road merchants' association, Linda Baldwin, is married to Adolfo Carrion, a member of the Bronx Borough Council and an ally of Mr. Ferrer. Ms. Baldwin is also the law partner of Roberto Ramirez, the chairman of the Bronx Democratic Party and a Ferrer supporter.
"You have different folks in politics who don't see eye to eye, and the public interest is forgotten," said the Rev. Richard Gorman, the chairman of Community Board 12.
Mr. Ferrer and Mr. Lynn both vowed to continue working together to come up with a solution that satisfies everyone.
Many people who live and work on or near Boston Road are waiting to see if they'll be successful. One of them is Catherine Lavelle, the principal of SS. Philip and James School. Ms. Lavelle often tells pupils to stay away from the nearby Crown Motor Inn. Still, she said, they occasionally come to class chattering about things they say they've seen through the windows. Efforts to reach the motel's owner or a representative last week by phone were unsuccessful.
"Everyone knew what that place was going to be used for," Ms. Lavelle said. "What was the city thinking?"

HEADLINE: Field Guide? Check. Binoculars? Check. Lobbyists? Soon. 

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: NEW ALEXANDRIA, Va., Feb. 3 

 BODY:
The golden-crowned kinglet alighted only briefly in the riverfront scrub of the Potomac River's western shore. But it arrived like a feathery punctuation mark for some fascinated bird watchers who had ducked out of the capital city across the river to take a midday break from their determined new task of building what amounts to a political lobby for birds. 
 "That's the code we're now trying to crack," said one of the birders, Gavin Shire, a conservation officer with the American Bird Conservancy, a nonprofit organization. "How to translate the immense popularity of birding into a political force to be reckoned with." 
He referred to the quiet, teeming world of bird watchers and feeders, a gentle public wary of being seen as foppish, that now includes about one-fifth of the American population, more than 50 million people who outnumber hunters and anglers combined, according to the Fish and Wildlife Service. 
Bird watchers now spend more than $25 billion a year on feed, binoculars, travel forays and high-tech innovations like winterized birdbaths and television "nest cams" to track their plumed favorites from home or watch penguins caper live on the Internet.
Many of the birders cannot believe the success of their own growing subspecies.
"I got into birding as a kid to get away from people, and I have to laugh now at the idea that it's become a booming industry," said Pete Dunne, the vice president of the New Jersey Audubon Society. "But, you know, there are damn few people who don't like birds."
The birders' world increasingly involves city and suburban denizens intent on breaking beyond the asphalt routine to find something fresh and contemplative about life. But, almost by definition, their pastoral calling lacks political clout. And this is the problem now challenging bird conservationists determined to find a way to build a populist lobby against the increasing threats to bird habitats presented by human progress.
This task may sound no less daunting than sighting a resplendent quetzal to the average weekend birder. But various birding and wildlife groups are forming an 83-member policy council through the conservancy (www.abcbirds.org) dedicated to building political awareness and translating it into budget and legal muscle to protect the myriad of nongame birds fluttering under the gaze of this special-interest public.
"If we could reach all of that group it would be remarkable," said Mike Parr, the conservancy's vice president for development, of the mass of amateur birders. "But so far we don't have a brilliant strategy to engage them all out there," he admitted in the midst of his midweek birding along the the Potomac River.
The quiescence of birders is no surprise to such master birders as Mr. Dunne. He directs the Audubon Society's Cape May Bird Observatory at the Jersey Shore, where hotels that used to close after Labor Day are now booked deep into the fall for the seasonal bird migrations.
"People shy away from the label bird watcher," said Mr. Dunne, who spies backyard feeders all over the landscape and gently questions their owners. "The answer is always, 'Oh, no, I'm not really a birder.' People have gone out of their way to buy a device that will give them intimacy with birds, but they're not bird watchers," he said.
The evidence of birding's popularity is mounting, with two major new field guides vying for the lucrative market, scores of new festivals helping local economies in some of the most exotic birding areas and an increasing variety of pro-bird measures. These include the annual Keep Your Cat Indoors Day on May 12 to sensitize the nation to the loss of millions of backyard birds every year.
Hundreds of high-style bird food stores have opened, offering everything from the Yankee Flipper (a battery-powered feeder whose perch begins wildly spinning at the touch of an intrusive squirrel to cast him off) to Under Cover Coffee (purist beans harvested without the usual denuding of bird habitats). Most birders ignore kitsch trappings and make do simply with a pair of binoculars and a field guide.
Birding has grown with Americans' leisure time and disposable income. Paradoxically, new birders are emerging in the suburban rings of "sprawl" that conservationists have denounced for destroying bird habitats.
Conservationists estimate that one in every six species is in decline in North America and could wane by half in the next 30 years as humans use up more land.
"It's this steady nibbling away at bits of habitat through big housing developments that's really creating a problem and could come to a crisis," said David A. Sibley, author of "The Sibley Guide to Birds" (Knopf, 2000).
Mr. Sibley doubts some of the booming numbers but not the passion of modern birding. The premier watchers' group, the American Birding Association (www.americanbirding.org), has only 22,000 members, but these are among the most traveled and sophisticated devotees.
Mr. Sibley is in daily demand as a speaker now that his book, based on 30 years of experience as a photographer and birder, has become a best seller, with 300,000 copies in print. It is being hailed as on a par with the classic Audubon and Peterson field guides.
A second new guide, "Birds of North America" (Houghton Mifflin, 2000), is also selling well. It offers computer-modified spotting photographs and the guidance of Kenn Kaufman, a Whitmanesque birder who hikes America and celebrates "the pleasure of simply watching a bird, without analyzing it to death."
Such was the mood here in the Dyke Marsh preserve as Mr. Parr led his colleagues on a birding trek against the backdrop of the national capital.
"I've got a bald eagle here," Mr. Parr announced as he trained his binoculars skyward.
His companions exemplified birders' idiosyncrasies. These range from "twitchers" who are in a hurry to merely checklist multiple sightings to "extreme birders" who go native and take up residence with the birds. Linda Farley, the conservancy's antipesticide specialist, loves the sounds of birds. She calls them forth, particularly with her practiced "pish-pish" cry - an alarm call that rallies birds to flock in large protective numbers.
"Hear that: tea-kettle tea-kettle?" Ms. Farley asked, easily mimicking the Carolina wren. And she beamed in responding to a nearby white-throated sparrow: "Oh Can-a-da!"
But few birders can rival the adventures of Mr. Shire, a nature roustabout. He took up piloting an ultralight airplane so he could be one of the shepherdlike guides who experimentally re-educate flocks of trumpeter swans to rediscover their ancient East Coast flyways, from which the swans had been displaced.
"Its phenomenal," Mr. Shire said of flying in the open skies as the trusted leader at the head of a vee of swans and even switching the engine off to "thermal" with them on the earth's heat vents.
The communal aspect of birding emerged as members of the group alerted one another to an unexpected winter sighting of a golden-crowned kinglet. As they chatted, they mourned the passing of Phoebe Snetsinger, a world-class lister -- a globe-trotting birder with an enviable record of exotic sightings. She died in an auto accident in Madagascar.
"I'm betting Phoebe was on the trail of something special," Mr. Dunne said of Ms. Snetsinger. Taking up the hobby when she was stricken with cancer, Ms. Snetsinger added wondrous years to her life, said Mr. Dunne in explaining a human being's need to watch birds.
"It's just a treasure hunt," he said.

HEADLINE: Workers in Silicon Alley Feel Underpaid and Fear Losing Jobs, Survey Finds 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
If the dawn of the new media world was supposed to mark the beginning of a fun and egalitarian workplace, Silicon Alley appears to have missed the target, according to a report released last week.
 The report, researched even before the national shakeout in the online industry, shows a transient work force in Manhattan with members worried about keeping their current jobs and ever-trailing in the training needed to find the next ones. 
 Women are often paid less than men, and workers in general are insecure about when the paychecks will stop.
"What we were really surprised at was this was a hip, cool industry, and we thought there would be more equality," said one of the report's authors, Susan Christopherson, a professor of city and regional planning at Cornell University. 
Despite relatively large pay increases between 1995 and 1998, most of the 335 Silicon Alley workers who responded to the 1999 survey thought they were underpaid. Men made $55.90 per hour on average, the study found, compared with $42.80 for women. Workers found that they spent 14 percent of their work week looking for jobs.
And the people who took part in the survey may have had better experiences than others in New York's new media, Dr. Christopherson said, because they were members of professional groups that tend to help employees get the most of their work.
The study was conducted by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, Dr. Christopherson and another Cornell professor, Rosemary Batt, and Ned Rightor, the vice president of the executive search firm Isaacson Miller.
Dr. Christopherson said the research suggested that professional associations and universities that cater to the new media had often not moved fast enough to stay on top of the training needed by people in rapidly evolving new technologies. But she said some of the more interesting findings involved differences in pay between men and women.
"Essentially, there is an old boys' network, and that women and minorities tend to go into jobs that pay less," she said.
Anna Copeland Wheatley of AlleyCat Information Services, one of several New York organizations trying to address this disparity, said: "It is not like a conspiracy of the old boys' network in the back coat room. It's simply that people have networks and they use them, and venture capitalists use recommendations. Minorities and women don't necessarily have the Rolodex at hand."
Only 2 percent of venture capital money goes to businesses owned by women, Ms. Wheatley said.
The study also said that new media workers tended to move from employer to employer every six months, compared with seven years for the typical American, and that only 56 percent considered their jobs secure.
"That does not surprise me at all," said Allison Hemming, president of the HiredGuns, a consulting company that helps quickly growing businesses find contract workers. She said many companies that were growing fast in 1999 and early 2000 looked to contract workers to keep costs down and waited to hire full-time employees until they were sure what their needs would be.
Although Ms. Hemming said she thought the paradigm shifted in 2000 when layoffs started and employees began looking for more stability, many of her clients are "like mercenaries: they like the change, the flexibility to finish an assignment and then go skiing in Aspen." 
"People now want click and brick, they want the 401(k) plan, they want someone cleaning their offices at night, not just once a week," she said. 
New media workers receive little fringe benefits relative to people in other industries: 57 percent receive basic health insurance; 51 percent receive comprehensive coverage; 46 percent have a retirement plan; and 42 percent have a deferred income plan, like stock options.
For example, according to federal estimates, 87 percent of workers have basic health insurance.
Some blame the lack of labor unions in the new media industry for the low benefits, but others believe they would have little impact.
Peter Cappelli, the George W. Taylor professor of management at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, said: "To some extent I think they are doing it on purpose. Their target work force would prefer to have higher upfront pay and options, and lower benefits."
But he said workers not saving money or not having health insurance posed dangers to the economy, because government programs often pass those costs to taxpayers. 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about a survey of Silicon Alley workers misstated the job held by Ned Rightor, who helped conduct it. He is president of MXCIX, an executive search and work-force research company in Boston. He is no longer a vice president of the Isaacson Miller executive search firm.

HEADLINE: French Parties Press for Women in Politics 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: CHATAULIN, France 

 BODY:
Most of the 35 women who gathered here in a City Hall conference room recently had shown up for moral support, either because they had decided to run for local office in the Brittany region, or because they were mulling a decision to enter a race. 
 Always before, these women -- and millions of others across France -- had remained at the fringe of politics, believing that they were not really welcome in an overwhelmingly male club. 
 But all that changed this year. Political parties are wooing women as never before because a law was passed last year in France that appears to go further than any other in the world in attempting to share representation more evenly between men and women.
Starting with municipal elections scheduled in March, the new law obliges all political parties to field an equal number of male and female candidates in almost all elections. 
And so these 35 women -- most of them mothers in their 40's who had led feminist groups, union delegations or parents' associations in Brittany -- have found parties of all stripes urging them to run.
"I know one woman who was asked by three different parties to be on their list," said Valerie Pau, who helped organize the meeting. "Every time she picked up the phone, it was someone asking her. She could sit back and take her pick." 
Right now, 7 percent of France's mayors and almost 9 percent of its national legislators are women. That is roughly comparable with the United States, where 13 percent of senators are women, but far behind the 45 percent of Sweden's legislators who are women. 
It is not proving easy to level the political playing field.
Parties say they have had to scour the countryside to find women willing to be candidates; few have come forward on their own. And even when asked to serve, many women demur, questioning whether they have the time and the competence to enter a field they regard as a male battleground. 
Some also question the sincerity of the process. 
"Everyone is being asked," said Ms. Pau, a 42-year-old secretary and union worker who is planning to make her first foray into politics running for office in the nearby town of Brest. 
"But in a lot of cases," she added, "they don't really know us. They don't want us to say anything. Really, they just want us to be quiet and sit on their lists."
Even as the parties struggle to find thousands of women to be candidates, and to smooth the ruffled feathers of the men who must step aside, the debate rages about whether France's new parity law amounts to too much, too fast. 
Some fear that the women swept into office will be mere figureheads or the wives of former officials, taking up space but offering little value. 
But others say that the law will not only bring justice but also the fresh faces that French politics desperately needs. For decades here, politics has been dominated by the same men, almost all of whom are graduates of the same college. 
Most everyone agrees that the speed of the transition is jolting.
"There is no question that this is a brutal arrival for women," said Jean-Claude Kaufmann, a sociologist at the National Center for Scientific Research based in Rennes. "In one fell swoop, the numbers will be huge," he said. "And they will really have to prove themselves because people will be watching."
The birth of the parity law was not easy. First seriously discussed in the early 1990's, it engendered fierce opposition, even from some feminists who said that quotas of any kind were demeaning to women. 
But since the passage of the law -- championed by the Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and his wife, Sylviane Agacinski, a professor -- the idea has steadily grown in popularity. 
These days a majority of French citizens believe it to be a good thing. In one recent poll, 63 percent of those surveyed said that the parity law meant that French voters would get a better choice of candidates, and that the law would bring about better governance. 
Sixty-five percent said they wanted a woman elected mayor in their town in 2001. 
Monique Prevost, who attended the gathering in Chateaulin, might just be one of those new mayors. She heads a list that has been carefully brokered by the Socialist and Communist Parties in the Breton village of Douarnenez. But it took her six months to accept the offer. 
The principal of a local elementary school, she had been active in various associations and unions in the past. She had expected that with the passage of the parity law she would be asked to be on a list and even to be chosen for a job in the town administration. But the offer to run for mayor shocked her.
"At first, I thought it was a joke," said Ms. Prevost, 50. "Then, I have to admit I was a little bit afraid of so much responsibility and I was worried that I was just supposed to be a showpiece. But finally I said to myself, we wanted this, what will the men think of us if we do not go out there now?" 
The man who organized the list had the credentials to run for mayor himself, she said. For the most part, he has been generous about stepping aside and easy to work with, though on occasion she said she could feel him itching for a bigger role.
"Especially when the photographers are around," Ms. Prevost said. "Sometimes I feel him crowding in. Luckily, I'm a large-sized woman."
Ms. Prevost is not the only new candidate to have doubts about herself. 
Marie-Jo Zimmermann, who oversees women's issues nationally for the conservative Rally for the Republic party and who is running for mayor of a medium-sized city, said it took her months to come up with the candidates for her list. She said she had less trouble than she expected finding women she deemed qualified, but all 10 of those she asked, she noted, had the same reaction to her offer: 
"Every single one of them said, 'Am I capable of this?' and I have to say men do not ask that question. You ask them onto a list and they say, 'Yes.' They don't doubt themselves. One of my candidates was the C.E.O. of a company and she said 'Am I capable of this?' And I said, 'You must be kidding.' "
But some of the women who did come forward on their own got a less than welcoming reception. Michelle Sabban, who oversees women's issues for the Socialist Party, said one woman told her how the mayor of the town had tried to discourage her after she filed her application.
"The man called her into his office and he said, 'You are not going to have any weekends free, you'll have to work at night, you'll have no time for your children and you know what all that adds up to -- divorce.' "
Ms. Sabban said she had a little chat with the mayor, who said he thought of the conversation as just friendly, fatherly advice. In fact, women who have become candidates say they are running into a lot of that. Some say the push to get them on the party candidate lists has meant an exodus of younger men. The older men have hung on to their seats, leaving an abundance of older men now dealing with younger, inexperienced women.
Out on the stump, though, the women say they are usually taken seriously. "Most people seem very receptive," said Clementine Autain, 27, who has written a book on feminism and is running for mayor of one of Paris's arrondissements. "They are tired of seeing old people in politics and they know that I have nothing to do with corruption. But I am a little tired of hearing, 'Heh look, she is pretty.' "
France's foray into candidate parity goes farther than other European efforts to guarantee women a place in government. But most European countries have made substantial efforts in the last decade to raise awareness on the issue and many have moved much faster than France, which only gave women the right to vote in 1944. On average the percentage of women in European legislatures is about 20 percent. But there are considerable differences among the countries. 
Several European countries have flirted with the concept of quotas for women in elected office but most have given up the idea, usually for constitutional reasons. 
In addition to France, only Belgium currently has a quota for the candidate list; political parties there are required to fill one-third of their lists with women. In several countries including Spain, Austria and Germany, however, political parties have put quotas on themselves. 
Other countries have developed an array of incentives such as financing to promote women's participation and watchdog groups to make sure women do enter politics.
The impact women might have once in office is also widely discussed. Surveys show that the French public expects the effect to be positive. 
One poll that asked what areas would be improved by the presence of more women in elected office found that more than 80 percent of people responding expected improvement in education for young children, social services and health issues. Those areas are traditionally considered to be of particular concern to women. But the survey also showed that the public had confidence in women in other areas as well. Nearly 60 percent thought women would bring improvement to the running of the economy, transportation systems and sports. 
On the whole, it is France's left that has done the most to promote women's participation in civic life in the last few years. Even before it was law, the Socialists devised their own quotas for women during the most recent European and legislative elections. Ms. Sabban says that the presence of those women and the large number that Mr. Jospin has appointed to his cabinet -- 10 out of 32 ministers -- can be felt.
"You can already see their hands at work," Ms. Sabban said, pointing to several new laws, including one allowing morning-after pills to be distributed in schools as well as the creation of the pacte civil de solidarite, a new form of legal union for heterosexual or homosexual partners. 
"Women do bring a different perspective" she said. "French politics has changed a lot, is changing a lot and will have to change even more."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
Conquering Czechs Rule With Creativity

BYLINE:  By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
In the neutral corridor between dressing rooms at Madison Square Garden there stood a middle-aged man in a dark suit, dark shirt and dark necktie. He had the sturdy physique of a former athlete and silver hair trimmed in a brush cut. This was Frantisek Cernik, general manager of the national hockey team of the Czech Republic.
 Cernik's two-week tour of the National Hockey League will include today's All-Star Game in Denver, where North America will play the World. Cernik is scouting for the Olympic Winter Games in Salt Lake City next February, when the Czechs will defend their gold medal. 
As Czech players passed Cernik after Monday's Rangers-Atlanta game, he chatted with them in their native language and also discussed in accented English how and why his country has dominated hockey in recent years. Is it the skating, the passing, the shooting or the checking? Cernik paused, smiled and answered by tapping the left side of his head with his index finger, a gesture that in most cultures suggests intelligence. 
"I think this is first," he said, referring to his gesture. "And the second is a combination. Canadian hockey is hard and tough. Czech hockey is technique. Together, ice hockey from Canada and Czech, half and half, is perfect."
Since the cold war ended a decade ago with the breakup of both Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union, European players have flowed into the expanding N.H.L., blending their artistic impulses with the rugged style of this continent. Czech players alone hold more than 60 N.H.L. jobs, more than Russians, Swedes, Finns or Slovaks. You could stock three N.H.L. teams with Czechs. The first-year coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins is Ivan Hlinka, the first European head coach in N.H.L. history.
Hlinka coached the Czech team to the 1998 Olympic championship, which set off a national celebration. The Czechs have won the last two world championships and the last two world junior championships. The N.H.L.'s Hart trophy for most valuable player was won by Czech players in three of the last four seasons -- twice by Buffalo goalie Dominik Hasek, once by Pittsburgh forward Jaromir Jagr. On the Rangers, the best forward line is nicknamed "the Czech mates." On the Stanley Cup champion Devils, three of the top six scorers are Czech.
"The talent is really huge back home and everyone sees the dream to play in the best league in the world," said Patrik Elias of the Devils. "It really pushes them ahead. In the last five years, Czech hockey has really broken through."
He spoke after his team beat Detroit by 3-1 in a crisp game last Tuesday. Devils goals were scored by Elias, Petr Sykora and Bobby Holik, all Czech players who knew the game was televised live back home in the early morning hours. Such trans-Atlantic exposure was rare until the 1990's. Before then, a Czech or a Slovak who wanted to play in the N.H.L. while still in his prime would usually have to defect.
Some of them, like Petr Klima, were smuggled across borders. Radek Bonk, an Ottawa Senator who is in the All-Star Game, said Klima, who played in the N.H.L. from 1985 to 1999, "was one of my big heroes." If the Czech Republic and Slovakia still pooled their talent for one hockey team, Slovaks like Zigmund Palffy and Petr Bondra could supplement the Olympic champions. "We would be even stronger," Bonk said.
In a broader discussion of Czech hockey, Bonk and a dozen other Czech players agreed with scouts, coaches and general managers that the Czech system patiently develops skills at the youth level without pushing children to play too many games too soon. Hasek, an All-Star and one of three Czech goalies in the 30-team N.H.L., said North Americans could improve by teaching skills the way they do in his homeland.
"I just think the program for the kids in the Czech Republic is better," Hasek said.
Bonk said he watches children practicing in the Canadian capital and does not approve of what he sees.
"The coaches were just giving them the puck, but they didn't even know how to skate," Bonk said. "My dad coaches some little guys back home, 5- and 6-year-olds, and, in an hour practice, they skate for 45 minutes without the puck." 
The Devils' Holik is the son of Jaroslav Holik, the coach of the Czech national junior team. When the younger Holik runs summer hockey schools in North America, he said, he uses the teaching methods of his father and other Czech coaches.
"It's a good system," Holik said. "If you know how to skate, you're a lot better off. All the players from my dad's generation, world-class players of the 1960's and 1970's, are giving back to the young players. They are all teaching and coaching. It's amazing."
David Conte, the chief scout of the Devils, said he is wary of making sweeping generalizations. But, when pressed specifically to comment about Czech hockey, Conte said, "Their creativity with the puck, teamwork-wise, is unsurpassed."
This observation was supported by Dave King, the coach of the Columbus Blue Jackets, who coached three Canadian Olympic teams and scouted Europe last season for the Montreal Canadiens. King said the "sports-school model" from the Communist days survived better in the Czech Republic than it did in Russia after the sweeping changes in politics and the economy. "Children play with their club teams and get extra help from professional coaches," King said.
One criticism of European players in the N.H.L. is that they pass the puck too much and shoot it too little. King and others said this is because Europeans learn the game on an ice surface that is 15 feet wider than North American rinks. On wider ice, European goalies play farther back in the net. Like soccer players using a ball, European hockey players often move the puck from side to side to pull a goalie out of position. 
"They are very creative; they are awesome to have on your team, even if at times they overpass and don't shoot enough," King said, speaking of Czech players. "Their style is to score tap-in goals, pretty goals, tick-tack-toe type of plays. They bring that same finesse to our game."
In the N.H.L., the word finesse is not always a compliment. Sometimes, it can suggest that a player avoids rugged play, and this was often said about Europeans in the N.H.L. when the Swedes and Finns led the first migration in the 1970's. One experienced agent attuned to this sort of stereotyping is Rich Winter, a Canadian who includes Hasek, Elias and Sykora among his many Czech clients.
"They still face a general prejudice," Winter said, referring to Czech players. "People say, 'You can't have too many of them on one team.' They would never say that about Canadians or Americans." With sarcasm, Winter asked if there were too many Czechs on the Czech Olympic team that won the gold medal. And he said some N.H.L. teams are "slow to change" and still reluctant to scout Europeans.
"The N.H.L. is not run by Fortune 500 executives," Winter said. He acknowledged that fewer N.H.L. general managers are limiting Czech players to "skill positions" on the first and second lines while refusing to consider them for checking lines, defense or goalie.
Cernik, who runs the Czech national team, said: "Ten years ago, many defensemen in Czech were small. Now, we have many good defensemen, big and strong."
One of them is Roman Hamrlik of the Islanders, 6 feet 2 and 215 pounds, drafted first over all by Tampa Bay in 1992. He played as a junior in Europe, but some young Czech players are moving to Canada as teenage juniors to learn a hybrid style. One is Pavel Brendl, chosen by the Rangers in the first round of the 1999 draft. Jason Arnott, the Devils center who skates with Elias and Sykora, was asked about the old impression that Czech players lack a taste for Canadian-style combat.
"They are in there just as much as I am," said Arnott, a 6-4, 225-pound native of Collingwood, Ontario. "They are good with the puck and they are all fast. They compete every night, especially my two wingers."
Despite their overall acceptance, Czech players are sometimes singled out for criticism by N.H.L. coaches. An example is on the Rangers. Although Petr Nedved, Radek Dvorak and Jan Hlavac make up the top line, Coach Ron Low frequently says that they don't shoot enough. After the Rangers beat Montreal by 4-2 last Wednesday behind three goals from the Czech line, Low's first comment about them was to complain about a turnover that resulted in a Montreal goal. And he admitted that he wanted Dvorak to shoot instead of pass before he set up Nedved's second goal. 
Nedved acknowledged this tension and said: "Maybe we don't shoot as much as we should, but I guess that's our game. We are trying to be unselfish and pass the puck. It's such a fine line." He noted that the North American style is to "dump the puck," that Europeans are still reluctant to do this and that the two styles are not fully reconciled.
One of the last players from Czechoslovakia to defect before the political changes, Nedved is 29. He played for the Canadian Olympic team in 1994 and he has seen both sides from inside and out. On the narrow rinks of Canada and the United States, Nedved said, the style is "north-south," up and down the ice. Players from the wider rinks of Europe, he said, tend to "go a lot more east to west."

HEADLINE: Jan. 28-Feb. 3; 
What's Both Up and Down?

BYLINE:  By David E. Rosenbaum

 BODY:
 Evidence mounted that the American economy is flagging. That led the Federal Reserve Board to cut key interest rates by another half a percentage point. 
Even so, the Congressional Budget Office predicted that the economy would grow faster than expected in the next 10 years and that the budget surplus would be $5.6 trillion, about $1 trillion more than its last forecast. "The dip in the economy is expected to be short-lived," said Barry B. Anderson, deputy director of the budget office, telling Congress not to let cyclical weakness obscure long-term strength. David E. Rosenbaum

HEADLINE: Sanctions' Ledger: Benefit or Harm? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Sanctions Are a Weapon We Need," by Aryeh Neier (Op-Ed, Jan. 28): 
 Mr. Neier is wrong about the need for sanctions. 
First, in the overwhelming majority of cases, they don't work. Second, it is virtually axiomatic that sanctions, to the extent that they are at all effective, hurt the people of a country more than their rulers. Third, even though they always come clothed in the rhetoric of freedom and human dignity, they are imposed by the United States in highly inconsistent and politically motivated ways.
The United States is not the arbiter of what is morally right in the world. Our national policies reflect self-interest and lack of understanding about other parts of the world as often as not. Our lack of consistent principles in applying sanctions that damage the lives of millions just generates one more legitimate reason for resentment against us in the world.

JOHN W. CHUCKMAN
Portland, Me., Jan. 28, 2001

HEADLINE: DATA BANK; 
Through the Looking Glass, Darkly

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
Last week provided ample proof that the markets have more in common with "Alice in Wonderland" than the real world.
 From a market perspective, the early part of the week was promising. 
The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the second time in a month. Two weak economic reports -- one showing the slowest manufacturing pace in nine years and one indicating a sharp decline in consumer confidence -- suggested that further rate cuts were likely. 
 The January unemployment report, issued on Friday, showed a surprising surge in new jobs and deflated some of the market's rally. Investors worried that the report might not take further action on rates.
 For the week, the Dow industrials ended at 10,864.10, up 204.12 points or 1.9 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500 finished at 1,349.47, off 5.48 points or 0.4 percent. The Nasdaq fell further, partly because of the fourth-quarter loss at Amazon.com, the e-commerce leader. The Nasdaq fell to 2,660.50, off 120.80 points or 4.3 percent.
 The unemployment report also snapped a three-day rally in the Treasuries market. The yield on the 10-year bond finished at 5.14 percent, down from 5.26 percent the previous week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN
