HEADLINE: New Home for Delaware's Noted Chancery Court 

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN MILFORD

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del. 

 BODY:
WHEN the corporate raider T. Boone Pickens made a hostile bid for the Newmont Mining Corporation during the takeover frenzy of the late 1980's, the battle ended up in Delaware's Dickensian-sounding Court of Chancery.
 But the day the Texas deal maker showed up for a hearing, the proceedings had to be moved to a courtroom in the federal building. Chancery -- the most important state court in the country when it comes to corporate law -- could not fit all the arbitragers, members of the news media and spectators into one of its cozy courtrooms in the 1916 Daniel L. Herrmann Courthouse on Rodney Square. 
 More recently, in a trade secrets case involving Merck & Company and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., lawyers brought so much technology into the courtroom that the building's electrical systems was overtaxed and a brownout ensued.
Despite its power to determine the outcome of multibillion dollar business matters, Chancery Court has had to make do for decades. 
Now, work is progressing on a $132.4 million courthouse at Fourth and King streets in which Chancery Court will have the top billing, with state-of-the-art courtrooms on the highest floor. The 570,000-square-foot building on 5.5 acres is the largest single public-building project in Delaware's history, illustrating how much the state champions its court system, particularly the specialized business court.
Chancery Court, an unusual entity founded as a court of equity as opposed to a court of law, which traces its heritage to medieval England, is one reason Delaware is the paper home to nearly half of the Fortune 500 companies. And corporations chartered in Delaware pay franchise taxes, which represent 22 percent of the state's operating budget, according to Sabrina D. Hill, assistant secretary of state.
"We want to have an adequate and safe courthouse for our residents, but also we recognize the need for dignified surroundings for people who come from all over the world to litigate in our Court of Chancery," said Delaware Supreme Court Chief Justice Norman E. Veasey.
The land was cleared more than 30 years ago as part of urban renewal efforts, and the steel framing of the 12-story building has altered the skyline in the southern end of the city's central business district.
The architecture of the New Castle County Courthouse by HLM Design of Orlando, Fla., will lack the massive fluted columns and granite facade of the 177,600-square-foot Herrmann building, designed by Palmer & Hornbostel of New York. Instead, the brick, glass and aluminum-panel courthouse promises to deliver the latest in technology and security.
"The new building will give us large courtrooms -- which we desperately need -- but the technology will be something that will assist the court in maintaining its reputation for promptness," said Chancellor William B. Chandler III, the court's chief judge.
Technologies include electronic filing, real-time transcription, digital voice recording, computer animation and video teleconferencing.
BESIDES Chancery, the building will house three other trial courts -- Family Court, Court of Common Pleas and Superior Court -- when it opens in September 2002. The Supreme Court is in Dover, the state capital.
Chancery Court has played a large role in establishing the national reputation of Delaware's court system, the chief justice of the United States, William H. Rehnquist, said in 1992 at the time of the court's 200th anniversary.
The court is so highly specialized and its decisions so scholarly that corporations' legal counsels refer to Delaware rulings to order their companies' actions to avoid litigation. "This recognition confers on the Court in Chancery one of the highest forms of praise a judiciary can receive," Mr. Rehnquist said.
Today, approximately 70 percent of all the filings relate to corporate law and other alternative business entities, like limited liability companies.
Because of various twists dating to the birth of Delaware's Chancery Court in 1792, the state has one of the purest forms of a court of chancery in the world, more like its ancient ancestor of equitable jurisprudence in England, according to the former Chancellor William T. Allen, who is now head of the Center for Law and Business at New York University School of Law.
The court handles no criminal, family or tort matters. It has no juries and is not bound by strict statutes of limitations. Judges may issue temporary restraining orders, injunctions and other equitable relief. 
In medieval England, as the common law courts became calcified with procedure, parties who felt they should have prevailed under principles of fairness would appeal to the king for relief. Cases were referred to the lord chancellor for review. Usually a church official schooled in canon law, the chancellor could tailor a remedy to fit the specific facts, said the former state Supreme Court Justice William T. Quillen.
"The English chancellor relied heavily on the common law, but would do what his conscience perceived was morally right where the common law would cause hardship in a particular case," reads a history written by Mr. Quillen and the Wilmington lawyer Michael J. Hanrahan.
Between 1400 to 1672, chancery developed into a full-fledged court of equity, with flexible procedures similar to ecclesiastical courts. Across the Atlantic, many of the original states eliminated their Courts of Chancery during the Revolution, viewing them as instruments of the Crown.
Delaware, with no such bias, created the Court of Chancery in its constitution.
Most states merged their equity and law courts in the 19th century. In Delaware, however, the legislature began to designate Chancery as a forum for certain corporate matters. Soon after passage of the General Corporation Law in 1899, the court began adjudicating significant corporate cases.
Only a handful of states still have chancery courts completely separate from their law courts, none comparable to Delaware's unique court, said Charles M. Elson, director of the Center for Corporate Governance at the University of Delaware. 
"Hands down, it's the most important corporate court in the country," Mr. Elson said.
The new courthouse should provide adequate space through 2020. The four Chancery courtrooms range in size from 1,200 to 1,800 square feet -- nearly tripling the current space. The court will also have access to a 3,000-square-foot courtroom on a lower floor.
Chambers for the chancellor and four vice chancellors, which will have views of the Delaware River, will be on the floor beneath the courtrooms. Vice Chancellor Stephen P. Lamb, representing the court during construction, said the new courthouse will include conference rooms and offices for clerks, things that do not exist now.
PRIVATE elevators off a secured parking lot on Walnut Street behind the building will allow judges to avoid walking through the courthouse. There will also be a 1,100-car parking garage for employees, jurors and the public. 
Much of the courthouse planning focused on the circulation of judges, jurors, criminal defendants, litigants and the public. Great pains were taken to create a design that separated the groups, said Paul F. Ignudo Sr., director of the state division of facilities management. Family Court essentially has its own wing, perpendicular to the rest of the T-shaped building.
MBNA America, the credit card company headquartered on Rodney Square, has contracted to buy the elegant Herrmann building, whose construction was engineered by John Jacob Raskob, a DuPont Company executive and builder of the Empire State Building. The old court building was designed in the classical style of the City Beautiful Movement.
The bank has not completed plans for the building but will probably renovate the once-elegant pink marble and Indiana limestone interior, said David W. Spartin, bank vice chairman.
Some in the legal community are unhappy about moving from the old courthouse despite its shopworn interior, feeling it could have been expanded at the rear, preserving the original facade.
Richard K. Herrmann, a Wilmington lawyer and the son of the chief justice for whom the courthouse is named, objects to the move, although he worked on the technology for the new courthouse.
"Quite frankly," he said, "I think it's unfortunate we're losing the fine tradition and location in exchange for technology. You can have both."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rendering of a new $132 million courthouse at Fourth and King Streets in Wilmington, left, where Chancery Court will have top billing after moving from its current 1916 building. (Marty Katz for The New York Times); (Buck Simpers Architect)

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Guns And Bitterness

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
What do Medicare and the military have in common? Both are about to be betrayed in the name of tax cuts.
 Start with the military. During the campaign George W. Bush warned audiences that America's military was in decline. "Not since the years before Pearl Harbor has our investment in national defense been so low as a percentage" of the gross domestic product, he declared. Strangely, if you looked at the numbers put out by his economic team, you found that he actually proposed to reduce that percentage further, spending substantially less on defense than his opponent. 
 Nonetheless, the military overwhelmingly supported Mr. Bush; officers thought that they had an understanding -- nudge nudge, wink wink, say no more -- that defense spending would quickly expand once he reached the White House. Indeed, senior officers have been telling Congress that they need a 30 percent increase in their budget. (Do they? Not my department.)
Guess again. Last week, according to newspaper reports, Mr. Bush told lawmakers that there would be "no new money this year for defense." Karen Hughes, a counselor to Mr. Bush, conceded that "we may in fact need resources" for the military -- may? after all that martial rhetoric? -- but made it clear that there was no rush. One officer bitterly declared, "It sounds like campaign promise No. 1 being broken."
Then there's Medicare. The Medicare system is currently running surpluses, but almost everyone agrees that the Medicare surplus, like the Social Security surplus, should not be considered available for tax cuts or new spending. The two programs both rely on taxes paid by working-age Americans to pay for benefits to current retirees, and both face a demographic crisis as the baby boomers get older. Their current surpluses are therefore, as everyone acknowledges, a necessary, even inadequate, provision for the difficult decades ahead.
Everyone acknowledges this, except the administration, which -- unlike members of its own party in Congress -- refuses to rule out raiding the Medicare surplus.
But isn't the federal government awash in surpluses? Hasn't Alan Greenspan told us that our big economic problem is how to give the money away, lest politicians end up owning the stock market? If there's plenty of money for tax cuts, why won't the administration give the military at least some of what it wants and promise to keep its hand out of the Medicare cookie jar?
Because someone in the White House is aware of the truth, which is that there isn't plenty of money after all.
Here's the arithmetic: the Congressional Budget Office has projected a 10-year surplus of $5.6 trillion. (I don't believe it, but never mind.) Take the Social Security and Medicare surpluses off the table, however, and you are left with only $2.7 trillion. That may sound like a lot, but the projected cost of Mr. Bush's tax cut has also grown, for reasons that are important but too boring to explain. It would now use up around $2 trillion of that surplus.
And what's left depends on the totally unrealistic assumption that federal spending, including defense spending, will not grow at all over the next decade, despite a growing population and a growing economy. Give the military what it says it needs, and we're already well into deficit -- and that doesn't include missile defense, not to mention prescription drug coverage, new education programs and all that. Oh, and what about the trillion dollars of Social Security money that Mr. Bush has proposed to spend twice?
Nonetheless, Congress is about to go into a tax-cut feeding frenzy, adding huge tax breaks for corporations to Mr. Bush's proposal. The spectacle will be distressing, but it will be over quickly. Pretty soon, quite possibly as soon as this summer, we'll be worrying about deficits, not surpluses.
Of course, some conservatives would say that's the point, that we need to starve the government to shrink it. But what the federal government actually spends its money on is retirement, health care and defense; the rest is small change. So guess what gets shrunk? And if the military elite is shocked to find that this administration considers eliminating the inheritance tax more important than providing new weapons systems, that it is more concerned with the security of estates than the security of the state -- well, that's what you get when you trust in winks and nudges instead of checking the numbers.

HEADLINE: Free-Tuition Program Transforms a University 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATHENS, Ga., Feb. 1 

 BODY:
In about eight weeks, the calls from furious parents will start to accumulate on the desk of Michael F. Adams, the president of the University of Georgia, in what has recently become a painful annual ritual. Doesn't he know they are alumni, Bulldog boosters, season ticket holders, prodigious writers of checks? How could he possibly refuse to admit their child to their alma mater?
 "You wouldn't want to hear the calls I get in April," Mr. Adams said this week. "Nobody likes having to deny admission to families with long-standing supporters. But we have to be upfront about what has happened here." 
 And so he has to tell them, not without a certain amount of pride, that the university has been transformed since their day. It is no longer the sleepy party school that would readily accept the offspring of any halfway prominent family in the state. Seemingly overnight, one of the South's largest public universities has become enormously competitive, able to pick and choose from among the region's best high school seniors, insisting on test scores that would have been unimaginably high less than a decade ago. 
The principal reason is a free tuition program used by almost every freshman at the university and paid for by proceeds from the Georgia lottery. Known as the Hope Scholarship, it pays for all tuition and fees at any state college or university for Georgia residents with at least a B average. Since it was enacted in 1993, it has proved a powerful financial incentive for the state's top students to bypass universities like Duke, Vanderbilt and North Carolina and remain in the state.
The average SAT score for incoming freshmen has increased to 1203 this year from 1086 in 1993, compared with the national average of 1019 now. For the first time, Georgia ranks in the top 20 public universities on lists like those compiled by U.S. News & World Report, equivalent to schools like Ohio State and Purdue.
"I couldn't get in anymore if I tried," said Nancy Freeman, a 1970 graduate who lives in Atlanta. "But we're about to put our fourth child through UGA on a Hope Scholarship, and we are just thrilled about it. The academic level has gone way beyond our expectations, and it was all free. For our kids, going there was a no-brainer." Current in-state tuition at the university is $3,276 a year.
Merit-based scholarships like the Hope program are becoming increasingly popular around the country, now used in 13 states, but after seven years as the pioneer program of its kind, the Hope system in Georgia is yielding several lessons.
Though it has substantially improved the academic quality of the state's top colleges, it has not significantly increased the overall number of students going to college. Instead, it simply keeps more college-bound students in the state. It has not increased the number of minority students at an elite institution like Georgia, though it has allowed more minority students to attend college. And the pressure to to maintain the scholarship often prompts students to drop difficult courses, and to take a lighter course load.
Most starkly, the scholarships represent an enormous transfer of money -- $1.2 billion since 1993 -- from lottery players, who tend to live in the poorest counties of the state, to 504,000 college students, who come from the wealthiest counties. The program has become one of the most popular middle-class entitlements, and politicians who champion it are often rewarded at the ballot box. 
The program has clearly succeeded in one of its principal goals -- keeping top students in the state. Its creator, Gov. Zell Miller (now a United States senator), campaigned on a belief that the brightest students were leaving the state and needed an incentive to stay. A new study by two University of Georgia economists found that the Hope program had increased enrollment by 10 percent at four-year public schools in the state, and by 20 percent at private schools, where the scholarship subsidizes students' tuition.
Since the Hope program began, the average SAT scores of college freshmen remaining in the state has increased by nearly 10 percent, putting Georgia freshmen at the same level as the national average for the first time beginning in 1998. The number of the brightest students staying in the state -- those with SAT scores of at least 1500 out of a possible 1600 -- has increased to 76 percent from 23 percent in 1993.
But the program has not expanded the overall number of students attending college, said Christopher Cornwell, one of the authors of the study, because it is based entirely on merit, not on need. Poor students who want to attend college can still rely on the federal Pell grants, while wealthier students, who probably would have attended college anyway, now do so free in Georgia.
"It's not too surprising that a merit scholarship like this one would tend to be given to students who would have gone to college anyway, particularly because higher educational achievement correlates to higher family income," Mr. Cornwell said. "The whole point was to improve the state's economy by getting the hardest-working students to stay here."
Last July, aware of the problem, the state expanded the program so that students who are eligible for both the Pell grants and the Hope scholarship can get both; previously, the scholarship was reduced by the amount of the grant.
The study found that the Hope program had increased the enrollment of black students at four-year public institutions around Georgia by 24 percent. Mr. Cornwell said those students were probably from families above the Pell income limits who would not have otherwise gone to college.
But those new black students are for the most part not going to the University of Georgia, the elite level of the state's public college system. Exactly 40 years after the university was desegregated, black enrollment remains stagnant at 6 percent, less than half the percentages at the Universities of Alabama, Mississippi and South Carolina, and the numbers are expected to decrease next year.
The university is fighting a series of court decisions prohibiting it from using race as a factor in admissions and effectively gutting its affirmative action program. But Mr. Adams acknowledged that the rise of Hope scholarships had played a role.
"Hope has made it somewhat more difficult to recruit African-American students, because so many of them come from educational backgrounds where they have not been as well prepared as they could have been," Mr. Adams said. "Some of that is a vestige of the two-tier system of the 50's and 60's, but it means we will have to work harder at recruiting."
Black students say the dominance of the mostly white fraternity system on campus makes life uncomfortable for them and has discouraged high school seniors from applying. Adora Ozumba, a pre-med senior from Nigeria, said someone shouted a racial epithet at an outdoor gathering of black students a few days ago. Michael Anthony Thomas, a senior from Atlanta who was the first black editor of the student newspaper, said he sensed less diversity on campus now than when he first arrived, though he credited the administration with trying to improve the atmosphere.
"There are still too many students with a 1950's mentality here, like the ones who put a big Confederate flag up on the porch of their fraternity," he said. "You'd think that brighter students would mean there'd be more tolerance, but this is still Georgia."
But students white and black said the university was a more serious place than it used to be now that everyone must sustain a B average to maintain the free tuition. Faculty members say students are clearly more conscientious than in the past, if not necessarily better prepared.
"I'm seeing better writing than I used to, and a lot more concern about their grades," said Delmer D. Dunn, Regents professor of political science. "I feel more confident now in giving them more and requiring more." Some instructors say the scholarships have increased the pressure on them to inflate grades, although grades have also gone up because of a brighter student body.
About 60 percent of students at the university retain their scholarships after their freshman year, double the state rate. Both figures are expected to increase in future years now that the state has tightened the requirements for a scholarship in core high school courses, reducing the overall pool of scholarship students but improving the group's academic level.
Of more concern to the school at the moment is the number of students who are dropping courses halfway through the term if they anticipate earning a grade that would lower their average. The university's own strategic plan notes that undergraduates are taking fewer credit hours per semester than they used to, a trend that is directly attributed to the scholarships and that students are perfectly willing to confirm.
"Everyone's always trying to keep their Hope," said Shannon McGhee, a junior from Alpharetta. "If they don't think they'll get a good grade, they drop the course. They figure, hey, if I don't keep it, I'm going to end up going home anyway."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the effects of the merit-based Hope Scholarships on enrollment and minority recruitment at the University of Georgia misstated the given name of the former editor of the student newspaper, who said he sensed less diversity on campus. He is Mark Anthony Thomas, not Michael.

HEADLINE: Bush Aides Debate Ways To Press China Over Rights 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is debating how hard to press China on human rights, and may be tempted to drop condemnation of China at an annual human rights meeting next month in preference for what some see as a more pragmatic approach to extracting reforms from the Chinese.
 During most of the Clinton administration, the United States was at the forefront of reprimanding China at the United Nations Human Rights Commission, a strategy that the Chinese always tried to block to stave off embarrassment. 
 This year, as China faces a vote by the International Olympic Committee in July on whether Beijing will be host for the 2008 Olympics, the Chinese government has offered a number of inducements -- including ratification of a United Nations rights covenant -- to persuade Washington to drop the traditional resolution.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said at his confirmation hearing that a recommendation to President Bush on whether the United States would support a resolution at the commission would be "the No. 1 item on our plate," but he did not say what he would do about it. 
In a meeting with the departing Chinese ambassador, Li Zhaoxing, General Powell warned that he would raise human rights issues and do so "frankly," a State Department spokesman said. China needs to follow "the rule of law and to be exposed to the powerful forces of free enterprise systems and democracy," General Powell told Mr. Li.
The words differed little from those of the former secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, but they carried particular import coming the day after five followers of the Falun Gong spiritual movement set themselves on fire in Tiananmen Square.
But administration officials said that first foray into the China human rights debate gave no clues about the attitude toward the annual resolution of condemnation in Geneva.
General Powell faces an array of liberal and conservative human rights advocates who want the administration to support a resolution -- even though, as in the past, it is almost certain to be defeated. These advocates argue that little will change in China if the United States accepts the alternatives, and that China will gain a moral victory by not being reprimanded.
The annual human rights report by the State Department, due at the end of this month, is expected to say -- as it did last year -- that the human rights situation in China has continued to deteriorate, with religious persecution particularly intense, and thus to increase pressure on General Powell for introducing a resolution.
The annual Geneva meeting of the United Nations Human Rights Commission begins on March 19, but lobbying is already at a high pitch. Last week, leaders of seven human rights groups, including Human Rights Watch and the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Center for Human Rights, wrote to General Powell and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, urging them to press ahead with the human rights resolution.
One factor General Powell must consider, officials and human rights advocates said, is whether the United States can do more to improve human rights in China by accepting some of the Chinese proposals.
The Chinese have offered, for instance, to ratify the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, which would oblige them to accept visits from officials assigned to hold China to international standards. The Chinese, however, would agree to ratify the covenant only without the section that calls for the right to form trade unions.
The Chinese have also signaled that they might be ready to allow the International Committee of the Red Cross to visit prisons in China and to allow the United States Customs Service access to suspected prison labor sites.
Another gesture by the Chinese, according to human rights experts, is a memorandum of understanding reached with Mary Robinson, the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, which will allow for Chinese and United Nations experts to meet to discuss reform of China's re-education labor camps.
The first of these gatherings is scheduled for late this month, just before the Geneva assembly -- timing that human rights advocates say should not diminish an effort to condemn the Chinese at the assembly.
As General Powell considers his options, he is in the process of choosing an assistant secretary for human rights, who will organize the complicated diplomacy of winning support for a resolution at Geneva. Among candidates who have been interviewed are Lorne W. Craner, the president of the International Republican Institute, which monitors elections abroad, and J. Kenneth Blackwell, secretary of state of Ohio, an African-American who served as ambassador to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights in the first Bush administration.

HEADLINE: Improvement Districts Balk At City Plan For New Fee 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
A proposal by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to charge business improvement districts a fee for services they have not had to pay for previously has rekindled tensions between City Hall and the public-private partnerships.
 Although they are reluctant to take on the mayor publicly, executives of some of the city's 41 business improvement districts, which provide security, sanitation, marketing and other services in commercial areas, say they are rankled by the plan to impose an administrative fee amounting to 2 percent of their budgets. The fee proposal was included in the mayor's Jan. 25 budget message. 
 The fees would amount to only about $1.1 million for all 41 groups, but some group officials said they would pose a hardship because the groups have not been allowed to increase their budgets for three years. The money for business improvement districts is collected from property owners and businesses, but because it is part of the city tax bill, any increases are subject to approval by the City Council and the mayor. 
"We're already stretched thin," said Brendan Sexton, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, which has an annual budget of $5.5 million. "To get a cash money decrease is definitely moving backwards."
The executive director of the North Flatbush Avenue Business Improvement District in Brooklyn, Richard Russo, said that the fee would have a "debilitating" effect on his small group, whose annual budget of $93,000 is not enough to cover extra security or street lamps. Mr. Russo said he would probably have to stop supplying the plastic shopping bags with the group's slogan, "Serving Diversity," which merchants say helps give an identity to the mile-long shopping strip between Atlantic Avenue and Grand Army Plaza. "We're having difficulty paying for them as it is," he said.
A spokeswoman for the mayor, Sunny Mindel, stressed that the budget process for fiscal year 2002 was still in its early stages. "This is a proposed budget," she said. "As such, everything is up for review. But because the BID's do receive services for free, this is one of the things we're looking at." Among the services the city provides to the business improvement districts are oversight and tax collection, and city officials would not provide further details about the proposed fee.
Richard A. Briffault, the vice dean of Columbia Law School and an authority on business improvement districts, said the administrative fees might be warranted if the money is actually used to expand oversight of the groups to make sure that they are responding to property owners' needs. "It wouldn't be appropriate if this was just a way of raising money," Mr. Briffault said.
Executives of the business groups said the proposed fee caught them off guard, but relations between many of them and the mayor have been strained for several years.
In 1998, Daniel A. Biederman resigned as president of the Grand Central Partnership, the city's largest business improvement district, after Mr. Giuliani accused him of amassing too much power. Mr. Biederman, who has remained president of two other groups, the 34th Street Partnership and the Bryant Park Business Improvement District, would not comment on the plan.
Mr. Giuliani replaced Mr. Biederman at the Grand Central Partnership with Alfred C. Cerullo 3rd, his former commissioner of finance. Other close associates of the mayor are also business improvement district leaders, including David Gmach, the executive director of the 14th Street Business Improvement District, who was a top aide to former Deputy Mayor Randy Mastro, and Lou Carbonetti, the executive director of the Fulton Mall Improvement Association, who is the father of Anthony V. Carbonetti, the mayor's chief of staff.
In 1999, Rudy Washington, the deputy mayor for community development and business services, said the business groups could not justify increasing their assessments because they needlessly duplicated existing city services. Taking issue with such criticism, business group officials say their contributions are obvious. As one example, city officials have talked for years about the need for public toilets. Last month, however, the 34th Street Partnership beat them to it by providing two pay toilets in Greeley Square.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL 3-12

U.S. Attempts to Defuse Missile Defense Opposition
Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, the first senior Bush administration official to visit Europe, tried to defuse opposition to plans for a national missile defense by offering to help European nations and other allies to deploy such defenses. He told European allies that the United States would consult them on its plan, but did not discuss how an anti-missile defense can be reconciled with arms control and a productive relationship with Moscow. 1

French Women Join the Ticket
Political parties in France are wooing women as never before as a result of a new law obliging them to field an equal number of male and female candidates in almost all elections. The law appears to go further than any other in the world in attempting to share representation more evenly between men and women. 8

U.S. May Change China Stance
The Bush administration is debating how hard to press China on human rights, and may drop annual condemnation of China at the U.N. Human Rights Commission in preference for what some see as a more pragmatic approach to extracting reforms from the Chinese. 4

Pardon Furor Over Swiss Elite
Prominent Swiss citizens who wrote President Clinton to urge a pardon for Marc Rich, then a fugitive trader, have become the focus of an outcry over whether Mr. Rich bought their support through charitable contributions. 11

Report on Aid to Poor Countries
The U.N. issued a report detailing dozens of ways to finance economic development in poorer countries. 12


NATIONAL 16-25

The Making of a Suspect In the Wen Ho Lee Case
A re-examination of the case against the Los Alamos scientist Wen Ho Lee indicates that in constructing a narrative to fit their suspicions, government investigators took ambiguous evidence about Dr. Lee's behavior and Chinese atomic espionage and wove it into a grander case that eventually collapsed. 1

Debate Over Desert Area
The environmental approach of President Bush faces an early test in the Jack Morrow Hills, a Wyoming desert with reserves of natural gas. 1

Bird Lovers Seek Influence
The nation's bird lovers, who are millions strong but lack political clout, are trying to find a way to build a lobby against the threats to bird habitats presented by human progress. 1

University Is Transformed
A free tuition program has transformed the University of Georgia into a competitive institution, able to pick and choose from among the region's best high school seniors. 16

A Shift on AIDS Treatment
Officials now recommend that treatment for AIDS be delayed for people without symptoms because of the toxic effects of the therapies. 16

Race and Redistricting
State officials say they will focus less on race than in the last redistricting 10 years ago in an effort to avoid constitutional challenges. 17

McAuliffe to Lead Democrats
The Democratic National Committee elected Terry McAuliffe as chairman, and he vowed to take on President Bush as fiercely as Republicans went after Bill Clinton. 24

In Albany, Insurers' Ally Has Profited From Them
State Senator Guy J. Velella of the Bronx and the partners in his small law firm have been repeatedly hired by insurance companies to represent their policyholders in lawsuits -- at the same time Mr. Velella headed the Senate committee that regulates the insurance industry. 1

Terrorism Trial Set to Begin
The trial of four men charged with conspiring in the bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa in 1998 and in other acts of terrorism that the government says were orchestrated by one man, the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden, opens in Federal District Court in Manhattan tomorrow. 27

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
How New Campaign Laws Would Help the Economy

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
TOO many comedians are making fun of George W. Bush's brainpower without any basis for their jibes. Why not give him a little quiz instead? O.K., Mr. President, which of the following would help the economy most?
* A big tax cut skewed toward the rich. 
 * Opening sensitive federal lands to logging and drilling. 
 * Campaign finance reform that would curtail the role of money in politics.
You don't have to be an economist to know the answer. Campaign finance reform is one of the most important things the government can do to improve the long-run economic performance of the United States.
Reducing the influence of money in politics isn't usually considered an economic issue, but it is by far the best of the three choices. Most economists, after all, are justly skeptical of a huge tax cut as a timely economic stimulant, and sacrificing the environment for more cheap oil won't seem like such a good idea when the greenhouse effect turns Wilkes-Barre, Pa., into oceanfront property. 
But just imagine how effectively the economy would hum along if not burdened by the dead weight of the subsidies, tax breaks and market-impeding regulations that arise from the legal influence-peddling known as campaign fund-raising. 
Consider how much better off we would be if American agriculture were freed of the market orders and price supports that the government has piled on over the years to the detriment of competitors and consumers. Or how much more sensible (and less costly) the tort system would be if lawyers could not speak as loudly as they do with their wallets.
Another economic benefit of true campaign finance reform would be a simpler tax code, without so many special breaks for the wealthy. Not only might this make investment decisions more rational, but it could save some of the $125 billion a year that it costs for all American taxpayers to comply with the current arcane rules. That figure is from the nonpartisan Tax Foundation, which estimates that the 4.3 billion hours consumed annually by this miserable task is equivalent to the labor of more than two million people. "The performance of the economy is dramatically affected by the state of tax law," the foundation says. 
But why stop at campaign finance reform? Many other things could be done to bolster the economy without even mentioning a tax cut or consulting Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
For one, we could spend more on science. There is strong evidence that research spending -- and having more scientists -- leads to greater economic productivity. Over all, federal research-and-development expenditures are just $83 billion a year. That may sound like a lot, but it is less than a single year's revenue at I.B.M. The budget of the National Institutes of Health is less than 1 percent of total federal outlays.
Speaking of health, how about some kind of national health insurance? Our wasteful and inequitable system is a major drag on the economy, while leaving more than 40 million Americans with no medical insurance at all, according to the Census Bureau. Sooner or later, we will have to embrace some combination of single-buyer purchasing of drugs, market competition and mandatory coverage to keep medical costs from seriously retarding growth. Why not get it over with?
Goading Americans to save more would help, too. Taxing consumption instead of income would encourage earning and investing, and we should reconsider the multiple taxes now levied on income. Corporations pay taxes on their profits, while we pay taxes on the ensuing dividends and capital gains.
The rich want us to change that, but in return we should sharply limit the deductibility of home mortgage interest, which, as constituted, benefits mainly them. This deduction is responsible for America's gross overinvestment in housing; if people did not have a huge tax incentive to buy giant homes (which they are often too busy to spend any time in), their capital might find its way instead into new plant and equipment that could increase productivity and national wealth. 
FINALLY, in the category of "pin the externality on the donkey," why not discourage dangerous cars by making sure that owners of sport utility vehicles somehow pay for the pollution and highway carnage they cause? After all, the lives we save may be economically productive ones.
And Mr. President, there is a bonus. Adopt any of these measures, and maybe, just maybe, the late-night comics will ease up a little. At least the economists won't be laughing.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
In God We Trust. In Government We Hope for the Best

BYLINE:  By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

 BODY:
ON his radio show last week, Jay Sekulow said he was swamped with calls from listeners around the country eager to talk about President Bush's new initiative to funnel government dollars and support to religious social service programs.
 Mr. Sekulow's audience consists largely of conservative Christians, and he is chief counsel of the American Center for Law and Justice, a frequent adversary of the A.C.L.U. His listeners are those most likely to applaud Mr. Bush for opening the government's coffers to church charities. So what were they concerned about? 
 The separation of church and state.
Many Americans are indeed enthusiastic about stepping up government support to religious programs so they can better tackle seemingly intractable social problems. But, as polls indicate, across the political spectrum Americans are wary of anything that appears to tamper with the First Amendment. Those on the left worry about religion meddling with government. Those on the right, like Mr. Sekulow's callers, worry about government meddling with religion. 
Americans may not be able to recite the amendment, or perhaps even explain it, but they are instinctively uncomfortable when their government appears to promote one religion over another, or allows discrimination based on religion, or interferes in the freedom of a church or synagogue or mosque. If executed carelessly, Mr. Bush's plan could spring all three of those traps.
"This is an area that is filled with land mines," said Mark Penn, a Democratic pollster. "Looking at public opinion data, it could be summed up as 'Yes, but don't go too far.' "
Yet, by devoting Week 2 of his presidency to creating a new White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, President Bush is betting that most Americans care more about helping poor people than they do about the First Amendment. The conventional wisdom in the White House is that the only people alarmed about a potential breach in the divide between church and state will be aggressive civil libertarians, some agnostic Ivy League professors and liberal editorial writers.
So, as the plan was rolled out last week, the White House did not articulate clear answers to many of the questions the proposal had provoked. By Thursday, Mr. Bush sought to assure the public, saying at a prayer breakfast, "As president, I'm interested in what is constitutional, and I'm interested in what works."
To address the perception that he is championing primarily evangelical Christian programs, the president said: "We do not impose any religion. We welcome all religions," a stance that raised the specter of government funding for the Nation of Islam's prison programs, which triggered a strong letter from a major Jewish organization, the Anti-Defamation League.
In theory, Americans like the idea of expanding the reach of religious social services. Mr. Bush pushed it in his presidential campaign. He was tapping into the widespread hope that spiritual approaches can succeed where secular ones have failed in helping the homeless, welfare recipients, prisoners, addicts and wayward teenagers. If a heroin addict can be cured with prayer, Americans say, let him pray. Like Mr. Bush, they are interested in what works.
ANNA GREENBERG, an assistant professor of public policy who studies American attitudes toward religion at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, said: "Americans are basically moderate. They will say, 'I see nothing wrong with religion being part of our public life and values. I just don't want anyone to tell me how to worship or to tell other people how to worship.' "
A poll conducted in November by Public Agenda, a nonprofit research group, asked more than 1,500 Americans whether it was a good idea to increase government financing for religious groups that help the homeless and drug addicts. Forty-four percent said it was a good idea, even if the programs promoted religious messages; 23 percent said it was a good idea, but only if programs avoided religious messages; and 31 percent said it was a bad idea. 
The cornerstone of the president's plan is that religious programs will not be required to censor their religious teachings in order to receive government contracts. The source for this, too, is in the First Amendment -- that government shall not prohibit religious expression.
So, for example, while Mr. Bush was governor of Texas, the state gave $8,000 to a job training program that required students to study Scripture and taught them that accepting Jesus Christ as their savior would help prepare them for employment. 
The state of Texas and now the White House say funding fundamentally religious programs like this is fine if they can show results, and if clients have alternatives. The rub is in the reality. The job training program in Texas was the only one in the county, said James Harrington of the Texas Civil Rights Project, a nonprofit group suing the state on constitutional grounds.
"The county had only enough money for one job training program, so these unemployed people would have had to drive 60 miles if they didn't like the Christian program," said Mr. Harrington. "The alternative wasn't down the street. You had to go to the next county."
Americans are likely to be uneasy about scenarios like that, said Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster. "It has to do with their sense of whether or not the services will be provided fairly, and with whether or not people have other options. They don't in general like it when religious institutions are the only choice, because if you don't like that religion, you've got no place else to go."
Several pollsters explained that Americans answer questions about First Amendment issues differently when the implications are spelled out. Asked if they support school prayer, a resounding number say yes. Asked if the school board or a teacher should tell their child when and how to pray, the same people say no.
The Public Agenda survey found that only 19 percent of respondents said schools should avoid sponsoring prayers entirely. The rest broke down this way: 53 percent said it would be best if schools would mandate not prayer, but a moment of silence; 20 percent wanted students to recite a prayer that refers to God; and only 6 percent said they wanted a prayer that mentions Jesus. Given that more than 80 percent of the American population is Christian, that is a strong hint that people do not want even their own creed set as a standard.
Finally, the White House may face opposition from those Americans who believe the separation of church and state is good for the church.
As Cal Thomas, the conservative columnist, wrote last week, "What concerns me is that religious organizations might be tempted, or forced, to dilute their life-transforming message to get government subsidies, thus negating the primary reason for their success. They also risk becoming an appendage of the party in power."
Americans will allow Mr. Bush to experiment, but they will be watching closely to see if he crosses constitutional boundaries.

HEADLINE: The Mayor's Book Deal 

 BODY:
It is disappointing that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has become the second New York politician in little more than a month to enter into a compromising book deal. Although the mayor's hefty $3 million advance from Talk Miramax Books, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company, does not match Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's recent $8 million contract with a publishing subsidiary of Viacom to write her memoir, it raises similar concerns. Both authors should have declined to accept large up-front payments while still in office, as such payments can too easily be seen as bids for favorable treatment. Instead, they should have limited themselves to royalties on books actually sold, a better indication that they are being paid what their books have earned. 
 The best course of all for Mr. Giuliani, since he has only 11 months left in his term, would have been to wait until he was out of office to sign a contract. Such restraint would have been an example for others and more in keeping with the mayor's emphasis on high standards for public officials. 
 In agreeing to accept a large advance to write two volumes, a memoir and a how-to guide to city management, the mayor has put himself in a financial relationship with an entertainment conglomerate whose varied business interests regularly require action or approval by City Hall or city agencies. Mr. Giuliani's pledge that he will stay away from matters relating to Disney is plainly necessary under the circumstances. But it is an inadequate antidote given the possibility of favoritism when officials below his level decide on economic assistance, filming permits or other discretionary favors the Disney Company might seek. 
The mayor, like Mrs. Clinton, is refusing to reveal the entire contents of his contract, including the size and timing of his advance payments. That sort of stonewalling is unacceptable from a mayor in a position to bestow favors on the very corporate interests that have now agreed to make him wealthy. The advance offered to Mr. Giuliani would be prohibited if he were a member of the House of Representatives. But it is not barred by city ethics rules -- a gap that obviously needs addressing before the next mayor takes office in January 2002.
Meanwhile, we hope that Mr. Giuliani's old prosecutor's passion for elevating the ethical standards of government will re-emerge and that he will see the civic need to renounce any advance. He should instead limit his payments to royalties on actual book sales when his epics finally appear. That will be after he leaves office -- and is no longer in a position to help the Disney Company.

HEADLINE: Gas-Rich Desert Will Test Bush Resolve 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., Jan. 31 

 BODY:
As a test of the new approach that President Bush has pledged on public lands, a good gauge will be what happens north of here, across an enormous, unfenced swath of high desert prized both for its rugged beauty and for the natural gas that lies beneath.
 For four years, the land, known as the Jack Morrow Hills, has been off limits to energy exploration, while the Bureau of Land Management tried to come up with a plan to balance conservation and development. Just before leaving office, the Clinton administration rejected one proposal and, in an extraordinary step, ordered that a new plan give top priority to conservation goals. 
 But now the fate of the Jack Morrow Hills is in the hands of a Bush administration that is giving top priority to closing what it contends is a big gap in the nation's energy supply. And in a region where most people live off what is pulled from the ground, many people say they hope the final decision will help to reverse a wave of government action that, in President Bill Clinton's final month, put scores of millions of acres of federal land out of reach to mining, logging and drilling. 
"To just lock up the land and have it for the sake of saying it's out there doesn't make a lot of sense to me," John W. Hay III, president of the Rock Springs National Bank and head of the local cattlemen's association, said. "But we have a change in administrations, and my guess is that we will have some rational people who see that there is room for multiple use." Across the West, many of Mr. Bush's allies have disparaged Mr. Clinton's approach as amounting to a land grab, and the new president himself has made plain his view that his predecessor overreached. At least some of the land that Mr. Clinton ordered protected, Mr. Bush said in a pre-inauguration interview, should be reassigned to allow development if it could be done in an environmentally sensitive way.
With an eye toward possible reversals, the new administration is reviewing all of Mr. Clinton's last-minute actions, including rules that banned logging and road building across nearly a third of the nation's national forest land and orders that created more than a dozen national monuments.
But rather than mount an across-the-board challenge, people who have been watching the process say, Mr. Bush is most likely to make his stand in places like the Jack Morrow Hills, where overturning the Clinton approach would be relatively easy and where development could clearly serve energy needs.
"A former secretary of the interior told the B.L.M. to go back to the drawing board, and the new secretary of the interior can say heck no," said Johanna Wald, a lawyer with the Natural Resources Defense Council, which is among the organizations campaigning to keep the Clinton protections in place.
At stake in the Jack Morrow Hills, Ms. Wald and others contend, is not just energy, but the fate of a vast habitat that environmental groups prefer to call the red desert, an area of shifting sand dunes, red rocks and soaring buttes that is home to some of North America's largest herds of desert elk, antelope and wild horses.
A substantial part of the area's 600,000 acres has a high likelihood of containing significant natural gas supplies, the Bureau of Land Management study concluded last June. But many nearby areas are already being drilled, and environmental advocates contend that any benefits of exploration in the hills will be outweighed by the certain costs of interfering with a fragile habitat.
"It's an oxymoron to say that you can make an oil well environmentally sensitive," said Tom Bell, a local historian who is a leader among those who have fought for years to gain better protection for the area.
Only six weeks ago, one of the Clinton administration's final actions had environmental campaigners who believe the land should be permanently protected from development hoping that they had finally won their battle. In contravening a draft plan by the federal Bureau of Land Management, which recommended that the Jack Morrow Hills be reopened to limited oil and gas exploration, the departing interior secretary, Bruce Babbitt, ordered in a Dec. 22 memorandum that the top priority in a revised proposal should be conservation.
"The presence of finite mineral resources should not deprive future generations of the natural and aesthetic wonders of the Great Divide Basin," Mr. Babbitt wrote in the directive, in which he instructed that "an appropriate decision will be made to protect this unique area and its outstanding resources."
The Bush administration has not signaled whether it intends to overrule that directive. But Mr. Bush and his deputies, including Vice President Dick Cheney, a Wyoming native, have said that decisions about public lands should keep in mind the need to meet a surge in the demand for natural gas, the cleanest of the fossil fuels.
At least 95 percent of the power plants under construction will be fueled by natural gas, and in large part for that reason a 1999 study by the National Petroleum Council predicted that American demand for natural gas would increase by about 30 percent by 2010, with much of the new supply to come from the Rocky Mountain regions like Wyoming, which is soon to outpace Texas as the country's leading producer of natural gas.
As across the West, a vast majority of Wyoming land believed to shelter new reserves of oil and gas is owned by the federal government, so the Bush administration's decisions about access are bound to have a direct impact on energy supplies. In the Rockies, according to the 1999 study -- which was commissioned by the Energy Department -- about 137 trillion cubic feet of natural gas, or 10 percent of the country's total reserves, is available only subject to federal restrictions.
And in Rock Springs, a city of 20,000 whose economy is almost entirely dependent on oil, gas, coal and a mineral known as trona, the dominant view is that any costs of energy development will be far outweighed by the benefits. "You can keep the habitat and you can go after the resources without affecting people's livelihood," said Shane Heavin, a roughneck who was driving over the frozen sand dunes one recent morning to check on some of the few dozen oil and gas wells in in operation.
Those who believe that energy development and the natural habitat can coexist point to the desert elk herd that is at least five times bigger now than when oil and gas exploration began about 1950. Now, scattered pipelines are visible across the desert sands and isolated wells stand out as industrial islands in the landscape, but advocates of renewed drilling say that goal and nature can easily coexist.
"Our analysis has basically shown that we can balance oil and gas production and providing habitat for elk," said John S. McKee, the director of the local Bureau of Land Management office, whose analysis was overruled by Mr. Babbitt. With an air of criticism, Mr. McKee described Mr. Babbitt's memo as "not normal," but added: "That was an order from the secretary, and whether it can be undone, I won't speculate on."
Others in Wyoming have been more vehement in their denunciations. "He was telling us what the outcome should be before anyone had done the analysis, and that's not scientific," Dru Brower, a vice president of the Petroleum Association of Wyoming, said.
For the oil and gas industry, the history of decisions on public lands in the Rockies under the Clinton administration was mostly a chronicle of defeat.
An effort by the Marathon Oil Company to develop gas reserves on federal lands across a vast area of northern Colorado was rejected at the last minute by the Bureau of Land Management, whose decision was upheld in 1999 by the Supreme Court. In 1997, a local forest service official put off limits the entire Lewis and Clark National Forest in Montana, along an energy-rich area known as the Rocky Mountain Front.
Mr. Clinton went a big step further with the forest-protection plan, made final in early January, that barred new road building and logging across nearly 60 million acres of national forest. That plan did not prohibit new drilling, and it allowed energy operations to stay in place, but industry officials say that its effect in terms of access will be to all but prevent new oil and gas operations.
Even more severe in its impact, the officials say, has been Mr. Clinton's decision to use his executive power to establish national monuments in states like Utah, Colorado, Idaho and Montana, giving those areas a status that carries with it a virtual prohibition on oil and gas exploration.
An unusual deal struck in the 1950's, in negotiations surrounding the establishment of Grand Teton National Park, has established Wyoming as one of only two states (the other is Alaska) in which a president cannot use his power under the Antiquities Act of 1906 to unilaterally designate a national monument. If it were not for that prohibition, people close to Mr. Babbitt say, the interior secretary would have almost certainly recommended that Mr. Clinton protect the Jack Morrow Hills by making it a monument, just as he did in his final weeks in office in protecting places like the Missouri Breaks in Montana, along a 149-mile stretch of the Missouri River, giving them a status that can be reversed only by a Congressional vote. Without that power in Wyoming, Mr. Babbitt and the Clinton administration resorted to an authority that can be much more easily overturned, leaving the door open for a possible reversal by Gale A. Norton, the new interior secretary.
"You can't have Wyoming be a pristine, untouched area and still be a major natural gas producer," said Russell L. Kirlin, the regional manager for Questar, a natural gas company. "You have to decide what you want."

HEADLINE: Convention Town 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "The Con Con: No Solution? No Problem," by John Tierney (Big City column, Jan. 30):
 The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center ranks 17th in size in North America -- only a third of the convention space in Chicago and less than even Cleveland or Rosemont, Ill. 
Ouch! 
 Despite this bleak fact, New York City is set to welcome 39 million visitors in 2001, a 35 percent jump from 1996. These guests are pumping more than $23 billion a year into our city, representing $3,200 for every city resident and 277,000 jobs. 
As to profitability of conventions, delegates spent $2.2 billion in 1999, and according to Trade Show Week, convention business is growing, not dwindling. Imagine the infusion of out-of-town dollars if we could increase convention capacity. 
Furthermore, trade shows are booked up to eight years in advance, cushioning the city from any future and much-predicted economic downturn. 
We need to get started now.

CRISTYNE LATEGANO-NICHOLAS
JOSEPH E. SPINNATO
New York, Feb. 2, 2001

The writers are the presidents of, respectively, NYC & Company and the Hotel Assn. of New York City.

HEADLINE: Tax Cuts for Today 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Medicine for the Economy" (editorial, Feb. 1):
 The purpose of a tax cut in the face of risks of recession this year should be to support personal incomes and economic growth this year, not to match hypothetical revenues to spending needs over the decade ahead. 
Cutting taxes mainly for the sweet hereafter could actually delay private spending plans and make our immediate economic problems worse. 
 Congressional Democrats should favor a substantial, but near-term, tax cut whose benefits flow mainly to working families. The proper way to limit the scope of tax cuts for the long term is to phase them down over time, knowing that future Congresses can extend them if needed. The basic structure of estate, capital gains and progressive income taxes at the federal level should be left alone.

JAMES K. GALBRAITH
L. RANDALL WRAY
Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.
Feb. 1, 2001

The writers are scholars at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute.

HEADLINE: Here's to Bad Times 

BYLINE:  By David Callahan; David Callahan, research director at Demos, a public policy organization, is co-editor of "Quality of Life 2000: The New Politics of Work, Family and Community."

 BODY:
Consumer confidence is plummeting and companies are cutting back, but I, for one, am not mourning. The 90's boom left me both financially battered and psychically troubled, and I don't think I'm alone. As the economy has slowed, I'll confess that my main reaction has been relief.
 In the past five years, while the New York economy surged, the rent on my apartment in Manhattan nearly doubled. I've hung on, but barely. New York has become less and less affordable for middle-class people like me who don't happen to work on Wall Street or in corporate law firms. One-bedroom apartments are hard to find for less than $2,500 a month. And ownership seems impossible: in the last quarter of 2000, the average sale price of a co-op or condo in Manhattan below 96th Street was $787,708 -- up from $395,035 in 1990. 
 Total wages and salaries for workers in the city, meanwhile, increased by only 19 percent between 1989 and 1998, according to the Fiscal Policy Institute. Low-income workers experienced the smallest gains. And as rising real estate prices have sent middle-class New Yorkers into poorer areas, those a rung or two lower on the economic ladder have been pushed aside. Many low-income people are now doubled or tripled up in conditions that Jacob Riis would recognize. Others are rent-poor, forced to choose every month between food, rent and medicine.
New York is not alone. You might make good money at Yahoo, but try buying a house in Silicon Valley, where groups of computer programmers share ranch houses while janitors live in garages or sleep on buses.
Commercial rents went skyward in the 90's, too, with devastating effects on nonprofit organizations in many cities. The good times have been anything but good if you run a dance school, a theater or a public service organization with a lease that expired in the past two years in one of the places plugged into the new economy.
Now, one thing looks certain: real estate costs will come down. It's happening already in Manhattan. For renters and prospective home buyers like me, whose jobs are secure, that means the cooling economy has tangible financial benefits. To be sure, I feel bad for the swelling ranks of people who have been laid off. But until we find a way to share the country's wealth more equitably during boom times and make sure that income gains aren't wiped out by rising costs in housing and health care, it's hard to get too excited about surges in national prosperity.
There is a larger solace, too, in the signs of recession. The economy of the late 1990's offered the promise of such extraordinary wealth that it inevitably brought out the worst in people. Materialistic values came to pervade our culture. The ideal of working hard over many years to achieve wealth lost traction. The pressure to pursue wealth instead of other goals grew enormously as the media focused on those winning big in the new economy. It became easy to feel that missing the gold rush was plain stupid.
I've seen the resulting distortion of values everywhere in Generation X -- my generation -- and in those coming after it. It's hard to stick to a goal related to something other than money -- working at an artistically creative or socially useful job, for example -- if you can't afford to rent a one-bedroom apartment. It is even harder when everybody else seems to be getting rich and there's no support in the mass culture for your choice. Who wants to be a schoolteacher when you can be a millionaire?
No, I won't miss the boom. I won't miss the killer rent increases or the news stories about the latest dot-com billionaire or the feeling that I'm a fool for working in the nonprofit sector. As I see it, the good times are coming, not going.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Michael Kupperman)

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Two pioneers in the study of e-business are creating a new cyberlab. And no one is calling them crazy anymore.

BYLINE:  By John Schwartz 

 BODY:
IT'S not every business professor whose photo appears on the lusty Web site Am I Hot or Not. The site (www.amihotornot .com) invites men and women to send in photos for all the online world to see. Viewers then rate each entry for its sex appeal.
 So what is that picture of Prof. Donna L. Hoffman of Vanderbilt's Owen Graduate School of Management doing there? Actually, her husband and partner in research, Prof. Thomas P. Novak, posted it -- not out of some kinky exhibitionist urge, but because he wanted to see how visitors to the oddly compelling site responded to a variety of images. It's what makes Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak such dogged investigators of all things Netly: they love to fiddle with the online medium. 
 Ms. Hoffman notes with a laugh that her rating on the site is rather low -- less than a 3 out of a possible 10. But what does that "Baywatch"-besotted crowd know? 
Within their field of research, Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak are, in fact, about as hot as it gets. And now they are about to embark on a new venture that could raise the temperature higher still: Vanderbilt is helping underwrite a new "eLab," a center proposed by Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak that will give researchers a chance to study the way people interact with Web sites as they surf. If it works, the eLab could be the first research tool to really get at what makes people tick -- and click -- online.
The new venture reflects years of frustration with trying to make sense of the Net. Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak were among the first college professors to recognize that Internet-based business could be a legitimate field of study, and in 1994 they established the first graduate business school e-commerce research program, Project 2000. 
They had been on the Internet for years already in those clunky days before the World Wide Web made online exploration so easy. When they downloaded the earliest browser, Mosaic, in 1993, "it was amazing," Ms. Hoffman recalled. "It was goose bumps, and you're jumping and your adrenaline's pumping," she said. 
They started thinking about how to apply their academic training in consumer psychology and methods of measuring consumer behavior to the new medium. The Internet opened a new field in which to test their statistical tools, and Ms. Hoffman said they had the freedom of pioneers to wander and to experiment: "We said, 'This is what we're going to study -- we've found it. This is how we can make an impact on society.' "
Although other scholars would also end up producing excellent research on e-business, Ms. Hoffman recalls that at the time many colleagues ridiculed her and Mr. Novak as fad chasers.
These days, Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak seem to be the ones laughing. Their program got the attention of some of the best-known companies in the online and offline worlds as business tried to get its own brain around the Internet. Paul Allen, the Microsoft co-founder, financed research, as did Sun Microsystems and CDNow.
While they were doing groundbreaking research, they were also making headlines. When Time magazine published an ill-advised cover story in 1995 about pornography on the Internet, relying heavily on a study by an undergraduate at Carnegie Mellon University, Ms. Hoffman's exacting analysis of both the report and the Time article showed them to be deeply flawed. The magazine partly retracted the story, based largely on the Hoffman critique.
When the Carnegie Mellon study nonetheless provided ammunition for lawmakers who passed the Communications Decency Act in 1996, Ms. Hoffman once again stepped into the fight by criticizing the law in testimony before a panel of federal judges in Philadelphia. When the court struck down the act as an unconstitutional restriction of First Amendment rights, the judges cited Ms. Hoffman's testimony. Since then, Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak have weighed in on various big issues, including arguments over the true size of the Internet and the width of the so-called digital divide between the rich and the poor. 
The new eLab will help Ms. Hoffman and Mr. Novak realize their vision of rigorous research on the virtual world. Vanderbilt has put up $1.05 million to start the program, and the researchers hope to raise $20 million to keep it going. 
Once the program is set up, possibly by the fall semester, the students and researchers will create Web sites that will be open to the outside world. As visitors wander through the sites, their actions will be closely monitored, with small changes to the sites to see reactions. It is exactly the kind of research that Ms. Hoffman would have loved to conduct with the corporations she has worked with over the years. But no real business could stand by while a college professor tinkered with the store, no more than Wal-Mart would let a researcher rearrange half of its aisles. 
Eventually, Ms. Hoffman suggests, the eLab might even sell products so that researchers can come face to face with one of the biggest issues in e-commerce: why do so many people study and gather goods online and then simply walk away from their virtual shopping carts without buying?
In the language of research, Ms. Hoffman is taking the world of market experimentation and moving from a controlled environment to something that more closely resembles a field experiment: watching how things happen in the real world.
That path, while enticing, could hold dangers, said Andrew B. Whinston. He is director of the Center for Research in Electronic Commerce at the McCombs School of Business at the University of Texas at Austin -- another highly regarded institution that studies online business. Without commenting directly on the Vanderbilt eLab, Mr. Whinston said his students had done Internet research in a more closed-environment online lab with a known population of visitors, meaning "the factors that you want to study are very much under your control."
Isn't opening a new center to study the Internet in the middle of the dot-com bust a classic example of bad timing? Not at all, says the Vanderbilt business school's dean, William G. Christie. Now is the time to take a deep breath and figure out how to come up with proper business models and smart commercial behavior, he said.
"E-commerce is here to stay," Mr. Christie added, "and now it's time to do it correctly. ELab will help people do that."
Ms. Hoffman isn't talking yet about what the first Web sites will be in her virtual virtual world. But she's willing to give one tantalizing hint: one might be modeled, to a degree, on Am I Hot or Not.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Hallmark's 99-cent cards, for those who don't care quite enough to send the very best, sell well.

BYLINE:  By Patricia Winters Lauro 

 BODY:
MARITA WESELY-CLOUGH of Hallmark Cards Inc. knew she was onto something when she saw garage sales proliferating in affluent suburbs and heard teenagers bragging about great deals at discount stores.
 Recognizing that America loves a good deal ultimately led Hallmark to introduce a successful line of 99-cent cards called Warm Wishes that are simple, direct messages in economical greeting cards designed mostly for casual relationships. 
 The Warm Wishes line is just one example of how Hallmark keeps close watch on cultural trends and then takes those insights and transforms them into greeting cards. It is similar to the way advertising agencies identify emerging moods and feelings in society and then use that information to design advertising. Like advertising, greeting cards have to immediately connect with consumers by capturing a tone of voice, a language and a mood that resonates, explains John Beeder, vice president of marketing greeting cards at Hallmark. 
The irony and sarcasm captured in commercials like last month's E*Trade spot on the Super Bowl that sent up dot-com failures or Budweiser's "What are you doing?" commercial making fun of yuppies trying to do "Whassup?" is also popular in many Hallmark greeting cards. One example is the ornery "Maxine" character known for her cynical, yet offbeat view on life, who has become so popular that Hallmark is about to start an entire line of Maxine cards and licensed merchandise.
The trick for Hallmark -- and the same for agencies and marketers everywhere -- is to capture the emerging trends as they gain acceptance in mainstream culture. Nothing dates a commercial faster than last year's buzz word or fashion, and the same is true in a greeting card.
To prevent that, Hallmark employs Ms. Wesely-Clough, officially the director of creative strategy development at Hallmark, a privately held company based in Kansas City, Mo., but she is also the company's chief trends analyst. She and her two-person staff make forecasts and synthesize them into reports that are widely distributed throughout Hallmark to be used by designers, writers and marketing executives for new cards and other products.
Looking into her crystal ball for 2001, Ms. Wesely-Clough sees a continuing consumer demand for a good deal. That's one reason Warm Wishes became the nation's sixth most successful new nonfood product last year, according to Information Resources Inc., which said that thousands of new products come out every year.
"It's now considered sophisticated and savvy to find the best deal at the lowest price," said Ms. Wesely-Clough. 
Hallmark also forecasts a backlash against the 1990's penchant for over-sizing everything, from super-sized fast food to oversized furniture. "People are overwhelmed by the sheer magnitude of it all," said Ms. Wesely-Clough.
Experiential marketing -- where retailers offer "transformational experiences" that leave consumers rejuvenated or emotionally moved -- is also hot. 
"Super-shocks" in entertainment and media will continue, Ms. Wesely-Clough predicts, as extreme sports like the XFL, over-the-top adventure movies and reality-based television shows like "Survivor" proliferate. Shock is one way to get attention in an over-commercialized world, she said.
And in a new twist, Hallmark sees a bit of a backlash against America's celebrity culture. Instead, the company has identified a need among people to find ordinary role models and is starting a card line that rewards "everyday heroes" like firefighters, teachers and volunteers. That trend is already under way in advertising, which seems to be using fewer celebrities.
"Americans yearn to recognize the ones who step up and volunteer, who come through with no monetary gain in sight -- ordinary people doing extraordinary things," Ms. Wesely-Clough said.
Ms. Wesely-Clough and her staff come upon these insights by traveling, reading, visiting museums, going to trade shows and art exhibits, closely watching advertising and, always, talking to people, she said. The research is then checked out by Hallmark's business research department, which uses more formal, quantitative tests such as random sampling to understand consumer's feelings. For instance, while Ms. Wesely-Clough was seeing a penchant for steals and deals in America, the company's business research department found consumers were looking for casual cards using informal language to give to people to whom they were not particularly close, said Jay Dittmann, Hallmark's business research vice president.
"It's not just that the lower price is appropriate," said Mr. Dittmann. "It's been so popular because the message is on target with what people want to say."
Indeed, it's often been said that advertising reflects society, and so do greeting cards. "I think both Hallmark and its main competitor, American Greetings, both do a good job of knowing what people want," said Sheldon Grodsky, president of Grodsky & Associates, securities analysts based in South Orange, N.J. "It's a bit of a guessing game. Still there's a lot of art involved."
Common Threads, which features a fusion of ethnic influences, was introduced in 1997 after Hallmark noticed that multiculturalism was spreading rapidly through the country's heartland. In the 1980's, when one celebrity after the next announced an addiction and subsequent recoveries, Hallmark saw that the topic was becoming acceptable to discuss, and began a line of recovery and rehabilitation cards. Last year, it started a complete line of cards for what are known as blended families, created by second and third marriages. 
Of course, Hallmark has had its misses. Divorce cards to name one example. Hallmark offered its first divorce card in the 1950's, and it bombed. America wasn't ready. Then in the "go-go" 1980's, with real estate and stock prices booming, Hallmark tried again, this time with a line of humorous divorce cards, but consumers found them too light for such a serious issue. The divorce cards that sell well now are more often expressions of support, said Rachel Bolton, Hallmark's spokeswoman.
So advertisers take note, if you want to know what is acceptable in American society, take a look at a greeting card.
