HEADLINE: American Communists Come Home, on Microfilm 

BYLINE:  By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
In 1993, John Haynes, a historian at the Library of Congress, was in Russia meeting with the head of that nation's archives when he was startled by a sudden remark.
 "Did you know that the Comintern has the American Communist Party records?" the Russian official, Kirill M. Anderson, asked Mr. Haynes. The Soviet Comintern controlled the Communist parties in the United States and in other foreign countries. 
 Mr. Haynes replied that American scholars didn't even know that the records existed. 
"They stuck me in an office and wheeled in a cart with these files," he recalled. "They were literally dust-covered folders. I blew off the dust, untied the ribbon and pulled out the papers. These were the American party's own records: letters, summaries of agendas, discussions, decisions, arguments over expense reports, like 'We're going to get the money to you but, by the way, this looks out of line.' They were the real records, not copies."
Mr. Haynes learned that from the 1920's to the 40's officers of the Communist Party in the United States routinely shipped their records to the Soviet Union for safekeeping.
In 1998 the Russian archives agreed for a $100,000 fee to make microfilm copies of the material. Now the papers have come home, in the form of 435,165 microfilmed pages at the Library of Congress.
Because scholars have seen just a fraction of the reports, which were delivered in batches to Washington last year, it is too soon to tell whether they will result in any major discoveries. Mr. Haynes has already published figures that show that the drop in American Communist membership resulting from the Hitler-Stalin pact of 1939 was not as great as previously thought.
Some of the records have a familiar ring. A Soviet leader tells American Communists in 1919 to expose President Woodrow Wilson "as a hypocrite and murderer, in order to discredit him with the masses." In a 1920 report a Communist boasts of doing better than the Socialist Party: "In instances we have held larger mass meetings than the S.P. ever held in its balmiest days. These mass meetings have gone forward without interference to now. We have conscripted the best of speakers and they are making national tours. Results have been exceptionally good." 
The writer adds, "It is probably known to you that the officialdom of the A. F. of L. is so reactionary," a reference to the union organization. 
A 1931 statement called for a boycott of the 1932 Olympic Games, which were held in the United States. "The National Provisional Counter Olympic Committee declares that the Olympic games are the creation of a few self-appointed millionaires, counts, army officers and Amateur Athletic Union job holders. The games serve the purpose of distracting the attention of the masses of the sport-loving youth of the United States and the entire world, most of whom are suffering under the burden of the economic crisis, from their own immediate problems. It is calculated to keep the minds of the masses on the question of Olympic victories and star performances rather than on the problem of keeping body and soul together. . . 'WIN FAIR OR FOUL, BUT WIN!' is the commonly accepted slogan of the Olympic games." 
Then the writer complains that the Soviet Union was not been invited to participate.
Allen Weinstein, president of the Washington-based Center for Democracy, which works with the Russian government to promote democratic reform in Russia, said that the records would provide Americans with "a remarkable historical reference," but that those expecting to find answers to persistent riddles like the Hiss and Rosenberg spy cases were likely to be disappointed.
Professor Weinstein, who is the author with Alexander Vassiliev of "The Haunted Wood: Soviet Espionage in America -- the Stalin Era" (Random House, 1999), said that whatever records the Soviet Union retained in those cases would be in the files of the K.G.B. and military intelligence, not of the Communist Party in the United States.
Still, Harvey Klehr, a historian at Emory University described the materials as "certainly the most thorough resource that scholars have had on the history of American Communism." 
Professor Klehr worked with Mr. Haynes in getting the archive to the United States and has written books with him on its contents ("The Secret World of American Communism," with a third author, Fridrikh Igorevich Firsov, published by Yale University Press in 1995).
"Everything in the past had been bits and pieces, stray documents," Professor Klehr said. "It's really a marvelous resource. When we were told that the Russians had the American Communist records, we were both skeptical. We were afraid it was just a file of clippings from The Daily Worker."
But there it was, millions upon millions of words. Most of it is in English, the exceptions being some of the earliest documents, written when many American Communists were foreign-born and wrote in their native languages. By the 1930's the majority of party members were American-born.
The archive is rich in material about women, particularly Emma Goldman, and labor unions, civil liberties and court cases. "It just makes you salivate," said Ellen Schrecker, professor of history at Yeshiva University and author of "Many Are the Crimes: McCarthyism in America" (Little, Brown, 1998). Mr. Haynes said that perhaps a dozen Americans had looked at the archive's originals in Moscow and perhaps a dozen more had seen the microfilm copies in the Library of Congress. 
There is no index of names, so it is difficult to find information on individuals. The Library of Congress has compiled a 166-page guide that lists general subjects in chronological order, but it will be years before the complete value of the trove will be realized.
As the records accumulated, the American Communists packed them up and shipped them to Moscow, Mr. Haynes said. The party was not illegal and there was no restriction on exporting such files, so the papers are thought to have simply been sent by freight until World War II broke out in 1939 and Soviet diplomats probably sent them out in pouches. 
Few people in Moscow evidently took the time to read them, and they were eventually placed in storage in western Siberia to be largely forgotten until Mr. Anderson, the Russian archivist, mentioned them to Mr. Haynes.
"It was a weird feeling to see this material pop up, material that I never expected to see," Professor Klehr said. "I'm not even sure members of the Communist Party knew it existed."

HEADLINE: Investment Opportunity. Strings Attached.; 
Musician and 15 Partners Join Forces to Acquire a Multimillion-Dollar Violin

BYLINE:  By SUSAN ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
 Five years ago Robert McDuffie found the instrument of his dreams: a 1735 Guarneri del Gesu violin known as the Ladenburg, whose list of players has included the 19th-century virtuosos Nicolo Paganini and Ludwig Spohr. It came with a sheaf of papers attesting to its pedigree; it was in mint condition. 
 "I had fallen in love," said Mr. McDuffie, 42, an affable Georgia-born New Yorker. This was the instrument that would take him to the next level of his burgeoning career. 
"It was more than an extension of my body," he remembered thinking. "It was an extension of my musical personality." 
There was only one problem. The price was $3.5 million.
The instrument's owner, Dietmar Machold of Machold Rare Violins, with offices near Lincoln Center, agreed to let Mr. McDuffie keep playing the Ladenburg (named for the German banking family that owned it in the mid-19th century) while he looked for a way to pay for it. That long and arduous quest, full of false starts and harsh doses of reality, came to a successful conclusion yesterday in the office of the Wall Street law firm Seward & Kissel. There, a group of 16 investors calling itself 1735 del Gesu Partners L.P., officially purchased the Ladenburg from Mr. Machold for the express purpose of leasing it to Mr. McDuffie. 
There are 16 partners in all, including Mr. McDuffie and Mr. Machold; the shares cost $100,000 each. Mr. McDuffie does not pay rent; his obligation is to play the violin, so it will maintain its value, and to pay for its maintenance and insurance, which he estimates at $15,000 to $20,000 a year. At the end of the 25-year lease (actually 23; it is retroactive to 1998), Mr. McDuffie is to return the instrument to the partnership, which intends to sell it, presumably at a profit.
The violin was appraised in 1999 for $3.5 million by the violin consultant in Christie's musical instrument department. It has already more than doubled in value since Mr. Machold purchased it from a collector in Europe under a confidential arrangement for $1.2 million in 1989. Were it to continue increasing in value at that rate (about 10 percent a year), an optimistic projection, the partners would wind up with about $25.7 million after taxes. A more conservative rate of 5.5 percent a year would yield close to $10.3 million. 
The price of rare violins makes it virtually impossible for individuals to afford them. In Europe, the Middle East, and Japan, governments or businesses purchase these instruments and lend them for little or no fee. The Fuji Corporation owned the Jupiter Stradivari that Midori played in 1991. Mr. Machold estimated he has sold $25 million worth of string instruments to the National Bank of Austria, including seven Stradivari and two Guarneri del Gesu violins, which are on loan to, among others, members of the Vienna Philharmonic. 
Giuseppe Guarneri (1699-1774), considered the greatest member of his family of Italian instrument makers, was known as Gesu (Jesus) because he signed his handiwork with a cross. His violin is preferred by most soloists over the more common Stradivari, primarily for its ability to soar over an orchestra. Midori, Anne-Sophie Mutter and Pinchas Zukerman play them, as did Jascha Heifetz and Fritz Kreisler. Mr. McDuffie said about 100 del Gesu violins still exist, as opposed to nearly 700 Stradivari. 
Mr. Machold, who also has offices in Bremen, Germany; Zurich; Vienna; and Tokyo, is eager to point out the potential for huge profits. "Prices never go down for these instruments," said Mr. Machold, who holds 3.5 of the $100,000 shares. "They only go up." But the other partners take a less sanguine view. 
"I certainly didn't commit with the expectation that it's going to provide an economic return that is better than other alternatives," said John Townsend, a del Gesu partner who is also a partner in Goldman, Sachs, the investment bankers. "That really isn't what it's about for me. It's about my friendship with Bobby and my interest in his career. The more I learned about the importance of this instrument to how he defines himself as an artist, the more I realized that we had to find a way to make this happen."
Mr. McDuffie realized that he would have to come out from behind the violin to attract investors, he said. "As one family member said to me, 'It's going to be hard to convince business people in America that a piece of wood costs $3.5 million.' And that turned out to be true. I had to come to terms with the fact that these people were investing in me, more than they were in the violin. It became very personal."
A well-established, highly respected violinist who has performed extensively in the United States, Europe and Asia, Mr. McDuffie favors contemporary repertory -- this season he is playing concertos by both John Adams and Philip Glass -- yet is adept with the lyrical war horses of Mendelssohn and Bruch as well.
The partners range from heavy-hitting Wall Street types to parents of Mr. McDuffie's 10-year-old daughter's classmates to the commissioner of the National Football League. About the only thing they have in common -- aside from some spare cash -- is an interest in Mr. McDuffie and his career.
"We wanted Bobby to continue his rise to the top of his profession," said the N.F.L. commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, a longtime friend. "And this seemed like the only way it was going to get done. There has to be some way for talented Americans to have access to these instruments."
While it is hard to imagine an American bank buying a rare violin and lending it for altruistic purposes, there are individual American collectors, like Herbert Axelrod in Allenhurst, N.J., who lend instruments from their collections. Leasing an instrument from a limited partnership is, by all accounts, unique. 
Mr. McDuffie said he arrived at the idea after a great deal of trial and error, not to mention disillusionment. Five years ago, "I actually thought finding $3.5 million would be a slam dunk," he said. "I had fallen in love with the violin of my dreams, and I thought I could tap into the Southern 'We're so proud of you, Bobby' thing." Mr. McDuffie is from Macon, Ga.; his wife, Camille, a book publicist, is from Atlanta, where her father, Mack Taylor, now retired, was arguably the city's most successful real estate magnate.
Early in 1996 Mr. McDuffie approached James B. Williams, a family friend who at the time was chairman of SunTrust Banks Inc. in Atlanta. "I was sure SunTrust would buy this violin, and I would promote the bank all around the world," Mr. McDuffie said. "But then Jimmy said, 'Well, it's great you play in Hong Kong, but we don't really care about Hong Kong.' "
Then there was the bank loan strategy, with 18 partners paying $10,000 each annually on a 6 percent loan. "That never got off the ground either," Mr. McDuffie said. "But it did make me realize I was in for a rough ride."
Having arrived at the limited partnership plan by the summer of 1998, he went looking for investors. A series of by-invitation-only soirees ensued in the designer homes of well-heeled friends and family members. To draw up his guest lists, "I pulled out the Rolodex," said Mr. McDuffie, who would play and talk about the instrument. Then Mr. Machold would discuss its pedigree (and his own).
Mr. Tagliabue and his wife, Chan, were at the first party, in January 1999. They were not quite ready to invest, they said, but they were intrigued enough to be hosts for additional gatherings. One took place in February 2000 in Atlanta at the home of Mr. Taylor. Guests included Senator Sam Nunn; Taylor Smith, owner of the Atlanta Falcons; and the bassist for the band R.E.M., Mike Mills, a childhood friend of Mr. McDuffie's.
"I've always been moved by Bobby's playing," said Mr. Mills, who became a partner. "I saw it as a remarkable chance to join in with a real diverse group of people and see an old friend of mine better able to express his talent."
The guest list at the final evening, last May at the Tagliabues' New York apartment, included a friend of the commissioner's who agreed to add the final $1 million to the pot. (He insisted on anonymity.) At last Mr. McDuffie and the partnership had reached their goal. 
"Giving money to a project like this is so much more personal than just sending a check to the Metropolitan," said Mr. Machold. But the partners do not get the same tax break. Mr. Tagliabue jokingly called his investment "a charitable contribution without a deduction."
Still, as Mr. Machold pointed out: "You do get your money back after 23 years. And there's the player. You can touch him."
Mr. McDuffie said he would perform at two private concerts a year for his partners, who will be kept up to date on his career through a newsletter. They will also be invited to an annual event at Mr. Machold's Castle Eichbuchl in southern Austria. 
"I can see more people, as they think about their commitment to the arts, doing this," said Mr. Townsend. "Instead of buying a $100,000 painting, why not invest in a violin? Especially if they have a personal relationship with the artist."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 16, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Feb. 6 about a group investment in the 18th-century instrument played by the violinist Robert McDuffie misstated the birth and death years of its maker, Giuseppe Guarneri, known as Gesu. He lived from 1698 to 1744 -- not 1699 to 1774.

HEADLINE: Europe Is One -- Until Disaster Strikes 

BYLINE:  By Tony Judt; Tony Judt is director of the Remarque Institute at New York University.

DATELINE: LONDON 

 BODY:
There are two versions of what is happening in Europe. One asserts that things couldn't be going better for the European Union. The Germans are in the driver's seat, confidently leading everyone else (including the reluctant French) toward a larger, more integrated community. The German foreign minister is bursting with ambitious projects for a European presidency and a European constitution. Productivity is up, unemployment down. Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank, can hardly contain his satisfaction at the prospect of a recession in the United States and the resurgence of the euro. The hour of Europe has struck. We are the masters now!
 Seen through a darker glass, however, the Continent is awash in scandal. Well-attested charges of influence-peddling, graft, money laundering and illegal party funding have brought down senior ministers and retired statesmen in Britain, Germany and France. The Italian and Belgian courts are still poring over the lurid political crimes of decades past. The political class in West Europe stands lower in public esteem than at any point in recent memory. And then there is the crisis in public health. 
 Today's European medical scandals take two forms. The first is government irresponsibility. The worst case involved H.I.V.-tainted blood in French hospital transfusions in the mid-1980's: 4,000 mostly hemophiliac patients were given the blood, and hundreds died. A blood-screening test was available from an American company, but the French health ministry had banned it -- preferring to wait, the families of the victims charged, for a competing French product to come on the market. In a trial concluded last year, the ministers concerned were held blameless even though the facts about the government's response were not in dispute. One of those tried, Laurent Fabius, is now the French finance minister.
The other kind of scandal involves administrative incompetence and private greed. Across the Continent there is a steadily rising panic about bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. Cattle appear to get mad cow because they were fed recycled bits of dead sheep and other animals. Humans who eat infected cattle risk contracting a new variant of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; so far 92 people have died -- 88 of them in Britain, where the disease was first diagnosed and where 180,000 cases of mad cow have been found in cattle to date.
Faced with an incipient epidemic, the British government finally came clean two years ago, had all older cattle killed and instituted universal testing of livestock. In other affected countries, the initial reaction was the same as in Britain: It isn't happening, and if it is, don't acknowledge it. Public ignorance was preferable to the only expedient response, which was to slaughter all the infected herds, test the remaining cattle and publicize the known risks. That remedy is hugely expensive and a disaster for the farmers.
French and other European governments confined themselves to banning the import of British livestock and cattle feed, politically popular measures that did little to halt the spread of the disease. Then came the news that mad cow had spread to continental Europe and that four more individuals had died from Creutzfeldt-Jakob. Meat consumption collapsed, and prices with it. Farmers were angry and desperate. 
Finally, the Europeans began to act. The Germans, who had insouciantly denied that the problem even concerned them, admitted the presence of mad cows on their soil and last week announced a plan to slaughter 400,000 cattle. And on Dec. 4, the European Union banned the use of animal products in cattle feed and ordered the removal of all cattle over the age of 30 months unless they were tested and proved to be disease-free. Because testing capacity is limited, more than two million cattle are likely to be slaughtered.
The mad cow scandal ought to be a tremendous opportunity for Brussels to flex its muscles. After all, the one thing an oversize bureaucracy should be good at is protecting public health. National governments are in thrall to electorates, pressure groups and self-interest, but the European Commission answers to no one and can thus do the right thing without impediment.
Unfortunately, reality is otherwise. The only way European governments will accede to the recent commission directives is if the European Union takes the blame -- and foots the bill (the belated German agreement to destroy suspect herds is contingent on Brussels footing half the $300 million cost). But this means countries must increase their own contributions to the union's budget, which they are extremely reluctant to do.
Instead, European governments proceed incrementally, stonewalling and blaming foreign governments for their domestic predicaments. France still bans British beef. The Finnish representatives in Brussels agreed only with great reluctance to the latest European Union directives. Their animals, they insisted (as the French and Germans had), were unaffected.
The outcome is thus the opposite of what might be expected. Brussels issues orders, which are then loudly protested in each individual country, and then the E.U. is condemned by press and public for being ineffective. The E.U. seems to be just an abstraction -- except when it is blamed in the tabloids for allowing diseased meat and other pollution across unpoliced national borders. Meanwhile, hapless European consumers can turn only to their own governments. Tony Blair, Lionel Jospin and Gerhard Schroder may seem irresponsible, cynical and even incompetent, but at least they are familiar and local: you can always vent your fear and fury on them at the next election.
Peter Sutherland, a former European commissioner from Ireland, recently dismissed polls suggesting that Europeans are increasingly skeptical about European integration. These worries, he intimated, were an insignificant hangover from the benighted "petty nationalisms" of the past. That is one view of Europe today. If only it were true.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS; 
30-Year Treasuries Rise a Bit On Speculation Sales Will End

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds prices were mixed yesterday with the 30-year bond rising on speculation the government's sale of 30-year debt this week may be one of the last.
 Investors clamored for bonds since a Treasury advisory panel last week held an informal vote to eliminate sales of the debt after August. That would enhance the value of bonds whose prices are already buoyed as the government buys back the high-cost debt with money from budget surpluses. 
 "There is an antique bid for the 30-year" bond, said Sam Paddison, who helps manage $16 billion at Evergreen Institutional Asset Management in Philadelphia. "They are all going to go and buy them because there aren't going to be anymore," though they may already be overvalued, he said.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 111 1/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.49 percent from 5.51 percent on Friday.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 6/32, to a price of 104 11/32. Its yield rose to 5.17 percent from 5.14 percent.
Bonds gained 21.3 percent last year as the Treasury bought back $30 billion of the debt, a program that has continued this year.
Treasury notes did not get the same boost, and fell as some bond dealers sold current issues to force prices lower on the $22 billion in 4 3/4- and 10-year debt set for sale today and tomorrow, traders said. Another $10 billion in 30-year bonds is set for Thursday. Primary dealers are required to bid, though not buy, at government sales.

HEADLINE: Obtaining Loans Got Harder in Last 3 Months, Survey Says 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
Worried bankers kept toughening their terms for loans to businesses and consumers the last three months as they grew more concerned that they might not be repaid, according to a Federal Reserve survey released today.
 "In general, banks indicated that the most important reasons for tightening standards and terms were a worsening economic outlook and a reduced tolerance for risk," said the report, which surveyed 57 large American banks and 24 branches of foreign-owned banks operating in the United States. 
 The results of the previous such survey were issued in mid-November. The new one said 60 percent of domestic banks tightened terms for lending to larger companies the last three months, and 80 percent of foreign banks imposed stiffer terms for customers seeking commercial and industrial loans. 
"Lending terms also firmed noticeably on the consumer side," the survey reported. It said "a much larger fraction of domestic banks" had tightened their terms for consumer loans than in November, although they had not changed standards for home mortgage loans.
The Fed said banks reported weaker demand for loans, but noted that mortgage applications on average had remained steady after falling in the November survey.
"Changes in demand for residential mortgages were quite disparate across respondents, with 30 percent reporting stronger demand and an equal fraction reporting weakness," the Fed said. "By contrast, about 33 percent of banks, on net, reported weaker demand for home mortgages in the November survey."
The report echoed Fed studies from previous months that said banks were exercising more caution in lending. In November, the Fed reported that 44 percent of domestic banks and 80 percent of foreign banks had tightened their lending standards the previous three months.
Lending standards have become stricter because the economy has slowed from its previous blistering pace. A slowing economy raises the risk that firms and individuals may be unable to repay loans if profits and incomes falter.
Some economists have said that bank lending standards became too slack the last several years and that tightening loan conditions would be a healthy development.
But some analysts worry that the United States may soon be faced with lending standards that are so tight that companies and consumers cannot obtain loans. Such a development could harm the already fragile economy by reducing business investment and consumer spending, two key drivers of the record economic expansion.

HEADLINE: Empty Aisles and Empty Stores; 
What Happens When Anchor Stores Weigh Anchor?

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Bradlees was the first to give up the fight. Then Montgomery Ward's, the long-troubled retailer, declared bankruptcy in late December, concluding that consumer spending was too soft to prop it up through the upcoming year. Soon after retailers like J. C. Penney, Sears, ShopKo, and OfficeMax all announced store closings.
 It is not unusual for some bad news to pop up in the retailing business right after Christmas -- many troubled stores insist on hanging on through December in hopes that the holiday spending surge will deliver a Frank Capra-style miracle. But this year's wave of distress is deeper and broader than any in a decade, according to lenders, liquidators and bankruptcy experts. The problems signal that the nation's merchants and their suppliers, already over-extended, are probably about to experience a painful shake-out, where chains are forced to close or scale back their ambitions. 
 "Bradlees and Montgomery are the edge of the curve," said Harvey Miller, who is in charge of the restructuring practice at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges. "What they are demonstrating is that there are major weaknesses in the market." 
Moody's Investors Service said the likelihood that publicly held retail companies will default sometime this year on a bank loan, outstanding bond or other form of debt has doubled from the beginning of 2000. That represents a surge in weakness that makes retailing the second-most-vulnerable industry -- behind telecommunications -- said David Hamilton, a risk analyst at Moody's.
The list of retailers whose stocks, bonds, or bank debt has sunk to distressed levels in the last year is long and ugly. Depressed prices do not, of course, indicate that bankruptcy is imminent, or even that store closures will be necessary, but they do usually indicate that a company's financial position has become particularly fragile.
The indicators are everywhere.
There has been a rise in the number of companies whose bank debt is suddenly thought to be worth a lot less than it was just a few months ago. "In the last year there has been a greater number of distressed loans in the retail sector," said Marc Lasry, managing director of Amroc Investments Inc., the country's largest broker-dealer of distressed debt.
A bank that owns part of a loan to Warnaco, the manufacturer of Calvin Klein jeans and underwear, for example, recently offered to sell the loan to any bidder that would pay 55 cents on the dollar. It got no takers, according to Amroc, which facilitates private trades of bank debt.
The private market for the bank debt of Revlon has also sunk beneath 90 cents on the dollar, Amroc said. 
Credits ratings are falling almost as quickly as the Nasdaq was last year. In the past four months alone, Moody's has downgraded the debt of both Saks and ShopKo Stores from investment quality to junk. Dillard's and J. C. Penney, are having their credit reviewed by Moody's. If they are downgraded, both would see their credit slip from investment grade to junk.
And while stock prices for retailers as a whole have risen lately, partly on expectations that the recent interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve will help revive consumer confidence and partly due to stronger-than-expected January sales, many retailers are suffering from sharply lower prices on Wall Street.
Among the stocks trading beneath the bargain basement price of 50 cents a share are Lechter's, the houseware chain, and Today's Man, which was delisted from Nasdaq in July. 
Delia's, a retailer to teenage girls, is off its 52-week high of $13.75 a share and is trading under $5. Last November, Delia's merged with iTurf, an e-commerce operation it had actually launched itself and then spun off as its own entity. The company's spokesperson, Amanda Mullin, said, "We do not believe that evaluating the company on the basis of the stock price of a single pre-merger entity is an accurate reflection of the combined entity's performance."
There are plenty of strong retailers out there, of course. No one thinks skilled operators like Wal-Mart Stores, Target and Gap cannot thrive in a downturn. They may actually benefit from carnage elsewhere. A wave of bankruptcies not only leaves less competition, but also offers an abundance of empty stores and brand name trademarks that can be snapped up for a bargain. 
Yet even as the Fed is attempting to ride to the rescue, industry gatherings are rife with whispers about the weakest of the weak, about chains closing some stores in hopes of saving the rest, and of consolidations across the retailing landscape aimed at eliminating some of the excess retailing space that sprouted in the boom of the 1990's.
"I've been doing this for 14 years," said Stewart Cohen, a partner in the Ozer Group, a liquidation and restructuring firm based in Needham, Mass., "and there is nothing like what we have experienced in the last 30 days in terms of the number of stores and the billions of inventory up for liquidation."
Numerous factors are putting pressure on the industry. First and foremost is the economy. Consumer confidence in the nation's near-term economic health has plummeted to its lowest point since 1993, the Conference Board, a business research concern in New York, reported last week. Retailing is always among the first to feel the effects of a consumer pullback in lower sales and profits.
Retailers are also being hurt by their own over-enthusiasm. During the boom of the second half of the 1990's, retail companies expanded operations at a brisk, some say suicidal, pace. Retail square footage in this coutry increased by nearly a billion square feet, or 10 percent, for the five years from 1995 to 2000, according to Economy.com, a consulting firm based in West Chester, Pa., that closely follows national and regional economic trends.
The Ames Department Store chain is an example of a merchant that has paid a price for its optimism. In 1998, the chain snapped up the 155 outlets of Hills Stores to add to 301 of its own. It was a bold move considering that regional department stores like Ames were just beginning to face crushing competition from national competitors like Wal-Mart and Target and that Ames itself had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1990, a result of too much debt from a previous acquisition.
When the economy went flat in 2000, Ames found itself struggling and in November of last year it announced it would close 32 stores, 31 of them from the Hills acquisition. The price of Ames' stock and its bonds tumbled in 2000 and were trading at very depressed levels until January of this year when GE Capital extended an $800 million line of credit.
"Maybe projections should have been more pessimistic," said Rolando de Aguiar, the company's chief financial and administrative officer, "but back then people just did not believe we could come out of a year with 6.2 percent growth and go flat."
Ames is far from alone in paying for industry expansion. Lenders are increasingly anxious about the mid-decade boom.
"There is no doubt that credit is tightening," said Andrew Moser, senior managing director at Wells Fargo Retail Finance, one of the nation's leading asset-based lenders to retailers. "In many of the nation's top banks, the level of nonperforming loans has increased continuously. So there is a lot of pressure internally from within these institutions or from regulators to re-evaluate loan portfolios."
Speeding the rate and severity of the credit cutback is the fact that the retail lending community has itself consolidated considerably in the last decade, leaving the fate of needy merchants primarily in the hands of fewer than a dozen major banks and other lenders known as factors.
And for the weakest retailers -- those contemplating bankruptcy -- the incentive for their lenders is to file early and get ahead of other retailers who might have fire sales that depress the value of everyone's inventories of clothing, housewares and the like. If enough merchants have been mortally wounded, it could depress prices long into the future.
"To the extent that there is a significant number of store closings, it could create a spiral effect," said Robert Pressman, chief executive, of Newmark Retail Financial Advisors, a consulting firm. "If a lot of retailers run going-out-of-business sales at once, the value of the inventory drops and it becomes a general industry problem."
The question now is whether the weakness among some retailers can be contained. It is possible that the cut in interest rates by the Fed will spur consumers to spend, thus slowing or stopping the cycle of bankruptcies. 
But at the mall level, store closings can also hurt merchants located nearby.
"With store closings by Penney's and Ward's taking place at the same time, you are going to see gigantic empty stores in malls, all on the market at the same time," said Larry Gottlieb, who runs the bankruptcy department at the law firm of Kronish Lieb Weiner and Hellman in New York. "What happens to businesses in the malls with two empty anchors?"

HEADLINE: Tunnel Vision; 
A Die-Hard Few Cling to Those Tokens

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
They are creatures of habit. They remember better days gone by. They don't trust technology. They frustrate economic theorists, refusing to change their behavior in exchange for a bargain.
 In the language of marketing, they are known as the nonadopters. 
 The rest of us can think of them as the token people.
And they are a dwindling breed, one that knows its days are numbered. New York City Transit reported last month that MetroCard users now represent more than 81 percent of the fare-paying public. The agency also said recently that within the next two years it expected to start phasing out tokens, which have served as tiny relics of the true New York since the first ones were minted in 1953.
Most people with reservations about switching have already put them aside in the seven years since the MetroCard was introduced.
But the token people, like the last old settlers to come down from the hills, are the ones who say they will hold out until the last token slot is welded shut.
"Other people can do what they want to do," said Jimmy Harris, a 50-year-old porter, who grew almost defiant the other day at the Times Square subway station when asked why he does not use MetroCards. "I like tokens, that's why."
All around them, the token people have seen their friends and co-workers slowly lose that certain jingle in their pockets.
Of course, this switch has not always been easy for the millions who have made it.
Staking out a token booth for a couple of hours, one can still detect a high level of affection for the token, an affection that seems mostly to do with urban practicality.
Flimsy cards can get bent. They can get lost in wallets, wallets that must be pulled out and exposed to thieves while lost cards are being fumbled for. The cards can also lose their magnetic whatchamacallit or require you to swipe them 10 times. But, unless you happen to get caught in a metal press on your way to the turnstile, your token will always work.
The other benefit to the token in many riders' minds is that it requires no math. One token equals one ride. It does not offer a discount, but it will also never be hiding an extra ride within it somewhere that you have forgotten about.
M. A. Horn, a credit manager, really, really did not want to switch. And he's still mad about it. "They forced me to do it," he exclaimed the other day outside a Times Square turnstile. "And they force me to buy lots of trips. If I don't, then I'm passing up free trips. And then I'm a fool." (Mr. Horn has clearly spent too much time thinking about this. He called a reporter later to explain that he had calculated that a penniless homeless person would have to redeem 300 bottles or cans to gather enough money to purchase a $15 MetroCard, the cheapest card that offers a volume discount. "Think of that!" Mr. Horn said.)
Norman Siegel, a civil liberties lawyer, did not want to switch either. Like everyone else, he gave in mostly because of the discounts. But he still does not use a credit card when he buys his MetroCard. And he still worries, every time he stands before a MetroCard machine, about the ability of the government to track people who use the card.
"I don't want them knowing where I'm going, even though I'm as innocent as anyone in the city and as lawful as anyone in the city," he said. "And you don't have to be paranoid to think that way."
Many of the true token people feel the same way, except they will not be dissuaded by discounts.
Carlos Fernandez, 23, a senior at the State University of New York in Purchase, reported by e-mail that when he tried out the MetroCard, he felt as if he were entering a kind of government-controlled "Area 51, where every little bit of information and detail is scrutinized."
In his message, he added: "Who will be there to open the gate manually when the M.T.A. computers befall a belated Y2K? In the era of online hackers, one can never be too certain."
Nick Liopiros, a waiter, is among that rarest of token people, one who has never even tried a MetroCard. "Forty one years in city, only token," he said. "This MetroCard, no. Never." He added: "With me is strong habit."
But that might be changing. Mr. Liopiros was asked if he felt a certain amount of pride in stubbornly passing up the discounts offered by the MetroCard. His countenance quickly changed. He leaned his stubbly face in close to the questioner.
"They give discount?"

HEADLINE: Setting Tempo at a Charter School; 
Bronx Prep Offers a Teacher Plenty of Room to Improvise

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
He is the maitre d'hotel, sprinkling firm handshakes around the breakfast buffet of Cheerios and apple juice. He is the drill sergeant, conducting backpack inspections at lunch.
 He is the Pied Piper leading star pupils in the island rap song "Who Let the Dogs Out" as they traipse across a movie theater parking lot, the reading coach tapping drumstick to table as struggling students sound out each word: wait, paint, sail, main, fail. 
 And on Saturday mornings, that music spilling down the stairs comes from the third-floor classroom where Jesus Concepcion conducts an orchestra of 57 youngsters who first picked up instruments when they met him last summer.
Hired as a 10-hour-a-week music teacher when the Bronx Preparatory Charter School opened its doors in August in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx, Mr. Concepcion has become the school's go-to guy. Now on staff full-time, his business cards say director of enrichment, but Mr. Concepcion also teaches and tutors reading and math as well as arts appreciation, and sets the disciplinary tone with a tough-love blend of terror and teasing that has won the hearts of the black and Latino children he calls "my son," "my brother," "my queen." 
Like any startup, a charter school in its first year confronts many challenges -- say, breakfast supervision -- not quite anticipated by the business plan. That, in turn, provides young staff members like Mr. Concepcion, 27, an uncertified teacher with an emergency teaching credential, the chance to reinvent themselves in roles -- say, reading teacher -- they had not imagined.
"We didn't sit down and say, 'You do this, and you do that,' " he said with a shrug. "I was never told that I had to do breakfast and I had to do lunch. It just happened because I was there. And now I have to be there."
There are extraordinary teachers picking up extra tasks at every successful school. But charter schools, in which entrepreneurs create ambitious educational programs that use public funds but are free of most state regulation, demand such flexibility, initiative and long hours from everyone. A recent study by Caroline Hoxby, a Harvard economist, found that charter school employees teach 13.4 hours a week more than what is required, compared with 8.6 extra hours per week for their public school counterparts.
At Bronx Prep, the schedule can switch weekly, even daily, with teachers forced to cover others' classes on a few minutes' notice. Like Mr. Concepcion, everyone runs at least one reading section, using an intensive phonics program. 
In August, there were computer work stations to assemble. This fall, the entire staff helped write the school's accountability plan, and now teachers are having dinner meetings to plan recruiting and curriculum for next year.
Before anybody discussed holiday decorations, a reading teacher had gift-wrapped classroom doors in shiny paper and big bows. A math teacher is helping design Bronx Prep's expansion through high school. On Sundays, the science teacher often shops for supplies, while a reading teacher sometimes takes girls to the movies. And when a boy's alcoholic father died last fall, Mr. Concepcion brought the child home to Cliffside Park, N.J., for the weekend.
"He demonstrates what charter schools crave in a startup team," Kristin Kearns Jordan, Bronx Prep's director, said of Mr. Concepcion, known as Mr. C. "Recognizing a need and jumping in."
On the day Bronx Prep's 100 fifth and sixth graders returned from a two-week winter break, Mr. C had 90 free minutes between 7:30 a.m. breakfast and 5 p.m. dismissal.
He helped Ms. Jordan teach the word of the day, "justice," at a morning meeting; ran his two 15-student phonics sessions; had two periods of arts appreciation, each with 50 pupils; met with his advisory group for 45 minutes; and conducted an hourlong orchestra rehearsal. 
Someone was out sick, so he also inherited the entire sixth grade for an hour and a half just before lunch.
With Martin Luther King's Birthday approaching, Mr. Concepcion found a crutch in a video biography of the civil rights hero. But the television he lugged upstairs was broken. By the time a second TV worked, the VCR refused to. Children were coming through the door, and he had no lesson plan.
"Take out your 'I have a dream' speech,' " the impromptu social-studies teacher ad-libbed. Soon, pupils packed into tight rows were reciting Dr. King's words, stumbling through the new vocabulary -- "promissory note," "emancipation," "tranquillity," "invigorating" -- and debating the unfinished civil rights agenda.
"What do you want?" Mr. Concepcion asked the class.
Johnny Menzies offered, "We want to be able to vote, to have expensive jobs, to live in fancy houses, to have everything the white man has."
Eric Sanchez added, "We want to be able to be truly equal." 
Mr. Concepcion, who is half Dominican and half Puerto Rican and grew up just a few blocks from the school, prodded further: "What are we still fighting for?"
Tayisha Western proclaimed, "Freedom."
Johnny said, "To be able to wear whatever you want without being judged by what you wear."
Joseph Cordero added, "To pick your own job."
Whether teaching history or the origins of the bass and treble clefs, Mr. Concepcion keeps tight control of his classroom with a sharp eye and booming voice, easily engaging even groups of 50 or 100 children. 
He mixes charm and chastisement as easily as he switches from English to fluent Spanish, and breaks lessons into digestible parts, reviewing relentlessly. Routinely singling out students by name, he alternates between hollering and heh-heh-heh, eyes bulging in anger one minute, teeth bared in a smile the next.
A dapper dresser who buys discount designer shoes in the Dominican Republic and wears a shiny watch and a bracelet plus a ring on each hand, Mr. C keeps a meticulous classroom of swept floors, chairs in perfect lines. It is often freezing in his third-floor domain, but coats are forbidden. Students' backs must never touch their chairs. Gum is verboten. Every index finger must follow along when someone reads aloud.
The children, eager to please a teacher they love, respond with almost undivided attention. In a reading session one morning, fifth graders tapped feet in time as they shouted sounds and words like cheerleaders at a football game.
When Mr. C stepped into the hallway to meet a surprise visitor, they continued uninterrupted.
"The trick to being a good teacher is to be able to break it down for people," he explained. "There's that gift of being able to dominate their attention and being able to draw them in.
"I think I could teach anything."
Mr. Concepcion is one of several defining elements of Bronx Prep imported from the KIPP Academy, a charter school about a mile away that has earned national recognition and is being replicated around the country. Bronx Prep's principal, Marina Bernard Damiba, was among the founding teachers at KIPP, which stands for the Knowledge Is Power Program; in addition to Mr. Concepcion, she brought a reading teacher with her and has hired KIPP's professional developer, Frederick Shannon, as a consultant.
Both schools have long hours and an extended school year. Both use the "Shannon Plan," organizing every lesson around a clear aim, which is written on the board along with an agenda, and assessing monthly reading skills with pre- and post-tests. The walls of both buildings are papered with inspirational sayings -- "Team always beats individual" is a KIPP staple, "TEAM: Together Everyone Achieves More" a Bronx Prep motto.
And both have impressive orchestral programs featuring violins, a rarity in such poor, minority neighborhoods.
Yet if the schools look like sisters, they are estranged. In bringing capitalism to public education, the charter movement also creates intense competition -- for attention, for private funds, for talent. So while leaders of both schools say their mutual success will benefit the community, they do not cooperate in tackling shared problems like the search for a long-term facility. In fact, they seldom speak.
Much of the enmity surrounds Mr. Concepcion, who originally planned to remain at KIPP full-time this year, moonlighting at Bronx Prep (he also works a few hours a week at Aquinas High School in the Bronx). 
But at KIPP, he was second fiddle to Charles Randall, a renowned orchestra director who had taught young Jesus to play the violin back in sixth grade at Intermediate School 166, a public school nearby, and plans to retire next year. Mr. Concepcion quit KIPP just before Labor Day, seeing more opportunity in Bronx Prep, which plans to expand through grade 12. "Just the idea that it was going to be my baby," he said. 
Mr. C's love affair with music began as a grade-school crush. "There was this pretty girl in the orchestra," he said. "Her name was Melissa Torres. I said, I want to be in the orchestra, I want to play whatever she's playing. You know what happens with kids, we started to hate each other," he said, laughing. "She was first chair. By the end of sixth grade, I had the chair."
He soon joined the elite citywide orchestra, and was admitted to La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts, then Manhattan School of Music. Just a year old when his father, a guitarist, committed suicide, landing his mother, a nurse's aide, on welfare, Mr. Concepcion proudly repaid his private violin tutor $600 for hours of discount lessons once he had grown up. Soon Mr. Concepcion realized he favored conducting over playing, and teaching most of all. "Most of my kids don't have an ear," he said of the children he auditioned this summer by asking them to repeat a series of clapping rhythms. "I didn't have an ear -- but I had a love for it."
Bronx Prep planned a 40-student orchestra, but now 57 crowd in for rehearsals three afternoons a week and on Saturday mornings, while others pester Mr. C every day trying to join (the school has spent about $40,000 on equipment). As they enter the room, the children chant, "Stick count four, stick count four," and stomp out four beats before sitting in unison. Often, after the group plays well, Mr. C will say, "Do it again, it was probably a mistake."
One Saturday, Ayana Gotay, a fifth-grade violinist, showed up 25 minutes late for rehearsal, so Mr. Concepcion -- after screaming at her -- made her stand at the front of the room, hands folded, for 25 minutes. When Sharif Jamel, a drummer had a "bad rhythm day," Mr. C gave him two leaves of a plant to bang together. Robert Brunner, a keyboardist, was suspended a few days before the winter concert for not doing his homework.
"I'm not going to accept anything less than perfect," Mr. Concepcion erupted one day, catching a drummer off tempo. "You were daydreaming, and you went on automatic. When you're a musician, you can't do that."
He quizzed the violinists, solo, on "Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star." Alex Marcano got booted from the first chair because he did not have rosin in his case. One by one, they squeaked out the notes, Mr. Concepcion interrupting after each mistake to rotate players, until Christian Green, a quiet sixth grader, ended up in the hot seat.
"There's a title for that chair, it's concert master," Mr. Concepcion said. "The person who's sitting there is there because they busted their butts to get there. You are setting the example for all of the orchestra."

HEADLINE: DiFrancesco Faces Cameras In New Jersey 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco today told New Jersey residents that he would fight to lower property taxes, end racial profiling and improve children's health, all in his first few months in office, while he assured state lawmakers that he would work closely with them, a break from the practice of his predecessor, Christie Whitman.
 Mr. DiFrancesco, the Republican president of the State Senate who is also a candidate for a full term as governor in this year's elections, billed his first televised speech to the Legislature as a message to the people of New Jersey. 
But he appealed most directly to the assembled lawmakers, calling on them to put "people ahead of politics."
"I do believe in consensus," he said, adding: "While my title may have changed, I promise that my commitment to this partnership will never end." The line prompted his only standing ovation.
If Mr. DiFrancesco's talk of bipartisanship echoed President Bush's, his small-bore agenda seemed to borrow liberally from Mrs. Whitman, who resigned on Wednesday to lead the federal Environmental Protection Agency. 
The acting governor proposed a new "workplace basic skills program" to help those at the bottom end of the economic ladder make themselves more marketable to employers. And he said he would ask his new education commissioner to set up "the very best teacher training, retention and recruitment program in the nation."
"New Jersey is already the best place in which to live, work and raise a family," Mr. DiFrancesco said, repeating Mrs. Whitman's well-worn line. "Let's also make it the best place to teach a child."
While Mr. DiFrancesco praised his predecessor, he also unveiled a style markedly different from that of Mrs. Whitman, who was given to entering the Assembly chamber surrounded by bodyguards and whose aristocratic bearing could be irritating to lawmakers. Reading from notes rather than from a teleprompter, Mr. DiFrancesco spoke plainly, referred several times to his late parents, who immigrated from Italy, and mocked his receding hairline.
But Mrs. Whitman came to Trenton in 1993 as an outsider, while Mr. DiFrancesco has worked here his entire legislative life. And although he had made a point of inviting the public to attend his address today, all but a few seats were filled by lobbyists and political operatives.
Mr. DiFrancesco also confronted the contentious issue of racial profiling, albeit delicately, at a time when Democrats like James E. McGreevey, the Woodbridge mayor who is running for governor, are vowing to hold him accountable for the Whitman administration's failures.
Mr. DiFrancesco neither placed blame nor took responsibility, but spoke generally of calling on New Jersey's tradition of embracing in diversity "as we face the ugly truth of racial profiling."
"This unjustified and unjustifiable practice has divided this state and has hurt the reputation of New Jersey's upstanding law enforcement officers," he said. "It is time for answers, for outreach and for solutions."
Mr. DiFrancesco did not say how he would end racial profiling, but said he awaited the recommendations of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which has begun interviewing witnesses in private and is expected to hold public hearings within weeks. "Our commitment to end racial profiling is unwavering," Mr. DiFrancesco said. "But just as strong is our commitment to stand behind the members of law enforcement who deserve our support because they've earned it."
Mr. DiFrancesco devoted much of his 21-minute speech to his previously announced plan to provide greater property tax rebates to homeowners. He wants to double the New Jersey Saver rebate to nearly $500 a year, and to raise the maximum Homestead Rebate, for the elderly and disabled, to $750 from $500.
"Seniors have waited 10 years for an increase," he said. "That's too long. And to make sure they never have to wait again, let's index the Homestead Rebate to inflation. Costs have gone up for our seniors. Help for our seniors must also keep pace."
Democrats were quick to note that Mr. DiFrancesco seemed to sound more like one of them than a Republican, pointing to his proposals for new spending, like a loosely described plan for improving the health of disadvantaged children.
Mr. DiFrancesco said he would travel the state to develop and promote the new "KidsNeeds" program, along with community and religious organizations, teachers, welfare caseworkers and doctors, but he gave no details.
Mr. DiFrancesco's political opponents were quick to point out what was missing from his speech.
Mayor Bret D. Schundler of Jersey City, who is challenging him in the Republican primary, said Mr. DiFrancesco's property tax relief plan avoided any serious effort at reform, because it amounted to keeping income taxes high to reduce property taxes.
"What people want is honest property tax relief," he said. "And what we're giving them is we take with the left hand and give it back with the right, and they know that's not honest tax relief."
Mr. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate, faulted Mr. DiFrancesco's plans for saying nothing of New Jersey's soaring debt burden over the last seven years, and called his proposals too little, too late.
"To announce in February of an election year that 'We'll focus upon property taxes, education and water quality,' after having served as Senate president for nine years, is to underscore his inability or unwillingness to grapple with these threshold issues for the entirety of the Whitman administration," he said. "And with all due respect, where have you been?"

HEADLINE: In Stagnant Japan, Economic and Social Ills Match 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
For anyone living in gloomy Japan these days, it is easy to forget that just 12 years ago, this country was seen by the United States and much of the world as a juggernaut, 10 feet tall and rising.
 From academic journals to the popular imagination, Japan was perceived as a ruthless predator that borrowed American technology and factory methods to take over the industries of yesterday, today and tomorrow, from steel, transistor radios and televisions, to automobiles, semiconductors and computers. 
 Whether they praised or criticized Japan's methods, the most influential books in the 1980's -- with titles like "Japan as No. 1" -- predicted that Japan would dominate virtually every industry worth being in, and that a United States in decline would be left to play a supporting role.
But the two countries could hardly have followed more different paths, and after more than a decade of slow growth, bankruptcy and record unemployment in Japan, and a resurgence in the United States, the change in the views about Japan is as revealing as any statistic.
With Japan's edge being dulled in industry after industry, either by the United States or by newer rivals in Asia, one of the most widely talked about Japan books these days, written jointly by two Japanese and one American scholar, bears the stark title "Can Japan Compete?" 
And increasingly, experts say Japan will only be able to compete if it looks at the problems more broadly, addressing not just its economic institutions but its politics and the very way Japanese live their lives.
At a discussion devoted to Japan at the recent gathering of economic leaders in Davos, Switzerland, there was much grim talk about the depressed stock prices, the possibility of a banking collapse and what has become a perennial flirtation with recession. In his closing remarks at the session, a leading Japanese industrialist, Minoru Makihara, the chairman of Mitsubishi, reportedly raised a copy of "Can Japan Compete?" and recommended it to the audience.
"The title says it all," said Hirotaka Takeuchi, one of the authors and dean of the new School of International Corporate Strategy at Hito tsubashi University in Tokyo. "Of course the answer is, 'Yes.' But the real question is: Will Japan compete? Does it have the will to compete? The government has basically mistrusted competition, and we are paying the price for that now."
The dramatic sweep of this reversal of fortunes between the world's two largest economies was also captured symbolically in a bit of news last week: The Sega Corporation, a pioneer in an industry that has long been a Japanese franchise, announced that it would stop making video-game consoles, concentrating instead on providing software for newer competitors, including recent entrants into the field like Palm Inc. and Microsoft.
Although they are virtual corporate newborns, Palm and its technological sibling Handspring together already have more than half the market value of Sony, the leader in video-game technology and the most prestigious name in Japanese consumer electronics.
Just as Americans became used to having Toyotas in their driveways and Sonys in their living rooms, Japanese are increasingly having to come to terms with products that say Intel or emit Microsoft's chimes, and with American chains like Starbucks and Costco, which are proliferating. 
For some Japanese, the transition is not comfortable.
If Japan's recent problems were limited to a single industry, like games, they could be brushed off. Instead, in broad fields that have long been strongholds of Japanese industry -- from electronics to auto parts to computer chips -- there has been a decline or a conspicuous leveling in performance.
Indeed, this mirrors Japan's overall economy. While the United States grew at an annual clip of 3.6 percent from 1992 to 2000, Japan limped along at a 1 percent growth rate.
The collapse of stock prices here in 1990 is usually considered the starting point for the crisis. But in a recent analysis titled "Shrinking Japan," the American economist Richard Katz, citing World Bank statistics, showed that the percentage of global exports coming from Japan peaked at 8.8 percent in 1986.
"Japan is virtually the only major country whose exports as a share of G.D.P. were no higher in 1999 (10.4 percent) than in the 1950's (11 percent)," Mr. Katz wrote in the newsletter The Oriental Economist. The share of gross domestic product that American exports accounted for doubled over a similar period, and now slightly exceeds Japan's. 
In fact, the most worrying elements of Japan's economic condition are not reflected in trade data at all but are reflected in internal data: Whether one considers bankruptcies, unemployment or funds for the national pension system, Japan is approaching postwar lows. 
The fearful talk in Tokyo financial circles for more than a month now has been the possible collapse of the banking system. Banks never recovered from the bursting of Japan's speculative bubble in 1990 and remain saddled with an untold (and undisclosed) sea of unrecoverable debts. If defaulting creditors set off a wave of failures, it would mark the second time in two years that Japan has experienced a banking crisis.
"The danger for Japan is not cataclysm," Mr. Katz said in an interview. "The danger is corrosion. There is a great reluctance to believe that the system is broke, and people are living proof of the adage, If it ain't broke, don't fix it."
There is one statistic that seems to have caught people's attention, and it may be the most damaging and difficult to deal with: the shrinking population. Japan has one of the highest percentages of older people in the world, with almost one in five -- 26 million people -- over 65. And their numbers are growing about 1 million a year.
At the same time Japan's fertility rate, the average number of births per woman of child-bearing age, dropped to 1.34 last year, the lowest since 1947 and far lower than the 2.08 needed to maintain a stable population. The number of Japanese is now expected to fall from 127 million now to 100 million by 2050, and only 67 million by the end of the century.
As it stands now, if current trends continue, today's teenagers could face two and a half times the current rates of taxation and expect 30 percent less in pension benefits just to keep the system afloat.
The list of purely economic problems is well known, from the debt hangover caused by foolhardy lending during the bubble, to the heavy regulation that affects almost every aspect of life, to the expensive subsidies that have long cushioned large sectors from competition.
But increasingly, economists and experts are saying Japan's problems are first and foremost political: This is the only major industrial democracy that for the last half century -- except for one brief interruption -- has been governed by the same political group, the Liberal Democratic Party.
And the Liberal Democrats' biggest legacy, economists say, is an aversion to a free market and, above all, to competition.
Just last month, as stock prices in Tokyo flirted again with a 10-year low, Shizuka Kamei, one of the party's most powerful politicians, proposed that the government even find a way to prop up Japanese stocks. 
"There are stupid people who say stupid things, like, 'Just leave it to the market,' " he said. "That's no joke. In a situation where stocks fall for reasons which have nothing to do with the economy, politicians must shoulder their responsibilities."
But Tadashi Nakamae, an economist who is president of Nakamae International Economic Research, and a fierce critic of the government, said, "Japan has had a more socialist economy than, say, the Eastern Europeans.
"Our ruling philosophy has been the convoy system, which means that every company must grow together at the same pace, without true winners or losers. As long as Japan was growing fast, we were blinded to the negative side of this system. But it's time to realize that this kind of structure is impossible to maintain."
Many economists are no less scathing in their criticism of the advice that the United States has offered to Japan. 
The Clinton administration advised Japan to irrigate the economy through heavy deficit spending to avoid a steep recession. Economists say this spending has wasted huge sums of money on public works of dubious utility and merely postponed the day of reckoning for thousands of unprofitable protected companies.
The Bush administration has already quietly shifted the direction of Washington's advice, suggesting that Japan begin reducing its huge fiscal deficits and hinting that the United States will help keep the dollar strong. That, in theory, would help Japanese exporters. 
But growing numbers of economists say the postwar obsession with exports here is a major part of the problem. According to this view, the welfare of Japanese people has been sacrificed in the name of mobilizing the nation's capital toward exports instead of developing goods for local consumption. Japan's electronic brands are known worldwide, but many middle-class Japanese do not own a clothes dryer or a dishwasher. 
Thus, this argument goes, the Japanese have been stuck with tiny, expensive homes in overcrowded neighborhoods, high prices for consumer goods and few affordable options for day care for children or the elderly, which meant women had to remain homemakers to care for both their children and their parents. 
"The Japanese focus has never been on making Japanese richer, their lives happier or more convenient and predictable," said Haruo Shimada, an economist at Keio University. "All of our energy has been focused on competing with the United States. 
"Japan's government has done all sorts of things to help export industry in this cause, but almost nothing for ordinary people. Our future growth will come from an untapped market: investing in satisfying the family, making life happier for people."

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:
 NEW YORK

LAKE GROVE: POLICE ENCOUNTERS DESCRIBED -- Four women spoke publicly for the first time yesterday about what they described as abusive encounters with Suffolk County police officers. The Suffolk County Police Department's Internal Affairs Bureau and the F.B.I. interviewed the women yesterday. One woman, who gave her name only as Ellie, identified an officer who she said had kissed and fondled her during a traffic stop 15 years ago, then harassed her again in 1998 while she was working at a highway construction site. The police would not comment on that case other than to say that the officer still works at the Fifth Precinct in Patchogue, had been investigated by the Internal Affairs Bureau and was at one point suspended from duty. The officer she named is not the same officer accused of making women disrobe after recent traffic stops. Tina Kelley (NYT)

HAUPPAUGE: HANDICAPPED-PARKING FINES -- A Suffolk County legislator, Andrew Crecca, announced yesterday that he was introducing a bill to raise the fine for parking illegally in spaces reserved for handicapped drivers by at least $100. Under the measure, the county's share of the fine would rise to $150 from $50 for first-time offenders and to $200 from $50 for repeat violators, said Mr. Crecca, a Republican. The state also imposes a penalty, ranging from $50 to $150. Al Baker (NYT)

GARDEN CITY: TAX EVASION CHARGE -- The former head of the union that represents officers with the rank of sergeant and above in Nassau County was charged in a federal indictment yesterday with conspiracy to evade income taxes and filing false tax returns, federal officials said. The charges against the former president of the Nassau Superior Officers Association, William Pattison, grew out of an investigation into a failed health insurance deal that cost the county $40 million in overruns, a federal official said.
 Al Baker (NYT)

ALBANY: PATAKI NAMES SENIOR AIDE -- Gov. George E. Pataki named John P. Cahill, the state's environmental commissioner, to the post of senior policy adviser yesterday. Mr. Cahill, 42, will fill the post occupied by Zenia Mucha, who left the governor's office to take a job with ABC News. Mr. Pataki said Mr. Cahill -- whose new salary is $156,000, up from $136,000 -- would handle a broad portfolio of issues, but said little about the details of the job. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

MANHATTAN: VOCATIONAL REQUIREMENTS -- Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy is urging the State Board of Regents to exempt vocational students from some of the state's strict new graduation requirements. In a letter to the Regents dated last Thursday, Mr. Levy recommended that vocational students be required to pass only the English and mathematics exams, and not the science, American history and world history exams required of other students. In addition, he wrote, vocational students should be offered alternative assessments that measure their grasp of whatever trade they are learning. Most vocational students are now required to pass all five Regents exams.Abby Goodnough (NYT)

CONNECTICUT

HARTFORD: TRIBAL RECOGNITION CRITICIZED -- Following similar calls from state officials, Senator Christopher J. Dodd said he planned to ask the interior secretary, Gail Norton, to review how the Bureau of Indian Affairs considers applications for tribal recognition. Senator Dodd said he would also propose a law to change the bureau's recognition process to make it more responsive to states and towns that would be affected by tribal claims. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

HARTFORD: ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN SEEN -- State Comptroller Nancy Wyman, in her annual report on state finances, warned yesterday of an economic slowdown and recommended measures to counteract its effect on government. These include increasing the state's emergency budget reserve by a projected $213 million. (NYT)

NEW JERSEY

JERSEY CITY: CARBON MONOXIDE KILLS THREE -- Three men who were using a gasoline-powered generator inside a house were found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning there yesterday morning, the authorities said. The men were described by neighbors as house-sitters and may have been working on the house, at 301 Claremont Avenue, said Battalion Chief George Johns of the Fire Department. The house was almost bare and had no power, and the men were using the generator to run the furnace and the lights, despite warnings on gas generators that they are not to be used in enclosed spaces, Chief Johns said. "It's like running a car engine," he said, adding that an autopsy found very high levels of carbon monoxide in the men's blood. The victims' bodies were found by a friend who went to the house around 7:30 a.m., Chief Johns said. The authorities released the name of only one of the victims, Robert Lee Jones.
(Andy Newman (NYT)

NEWARK: SLAIN MAN IDENTIFIED -- Although nearly 300 patrons packed the nightclub where a teenager was shot and killed and seven other people were wounded Sunday, no one has come forward as a witness, the police said. Sgt. Amilkar Velez, a spokesman for the Newark police, said Tyrone Shelton, 17, of Newark was killed in the 2 a.m. shooting at the Jetaway Launge on 16th Avenue. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

NEWARK: NEW JUDICIAL DISTRICT URGED -- Southern New Jersey would have a new judicial district under a bill introduced by Senator Jon S. Corzine that calls for the reorganization of the state's federal judicial system. Mr. Corzine said the 13 counties that would make up the Southern District of New Jersey would have a combined caseload that is higher than all but 36 of the 93 federal court districts. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

GRAPHIC: Photos
