HEADLINE: The Stock Market Has Made Inmate 90T1282 a Rich Man 

BYLINE:  By TINA KELLEY 

DATELINE: ELMIRA, N.Y. 

 BODY:
On his tax returns, Michael Mathie writes "investor" in the blank reserved for occupation. He claims to have traded more than $8 million in securities since 1998. In 1999, his adjusted gross income was $899,969, all but a sliver in capital gains. He has also invested in a house for his family on Long Island and bought four cars, including a $97,000 Dodge Viper. Plus a garage to keep it in. 
 But here at the Elmira Correctional Facility, a maximum-security state prison where the guards call him "our resident millionaire," Mr. Mathie is formally known as Inmate 90T1282, who has completed almost 12 years of a 10- to 30-year sentence for manslaughter. He is also known for advising and helping pay for other inmates' legal efforts and for providing free legal advice to his fellow prisoners and stock tips to anyone who asks. Given his successes on Wall Street, people listen. 
 "It runs the whole gamut, from lawyers to inmates to everybody," he said in a recent interview. 
Inmates cannot run their own business from prison, but, as a state prison official said, they do not give up their right to free speech. Mr. Mathie's investing is not considered a business because he does not actually conduct the transactions. His father does, making this one of the odder tales of America's infatuation with the stock market.
Mr. Mathie, 33, has no Internet connection, no cell phone, not even a phone in his cell. He makes his trades by calling his father collect from a pay telephone -- up to 10 times a day when the market is more vigorous. His father then places trades on the Internet.
"I could be paying a mortgage with what I pay MCI," he said, adding that he pays his father $500 to $1,200 a month for the calls.
He remembers investing in China Prosperity International Holdings, now China Converge, a foreign company that trades on the Nasdaq, when China's proposed membership in the World Trade Organization was a hot topic. 
"It went from $1 to $10, and the next day it was $18, so I threw $50,000 at it, and called back at 10:30 or 11, and it was at $70," he said. "So I cleared $150,000 and got my $50,000 back in two and a half hours." 
He has also taken his lumps, mostly in paper losses, when tech stocks tanked. He gets chills when he recalls the market plunge of August 1998, when he lost $750,000 in market value in 20 minutes. 
But he remains a true-believing bull, and predicts that the Nasdaq will top 6,500 by the end of 2002, up from its current 2,643. "Definitely, we're not headed for no recession, and if we do go into a recession, it's because of the media," he said. "It's a self-fulfilling prophecy." 
Mr. Mathie, a slight man who looks more like a clerk than a killer, was well acquainted with risk -- but not the financial kind -- when he landed in jail in 1989. He was 21, a high school dropout and former cocaine addict. He and three others had been charged in the murder of Paul Vincent Lamariana, 49, who was hit in the head with a tire iron, choked with an electrical cord, stuffed in plastic bags, wrapped in carpeting and dumped by a road in Oak Beach, Suffolk County. Mr. Mathie admitted that he had hit Mr. Lamariana with the tire iron and choked him. 
Mr. Mathie said that he felt remorseful about the killing, and that some in the group of four friends believed that Mr. Lamariana was abusing the daughter of one of them. He has made inquiries about how he could help Mr. Lamariana's family. 
Contacted in California, Mr. Lamariana's mother declined to speak to a reporter. 
Mr. Mathie pleaded guilty to manslaughter and conspiracy, but said he did so to get out of pretrial detention in the Suffolk County Jail, where he said he was raped and repeatedly sexually abused by the chief of internal security, Roy Fries. 
In 1996, Mr. Mathie won a $750,000 settlement in a federal civil suit; the judge who oversaw the case ruled that the evidence was "overwhelming" and called Mr. Fries's acts "an outrageous abuse of power and authority." No criminal charges were filed, the Suffolk County district attorney's office said, because there was insufficient evidence. (Mr. Fries is retired and did not respond to two phone messages left at his home in Lindenhurst.) 
On appeal, Mr. Mathie's award was reduced to about $500,000. With $75,000 of that, he began trading stocks. 
Jim Flateau, a spokesman for the state's Department of Correctional Services, said inmates are not allowed to have computers or to run businesses from prisons. 
"Certainly, since the transaction is occurring outside prison, it's not something over which we would exercise any control," he said. "Inmates have a First Amendment right to discuss whatever they want on the phone," so long as it is legal. 
Such behind-bars business is very unusual, said Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, a nonprofit policy analysis group. 
"Most inmates wouldn't know a stock exchange from a soccer ball," he said. 
Under the "Son of Sam" law, prisoners are not allowed to profit financially from their crimes. An unsuccessful bill proposed by Gov. George E. Pataki in 2000 would have revised the law to allow crime victims to sue convicts for money and property from any source. That bill will be proposed again this year, said Caroline Quartararo, a spokeswoman for the state's Crime Victims Board.
In the meantime, Mr. Mathie continues his daily routine, turning on the television in his cell at 4 a.m. to watch news of the European markets on ABC and PBS; there is no cable for convicts. He receives about a dozen publications that help him make his investment decisions, including The Wall Street Journal, Barron's, Investor's Business Daily, Value Line Investment Survey and Individual Investor. The guards who deliver his mail complain that he gets too much. 
"I compensate them," Mr. Mathie said. "They want to know what stock tips to go on, for their retirement portfolios and so forth." 
He favors a diversified approach. Some of his favorite stocks? Corning, which he expects to double in price; Juniper Networks; JDS Uniphase; and AT&T, which is planning to split into four divisions.
"You can't beat that with a stick," he said. "It's a good long-term hold." 
Technology stocks have been kind to him, and he said he considered their recent turn downward to be "a fabulous buying opportunity." He is particularly fond of Yahoo. 
"Yahoo paid for the Viper," he said, referring to his new 450-horsepower convertible. "I had a picture of one on my wall for three years. I got sick of looking at the picture on my wall, and I ordered one. I put a $1,000 deposit on my Visa, and sent my sister over there. She paid the rest in cash. Same with the garage," a prefab model at his sister's house. 
He has also purchased a Lincoln and a Suburban for each of his two sisters, and a $145,000 house in his Suffolk County hometown, Islip Terrace, for his father, one sister, brother-in-law and nephew. 
He helps other prisoners by putting up money when needed. For example, Mr. Mathie said, he has given $2,000 to pay for the DNA testing of evidence that one inmate, Frank Sterling, believes could clear him of his murder conviction. In addition, he has posted a $25,000 reward for information leading to the conviction of the killer of Steven Maida, the son of a family friend. 
Mr. Mathie has also sent $5,000 to the Office of Prison Ministry of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, in part to provide a special Christmas breakfast and presents for residents in juvenile detention. When he gets out of prison, he said, he hopes to start a nonprofit organization to help young people. He was denied parole in 2000, and his next parole hearing is in June. 
A Columbia psychology professor and an expert in coping with trauma, Leah Blumberg Lapidus, said Mr. Mathie suffered from post-traumatic stress disorder and "massive flashbacks" from his time in the Suffolk County Jail, adding that he needed counseling at least twice a week. 
She testified at a recent trial in which Mr. Mathie maintained that he needed treatment for stress, and she found him ready for parole. 
Thomas F. Liotti, Mr. Mathie's lawyer, also said he should be released. "Way back when he had his legal problems, he probably had those problems because of bad judgment," Mr. Liotti said. "Now it looks to me that he has terrific judgment." 
Mr. Mathie said one of his first priorities outside prison would be to finish college, which he started in prison. Now that the market is slowing, he calls his father only about once a day. But he remains optimistic. 
"I don't believe the fundamentals have changed much," he said. And he offered a prognosis of the first half of the year for the market that perhaps also applies to himself as he heads toward his next parole hearing. 
"The first two quarters until June are going to be tough," he said. "You've just got to stick with it. You've got to have an iron gut."

HEADLINE: A Ford Heir Struggles For Control 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
William Clay Ford Jr., the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, has been frustrated in recent months at being left out of decisions at the company that bears his family's name, people close to Ford's leadership said. 
 Mr. Ford last autumn even raised the idea of appointing a chief operating officer, which would have made him less dependent for information on Jacques Nasser, the company's chief executive and president, these people said. Mr. Nasser opposed the creation of the post, and the idea -- which the company has not talked about publicly -- has been shelved for now. 
 Mr. Ford is not dissatisfied with Mr. Nasser's performance, people close to the two men said, but rather is frustrated at sometimes being left out of the loop on the company's day-to-day operations. 
Indeed, several people said Mr. Ford was particularly irritated that some vice presidents and group vice presidents who report to Mr. Nasser had been cagey about sharing information with him, as well. In recent days, Mr. Ford has begun asking some of them to meet with him regularly.
"He's upset about it; he'd like to be more involved," one of the people close to the company's leadership said. Mr. Ford and Mr. Nasser declined today to provide comment on their working relationship.
A great-grandson of the company's founder, Henry Ford, Mr. Ford, 43, has been chosen by his cousins, aunts and father to represent Ford family interests at what, in terms of sales, remains the world's largest family-controlled enterprise. 
He also has the strong support of Ford Motor's outside directors, the result of having served as chairman of the board's finance committee before he and Mr. Nasser assumed their current posts in January 1999.
And he was trained from boyhood to run a car company, going directly from Princeton University into a succession of nearly two dozen increasingly important posts at Ford Motor.
But Mr. Ford is finding that his title alone does not assure him control of the vast bureaucracy of a company with 335,000 employees. 
In the nearly two decades between the retirement of Mr. Ford's uncle, Henry Ford II, and Mr. Ford's ascension to the top job, the company was run by a succession of professional managers. They sought to limit the influence of the family, which holds a special class of stock giving it 40 percent of the votes at the company. Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive until the end of 1998, struggled unsuccessfully with the board to prevent Mr. Ford from becoming chairman.
Mr. Ford was conspicuous by his absence from public view during most of the tempest last autumn over the recall of Firestone tires supplied with Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles. He never went before television cameras during the controversy, limiting himself to a single conference call with reporters on Sept. 14. He said then that Ford's management initially handled the recall, and that he had not wanted to undercut management by jumping in when the issue turned into a national debate over auto safety and the credibility of Ford Motor and Firestone.
Until then, Mr. Ford had met frequently, but informally, with the layer of executives directly below Mr. Nasser. Those meetings ended when the executives became caught up in managing the tire recall, leaving Mr. Ford feeling increasingly isolated, people close to the company's leadership said. 
Mr. Ford's low visibility has not been confined to the Firestone problems. A little over a year ago, he was at center stage -- standing in an auditorium at the North American International Auto Show here and introducing prototypes for future vehicles. 
This winter, Mr. Ford has been much less visible. He spent much of December shaking up the management of the Detroit Lions football team, which his family owns. Then he badly injured his shoulder in a skiing accident on Jan. 2, preventing him not only from visiting the auto show but also from giving a planned party in Washington for President Bush's inauguration.
Mr. Ford is now back in the office and is expected to recover fully, though he is temporarily unable to drive because of the shoulder injury, which required surgery.
But even before the accident, Mr. Ford had not been scheduled to unveil any Ford vehicles at this year's Detroit auto show.
"There wasn't anything that fit perfectly; that wasn't contrived," said Jason Vines, the Ford Motor Company's vice president for public affairs.
Some auto analysts say that the company is missing an opportunity by not finding more of a role for Mr. Ford, given his access to government and financial leaders and his surprisingly common touch. "He could be better utilized here," said Stephen Girsky, who follows Ford for Morgan Stanley, "even if it's more in a public relations-type fashion."
Some members of the company's old guard are uncomfortable with Mr. Ford's strong emphasis on environmental responsibility, and leery of letting him speak publicly. This has been particularly true since the Ford annual meeting in Atlanta last May, when he said that sport utility vehicles posed serious safety and environmental problems that the company would have to address. 
Mr. Ford has been much less visible in public since then. And though Mr. Vines said the lower visibility was not the result of a policy decision, Mr. Ford's comments clearly fed distrust of him among both some longtime Ford executives and executives at rival automakers.
Mr. Ford's critics in the industry contend that "sometimes he's a goody two-shoes green; other times, he's a businessman," a person close to Ford Motor leaders said.
Mr. Ford has consistently argued that environmental responsibility makes business sense, because it enhances the reputation of Ford Motor brands.
"It's not a flavor of the month, it's a flavor of a lifetime, it's a flavor of a career," he said in the September conference call with reporters.
Mr. Nasser has supported Mr. Ford's position, but expresses the idea differently. Ask him about the environment, and the result is a 10-minute monologue about how companies in a global, Web-linked economy must do whatever is necessary to prevent their brands from becoming tarnished by poor behavior in any country.
Mr. Ford's dalliance with the idea of appointing a chief operating officer foundered, in part, on the lack of obvious candidates. And if Mr. Ford were to sour on Mr. Nasser, there would be few obvious alternatives to him, either. 
Mr. Nasser has pushed out both of the most obvious contenders: John Devine, who was Ford's chief financial officer and is now vice chairman and chief financial officer of General Motors; and Peter Pestillo, who was Ford's vice chairman and is now chairman and chief executive of the Visteon Corporation, an auto parts maker spun off by Ford last summer.
Though Ford Motor has outperformed its rivals in profitability over the last year, it has had several stumbles lately. It is not clear how much, if at all, these can be attributed to Mr. Nasser's efforts to run the company without a strong number two. 
Mr. Nasser was heavily criticized last summer for initially resisting a request from Congress to testify about the Firestone matter. His decision to appear in television advertisements about the tires was widely questioned. (He speaks with a strong Australian accent.) 
Ford's recent introduction of the Escape sport utility vehicle has been marred by recalls, while the introduction of a new Ford Explorer has been repeatedly postponed this winter, partly because of concerns about quality.
Mr. Nasser himself is deeply unpopular within the company. He has removed thousands of midlevel managers by requiring executives to evaluate their subordinates on a curve and then to tell some that they have little future -- a shock at a company long known for its collegial ways.
While the idea of naming a chief operating officer has been shelved for now because of Mr. Nasser's opposition, it has not been discarded forever, one of the people close to Ford's leadership said, and adding:
"Is it in the cards? Maybe. Is it imminent? No."

HEADLINE: British Airways Posts a Profit; Will Continue Cutting Fleet 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
British Airways returned to profitability in its third fiscal quarter, helped by a strategy of raising prices for premium services like seats that convert into beds on long-haul flights, while trimming overall capacity. 
 The less-is-more approach was begun by Robert Ayling, who presided over the airline's first full-year loss before resigning as chief executive last March. His successor, Rod Eddington, continued the plan and, perhaps more important, won support for it among British Airways employees at a time when European rivals were adding capacity. 
 A spokesman for the airline, Nick Claydon, said today that it expects to have reduced capacity 3 percent by the time the fiscal year ends on March 31, and by 9 percent further in the next fiscal year. Both the number and size of planes will be reduced, mainly at the expense of economy-class customers.
The resulting 3.1 percent reduction in unit costs other than fuel helped the British Air surpass analysts' forecasts, with a quarterly pretax profit of $:65 million ($96 million) on revenue of $:2.29 billion ($3.38 billion). The airline lost $:60 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier.
Still, worries about how British Airways will fare as the United States economy slows seemed to depress investor interest, and its stock price slid nearly 8 percent here, to $:4.21, or $6.21.
Other issues loom for British Airways, including its prospects for long-term growth through acquisitions and alliances. A deal for KLM unraveled in September, and regulators in the United States have kept British Airways and American Airlines from working together as closely as they would like.
Chris Tarry, an analyst with Commerzbank, said he expects demand on North Atlantic routes, which supply two-fifths of British Airways' revenue and profit, to continue growing, though he is skeptical that British Airways will succeed in substantially tightening its relationship with American Airlines any time soon. 
Mr. Eddington and Donald J. Carty, his counterpart at American's parent, the AMR Corporation, met last month in Phoenix, Ariz., to explore ideas like creating a single reservations center for all members of the airlines' One World alliance, and doing more joint purchasing of supplies. But Mr. Tarry of Commerzbank called such steps incremental.
Mr. Claydon, the British Airways spokesman, said the two big carriers had no immediate plans to lobby with United States regulators for antitrust immunity, which some other airline alliances have on a limited basis. "For now," he said, "Rod is focused on getting the core business right."
In part, that includes selling Go, British Airways' reduced-fare airline. The short list of prospective buyers has been winnowed to 6 from 24 who made preliminary offers.

HEADLINE: Washington's Other Mr. Powell 

 BODY:
George W. Bush has named Michael Powell to be the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, making the Powells one of Washington's most powerful father-son teams in a long time. The powers held by the secretary of state are well known. Less obvious is the importance of the F.C.C., the traffic cop to the nation's information technologies. The agency was created seven decades ago to insure an orderly allocation of the airwaves, and its power and responsibilities have increased greatly with the explosive growth of the Internet, wireless communications and cable and broadcast television. Not knowing what will come next, or even how today's technologies will intersect tomorrow, is what makes the F.C.C.'s regulatory work so conceptually challenging. 
 Mr. Powell is well qualified for the task, having been one of the five F.C.C. commissioners since 1997. He previously served as chief of staff to Joel Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust office, and as a law clerk for a federal judge on the District of Columbia Circuit. It is an impressive resume for a 37-year-old Republican who turned to the law after his military career was cut short by a near-fatal jeep accident. 
 As a commissioner, Mr. Powell has been a firm believer in the self-regulating nature of markets. But we hope that as chairman he will take a more expansive view of the commission's role. He is right to fear premature regulation of nascent technologies, but a number of issues that are likely to dominate his tenure as chairman will require aggressive regulatory action to encourage competition. This will be true, for instance, in the continuing struggle to force the regional Bell companies to open up their local markets to competitors. 
Mr. Powell's predecessor, William E. Kennard, tried to keep markets open to a diversity of voices and new competitors. Consumer groups are concerned that Mr. Powell will reverse course and allow a greater concentration of market power in the hands of the most economically powerful companies. Mr. Powell, for example, has been critical of rules that limit the number of TV stations broadcasters can own in a market or across the country. On another front, his hands-off regulatory approach may not be the best means to foster wireless Internet services and interactive television. 
Consistent with his philosophy, Mr. Powell voted against some conditions designed to protect competition in the merger of America Online with Time Warner. The AOL deal was approved by a 5-to-0 vote on Jan. 11, and the conditions by a 3-to-2 vote, with Mr. Powell as one of the dissenters. But he should not even have voted on this issue. Mr. Powell's father was an AOL director until the day of the vote, holding options to buy 320,000 shares of the company. 
Mr. Powell said he never discussed AOL matters with his father, and neither federal law nor commission rules required him to recuse himself. Still, his failure to do so strikes us as a lapse in judgment given the apparent conflict of interest. General Powell announced the day after the vote that he would be exercising those options, which will net him millions. That will clear his son of a continuing problem on AOL matters. But Michael Powell will need to exercise better judgment during his tenure as F.C.C. chairman.

HEADLINE: Defense Veteran Chosen as No. 2 at Pentagon 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
Paul D. Wolfowitz found himself at the center of a political firestorm eight years ago when as under secretary of defense for policy he drafted a document calling on the United States to use its military might as the lone superpower to prevent the rise of strategic competitors.
 Foreign capitals denounced the notion, and the first Bush administration quietly excised it from its post-cold-war strategy, but the episode cemented Dr. Wolfowitz's reputation as a conservative intellectual known for hawkish views on everything from Russia to Iraq to national missile defense. 
 Today, President Bush announced that he intended to return Dr. Wolfowitz to the Pentagon, this time as deputy secretary of defense, responsible for managing the Pentagon's sprawling bureaucracy and, perhaps more than his predecessors, involving himself in foreign policy. Dr. Wolfowitz's nomination requires Senate confirmation. 
"Wolfowitz will be stronger from a policy point of view than many of his predecessors," said Lawrence J. Korb, vice president of the Council on Foreign Relations and former assistant secretary of defense in the Reagan administration. "He's very close to the vice president and the president. A lot of people who've had that job have never met the president before."
Dr. Wolfowitz, now 57, rejoins a cadre of senior national security officials returning to office after eight years in political exile. 
As under secretary of defense for policy from 1989 to 1993 -- essentially the Pentagon's third-ranking position -- he worked closely with Dick Cheney, now the vice president, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, now secretary of state. Dr. Wolfowitz was particularly instrumental during the Persian Gulf war, bolstering Mr. Cheney's case for an aggressive response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and managing sensitive diplomacy with key allies like Israel.
Dr. Wolfowitz has also over the years worked closely with his new boss, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld. When Mr. Rumsfeld took over Senator Bob Dole's flailing presidential campaign in 1996, he tapped Dr. Wolfowitz as the campaign's foreign policy adviser -- a role he reprised last year as one of "the Vulcans," Mr. Bush's closest advisers in that field.
He also served as a member of the Rumsfeld Commission, the panel that in 1998 warned that the United States was increasingly vulnerable to attack by long-range ballistic missiles from countries like North Korea, Iran and Iraq. The commission's report became one of the most influential documents in American military planning.
Dr. Wolfowitz had himself been a candidate for the top job at the Pentagon, as well as that at the Central Intelligence Agency. However, some in the Bush transition team questioned whether his intellectual rigor and academic approach would prove ineffective in reining in the Pentagon's bureaucracy -- an important part of the deputy's job.
There is no question, however, that he brings considerable experience to the job. Mr. Korb referred to Dr. Wolfowitz as "the most qualified person nominated to be No. 2 at the Pentagon." 
Born in Brooklyn and raised in Ithaca, N.Y., Dr. Wolfowitz studied mathematics and chemistry at Cornell University and later earned a master's degree and a doctorate from the University of Chicago in political science and economics.
From 1973 to 1977, he worked in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, serving for a time as a special assistant during the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, or SALT. He later served as an assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs and as ambassador to Indonesia during the Reagan administration before joining the first Bush administration.
Dr. Wolfowitz became dean of the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies at Johns Hopkins University in 1994.
He is known for sharp, hawkish views. In 1998, he told a Senate committee that the United States should arm opponents of Saddam Hussein and provide air cover, if necessary, as they liberated the country. "Anti-tank weapons, in particular, could have a powerful equalizing effect," he said at the time.

IVillage and Women.com, start-ups that competed to attract women Web surfers and advertisers to cater to them, said that they would join forces, with iVillage paying $27 million to acquire Women.com. C9.

Frito-Lay Lifts PepsiCo Results
PepsiCo reported its fifth consecutive quarter of double-digit earnings growth and predicted a sixth, despite a persistent weakness in soda sales. Driving the gains was the Frito-Lay unit, which accounts for more than 60 percent of PepsiCo's sales and has benefited from a consumer shift away from sit-down meals in favor of snacks eaten on the run. C4.

Investors in search of safe bets sent blue chips sharply higher as technology issues fell. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 101.75 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,965.85. Eastman Chemical said that it planned to split into two companies to protect its fast-growing specialty chemicals business from the ups and downs of prices for commodity plastics and fibers. In a move that may eventually transform one of the world's biggest media empires, Bertelsmann of Germany agreed to take control of Europe's biggest television broadcaster, the RTL Group, in a stock deal worth roughly $9 billion. World Business, Section W.

Senator John McCain will join Democrats in proposing legislation intended to break an impasse over patients' rights. A17.

Worried bankers kept toughening their terms for loans to businesses and consumers over the last three months as they grew more concerned that they might not be repaid, according to a Federal Reserve survey. C4.

HEADLINE: BUSH TO PROPOSE MAKING A TAX CUT EFFECTIVE IN 2001 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he wanted substantial parts of his tax-cut plan to apply retroactively to the beginning of this year -- a full year ahead of what he proposed during the campaign -- as a means of shoring up the faltering economy.
 Administration officials said they were considering a variety of ways to have the tax cut take effect on an accelerated basis and so put additional money into taxpayers' pockets as quickly as possible. Among the ideas is to send taxpayers a one-time payment that would reflect their expected tax savings for a part of this year, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said in an interview today. 
 At the beginning of a week in which Mr. Bush has scheduled a series of events to help him build support for his plan to cut taxes by $1.6 trillion over the next decade, administration officials said he intended as a matter of principle to submit to Congress on Thursday the exact proposal that he advocated during the presidential campaign. 
But they made clear that the president would support efforts in Congress to speed the schedule under which the tax cut would be phased in, and its benefits passed along to individuals, despite doubts among economists including Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that such a move would help the economy in time to make a difference in this slowdown. 
Asked by reporters at the White House today whether he favored making his tax cut retroactive to the start of this year, Mr. Bush said yes.
"A lot of members of Congress have talked to me about that, and I do," he said, flanked by families he said would benefit from his plan. "And we look forward to working with Congress to expedite money into the pockets of the American people. I strongly believe that a tax relief plan is an important part of helping our country's economy recover."
Even some of Mr. Bush's Capitol Hill allies are skeptical of the assertion that the tax cut would be of substantial help in reviving the economy. "If we do it earlier, I don't think we're really stimulating the economy," said one Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. "I think we're putting in place at an earlier time basic tax restructuring."
Mr. Bush said he would resist pressure from members of his own party, as well as from lobbyists and interest groups, to stuff this year's tax bill with provisions other than those he has proposed. 
Republican leaders on Capitol Hill have said over the last several weeks that the tax cut could grow bigger than $1.6 trillion and that there is considerable support for proposals not included in Mr. Bush's plan, like a reduction in the capital gains tax and breaks for businesses.
"Some in Congress view this as an opportunity to load up the tax relief plan with their own vision of tax relief," Mr. Bush said. "And I want the members of Congress and the American people to hear loud and clear: This is the right size plan, it is the right approach, and I'm going to defend it mightily."
Democrats said it would be a mistake to count on the surplus to finance a large tax cut, given the inherent uncertainty in long-term economic and budget projections.
In testimony prepared for delivery to the Senate Budget Committee on Tuesday, David M. Walker, who heads the General Accounting Office, the nonpartisan agency that conducts audits for Congress, said that "no one should design tax or spending policy pegged to the precise numbers in any 10-year forecast."
Democrats have shifted their sights to limiting the size of the tax cut, and to focusing more of its benefits on low- and middle-income people than Mr. Bush's proposal would. Although the White House says that in percentage terms many lower-income taxpayers would see a larger reduction in their tax bills than would the wealthy, the biggest share of Mr. Bush's cut would go to affluent taxpayers, those who pay the most in taxes.
"If you make over $300,000 a year, this tax cut means you get to buy a new Lexus," said the Senate Democratic leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. "If you make $50,000 a year, you get to buy a muffler on your used car."
It is likely that Mr. Bush's plan will be altered as the tax committees in the House and the Senate write their own legislation, and it is possible that the White House's proposal will be scaled back. 
In an indication of the difficulties the proposal could face, a bipartisan group of five senators said today that any tax cut should be contingent on the projected surplus's materializing on schedule. They were Senators Evan Bayh of Indiana, Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana and Dianne Feinstein of California, all Democrats, and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, both Republicans.
But the administration has so far shown no willingness to compromise.
Lawrence B. Lindsey, the White House's economic adviser, said in an interview that the projected surplus was large enough in coming years to accommodate an acceleration of two of the Bush plan's main components: the reduction in all personal income tax rates and a doubling, to $1,000, of the per-child credit.
Under the plan Mr. Bush set out during the campaign, income tax rates would be reduced gradually over the next five years, and the child credit would be increased gradually over the same period. 
Mr. Lindsey said the administration was not proposing specific changes to the timetable at this point. But he maintained that even after setting aside the portion of the projected surplus that would come from Social Security, "there is enough flexibility to move a significant portion of the rate cuts and the child credit forward."
In addition to cutting income tax rates and doubling the child credit, Mr. Bush's plan would give a break to many two-income couples, repeal the tax on large estates, allow more people to deduct charitable contributions and extend a credit for corporate research and development.
There is general agreement among economists that the stimulus of a tax cut can help in theory to revive a weak economy. But there is also agreement that in practice the stimulus usually comes too late to do much good. That is all the more so in the case of the Bush tax cut, many economists say, because it is taxpayers in the lower brackets who are most likely to spend whatever they save in taxes, and they would not be getting back enough to stimulate the economy, at least in the short run.
At his confirmation hearing last month, Mr. O'Neill, who as treasury secretary is one of the administration's primary salesmen for the tax cut, said there were better reasons than immediate fiscal stimulus to reduce taxes. Mr. O'Neill said at the time that he would not "make a huge case that this is the instrument to ensure that we don't go into recession," although he was referring to Mr. Bush's original schedule, under which no tax cut would have taken effect until next year.
It would be hard for Congress to pass a tax bill before late spring or early summer, and it would probably be late summer or fall before the effect of the cuts would be felt by taxpayers even if the administration and Congress found a way to expedite the process.
Moreover, the tax cut would amount to only $20 billion in the first year under the schedule originally set out by Mr. Bush -- a tiny drop in an economy that is expected to produce more than $10 trillion of goods and services this year, and not enough to do much good if the nation is sinking into a recession.
On the other hand, the greater the early economic punch that Mr. Bush tries to achieve by loading more of the legislation's benefits into the next year or two, the more trouble he will have meeting his own goal of holding the package's total size to $1.6 trillion over the next decade.
Accelerating the tax plan would also create a number of other problems that administration officials said they had not fully worked out.
The obvious way to put additional money into people's pockets this year would be to change the tables that determine how much employers withhold from paychecks toward income tax liability. 
But the withholding tables cannot be changed until after the tax cut becomes law, probably not before summer. And if withholding levels are reduced for the rest of the year to reflect a cut that applies to a full year's income, withholding levels would have to rise again in January, a step that Republicans said they wanted to avoid because it would feel to many people like a tax increase.
As a result, Mr. O'Neill said, the administration is considering whether it can send all taxpayers a check later this year that would approximate the amount by which they had been over-withheld up until that point. The withholding tables would then be reduced just to reflect the diminished tax liability on earnings from that point on.
"Is it feasible to think about a one-time catch-up payment before you phase in a rest-of-the-year withholding-table change?" Mr. O'Neill said. "There are a lot of important technical questions about how you can do that, but we're looking at it."

Democrats say an additional $400 billion, which comes from Medicare, should also be off limits, although the White House disagrees, leaving between $2.7 trillion and $3.1 trillion for tax cuts and other needs. HEADLINE: McCain Joining Democrats To Offer Health Rights Bill 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
Senator John McCain, the maverick Republican who irritated many leaders of his own party in his quest for the presidency, will join Democrats this week in proposing legislation intended to break a three-year impasse over patients' rights. 
 Mr. McCain has come up with what he calls a compromise, hammered out in weeks of negotiations with Democratic senators, including liberals like Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and moderates like John Edwards of North Carolina and Bob Graham of Florida. 
 In an interview today, Mr. Graham said: "We've now got a plan that will get the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster in the Senate. The House had a strong majority for a similar plan in 1999. We are closer to enactment of a patients' bill of rights than at any time since it's been considered in Congress." 
The issue will be an important test for moderate Republicans like Senator Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island. Jeffrey Neal, a spokesman for Mr. Chafee, said the senator "definitely supports" the McCain-Kennedy bill.
The bill, to be unveiled on Tuesday, defines a wide variety of patients' rights, including access to emergency care and medical specialists. Patients would also receive new rights to sue insurance companies and health maintenance organizations that improperly deny claims or cause injuries. 
Though promoted as a compromise, the bill does little to appease insurers and employers, who have staunchly resisted any legislation expanding the right to sue.
"This legislation is a recipe for more litigation, more liability and higher costs," said Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, the chief lobby for H.M.O.'s.
People on all sides of the debate say that prospects for enactment of a patient's bill of rights have increased with the inauguration of President Bush. But in expanding the right to sue, the compromise legislation appears to go somewhat further than anything he has endorsed. 
Under the bill, some lawsuits, involving disputes over the terms of a contract, would go to federal court. Other claims, involving questions of medical judgment and the need for a specific service, would be heard in state court. Plaintiffs often prefer state court because experience suggests that they can win larger damages there.
The federal court would decide questions like these: Is John Doe enrolled in the local Blue Cross health plan? Is a particular benefit covered under the contract? Is the co-payment $5 or $10? State courts, by contrast, would decide whether a patient had been injured by the negligence of an H.M.O.
Mr. McCain, an Arizonan, and Democratic senators intend to portray their proposal as a significant compromise that could help break the deadlock on patients' rights by imposing some limits on punitive damages and by limiting the liability of employers. Employers would be protected from liability unless they directly participated in a decision on a claim for benefits.
Senator McCain may pull several Republican senators with him. But H.M.O.'s and insurance companies said they opposed the bill because, like the one passed by the House in 1999, it would expand the patient's right to sue.
Under the draft legislation, a health plan could be required to pay a "civil assessment," similar to punitive damages, up to $5 million if a patient established in federal court that a defendant had shown "bad faith and flagrant disregard" for the patient's rights.
If a patient was injured because of a health plan's failure to exercise "ordinary care," the patient could sue under state law for economic damages and pain and suffering. The patient could also recover punitive damages if the defendant acted in "willful or wanton disregard" for the patient's rights. 
H.M.O.'s would generally be protected against punitive damages if they followed the recommendations of an independent panel of medical experts. But patients could bypass such administrative appeals and go directly to court if they asserted that the delay would cause "immediate and irreparable harm or death."
Mr. McCain's eagerness to work with Democrats on patients' rights may make it more difficult for Democrats to cut a deal on campaign finance laws with Senate Republican leaders, who have no desire to let Mr. McCain set their agenda.
A White House official said President Bush would send a letter to Congress this week urging lawmakers to adopt a patients' bill of rights, though without endorsing a specific piece of legislation.

HEADLINE: Statehouse Stalemate Delays Relief from Tax on Heating Fuel 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5 

 BODY:
The State Senate and the Assembly both passed bills today authorizing the New York City Council to suspend the city's 4 percent sales tax on heating oil and natural gas this winter, but the two measures differ slightly, leaving it unclear when consumers might see an actual tax reduction.
 In December, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani asked the Legislature to grant the city the ability to roll back taxes temporarily on heating oil for 60 days this winter, giving a break to consumers dealing with high energy prices. 
 But the speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, a Manhattan Democrat, let it be known early last week that he intended to urge passage of a bill that would also allow the city to suspend taxes on natural gas.
Mr. Silver also said he wanted to give New York City the same power other cities around the state already have to change fuel taxes as they like, whenever they like. 
On Thursday, Mr. Giuliani, in a closed-door meeting with senators, agreed to add natural gas to the city's proposal, which has been championed in the Senate by Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican. This afternoon, the Senate unanimously passed Mr. Goodman's bill.
The Senate measure would enable the City Council to vote to suspend the tax on natural gas and heating oil for a single 60-day period. It would cost the city $28 million in lost revenues.
The state granted most local governments the authority to control their own sales taxes years ago. However, the city government does not have the power to reduce sales taxes without Albany's approval because those revenues backed bonds issued in the 1970's to bail the city out of its financial crisis.
But minutes after the Senate acted, the Assembly passed, 149-0, a version of the bill that would let the city repeal the sales tax not only on oil and natural gas, but also on all other forms of energy used for heating, like steam and electricity. The Assembly bill would give the Council the flexibility to suspend the tax on any fuel for a short time or repeal it indefinitely, aides to Mr. Silver said.
Senator Goodman said the Legislature was locked in a stalemate because the Assembly decided not to pass the Senate version backed by the mayor.
The Giuliani administration has not taken a position on the Assembly's proposal. Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota said the mayor wanted to read the Assembly bill before commenting.
"We withdrew our bill last Thursday morning and replaced it with a 60-day moratorium on both home heating oil and natural gas," Mr. Lhota said. "That is our bill, our preferred bill." 
It remained unclear today whether the Democrats who control the Assembly and the Republicans who control the Senate can reach an agreement on a single bill. Unlike in Congress, legislative leaders in Albany rarely resolve their differences in conference committees.
One consequence of the competing bills is that residents and landlords may have to wait for relief on their fuel bills. Legislative aides said the City Council and the mayor could speed up the process by sending an unequivocal message to the Legislature about what the city wants, but since Mr. Giuliani and the Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, appear to be supporting different bills, that could take some time.
Senator Goodman said: "We will do everything we can to try to provide this relief as soon as possible. We want to do it while it's cold. It doesn't do much good to do it in the middle of the summer."
Mr. Vallone is leaning toward supporting the Assembly's bill, said his spokesman, Jordan Barowitz.
"What the City Council is looking for is discretion and flexibility," he said. "All the other localities in the state can roll back taxes when emergencies arrive. The City Council wants that same power."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
The War Saddam Won

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar 

 BODY:
The Bush team has a full-fledged public relations disaster on its hands in the Arab world.
 From the smallest pistachio seller here on the shores of the Persian Gulf to the highest Arab ministers, there is not only total opposition to any Bush plans to tighten sanctions on Saddam Hussein until he is squeezed out of power, but in fact virtually unanimous support for lifting sanctions immediately. 
 America has lost the propaganda war with Saddam. Period. And before the sanctions regime collapses entirely, the U.S. needs to find a way to at least salvage an international ban on all weapons sales to Iraq, with border inspections, so that Saddam's military power is contained -- and forget about using endless economic sanctions to get rid of him. They are not sustainable. 
Especially after Ariel Sharon wins the Israeli election today. Judging from many conversations here, the Arab street is poised to say to the Bush team: "Let me get this straight. You want us to join America in imposing sanctions on the Iraqi leader who smashed Kuwait, while America accepts the Israeli leader who smashed Lebanon? Not a chance."
The U.S. effort to isolate Saddam has died of many causes. For one, Saddam totally outfoxed Washington in the propaganda war. All you hear and read in the media here is that the sanctions are starving the Iraqi people -- which is true. But the U.S. counter-arguments that by complying with U.N. resolutions Saddam could get those sanctions lifted at any time are never heard. Preoccupied with the peace process, no senior U.S. officials have made their case in any sustained way here, and it shows.
You would never know from talking to people in the gulf that just a few weeks ago Saddam Hussein's son Uday put forward a "working paper" to the Iraqi National Assembly calling for a new emblem that showed Kuwait "as an integral part of greater Iraq." You would never know that Iraq's deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, recently declared that "Kuwait got what it deserved." You would never know that during the period from June to December 2000, despite all the hunger among the Iraqi people, the U.N. reported that Saddam bought only $4.2 billion worth of food and medicine for his people -- even though under the U.N. oil-for-food program he had $7.8 billion to spend. 
No, all you hear now are the sorts of arguments that Egypt's foreign minister, Amr Moussa, made at the Davos Forum last week: "We can't expect that the people of Iraq live under sanctions forever. . . . Since the war, public opinion in the Arab world has moved 180 degrees." Many here would agree. 
Even if Colin Powell came to the gulf to make the right arguments, he would have an uphill battle. For one thing, Washington has forgotten how different Iraq looks from the Arab world. The leaders of the small Persian Gulf sheikdoms are very good at calculating the balance of power. They know the difference between the mirage and the oasis, and they know that as long as Saddam is posing no immediate military threat to them, his army is still a useful counterweight to their more dangerous historic enemy -- Iran.
At the same time, on the Arab street the notion that at least one Arab country, Iraq, has weapons of mass destruction that can balance Israel's is very popular. Moreover, the daily Arab TV diet of pictures of the Palestinian uprising and the Israeli retaliations has produced a gut desire on the Arab street to poke a finger in America's eye.
Finally, the Arab street no longer accepts the logic of sanctions -- that if you squeeze Iraq long enough the Iraqi people will oust Saddam. It is widely felt that Arab leaders can never be ousted by the "people." It never happens in this neighborhood. As one Qatari intellectual said to me: "If your sanctions on Castro have not worked for 40 years to get rid of him, and he is right next to you, why do you believe that they will work to get rid of Saddam?" For the most part, the Iraqi opposition groups (funded by the U.S.) are viewed as corrupt outsiders who would be rejected by the Iraqi body politic in the unlikely event they ever did oust Saddam. 
Bottom line: If Colin Powell tries really hard, launches a real P.R. campaign against Saddam, he might be able to hold together the sanctions long enough to get them lifted in an orderly way and replaced by a U.N. ban on all military sales to Iraq. If you think otherwise, well, I have some lakefront property on the Saudi-Qatari border I'd like to sell you.

HEADLINE: O'Neill Offers a New Approach to Japan 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 

 BODY:
President Bush's treasury secretary described a new approach today for dealing with Japan as the world's largest and second-largest economies appear headed into decline, suggesting he would abandon Washington's constant stream of advice to the government in Tokyo and try working directly with Japanese executives he came to know while running Alcoa.
 In an interview this morning, the new secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, also said that he thought the Clinton administration's efforts to rescue the Russian economy when the ruble collapsed in 1998 were "crazy," and he strongly suggested he would refrain from participating in multibillion-dollar economic bailouts aimed chiefly at stabilizing the currencies of countries where corruption and mismanagement led to crisis. 
 Mr. O'Neill's description of his new approach to Japan appears in keeping with President Bush's repeated insistence that he would conduct a "humble" foreign policy, in which the United States lectured less and listened more. The Treasury Secretary's comments indicated that he would advocate intervening less often in the economies of other nations, as opposed to the Clinton White House, which often did so as it tried to shape a post-cold war global economy. 
But Japan will be an early and critical test of whether that approach is feasible. Once again the world's second-largest economy is slipping into recession, after a decade of dead-slow or no growth. But this time the problem takes on added dimensions, because the United States economy is also slowing.
The combined effect of slumps in both nations, which together make up roughly 40 percent of the world economy, is already being felt around the globe. Yet politicians and bureaucrats in Japan appear to be invoking the same prescriptions now -- hundreds of billions of dollars more in deficit spending by the government -- that have repeatedly failed to start the country growing again.
Mr. O'Neill said he was "still working" on how to approach Japan, but he made it clear he saw pursuing traditional conversations with Japanese politicians but would try to also seek solutions with "industrial people I have worked with who know the real economy."
He rejected any approach that "presumes these are the kind of issues that can be dealt with from the top of one government to the top of another." 
"That," he said, "is a kind of royal view of the world."
"It's important not to give a government-to-government lecture that says 'We're smarter than anyone else,' " Mr. O'Neill said. "I don't find that productive. In most places they will tell you to go to hell. In Japan, they will smile and not do anything."
He said, for example, that he was not interested in lengthy, vague discussion of Japan's myriad regulations. Instead, he said, he wanted to introduce "price competition" to Japan, noting that it was exactly that kind of competition from abroad that reformed American industry in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
At the same time, though, the same Japanese executives with whom Mr. O'Neill says he wants to deal directly have spent years fighting low-priced competition, both foreign and domestic. 
In many ways, the approach to the international economy that Mr. O'Neill described reflects the drastically different background he brings to the job. President Clinton's first treasury secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, was a former senator who enjoyed international diplomacy. His second, Robert E. Rubin, had grown up on Wall Street and focused heavily on the effects of markets, exchange rates and government policy. The third, Lawrence H. Summers, was a Harvard economist whose instincts were to look at a country's macroeconomic and monetary policies.
But Mr. O'Neill is interested in the factory floor, in productivity, and in products. That is evident in his office. He has replaced the traditional computer displays behind the treasury secretary's desk with four large, flat-screen panels. At 8 this morning, he was examining prices on the metals market in London -- "I like to start the day by seeing how London is opening." Another showed stock prices in the United States; Alcoa's trading symbol was the first listed.
"I have to get rid of that now that I'm here," he said with a laugh. 
A third screen had a constant update of his e-mail. Already he has made it clear to the Treasury that he plans to run the place on corporate hours. He gets into work around 6:30 a.m., aides say, keeps strictly to a schedule, and tells his staff that any briefing papers that make it to him past 5 p.m. may miss him as he heads home.
Today Mr. O'Neill made it clear that one of the Clinton administration ideas he would have killed, had he been in office, was the failed attempt to rescue Russia. While the International Monetary Fund led the effort to prop up the ruble, it was the Treasury that pushed to provide the loans to Moscow in return for promised reforms -- promises that evaporated even before the currency crumbled.
"It's awfully easy to be outside and be a critic," Mr. O'Neill said. "I don't know what the insiders thought they were doing when they did Russia. But now permit me to be an outsider again. From an outsider's point of view I thought what occurred was crazy. It made no sense to me, and this is based on my own experience of being in and with, and trying to become a factor in the Russian economy."
In an apparent reference to the Russian businessmen often called oligarchs, who converted their rubles into dollars and shipped them out of the country just before the I.M.F. and Treasury effort failed, he said: "In the world of fungible money, if you don't hold on to your money until its converted into something tangible, you are likely to lose it. And so when you send money in a wire transfer, or send it in on a plane that gets refueled and takes off somewhere else you shouldn't be too surprised if you didn't accomplish what you thought you were trying to do."
A senior official of the I.M.F. acknowledged that the Russian bailout was a failure, but said that it was a legitimate risk given the potential global effects of a crash of the country's currency. That was also the argument the Clinton administration made in 1998, noting that the Russian debacle triggered a run on markets around the world, the collapse of a major American hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management, and a rush by industrial nations around the world to cut interest rates to stabilize the world's currencies. 
"Currency stabilization for who's benefit?" he said. "I really don't understand why someone would take billions of dollars and give it to people who willfully created their own economic mess."
In the future, Mr. O'Neill said, he would press the I.M.F. -- which arranges emergency rescues and has emerged as a major player in determining how nations organize their economic affairs -- to blow the whistle on nations that it believes are headed toward economic disaster.
He made the same case recently in a private meeting with the leaders of the I.M.F. They emerged from the meeting with Mr. O'Neill less than fully convinced. While the fund has begun to make public its assessments of how well countries are managing their economic affairs, it has always been leery of publicly singling out wayward countries.
In part that is because the countries are members of the organization (the United States, however, is the largest single shareholder). I.M.F. officials also say that if countries are fearful of public humiliation, they will not come clean about their fiscal problems. And some I.M.F. officials fear that a published list of nations that are mismanaging their economies would lead any rational foreign investors to pull out their capital -- touching off the kind of crisis the I.M.F. is trying to avoid. 
But Mr. O'Neill, who speaks with the bluntness of an executive interested in uncovering a glitch in the manufacturing line and getting it fixed, says he is not interested in sugar-coating bad economic news. 
Honest assessments, he said, "might be a useful device." "And it puts the institutions," he added, referring to the I.M.F. and others, "in a position where they don't work in smoke and mirrors, they have to call things as they are -- which may be politically inconvenient for people."

HEADLINE: Public Interests; 
All In the Family

BYLINE:  By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
The New York State governor's race is already under way, a 21-month endurance test designed for all the voters who felt the last presidential contest ended far too soon.
 Andrew Cuomo returned home from his stint as secretary of housing and urban development last week, and instantly announced he was running for his father Mario's old job. He made his big revelation at a party at an upscale shoe store owned by his brother-in-law, Kenneth Cole. The waiters dispensed flutes of champagne and fancy hors d'oeuvres, and the fact that they were not tackled the second they came into the room confirmed suspicions that the guests were not your normal crowd of Democratic regulars. 
 Mr. Cuomo has a campaign but no New York address, although he's looking for a house in the suburbs of Westchester County, where the Clintons live. (People who run for statewide office here spend the bulk of their campaigns talking about how much they love upstate New York, but it never seems to occur to any of them to put down roots in Utica.)
The forces supporting Comptroller H. Carl McCall for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination have seized on Mr. Cuomo's eight-year absence as proof that he's an interloper. These are the same people, you understand, who gave the world the Hillary Rodham Clinton Senate campaign.
"We really don't need any outsiders this time," said Representative Charles Rangel last week, at a $1,000-a-plate dinner for Mr. McCall. Mr. Rangel, the first New York politician to urge Mrs. Clinton to get in the race, did everything but call Mr. Cuomo a carpetbagger.
"We don't need a welcome-home party for Carl McCall," agreed Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. He was introduced by Mr. Rangel, who gave a playful speech suggesting ways his fellow Democrats could tell if Mr. Spitzer was planning on indicting them.
In his remarks, Mr. McCall blasted the Republican governor, George Pataki, for "lack of direction," and vowed to improve the upstate economy and "make this the great state the Empire State can be." Mr. Cuomo, by contrast, blasted Mr. Pataki for "lost opportunities," vowed to improve the upstate economy and promised that "2002 is going to be the year that the Empire State strikes back." Obviously, this will be a race that is fought completely on the issues, and personalities will not make any difference whatsoever.
Mr. Cuomo's welcome-home party had an aura of exclusivity that politicians seldom strive for except when they're attempting to collect large sums of campaign contributions. You had your surly bouncers, your TV cameras held behind a rope line and speeches from high-profile co-hosts, including Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg and Martin Luther King III, who had the unfortunate habit of repeatedly pointing out that he doesn't live in New York.
Since Mr. Cuomo is both the son of a former governor and the husband of one of Robert Kennedy's daughters, the theme was dynastic succession, something this state understands very well. Washington may think it's leading the way in elevating sons of elected officials to office, but New York is Nepotism Central. The upcoming City Council races are absolutely stuffed with sons and daughters of term-limited incumbents. Some of them are so youthful that the feel is less "Next Generation" than "Bringing Up Baby."
This month there's a special election in the Bronx for a City Council seat being vacated by Jose Rivera, a Democrat who just moved up (or at least north) to the State Legislature. Mr. Rivera's 22-year-old son, a college student, is running for the seat. His opponent's campaign is being managed by the Council member Pedro G. Espada, the son of State Senator Pedro Espada Jr. The City Council speaker, Peter Vallone, who is running for mayor, is supporting Peter Vallone Jr. as his successor, and Comptroller Alan Hevesi, who's running as well, has already installed a son in the State Senate.
It's hard to decide if this is a healthy sign. At least there are some kids who see politics up close and don't come to loathe it. (Don't hold your breath waiting for Chelsea Clinton or the Bush girls to pick up the torch.) But you wonder if politics is becoming one of those insular occupations that nobody would think of pursuing unless it ran in the family -- like tightrope walking or hog farming.

Russia Warns of Arms Race Over U.S. Missile Shield

HEADLINE: Miss Manners Would Be Appalled 

BYLINE:  By AMIE PARNES 

 BODY:
One would think he would have had more sense. The chief executive of a Fortune 500 company, posing for a photo with executives of a Japanese corporation at the end of arduous negotiations in Tokyo to seal a business deal, stuck his hand behind one of his colleagues' heads and made rabbit ears.
 Funny in America, maybe. Not at all amusing in Japan. The deal later fell through. "You don't really know the effect your behavior might have" said Sue Fox, president of Etiquette Survival Inc. in Las Gadas, Calif., and co-author of "Business Etiquette for Dummies," who tells the story. 
 That may be an extreme example, but business consultants say the American workplace is suffering an epidemic of bad manners these days. Some blame the Internet culture of casual dress and pizza-on-the-run, others the general decline in civility. Whatever the cause, though, they warn, even minor lapses in etiquette can crimp an otherwise promising career.
That insight came to Arlene Chien in a Santa Clara, Calif., restaurant after work. Ms. Chien, a senior sales trainer for the Guidant Corporation, a maker of medical devices, and several colleagues had just given their orders when the waitress arrived with a basket of fresh bread.
Before she could help herself to a slice, the bread was gone. Ms. Chien remembers watching her table mates devour every last crumb and thinking how impolite they were, when suddenly she realized she had been guilty of the same behavior in the past. Then she had a disquieting thought. "What if we were out with clients?" she recalled wondering. "What would they think of us? We didn't really know what the proper rules were when dining."
They decided to find out by taking a course in table manners.
Ravi Singh, 26, a materials analyst at Applied Materials, a San Jose, Calif., maker of semiconductor equipment, is also aware of the connection between job security and workplace etiquette. But it was no sudden revelation. "I always thought about the movie 'Pretty Woman,' " Mr. Singh said. "The character Julia Roberts played didn't have a clue about holding a fork and a knife. I never wanted that to be me."
Besides, he said, he has seen any number of colleagues lose out on promotions or flunk job interviews because of some social gaffe or another. He did not want to suffer a similar fate, he said, so he routinely takes lessons in proper protocol and encourages his colleagues to do the same.
Mr. Singh thinks that training helped him win two promotions at Applied Materials the last year and a half. In one lunch interview with a future boss, he was able to concentrate on what he said because he did not have to worry about what he was doing, and thus made a better impression, he said.
"I was able to ask good questions and really inquire about the job because I wasn't focused on my dining skills," Mr. Singh said.
Knowing how to act has become even more important today than just six months ago, he says, as mass layoffs at dot-coms and a weakening economy are making job seekers more desperate and employers more discerning.
"Before now, all you had to do was basically show up to work and produce and sooner or later you'd get promoted," he said. "Now every little thing helps. Having etiquette skills makes me a better candidate than the next guy who doesn't."
Aware of the negative impact that loutish behavior can have in business, more companies of all sizes are hiring etiquette consultants to give crash courses in decorum to their employees, career counselors say. 
"People are becoming more and more aware of the need for professionalism," said Michael J. Gage, director of the University of Miami's Toppel Career Placement Center, which holds classes twice a semester on workplace etiquette. "We've increased the number of courses we offer here because of the high demand. We've received dozens and dozens of requests."
In recent months, the message that good manners can bolster one's career has become a trendy topic in books. In 1999, HarperCollins released "The Etiquette Advantage in Business," by Peggy and Peter Post. And this year, IDG Books, the Dummies book series, published Ms. Fox's tome.
The message is simple, if exacting. "What you really want to do is make sure you, the employee, are perfect in everything that you do. Don't give the boss any reason to give you the pink slip," Ms. Fox said.
To that end, the experts teach the proper way to do everything from holding a fork to eating soup to dressing down on casual Friday. Some important do's: sitting upright at business meetings with both feet planted firmly on the floor; knowing how to order a good wine at a business meal; being a good listener; and mentioning the names of people you talk to at business meetings.
And some equally important don'ts: handing business cards out like candy; answering a cellular phone in the middle of a business lunch or dinner; and eating hot, spicy foods in an office cubicle where colleagues are forced to breathe the aromas.
Also, body contact is out. "The corporate kiss on the cheek is dead," said Audrey Kardon, a corporate etiquette specialist in Palm Beach. "And the good ol' boy slap on the back has been dead for years."
In most cases, you do not really have to take a course. You just have to show common courtesy and use common sense.
For example, it helps to stay alert. Ms. Fox relates the tale of an executive whose attention apparently wandered at a business meeting when a woman with a male first name was introduced. She was the other company's president, but the executive assumed the man sitting next to her was in charge, and addressed him rather than her throughout the negotiations.
Annoyed at his ignorance, one of her top aides urged her to scuttle the talks.
Ms. Chien says most people understand the basics of etiquette, like not eating with their mouth full at a lunch with potential clients. But a little study is probably necessary to master the finer points, she said.
"Many people don't know that you're not supposed to talk about business until you get to the dessert part of the meal," Ms. Chien said. "When you know this, that's when you know you've taken your business to a higher level."

HEADLINE: MIXED MEDIA; 
Lands Without Plenty: Images of Asia

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
IF a Big Mac tells only part of the story of eating in America -- where hunting, gathering and cultivating food means logging on to the Internet, ordering overpriced takeout or strolling through the neighborhood singles' supermarket -- the food of India, China, Vietnam and Nepal tells a more complicated tale. When there are 3.6 billion fellow Asians clamoring for lunch, everyone had better work. 
 Or so the story goes as told by the images in a new exhibition at the Asia Society about the delicacies, and necessities, of Asian cuisine. The show, "Can We Feed Ourselves?" -- a collection of 52 photos by Hiroji Kubota -- has a clear political point: there is a crisis of nutrition in Asia. Or, as the somewhat morbidly enthusiastic tour guide announced last Saturday as she shepherded a group through the collection, "Did you know that 35 million infants die of malnutrition every day on the planet?" (Not to play down the gravity of the hunger issue, but the number is 35,000, according to Mr. Kubota's postscript in the exhibition catalog.) 
 Behind that compelling figure, though, is the sheer economic complexity of feeding 3.6 billion people. Mr. Kubota, a photographer for Magnum, tries to convey this, not to mention the occasionally provocative and sometimes just plainly poetic image. 
There is the photo of fishermen in Daqing, China, searching for carp through ice that is six feet thick. Their cheeks are coated with a sheen of frost, and when the fish are flipped onto the surface, where the air temperature is minus 30 degrees, they freeze instantly. There is a Chinese farmer hacking away at an endless landscape of yellow-brown loam, in what looks like a fruitless attempt to coax anything edible from the earth. And there is a woman in Jiangxi Province, China, squinting at a naked duck, a skein of string in her mouth, her job being to rip out any remaining feathers. The caption reports that in addition to her modest daily pay, she receives 7 cents a duck, and a skilled woman can process 80 ducks a day. That's $5.60. 
There is beauty, too: a Balinese farmer pushing his two oxen in a field, Bali's holiest mountain against the Kodachrome-blue sky; a girl milking her goats in Mongolia, her foot tucked demurely under her like the young subject of an Impressionist painting.
The notion of some Asian meals invokes complex feelings for Americans. After all, not many Americans eat dog or cat. And so a photo of a cat -- looking so fluffily pretty and pampered you can practically hear Lauren Bacall's voice-over for Fancy Feast -- on sale as food would disturb many Americans. The photographs of dogs roasting on a spit and water buffalo carcasses spread out on a soiled sheet for sale might also shock. But why should they? Most of us would eat a steak from a cow with a white hide, which is anathema to Indians. And it would be just as unsettling to visit the factory where a fast-food chain manufactures the cheese analog and special sauce that transform a hamburger into a Big Mac.
The exhibition runs through April 1 at the Asia Society, 59th Street and Park Avenue; admission is $4, $2 for students and senior citizens, and free from noon to 2 p.m. Tuesdays through Fridays.
Is there a single food that merits its own magazine? Can you imagine Yogurt Weekly, Cheesecake Quarterly or Kumquat Digest? 
The chili pepper has apparently merited its own magazine since 1987, one with a circulation that has grown to 100,000, about the same as The New Republic's, but not quite Bon Appetit's 1.2 million. And Chile Pepper magazine is intriguing despite its limited subject matter. Where else can you learn that Indian scientists have been searching for the chilies with the highest levels of capsaicin, the ingredient that gives the chili its kick, for use in riot-control agents? Or get a recipe for Jump-Up Bussu Soup? (Bussu are small Jamaican river snails.) Or read about the culinary history of the affair between Gov. Earl Long of Louisiana and the stripper Blaze Starr? (Hint: they were not eating cookies in bed.) 
Joel Gregory, the editor in chief and publisher, said last week that sales have been robust ever since baby boomers started to look for less fattening and more flavorful ways to cook. 
But baby boomers are aging, and even if they love salsa and jambalaya, their gastrointestinal tracts may not appreciate major infusions of spice. So Mr. Gregory has joined in a marketing partnership with Pepcid Complete, a heartburn medication. Last month, Johnson & Johnson, the company that manufactures Pepcid, and the magazine gave a barbecue at the New York Stock Exchange, providing passers-by with packets of Pepcid along with free barbecue (don't hold the pepper sauce) from a 72-foot smoker imported from Texas. 
"There are folks who enjoy too much of a good thing, and we feel like it is sort of a natural relationship for us to be in a marketing partnership with Pepcid," Mr. Gregory said. "I guess we're the cause and they're the cure." 

GRAPHIC: Photos: HOW THEY EAT -- A food market in Taunggyi, Myanmar, left. Sorting rice in Myanmar, below, and planting it in Bali, Indonesia, bottom. (Hiroji Kubota/Magnum Photos)
