HEADLINE: Trade Feud On Bananas Not as Clear As It Looks 

BYLINE:  By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
In the simmering eight-year trade feud over bananas, the two sides have publicly staked out simple positions: the European Union maintains import quotas to protect the fragile economies of former colonies where bananas are grown, while the United States is foursquare for unfettered trade. Likewise with the position of the war's biggest apparent casualty, Chiquita Brands, which said last month that it was near bankruptcy, and that it was suing the European Commission over the quotas.
 A closer look at the European banana market yields a very different picture, and some curious paradoxes -- among them, that Chiquita sells more bananas in Europe than any other company; that three of the top four companies in the market are American; that Europe has already decided to stop explicitly favoring its colonies' produce; and that neither Chiquita nor the United States government seems to really want unrestricted banana imports in Europe. 
 "It's very confusing," said Liam Igoe, a food industry analyst at Goodbody Stockbrokers. "It's like an onion: you peel away layers, and layers, and layers." 
Things will become even stranger in April, analysts say, when the European Union plans to replace its current quota system with a first-come- first-served approach. Company quotas will fluctuate week to week based on when their bananas arrive, raising the specter of a weekly trans-Atlantic banana boat race. Chiquita says that plan is unfair, too.
The company that would appear to be on the offsetting side of Chiquita's woes, reaping the benefits of trade protection, is Fyffes, based in Dublin, the importer that dominates the European produce market. Along with marketing about 5 percent of all fruit and vegetables coming into the European Union, Fyffes is the only major European banana importer. Analysts estimate that its share of the banana market is a close second to Chiquita's. (By Fyffes's slightly different reckoning, it, Chiquita, Del Monte and Dole are neck and neck.)
Yet there is little evidence that the quota system is producing windfalls for Fyffes: net income fell 40 percent in the six months ended in October. Paul Meade, a food industry analyst with NCB Stockbrokers, said he expected Fyffes to report "pretty poor" annual results in March.
Profits in the banana trade generally have suffered lately, in part because of adverse exchange-rate movements -- importers' costs are largely paid in dollars, especially shipping, while their European revenue comes in euros -- and partly because of a global glut of bananas, a problem European executives lay at Chiquita's door.
"The E.U. is the only profitable banana market in the world, because it's protected," Mr. Meade said. "It's somewhat of a fallacy that the Americans want the regime disbanded." Instead, he said, Chiquita simply wants a bigger quota.
European fruit executives and analysts said Chiquita's troubles stemmed from a series of strategic missteps, starting with overeager expansion in Europe in the late 1980's and early 1990's, around the time European economic integration was gathering steam.
Chiquita invested heavily in anticipation of a vast open market across Western Europe that it hoped to dominate. The bet proved a poor one when banana quotas were imposed in 1993. Meanwhile, the retreat of communism from Eastern Europe was opening up a market with rapidly growing demand, but Chiquita was poorly placed to exploit it because its plantations and ripening centers were too far away.
More recently, Chiquita has piled up debt by expanding production in Latin America, where bananas grow larger but are less sweet than those grown in the Caribbean basin.
"Chiquita had made a number of mistakes along the way strategically," Mr. Igoe said.
Chiquita and Fyffes are very different combatants in the trade battle. While Chiquita is quite active politically in Washington, Fyffes has no office in Brussels, where the European Union is based, and spends less than 50,000 euros ($46,900) annually for political contributions, said Philip Halpenny, Fyffes' corporate secretary. "It certainly would be nothing like what is alleged to go on in the U.S. by the U.S. banana companies," he said. "We don't need the hassle of being asked, 'Why did you contribute that?' "
Fyffes is in better financial shape than Chiquita, with modest debt and a cash reserve of $80 million. To cut costs, it has restructured its supplier relationships and closed banana warehouses in England run by Geest, which is half-owned by Fyffes. And it is open to new strategic moves, Mr. Halpenny said, like teaming up with other companies to share shipping expenses, the bane of an industry that relies on a fragile and time-sensitive cargo.
But Fyffes, too, has had setbacks recently, notably in an Internet business-to-business venture, WorldofFruit.com, that briefly sent Fyffes stock soaring last February. The Internet unit has struggled to grow beyond being merely an adjunct to Fyffes's own business. Last month, it announced a handful of layoffs and a ceiling on further investment. And Fyffes stock has returned to earth, closing yesterday at 0.98 euros.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
In a Society of Their Own, Children Are Learning

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
Jorge Tirado had the skills. "I am a good writer, so I can write tickets," he told the chief of police during his job interview.
He had the experience. On his resume, under hobbies, it lists "acting like a bodyguard" for the newly elected president, Kuni Muto.
 And attitude? 
 "I need to work on my temperature and my respect," he admitted. 
"Your temperature?" asked the chief, Diana Cardona, looking down her nose over blue-rimmed glasses as she suppressed a giggle. "You mean your temper?"
"Yes, I will work hard to calm myself down," the humbled applicant said. "I would not let girls pass by me if they're running in the halls. Or boys. Even if they're my best friend."
After a firm handshake, Jorge, a 12-year-old seventh grader aspiring to a career in law enforcement, got the job, one of seven newly sworn officers who will patrol the halls here at Amistad Academy under the command of Chief Cardona, also age 12. Five of Jorge's schoolmates were hired as tellers for the bank, which will soon be set up in one of the classrooms, and 18 will work at the museum, whose exhibits will adorn an alcove outside the cafeteria. Sixteen got jobs in the court -- normally the library -- as judges, bailiffs and, assuming they pass the Amistad bar exam, lawyers.
They are all part of "microsociety," an effort to link lessons to life, in which pupils have jobs, pay taxes, run businesses, make laws and punish lawbreakers -- at least for a few hours a week, after traditional classes. Amistad, a charter school in its second year, joins at least 200 schools in 40 states experimenting with the approach, which began as one New York City teacher's attempt to control unruly fifth graders in the 1960's and has won praise for making school more relevant and fun, while also building practical skills transportable to the adult world.
A 1998 study of 15 microsociety schools in six states, conducted by a professor at Drexel University in Philadelphia, suggested that it might also help boost student achievement: students at two-thirds of the schools posted gains on standardized math and reading tests that were greater -- as much as 21 percent -- than their peers'.
At Amistad, microsociety is a critical element of a curriculum designed to prepare a poor minority population for competitive colleges, careers and citizenship.
Eighty-four percent of Amistad's 135 fifth, sixth and seventh graders qualify for the federal free lunch program, and they enter the school, on average, performing two years behind grade level. Most of the day is spent on familiar subjects, with reading and math taught in groups of 6 to 16. The school raised its average test scores last year two and a half levels in math and one and a half in reading.
But Amistad's director, Dacia Toll, said that her students "need a running start," and that reading, writing and math are simply not enough. Amistad is organized around a set of core values: respect, enthusiasm, achievement, citizenship and hard work, whose acronym, Reach, is posted everywhere the eye turns. Microsociety brings those values to life, and keeps eyes on the prize of long-term success.
"It's the most powerful thing we can do in terms of career aspirations," said Ms. Toll, 28, who founded Amistad after graduating from nearby Yale Law School. "I can be a lawyer. Why? Well, I was a lawyer in sixth and seventh grades; it was fun.
"You can't teach citizenship by saying, 'Turn to Page 287 and let's read the preamble to the Constitution,' " she added. "We really wanted these kids to understand what it means to be a citizen of a society."
For the 13 Amistad students who remain unemployed, hampered by poor grades or bad reputations or interview stutters, that means applying for second-, third-, maybe eighth-choice jobs, until they can persuade one of the student managers to give them a chance. Or they could try persuading the 12-member legislature, with two representatives from each classroom, to establish an unemployment agency.
"We'll have lobbyists pretty soon," Ms. Toll said with a laugh.
The microsociety concept was born in Brooklyn in 1967, when George Richmond, a rookie teacher frustrated by his pupils' lack of motivation, started paying them in fake money for attendance and achievement, then created a fantasy world where they could earn and spend. Dr. Richmond's 1973 book inspired parents and teachers in Lowell, Mass., to open the first microsociety school in 1981. Over the next decade, handfuls of imitators sprouted in several states, with some, like a school in Yonkers, housed in special buildings resembling a marketplace or small town.
The movement took off in 1996, when the federal government approved the microsociety concept as one of several whole-school overhauls eligible for three-year grants of $150,000. Dr. Richmond's nonprofit organization, Micro-Society Inc., in Philadelphia, runs summer training workshops for about 400 teachers a year. About 60 percent of the participants are elementary schools, and the rest middle schools like Amistad.
Each program is different, as student entrepreneurs shape their societies. In Texas, younger pupils rent older ones to read to them in the library. In Savannah, Ga., kids pay to play basketball against their teachers. At a performing arts school in Florida, one student made and sold an exercise video. In Lowell one year, a boy who wrote a string of bad checks at the Christmas auction had his wages garnisheed and was sentenced to community service.
"It's very theoretical for a kid in a classroom to make that connection between reading and math and what's happening in the outside world," said Marc Michaelson, a civics teacher and director of Amistad's program. "But in micro, it's very simple to make that connection; it comes screaming at you."
Last year, Amistad students elected delegates to a constitutional convention, which spent months honing a document whose bill of rights includes a guarantee that taxes will not rise above 40 percent of income. Last fall, Kuni, a quiet sixth grader with an impeccable transcript, beat five seventh-grade opponents -- including one who handed out chocolate chip cookies -- by focusing his campaign on the younger students, promising to appoint at least one from each grade to his cabinet.
In art class, students are designing the currency, which will carry the faces of heroes they selected, including Marian Wright Edelman of the Children's Defense fund; the legendary Puerto Rican baseball player Roberto Clemente; and Sengbe Pieh, the leader of the revolt aboard the slave ship for which the school is named.
Teachers selected managers for each sector, then the job fair began.
"The first one I interviewed, her head was down and she was mumbling, I couldn't hear her, and she didn't ask any questions," said Jessica Zullo, the museum's head tour guide. "The second one I interviewed, she gave me a nice firm handshake, she looked me in the eye, she wrote a nice thank-you note." In class, Jessica added, "every time there's something to do, she's right there trying to help me out."
Jessica, who is 11, applied to be a manager because "I like being in charge." In real life, she, like several other micropoliticians, wants to be president. "You have to start out a lawyer, then you have to be a judge, then you become a legislator, then governor, then you can be president," Jessica explained.
"I have two more years left here," she pointed out. "Next year I'll be a legislator, then the year after that, I'll run for president."
She may as well wait. Article III, Section 3 of the microsociety's constitution sets a one-year term limit for president.

(Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate; 
Planned Office Complex: Big and Easy to Get To

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
After sitting fallow for 15 years, a 35-acre property that lies south of Black Rock Turnpike and east of Kings Highway East in Fairfield, Conn., is now the proposed site for a $250 million, eight-building office-and-retail complex. Real estate executives say it would be the largest commercial development ever in the town and one of the largest in the state.
 Despite having an enviable site right off Interstate 95, the property has long been an eyesore. The United Parcel Service bought the land in the mid-1980's with the goal of turning the 40-year-old foundry there into a major distribution center. But those plans were never realized, and for 15 years the land, which used to belong to the Bullard Company, a machinery maker, has been unused. U.P.S. recently sold the property to Blackrock Realty, a developer based in Stamford that is not associated with either the Manhattan-based BlackRock investment management firm or the similarly named real estate brokerage firm, also in Manhattan. 
 Planning has been under way since last summer for the complex project, which is a collaboration by the town of Fairfield, the state and Blackrock, a partnership formed by the Rugby Realty Company of Teterboro, N.J., and Kurt Wittek, a Stamford developer. 
Current plans call for the complex to have 1.1 million square feet of office space, 120,000 square feet of retail space, a new Metro-North Railroad station and parking for 1,200 commuter cars.
The project, which is scheduled to be completed in 2010, faces a few remaining hurdles. For one, while Blackrock already has the support of the town and the state, it is awaiting the formal approval of the town's planning and conservation departments as well as certain divisions within the state's Department of Transportation. 
Nevertheless, the state has already committed $16.2 million for the project, and Fairfield is considering adding $12 million, for a total of $28.2 million. That money would go toward building a platform for the new train station as well as a local access road and bridge. Blackrock, meanwhile, would be responsible for building the train depot and for the environmental cleanup of the entire site, an effort that would include restoring roughly 11 acres of open space adjacent to Ash Creek to a functioning wetland. 
John G. Metsopoulos, first selectman of Fairfield, said the project would solve some problems in the town, including a shortage of commuter parking and a federal mandate that Fairfield have at least one train station that can serve disabled travelers. While downtown Fairfield already has a Metro-North station, which is about a mile away from Blackrock's proposed depot, it cannot accommodate either more commuters or disabled travelers, he said. 
Mr. Metsopoulos also agreed with the findings of a recent economic impact report, commissioned by Blackrock, which estimated that the project would eventually bring 4,300 jobs into the Fairfield area, as well as $6 million in annual tax revenues. According to the report, the old Bullard site now produces tax revenues of about $100,000. 
"I think this project will have a very strong economic impact in our area," said Mr. Metsopoulos, who added that when he was a child, the Bullard foundry was a symbol of the vitality of the Fairfield and Bridgeport area. 
Blackrock executives say they want to restore that vitality. After first converting the old foundry building into three floors of office and retail space, they hope eventually to build seven additional office buildings, a health club and a hotel. Their plans also call for building a 2,000-foot-long nature walk as well as an additional 4,500 parking spaces for the office and retail users. 
Still, the proposed train station is what Blackrock's executives hope will set their development apart from other office parks.
"Office users now looking for space have to make an apples-or-oranges decision, either staying downtown, where they have various amenities and ease of access to public transport, or moving to a suburban office park," said Aaron D. Stauber, managing director of Rugby Realty. "This project incorporates the best of both worlds."
But the project may also help address the growing demand for office space northeast of Greenwich and Stamford. Real estate executives say this demand is being driven not just by high rents in those locations but also by the desire of many companies to relocate to an area that is already home to a large number of their workers, many of whom cannot afford to live farther south and west. 
"Right now there is a 1 percent vacancy rate for high-quality office space in the Fairfield area," said Daniel A. Mambrino, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield of Connecticut. According to Mr. Mambrino, who helped to broker the recent sale of the U.P.S. property, the asking price for office space in the area has risen about $10 in each of the past two years and is now running in the low $30's per square foot. 
Mr. Wittek said his company was already in discussions with potential tenants now in Fairfield County. 
"We think our project is uniquely positioned to solve a number of problems for companies and their employees," he said. "The size of our property means we can change our plans to accommodate the needs of unique tenants, as well as attract world-class companies. But this is also a site that is 30 seconds off of I-95, in an area where overall development is headed." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: A $250 million office-and-retail complex, planned on 35 acres off Interstate 95 in Fairfield, Conn., would be one of the largest in the state. (Perkins Eastman Architects PC)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Technology Gains, but Dow Slips After Topping 11,000

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Technology stocks rose yesterday, but the Dow Jones industrial average's rally above the key 11,000-point level lost steam and blue chips closed slightly lower.
 "The underlying premise is that the economy is going to be a lot better in the second half" because of the Federal Reserve's easing of interest rates, said Alfred Kugel, senior investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham. "Therefore, you don't want to be too negative on technology, but try to pick your spot." 
 Bargain hunters bought shares of beaten-down computer chip companies like Intel and personal computer makers like Dell Computer. Wall Street keenly awaited the results from the technology bellwether Cisco Systems, which, after the close, reported a 48 percent increase in profits, but still missed analysts' sales and earnings estimates by a penny a share. 
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.43 points, or 0.10 percent, to 10,957.42, after rallying early in the day above the 11,000 mark. The index has risen above that watermark several times in the last few months, but has not closed above it since mid-September.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 21.28 points, or 0.8 percent, to 2,664.49, after climbing more than 2 percent earlier. The Nasdaq bounced back after falling more than 4 percent on Friday as investors worried about the slowing United States economy and dwindling corporate earnings in the high-tech sector.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index shed 2.05 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,352.26.
The Dow's technology components, like I.B.M., bolstered the index, which was weighed down by faltering financial stocks like J. P. Morgan Chase, which closed down $2.32, at $52.28.
Both the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq showed strength earlier in the day. But the rally lost momentum as investors locked in profits, especially after the Dow's rise above 11,000 faltered, analysts said.
"The Dow had a triple-digit gain yesterday, so once it got above 11,000 and could not hold, the profit taking comes in," Mr. Kugel said.
The possibility that the Dow could break out of its trading range helped the Nasdaq, noted Barry Hyman of Weatherly Securities.
"There is a correspondent spillover effect, in terms of the effect of how interest rates going lower can help the economy and growth stocks," Mr. Hyman said. "I think it is very important that the Dow closes above 11,000 to give us that technical break in the market to the upside."
Cisco Systems gained $1.19, to close at $35.75, but its shares fell to $34.38 in after-hours trading after the company reported its results.
Antitrust regulators cleared Dow Chemical's $7.3 billion purchase of Union Carbide after Dow agreed to sell a key plastics technology and divest itself of three other chemical businesses. Shares of Dow fell 79 cents, to $32.60, while Union Carbide fell 52 cents, to $52.25.

Treasury Prices Fall
(By The Associated Press) -- Treasury bond prices slipped yesterday, as traders looked toward Treasury auctions this week and pondered the fate of the 30-year bond.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 3/32, to a price of 104 8/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.18 percent from 5.17 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 5/32, to 110 28/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.50 percent from 5.49 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
His Rear-View Mirror Reflects Big Business

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
Lloyd D. Ward, the former chief executive of the Maytag Corporation, is sitting in a cramped office here, talking about how he is going to make a household name out of a company most people have never heard of.
 After 15 stormy months at the top of Maytag, Mr. Ward resigned last November and then stunned corporate America by accepting a job as chairman and chief executive of an Internet start-up called iMotors, an online seller of used cars. 
 It was a giant step down from a brand-name maker of home appliances with 25,000 employees and $4 billion in annual sales to a privately held venture with 600 employees and tens of million of dollars in revenue. But Mr. Ward said he did not care that he jumped from an old-economy stalwart to a dot-com just when everyone else seemed to be fleeing in the opposite direction. 
On the contrary, he says, he relishes the challenge. "Someone said to me, 'Don't you feel like you've gone through a demotion?' I said, 'That doesn't even compute with me,' " he recalled. "If it's about performance and discovery, the opportunity I now have is the best opportunity of all the ones I looked at. This is the best for me."
Mr. Ward, 52, became only the second African-American to run a Fortune 500 company when he took over Maytag. Franklin D. Raines, chief executive of Fannie Mae, was the first. Now, he has set an even more extraordinary goal for himself: to become the first African-American to create such a company. He says he will turn iMotors, which finds, refurbishes, certifies and then resells used cars on the Web, into the Dell Computer of the car industry.
The dot-com world is littered with the wreckage of grandiose projects that have crashed into old-economy realities, of course, and skeptics say iMotors is a prime candidate to join the casualty toll. Car sales on the Web have fared poorly over the last few years, they say, and iMotors cannot hope to succeed unless it creates a national system with a widely recognized brand name. To do that, it will not only have to raise a huge amount of money but also capture the public's imagination.
"It certainly is a long shot, but there is a glimmer of hope," said Baba Shetty, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. Selling cars over the Web is tough, Mr. Shetty said, because while consumers like to glean pricing information from the Internet, they prefer trooping off to car dealers to inspect the actual merchandise.
Mr. Ward brushes aside such concerns. "I think iMotors will be a Fortune 500 company," he said in an interview at his office in San Francisco over a turkey and cranberry sandwich. "I'm not sure it'll be a Fortune 100 company."
This is no fly-by-night outfit, he says. Over the last two years, iMotors has raised about $137 million, and is backed by several big venture capital firms including one controlled by Paul G. Allen, the Microsoft co-founder. And last October, it beefed up its executive ranks by hiring Kiran Patel, the former chief financial officer at Cummins Engine, the diesel engine maker.
Mr. Ward, with an extensive corporate pedigree, is by far its biggest catch. He joined Maytag as executive vice president in 1996 after stints at Procter & Gamble, the Ford Motor Company and PepsiCo. After he was elevated to chief executive, a cover story in Business Week called him "one of the most driven men in America." And after he left Maytag, he was wooed by a bevy of would-be employers, including a Fortune 100 company, before going to iMotors.
Even so, for all of Mr. Ward's talk of exploiting the speed and versatility of the Internet at iMotors to sell a big-ticket consumer product, critics say that is what he tried and failed to do at Maytag. There, he pushed Internet ventures, like Outdoorliving .com, a Web site devoted to selling Maytag grills as well as delivering steaks and seafood to customers' homes, and he championed a partnership with Microsoft to develop appliances that interact with television and the Internet.
Nicholas Heymann, an analyst at Prudential, said Mr. Ward was a great promoter, wowing Wall Street with visions of Maytag's electronic future, only to let them down later. "The guy was a super e-dude. He had all these e-groups out there talking about how Maytag's goal was to enhance the joy of living," Mr. Heymann said. "Lloyd came in and got all these people gassed up."
At least some Maytag insiders share that view. "Lloyd's very charismatic, you get him in meetings and he energizes people," a senior executive said. The problem was, this executive said, "he went off on tangents."
"He'll grab onto something and he'll run with it and he'll forget the old stuff."
Outdoorliving.com, for example, the executive said, "isn't a bad business school concept, but it's not Maytag."
Mr. Ward did not dispute the executive's assessment.
To some extent, Mr. Ward was the victim of bad luck, or perhaps, bad timing. Even as he took over Maytag in the summer of 1999 and set the goal of doubling revenue within five years, sales were showing signs of weakening. Within a year, Circuit City, a major retailer, stopped selling home appliances, and in August 2000, Heilig & Meyers, another national chain that carried Maytag products, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and shut down a third of its nearly 900 stores. Maytag's Dixie-Narco vending-machine unit, meantime, was hurt by softening demand for soft drinks.
Mr. Ward also sought to cut costs by farming out administrative work and he instituted a quality-control regimen that he called "lean Sigma," a variation of the Six Sigma program made famous at General Electric. But as it became increasingly apparent that the company would fall short of his rosy profit forecasts, its share price fell sharply and several top executives departed. In his final months, employee morale was sapped by newspaper reports that the company was planning to move its headquarters to Chicago from Newton, Iowa, and that it was in merger talks with Electrolux, the Swedish maker of household appliances.
On Nov. 9, Mr. Ward abruptly resigned, citing "strategic differences" with the board. He was replaced by Leonard A. Hadley, his predecessor at Maytag, who is serving as interim chief executive. Mr. Hadley, who has made it clear that he intends to keep Maytag in Iowa, quickly shuttered several of the ventures started by Mr. Ward, including Outdoorliving.com.
Mr. Ward said he had no regrets about the way things ended. "I have no misgivings, malice or bad feelings about Maytag," he said. "The thing I feel very good about is the board and I were upfront and forthright. We looked things squarely in the eye; there was nothing clandestine. These were the rougher discussions you had to have in these challenging times."
Besides, he said, even though he may have moved too fast at Maytag, the experience taught him that he needed to be somewhere at the intersection of the new and the old economies. Within five days of his resignation, he received feelers from a number of corporations and universities and even from political professionals who wondered if he was interested in running for public office, he says.
"I'm interviewing at one of the Fortune 100 companies," he said. "I'm in this incredible office, this awesome mahogany palace in a wonderful setting. Everything at your fingertips, all the resources."
But he was most intrigued by the offer from iMotors, because it promised the opportunity of building a corporate culture, rather than altering or reforming one. He visited the company's three refurbishing plants with his wife, Lita, and one of his two sons, who had run an Internet start-up that failed, he said, and thus had a keen eye for bubbles ready to burst.
This was not one of them, in his view. He liked iMotors, he says, because it was a hybrid, a blend of the old bricks and mortar and the digital age. So Mr. Ward, who says he follows the value-investing philosophy of Warren E. Buffett, became convinced the iMotors model of buying used cars that have been on the road for no more than five years, sprucing them up in its own factories and then selling the "premium-priced, premium cars" over the Internet, was not just viable, it was potentially lucrative.
"As part of my exploration I go to every factory," Mr. Ward said. "I shake hands with the workers, I listen to their stories; I see the dents, dings and scuffs, and I see it come out of the factory like new. I saw the product under a fluorescent light and it was magical. I said, 'There is a value-added product.' "
He says he does not underestimate the hurdles ahead. He knows that creating a major business in an online space where few auto companies have succeeded will not be easy. Nor will branding iMotors as the leading company in a category, used cars, that the public does not look fondly upon.
"The used-car experience is one of little trust," Mr. Ward said, "and it's in need of significant re-engineering."
Joining iMotors also completes a personal journey for Mr. Ward, who grew up poor in Romulus, Mich., just outside of Detroit. As a boy, his father had dreamed of opening an auto mechanic shop with his sons called Ward & Sons. But he died in 1967, at 47.
"That's one reason I can take a job like this," Mr. Ward said. "It's a little bit taking me back to my roots."
Mr. Ward is spending his time now worrying about cash flow, and trying to bring discipline to a company that is hoping to raise another round of money. Most of the corporate perks he knew at Maytag are gone. There are no corporate jets, no speech writers and not even a secretary for him at iMotors. He orders his own meals, answers his own e-mail messages and sometimes makes his own rental car arrangements.
None of that matters, he says, because he is in charge of something new. "I've always wanted to be an entrepreneur," he said. "I've spent 30 years in big business, but in many ways I've always been an intrepreneur -- an entrepreneur working inside a big company -- and so it seemed like a good time to do this."
Besides, he says, he can always go back. "I'm telling you," he said confidently, leaning back in his chair, "I will run a Fortune 100 company before my journey is over."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Ex-Drug Dealer Gets Help In Keeping a Legal Job

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
David Harris's drug-dealing friends knew they had a winner when he told them he had never been arrested. They asked him to help them sell drugs and assured him that if the police ever caught him, he would not go to jail. "My friends said, 'David, you have no record,' " he recalled. " 'How would you like to make some quick money and get high?' "
 To Mr. Harris, a developmentally disabled man from the Bronx who had a young son, David Jr., but no job, it sounded like a good idea, though he had reservations. "I knew eventually I was going to get killed or get in trouble," he said recently. 
 Eventually he did get in trouble, but his friends who told him that he would not be given a prison sentence were right. When he was arrested in 1987 for drug possession, the judge gave him a few months' probation.
But he kept dealing drugs, and in 1989, when he was arrested a second time, the judge sentenced him to eight months on Rikers Island.
And when he was arrested for the third time, in 1995, he was given two to six years, which he began serving in prisons upstate.
"Every time I came home from prison, I always went back," Mr. Harris said, "because I had no help."
A prison staff member told officials of the State Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities about Mr. Harris, and they began to search for a program that could help him. They suggested that he be put in the Arthur Kill Correctional Facility on Staten Island to be closer to programs in the city and began telling nonprofit agencies about him in the hope that one would volunteer to help him.
Information about his case came to the attention of Caryn Sicignano, an intake coordinator for FEGS, formerly the Federation Employment and Guidance Service. FEGS, which specializes in job training for the unemployed, is a beneficiary agency of UJA-Federation of New York, one of the seven local charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
Ms. Sicignano visited Mr. Harris at Arthur Kill and told him that when he got out, FEGS would help him get a job and guidance. "She was like a mother to me," said Mr. Harris, 37. "For someone from the other side to come and visit me, it was like a joy. I will never forget her."
He was released last June into the custody of FEGS, which put him in supervised housing. 
"They weren't going to let him out of prison into the street," Ms. Sicignano said. "He needed a 24-hour -- or close to it -- supervised setting."
He was also enrolled in a short-term job-training program. It teaches developmentally disabled adults the communications skills they need to get a job and how to travel by subway and bus, and puts many in short-term jobs working in soup kitchens and the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in the Bronx. "David was a very big help to us," said Nigel Nero, the job-training program supervisor. "He has a lot of abilities."
After days at the program, he returns home to a three-bedroom apartment in the Norwood section of the Bronx that he shares with two other men enrolled in FEGS programs. FEGS staff members visit daily to make sure the men are taking the medications they need, teach them how to cook and help residents get ready for work by waking them up in the morning and by supervising as they eat breakfast and get washed and dressed for the day.
On Monday, Mr. Harris got a job as a Manhattan foot messenger. Now that he has a job and is living in a stable environment, he can focus more attention on David Jr., 18, a freshman at Columbia who lives with his mother in Harlem. The two speak on the phone every day.
"I'm very proud for him to be the only one from the family that grew up to go to college," Mr. Harris said. "I couldn't believe it until I went on campus to see it myself."

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA; 
TOSHIBA CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK

BYLINE:  By Miki Tanikawa 

 BODY:
 The Toshiba Corporation warned that its group net profit for the year ending in March will be 30 percent lower than had been previously forecast because of falling sales and prices of chips and PC's caused by the slowing economy in the United States. Toshiba, a leading Japanese chip maker, lowered its profit forecast to 96 billion yen ($837 million) from 137 billion yen. The company lowered its revenue forecast 3.9 percent, to 5.98 trillion yen ($52 billion). Toshiba also said its American unit would lay off 500 assembly line workers and engineers at its computer-making plant in Irvine, Calif., and shift much of the work to Asia.
 Miki Tanikawa

HEADLINE: Women's Health Is No Longer a Man's World 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
When Dr. David Garfinkel joined a New Jersey ob-gyn practice in 1996, his contract provided for a $65,000 raise his second year and a share in the practice the third year. But Dr. Garfinkel received no raise -- and in January 1998, he was told that he would not become a shareholder in the practice, Morristown Obstetrics & Gynecology Associates. 
 "They said that because I was male, I wasn't drawing as many patients as they'd expected," he said. 
 Two months later, Dr. Garfinkel was fired. He responded by opening his own practice, right next door -- and suing for breach of contract and sex discrimination. 
The Morristown practice he is suing refused to comment on the case, but the lawyer representing the practice said Dr. Garfinkel's firing had nothing to do with his sex. 
"Dr. Garfinkel was let go for economic reasons," said the lawyer, Glenn Montgomery. "He was brought in at a salary twice what a normal beginning doctor would get, because he said he had a big following, and it turned out he didn't have that following."
Whatever the facts of Dr. Garfinkel's case, no one denies that the field is changing rapidly, and Dr. Garfinkel is by no means the only man in it feeling that his professional prospects have been chilled by the winds of social change across the nation -- and the increasing availability of, and patient preference for, female ob-gyns. 
Though men still dominate the field -- about 64 percent of the doctors practicing obstetrics and gynecology are male -- most of the doctors now training in the specialty are women. This year, women have filled 70.3 percent of the nation's ob-gyn residencies, compared with slightly less than half 10 years ago. And the shift is apparently intensifying. 
"From what I hear, most program directors found that that 80 to 90 percent of their residency applicants this year are females," said Dr. John Musich, chairman of the Council on Resident Education in Obstetrics and Gynecology. "It's a huge issue for male medical students. We can't force patients to see a particular gender, and there are women who feel that women are more sensitive as physicians to female complaints than men might be. It's reality, and we have to deal with it." 
Dr. Erin Tracy, of Massachusetts General Hospital, chairwoman of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists Junior Fellow Advisory Council, said her group had become concerned about how few men were now choosing the specialty of caring for women. 
"At some medical schools, male medical students are being discouraged from going into ob-gyn," Dr. Tracy said. "It really is reverse discrimination. We don't want this to be a specialty just for women." 
Recently, a few men have begun to fight back, arguing in court and other forums that the preference for women constitutes sex discrimination. 
It is a novel legal argument: sex discrimination against male doctors, by male doctors, in a field where most practitioners are male. And it tests the limits of a longstanding tenet of employment law, namely, that customer preferences generally do not justify discrimination in hiring or employment. 
Most doctors and patients believe that women should be able to choose a female physician. How that plays out in hiring is complicated, especially for private practices competing for patients. Recruiters say there is strong demand for female doctors, both from all-women practice groups and from older male doctors hoping to attract new patients by adding a woman to their practice. 
"There's a lot of very fine male gynecologists out there, but many women find it easier to talk to another woman when the subject is sexuality or menopause or pregnancy," said Dr. Susan Klugman of the all-women Montefiore Larchmont Women's Center. "And it's perfectly understandable. Find me a lot of men who'll go to a female urologist for their yearly prostate exam." 
Given patient preferences, is it wrong for a practice with an opening to favor female applicants? 
"That's for the lawyers to work out," said Dr. Klugman. "All I know is that many of our patients tell us how glad they are to be able to see women, who know exactly what they're going through." 
Dr. Tracy rejects that approach to choosing a doctor. 
"It's unrealistic for women to say that their doctor has to have gone through labor to understand labor," she said. "They'd never expect their cancer doctor to have had cancer." 
It was precisely the desire to market to women's preferences for female doctors that led to his firing, Dr. Garfinkel contends, adding that the practice hired three female doctors and no men after him.
Dr. Garfinkel's case is now before the New Jersey Supreme Court on a procedural question. 
In similar cases over the last year, courts have rejected sex-bias claims by fired male ob-gyns. In a federal appeals ruling in Connecticut last August, and a federal district decision in New York in September, judges found that there were nondiscriminatory reasons for the firings. 
In the New York case, Dr. Mircea Veleanu argued, in part, that the Beth Israel Medical Center practice with which he had been associated, discriminated against him by accommodating female patients who had requested female doctors. 
In dismissing Dr. Veleanu's claims, the court cited past cases, involving wash-room attendants and male nurses, that recognized a justification for sex-based requirements in certain jobs.
"That a medical entity may seek to respond to some medical treatment requests of its female patients -- an expression of preference particular to the health care field -- does not, of itself, indicate that it discriminates against male doctors," Judge Victor Marrero of Federal District Court wrote in the decision. 
Many young male doctors are aware of the bias against them each time they see advertisements in professional journals saying "female ob-gyn group seeks associate," or "seeking board certified ob-gyn to join all-female private practice." 
"I've learned that they're not looking for me if the ad says they need an ob-gyn in an all-female practice," said Dr. Randy Fink, chief resident at Women and Infants Hospital in Providence, R.I. "I've sent C.V.'s, and haven't heard back. It does bother me. I don't see how it's different from an ad saying 'physician wanted to join all-Caucasian practice.' "
Dr. Fink said he was discouraged from becoming a gynecologist at every step of the process. 
"When I talked about choosing ob-gyn, people would say, 'You're never going to have a job,' or tell me that all their patients want to see a woman," he said, adding that the issue also arose again in his first residency interview. "There was a woman who sat down and said, 'What gives you the right to take care of women?' " 
Dr. Fink is about to join a two-woman practice in Florida. But, he said, the preference for women has quietly defined the job prospects of those he has trained with. 
"In the group of seven residents here, five of us have lined up jobs, and here's one woman who has not found a job because she hasn't looked, and one man who hasn't found a job because he wants Boston, and he's getting told there are no jobs," he said last month. "But the woman is getting calls from Boston practices several times a week. It's all market driven." 
Recruiters are keenly aware of the preference for female ob-gyns and of the need to walk a careful line in giving clients what they want without breaking the law.
"Some people who come to us will say that they're looking for a woman, but we remind them that we will send them all qualified candidates," said Julie Sherriff of Sherriff & Associates, a physician search firm in Kansas. "Sometimes, they do end up hiring a man even if that's not what they initially said they wanted. But females have an edge because once the word gets out that a female has joined a practice, within a month or two, max, their practice is full." 
Dr. Garfinkel's practice, meanwhile, has grown enough for him to hire another doctor -- a man. 
It is not lost on Dr. Garfinkel and others in the medical community that male doctors may be facing what women seeking work in male-dominated fields experienced not so long ago.
"I think it's similar to certain fields where women have to work harder to prove themselves," he said. "Men in this field have to be more sensitive." 
Given the long history of male control of female medicine, that may be a good thing. But every social change exacts a price.
"Whenever the topic of discrimination comes up, there are all these women to talk about how, when they were the only women, they had to fight and claw their way to the top, as if turning the tables makes it O.K.," Dr. Fink said. "But it doesn't."

HEADLINE: Despite Recovery Efforts, Sunbeam Filesfor Chapter 11 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS and JANE TANNER 

 BODY:
The Sunbeam Corporation filed yesterday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, the latest step in a nearly three-year effort to recover from an accounting scandal and a series of acquisitions that left it with $2.6 billion in debt.
 The filing came as little surprise to investors in Sunbeam's stock, which sold for 51 cents a share yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange suspended trading in it and began working to delist it. The stock traded for as much as $6 a share last March. 
 With just $15 million in cash as of Feb. 2, according to yesterday's filing in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, Sunbeam had little choice but to file for bankruptcy protection. "They were so dangerously leveraged, they had too much wind in their face to overcome," said Rommel Dionisio, an analyst with Friedman, Billings & Ramsey. "There was no breathing room, no margin for error." 
As part of the reorganization plan for the company, which makes Oster blenders, Coleman camping equipment and Sunbeam household appliances, banks that made a combined commitment to lend $1.7 billion have agreed to provide another $285 million to let Sunbeam stay in business. This arrangement, known as debtor-in-possession financing, gives the lenders first claim on a company's assets. Since Sunbeam is still losing money, banks are unlikely to lend more without this secured status, loan traders said.
Sunbeam's problems became apparent in 1998, when it was discovered that Albert J. Dunlap, a turnaround expert who was then the company's chief executive, had artificially bolstered sales by getting retailers to accept more goods than they could possibly sell.
At the same time, Sunbeam was struggling with a load of debt, including the $1.7 billion bank loan it had taken on earlier that year after making three acquisitions. The loan was made by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, the First Union Corporation and the Bank of America Corporation. After Sunbeam's accounting irregularities became known, the banks were unable to sell portions of the loan to other lenders, as is customary with syndicated loans.
Sunbeam's current chief executive, Jerry W. Levin, who replaced Mr. Dunlap, has struggled to revive profits, even as he has negotiated with lenders to cut the debt. Mr. Levin also had to cope with shareholder lawsuits and an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Last November, Sunbeam said that the federal agency expected to file charges against the company.
Before joining Sunbeam, Mr. Levin was a strategist for the financier Ronald O. Perelman, who owns 14.1 million shares, or about 14 percent, of Sunbeam. Mr. Perelman acquired the shares in February 1998, when Sunbeam bought the Coleman Company, which made camping gear, from his holding company, MacAndrews & Forbes. The sale closed just weeks before Sunbeam's accounting irregularities became apparent.
"Like every other stockholder, MacAndrews & Forbes was victimized by what happened at Sunbeam," a spokesman for Mr. Perelman said yesterday.
While Mr. Levin restored some stability to Sunbeam and repaired relationships with suppliers and discount retailers, the company's sales were still down 9.6 percent in the first nine months of 2000. The company blamed a weak economy.
Mr. Levin, who has been negotiating with the banks for several months to restructure the terms of their loan, said yesterday in an interview that the lenders would ultimately control Sunbeam. "The company will be owned 100 percent by the banks," he said.
Both Bank of America and First Union said in the third quarter of 2000 that they expected to write down the value of a large corporate loan before the end of the year. While neither bank would identify the borrower, it is widely believed to be Sunbeam.
A spokeswoman for First Union and a spokesman for Bank of America declined to comment on the bankruptcy filing. A spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley said only that "Sunbeam's filing was well anticipated, and we are comfortable with our asset mark."
Since First Union and Bank of America are believed to have marked down the value of their Sunbeam loans, traders of bank debt have been anticipating that the banks will look to sell off portions of the loan. In recent weeks, a $50 million piece of the loan changed hands, said several executives active in the loan market, who thought Bank of America was the seller. The price was thought to be around 50 cents on the dollar, they said.
Some traders say the banks will have a rough time salvaging much of their investment. Since the piece of the Bank of America loan was traded, the price offered for the debt has fallen even further, traders said. 
Mr. Levin, who has two years left on his contract, said he intended to see the reorganization through.
"We're committed to stay through the process," he said.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Bums and Rushes

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
"Hurry up!" say the Bush people. "We need tax cuts now! In fact, we need them yesterday!"
 No, seriously. The administration has declared not only that it wants to accelerate tax cuts, but that it wants to make the cuts retroactive to the beginning of this year. Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill has suggested that later this year he may be mailing out checks, refunding the "excess" taxes paid before those retroactive tax cuts actually become law. 
 Think of it as a bum's rush -- an attempt to run tax-cut skeptics out of town before they have a chance to make their case. But the attempt itself is a giveaway; it shows why the tax cut Mr. Bush proposes is not what the country needs.
Let's say right away -- in fact, let's make this observation retroactive to Jan. 1 -- that claims that tax cuts can be accelerated without reducing our soon-to-be-gone budget surplus are disingenuous. George W. Bush's economists have always tried to hold down the headline number on tax cuts by delaying the start of the big tax breaks. The $1.3 trillion number you heard about during the campaign, which has since grown to $1.6 trillion, depended on the assumption that many of the tax breaks would phase in only very slowly. Accelerate the phase-in, and the number becomes a lot bigger.
Furthermore, early tax cuts take a larger bite out of surplus projections. That $1.6 trillion cut is really $2 trillion off the surplus, because tax cuts reduce the rate at which the government pays off its debt and therefore raise its interest payments; the earlier the cut, the larger that effect. Each dollar of tax cuts this year will actually slash about $1.80 off the 10-year surplus.
The real story, however, is not the cost of this proposal but the way it undermines the whole rationale for tax cuts tilted toward the rich.
Conservatives used to be supply-siders -- they wanted tax cuts in order to increase the incentive to work hard, take risks and all that. But a retroactive tax cut, a cut in the taxes due on the income you have already earned, can't provide an incentive to earn more. Goodbye Reaganomics, hello crude demand-side Keynesianism. 
And if pumping up consumer demand is the rationale for tax cuts, why must they go mainly to the very, very affluent?
If incentives are the issue, what you want to do is reduce marginal tax rates, the rates taxpayers pay on any additional income they earn. And it's hard to reduce marginal rates without giving disproportionately large tax cuts to people with high incomes. That, say conservatives, is why their tax-cut proposals always provide such large benefits to the top 1 or 2 percent of the income distribution. It's all about incentives, they claim, and it just so happens that the biggest positive impact is on the lifestyles of the rich. 
But a retroactive tax cut, one that applies to income you've already earned, can't have any incentive effects; so why tilt it toward the top? If the purpose of a tax cut is simply to put more money into people's pockets, why not put it into the pockets of those who really need it? One simple proposal would be to make Mr. O'Neill's checks proportional not to income taxes but to Social Security and Medicare contributions; after all, four out of five families pay more in these payroll taxes than they do in income tax.
But Mr. Bush surely won't accept any such proposal, because the alleged need for economic stimulus is only an excuse. Senator Charles Grassley, chairman of the Finance Committee, was refreshingly frank: "If we do it earlier, I don't think we're really stimulating the economy. I think we're putting in place at an earlier time basic tax restructuring." In other words, all this talk about the need for fast tax cuts is an attempt to give skeptics the bum's rush, using panic over a short-term slowdown to hustle through long-run tax cuts that will do nothing to fight that slowdown.
It's a tactic Mr. Bush's people clearly like; they're doing the same thing on environmental policy, trying to use California's electricity crisis to hustle through a weakening of environmental protection in Alaska and elsewhere. It's up to the Democrats, and perhaps a few principled Republicans, to demonstrate that they aren't bums, and they won't be rushed. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH 

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Op-Ed

 BODY:
 EUROPE

FRANCE: KOUCHNER RESUMES POST
Bernard Kouchner, the outspoken former United Nations chief adminstrator in Kosovo, has gotten his old job back as France's health minister. Dr. Kouchner -- a physician who was co-founder of Doctors Without Borders -- had been health minister for two years when he left for Kosovo in July 1999, soon after NATO troops entered the Serbian province after the bombing campaign to end the oppression of ethnic Albanians. MIDDLE EAST

SYRIA: GREEN LIGHT FOR PRIVATE UNIVERSITIES
Syria approved the establishment of private universities, ending over half a century of socialist government monopoly over higher education. The decision came at a Baath Party meeting, led by President Bashar al-Assad, who has begun wide-ranging reforms since succeeding his late father Hafez al-Assad last year as Syria's ruler. (Reuters)

THE AMERICAS

HAITI: U.N. SHUTS OFFICE
The United Nations closed its police training and human rights mission as its mandate expired. Secretary General Kofi Annan said last fall that the mission would not be extended, citing a lack of funds and a "political turmoil." (Agence France-Presse)

CUBA: JAILED CZECHS FREED
Two prominent Czechs jailed for more than three weeks headed home after they admitted breaking Cuban law. A Czech lawmaker, Ivan Pilip, and Jan Bubenik were arrested Jan. 12 after meeting with Cuban dissidents. They were released Monday night after drawing up an admission signed before diplomats from several nations. (AP)

MEXICO: GAINS FOR ENVIRONMENTALISTS
President Vicente Fox said the government would review the cases of two jailed enviromentalists to see if "injustice has been committed." The national human rights commission has said the prisoners, Rodolfo Montiel and Teodoro Cabrera, who had fought illegal logging in the state of Guerrero, may have been framed. Meanwhile, Mr. Montiel received a award from the Sierra Club, which cited his "extraordinary courage." Tim Weiner (NYT)

MEXICO: U.S. TO PAY PARALYZED MEXICAN
The United States Drug Enforcement Administration will pay $1.75 million in damages to a Mexican migrant shot and paralyzed by one of its agents, Mexico's foreign ministry said. Two years ago, the agent, Wilburt Honeycutt, shot Abecnego Monje Ortiz, then 18, as he tried to cross into Texas. Mr. Honeycutt is serving a 15-year prison term for aggravated assault. Tim Weiner (NYT)

AFRICA

ETHIOPIA, ERITREA: PEACE MOVE
Ethiopia and Eritrea agreed to a temporary buffer zone between them, removing a roadblock to the peace effort begun in December after a cease-fire ended their two-year border war, the United Nations said. The December agreement required Ethiopia to pull back its troops to positions it held before the war broke out in 1998 and Eritrea to withdraw to 15 miles from Ethiopian positions, but the moves were delayed by disputes over what territory the countries controlled before the conflict. (Reuters)

ASIA

JAPAN: E-MAIL FUROR
The commander of United States forces on the island of Okinawa aplogized for calling local officials "nuts" and "wimps" in e-mail sent to 13 fellow officers that was leaked to Japanese media. Lt. Gen. Earl Hailston was reportedly responding to a call by Okinawa's local assembly for a reduction in American troops. The assembly acted after the arrest in January of a Marine corporal for lifting a girl's skirt to photograph her underwear. (Reuters)

CHINA: CALLING ON WASHINGTON
China's top foreign policy official, Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen, plans to visit Washington next month for what are expected to be Beijing's first high-level exchanges with the new Bush administration. Mr. Qian is likely to press the United States to maintain a "one China" policy and to hold down arms deliveries to Taiwan. In October, President Bush is to make his first official visit to China for an Asia-Pacific economic meeting. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

SINGAPORE: LIMITS OF FREE SPEECH
The head of a local civil rights group, Jim Gomez, said he had been summoned by the police over a rally he had organized on Dec. 10 to mark International Human Rights Day. It was the second summons of a member of his group for activities held at "Speakers' Corner," an open-air venue inaugurated last year to experiment with the idea of free public speaking in Singapore. Seth Mydans (NYT)

INDIA: TOBACCO RESTRICTIONS
Parliamentary Affairs minister Pramod Mahajan said the government will introduce legislation this month to ban the sale of tobacco products to anyone under age 18, fine people for smoking in public spaces and end the sponsorship of cultural and sporting events by tobacco companies. He said treatment of tobacco-related ailments costs India almost $3 billion a year. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Celebrating the Birthday And Legacy of Reagan

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
It sometimes seems as if he never left.
 On the 90th birthday of Ronald Wilson Reagan, the capital he departed a dozen years ago is awash in debate over policies at the center of his presidency, from tax cuts to a missile defense shield, from free trade to the privatization of Social Security. 
 Mr. Reagan, his memories of Washington dimmed if not destroyed by Alzheimer's disease, was reported to have spent his birthday quietly at his home in Los Angeles, where he is recovering from a broken hip he suffered last month. "He's not in pain," Nancy Reagan said in an interview broadcast today on CNN. "He heals very quickly." 
But on the opposite side of the continent, in the city that was both home to the movement known as the Reagan Revolution and to the government bureaucracy it sought to dismantle, memories of the 40th president were as vivid today as ever.
Among the army of Reagan supporters and the legions of his critics who still populate Washington, there was agreement that ideas championed by the movie-star-turned-governor-turned-president still dominate the political landscape, especially with Republicans in control of both the White House and the Congress.
"Very few things that were said during the last campaign by George W. Bush could not have been said by Ronald Reagan," said Martin Anderson, who was Mr. Reagan's domestic and economic policy adviser in 1981 and 1982 and was a campaign adviser to Mr. Bush.
"If you look at rebuilding the military or missile defense -- that's Reagan," he said. "If you look at Social Security and using some of the tax payments to invest in the private market -- that's Reagan. If you look at educational vouchers -- that's Reagan. If you look at tax policy and cutting marginal tax rates -- that's Reagan."
Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, Mr. Reagan's United Nations delegate and now a professor of government at Georgetown University, said Mr. Reagan -- along with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Boris N. Yeltsin -- deserved credit for ending the cold war. She rejected the argument often made by Democrats that the collapse of the Soviet Union had been inevitable, and that Mr. Reagan simply accelerated the process.
"I don't imagine that Ronald Reagan singlehandedly ended the cold war, no such thing, but I think his contributions were absolutely critical," she said, singling out his deployment of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe and his advocacy of an antimissile shield.
Another politician who arrived in Washington along with Mr. Reagan in January 1981, Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the former president's legacy was found not in the long economic boom of recent years or the end of the cold war, but in the nation's continuing struggle with urban poverty, homelessness and AIDS.
"He got the government out of the business of helping people with housing, and today we have an exacerbated housing crisis because of it" Mr. Frank said. "He was terrible on race, he was terrible on gay issues, he ignored AIDS. He may personally have been a very nice man, but the policies -- to the extent that they had an effect -- were disastrous for vulnerable people."
And like many prominent economists, Mr. Frank said the Reagan legacy would forever be tarnished by the government deficits he piled up as a result of his tax cuts and military buildup. The total federal debt owed to the public rose during the eight years of his presidency from $712 billion to more than $2 trillion -- debt that is still being paid off. 
Mr. Frank was not invited to tonight's birthday celebration in Washington, which was being held at the gargantuan federal building along Pennsylvania Avenue named for Mr. Reagan.
The Reagan Alumni Association, a group of nearly 5,000 dues-paying veterans of the Reagan administration and his presidential campaigns, sponsors the event every year, and the $90-a-ticket, 90th birthday party was expected to be the biggest yet.
The guest list included newly appointed senior officials of the Bush administration, many of whom came to Washington 20 years ago because of Mr. Reagan. Some admitted they can sound a bit like cult members when they discuss the former president. More than a few have named children after him.
Grover Norquist, a conservative activist who helped lead the successful campaign to rename Washington National airport for Mr. Reagan, will probably recruit at the party for his next crusade: replacing Alexander Hamilton with Mr. Reagan on the $10 bill. "Hamilton was a great American, but it's time to move on," Mr. Norquist said.
Reagan Dunn, who recently arrived here from his native Washington State to take a job as a lawyer-adviser in the public affairs office of the Justice Department, is the 29-year-old son of Representative Jennifer Dunn, a Washington Republican and Reagan supporter from the early days of his political career.
Mr. Dunn was given the name to honor Mr. Reagan when he was still governor of California. "I wear it with great pride," Mr. Dunn said, adding that he saw many similarities between his namesake and the newest occupant of the White House. "George Bush has the same quality of integrity," he said.
President Bush -- the son of Mr. Reagan's vice president and a man often compared to Mr. Reagan because of their shared policy goals, folksy disposition and occasional difficulty with extemporaneous speech -- said in a statement that Mr. Reagan "changed the world."
"You came to the White House when the cold war was real," Mr. Bush said, reading the statement on CNN. "You came here at a time when our country needed confidence. You told us we could be strong again, at home and abroad. And when you left, we were."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elementary school students celebrated the 90th birthday of former President Ronald Reagan yesterday at his museum in Simi Valley, Calif. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Bush to Open Country to Mexican Truckers 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Bush administration indicated yesterday that it would reverse a Clinton administration policy and begin allowing Mexican trucks to haul goods throughout the United States, notwithstanding concerns about the trucks' safety problems.
 Administration officials disclosed the plan on the same day that a dispute-resolution panel ruled that the United States was violating the North American Free Trade Agreement by not already allowing Mexican trucks to enter. 
 "The president has said that Nafta trucking provisions should be implemented, and we intend to do that," said Clair Buchan, a White House spokeswoman.
The proposed change, long sought by Mexico, comes just 10 days before Mr. Bush travels to Mexico. 
The president has not decided on the exact timing of the move, administration officials said, noting that it remained unclear whether he would agree to a limited opening of the border or a broad one.
The plan is expected to generate protests. Union officials voice fears that Mexican truckers, who often earn one-fourth as much as unionized American truckers, will take American jobs. And consumer groups, noting that 41 percent of Mexican trucks failed American inspections at the border, argue that the trucks will endanger Americans.
Bret Caldwell, a spokesman for the Teamsters union, said, "We will continue to fight the opening of the border until the Mexican government can guarantee their standards are higher and the U.S. can guarantee that we have the inspection facilities to keep unsafe trucks out."
The administration's move surprised some union leaders, because Mr. Bush has courted the Teamsters more than any other union.
Under Nafta, the United States was supposed to give broad access to Mexican trucks in 1995, but President Bill Clinton, under heavy pressure from his union allies, kept the provision from taking effect, saying Mexico had to do more to address safety problems first.
That year, the Mexican government, invoking Nafta's provisions, asked that a five-member panel be set up to determine whether Washington was violating the accord.
In its decision, the panel -- two Americans, two Mexicans and a British chairman -- unanimously ruled that the United States would be in violation if it did not begin considering applications from Mexican trucking companies. More than 160 applications are pending.
"The decision says the Department of Transportation must consider applications on individual merit and may not refuse authority across the board to all Mexican companies," said an American trade official who had read the decision, which is to be released today. 
The official said the panel made clear that the United States was entitled under Nafta to set its own safety standards and to ensure that Mexican trucking companies meet them.
"As we move forward, the United States will not compromise highway safety in any way," the official said.
Currently, Mexican truckers can drive up to 25 miles north of the border. Then they normally transfer their loads to American trucks. Each year, about five million commercial trucks cross the border, hauling about three-fourths of the $250 billion in United States-Mexico trade. 
Mexican officials say opening the border will save American consumers millions of dollars by lowering transportation costs. 
"The cost has been lost business opportunities for Mexican trucking companies," said Luis de la Calle, under secretary in Mexico's Economy Ministry. "The system we have today is archaic. To change tractors at the border creates lines, which means more lost time and greater costs of doing business."
A 1996 letter that Mr. Bush, then Texas' governor, signed with the governors of Arizona, California and New Mexico, said, "This transborder trucking delay robs the entire U.S.-Mexico border region of the full economic benefits that Nafta promises."
Under Nafta rules, the United States could continue to keep the trucks out, but then it would have to compensate Mexico by, for example, agreeing to let it impose punitive tariffs on some American goods.
Critics warned that opening the border could backfire politically for Mr. Bush if Mexican truckers caused accidents that killed Americans.
"It is imperative that we continue to limit access for these dangerous trucks even if it means paying trade sanctions," said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a consumer safety group. "It is impossible to inspect every truck, and we cannot knowingly put drivers at risk by inviting dangerous rigs onto U.S. highways."

HEADLINE: Liberties; 
Taxing My Patience

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
At first, I had separation anxiety.
 I missed all the chaos and intrigue, the lies and cover-ups and sweet talk and reconciliations and razzmatazz. 
 I stalked my ex. I couldn't help myself.
I drove up to Chappaqua and stood around for hours in the cold and slush of Bill's driveway. I bought a box of Pepperidge Farm Double Chocolate Chunk cookies at his favorite deli, hoping the aroma would lure him out of the house. 
Bill still had trouble written all over him. I still wanted to cover a guy who had trouble written all over him.
I wasn't ready for Junior. I wasn't looking forward to a lot of towel-snapping bonhomie, punctuality and discipline from the West Wing, and peace and quiet from the East Wing.
The future was looking depressingly like the past. Washington smells of mothballs -- a tax cut, recession fears, a Star Wars shield, energy woes, abortion curbs, Christian right-eousness, a rumor of war in the Middle East, the trio of Bush, Powell and Cheney saber-rattling at Saddam.
In this week of birthday homages to the Gipper, W. even resumed a Reaganesque theme-of-the-week to hawk a Reaganesque tax cut.
As Bill flew off to the Boca sunshine, I slunk back to rainy D.C. to face the music.
W. was busy peddling his tax cut with a lot of photo ops featuring working-class families.
To hear the Bush rhetoric, the tax cut was all about helping poor single waitress moms, grannies who can't pay their heating bills, lower-middle-class families that are maxing out credit cards for their kids' medical bills, and small businesses owned by women.
On Monday, President Bush made like the host of a game show and displayed a big blown-up check made out to "U.S. Taxpayer" for $1,600, the average benefit that he says the average family with two children would receive. He introduced three average families that would get anywhere from $1,055 to $3,266 in savings from his plan.
On Tuesday Mr. Bush went to McLean, Va., to visit an adorable store, Tree Top Toys and Books, and make the pitch that his tax plan would create capital so that other adorable businesses like this one, and trail-blazing female entrepreneurs like its owner, could thrive.
Today the president planned to have a reunion with the "tax families," as the families used as props on airport tarmacs during his campaign were called. At the White House he will be welcoming Tammy, a waitress at the Pit Stop Emporium; Ken, a repairman at Bennett's Garage; Joseph, a manager at Aldi Foods; Denise, a stay-at-home mom; and Michael, a driver for U.P.S.
I seem to recall President Bush vowing to restore integrity and honesty to Washington. Then shouldn't his photo ops this week have been a whole lot different?
On Monday he could have gathered Jack Welch, Bill Gates and Kenneth Lay, the chairman of Enron Energy Corporation, one of W.'s biggest corporate contributors. 
The president could have brandished a blown-up check made out to "U.S. Fatcats" for $160,000 and come clean about who will make out like bandits, courtesy of his bill: not the blue-collar crowd but the golden-parachute crowd, that elite 1 percentile that will get 40 percent of the cut.
Dick Cheney, lately of Halliburton, and Paul O'Neill, lately of Alcoa, could have been on hand to share inside tips about tax shelters, trust funds and stock option packages to defer income.
All the moguls' progeny could have smiled for the camera, since, if the Bush tax cut passes, they won't have to pay any of those niggling inheritance taxes on their parents' estates.
On Tuesday, instead of going to a toy store the president would have headed to the nearest Lexus dealership to show the sort of toys the wealthiest Americans could buy with their humongous tax cuts.
Today, instead of a reunion of his tax families, he could have gathered the fur-clad and Gulfstream-riding Pioneers, the rich Republicans who pumped $90 million, the biggest fundraising haul in history, into W.'s campaign, hoping for a tax windfall.
Lastly, in the spirit of bipartisanship, W. could have ushered out to the cameras a new millionaire who could use a good tax cut now that he's raking in $100,000 a pop for his speeches: my ex.
