HEADLINE: Cisco Results Come In Short Of Forecast 

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
Raising fears of a deepening economic slowdown in the United States, the Silicon Valley bellwether Cisco Systems Inc. fell short of Wall Street's already lowered expectations today, reporting revenue of $6.75 billion for the second quarter of its 2001 fiscal year.
 Wall Street analysts had expected Cisco to earn 19 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial, but the company reported earnings today of 18 cents a share. That was still a 50 percent increase over the 12 cents a share reported in the second quarter of 2000. 
 Cisco, which has had 44 consecutive quarters of revenue growth, shocked the financial analysts that follow the company by saying today that it expected revenue to decline in the next quarter by as much as 5 percent. 
"I've followed the company since it went public, and I've never seen a down sequential revenue quarter," said Paul Johnson, a financial analyst at Robertson Stephens. "That took me by surprise."
Cisco's revenue rose 55 percent, up from $4.36 billion in the quarter a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, including research and development costs and amortization of goodwill and other acquisition-related charges, net income rose to $1.33 billion, an increase of 48 percent from $897 million a year ago.
It was the first time in three and a half years that the company had failed to meet or exceed earnings expectations. But Cisco executives, who have repeatedly told Wall Street that the company plans to grow by 30 percent to 50 percent a year, took pains to point to slowing purchases by American telecommunications service providers and manufacturing companies as the reason for Cisco's pessimistic forecast.
"While we were pleased with certain areas of our business," said John Chambers, Cisco's chief executive and chairman, "this quarter was even more challenging than we anticipated in light of the abrupt economic slowdown in the United States."
Mr. Chambers said the company responded to the downturn, which it saw in the beginning of December, by slowing its hiring and discretionary spending.
International financial markets had been awaiting Cisco's results, looking to the Internet infrastructure maker and its forecast for the rest of 2001 as an indicator of the direction of the economy.
The company, which has been widely viewed as a barometer of the strength or weakness of the Internet economy, finished regular trading at $35.75, up $1.19, on the Nasdaq market. In after-hours trading, Cisco fell to $34.38.
"The numbers are worse than we had expected, that's clearly a cause for concern," said Michael Ching, a financial analyst at Merrill Lynch. "We are going to need to recalibrate for the April quarter on this lower base." 
Other analysts wondered whether Cisco was seeing competitive pressures that it was not completely acknowledging. "If their competitors nail their numbers this quarter, then it will be an indication that leadership in the market has shifted," Mr. Johnson of Robertson Stephens said.
During a conference call with financial analysts this afternoon, Mr. Chambers said that although the next several quarters would be challenging, he expected the downturn to be a short one. 
He said he thought it would be limited to one or two quarters pending the actions of the Federal Reserve Bank and the quick passage of a tax cuts in Washington.
"The uncertainty on capital spending," Mr. Chambers said, "is leading us to widen the range of our projections."
He repeatedly pointed to the slowing purchases of new equipment by what he referred to as the "alternative" telecommunications service providers -- those companies that compete with the major telecommunications companies. Cisco has also seen slowing in some portions of the corporate market, particularly in the manufacturing sector, which Mr. Chambers said was for practical purposes already in a recession.
Cisco said that it expected its growth would be flat or would decline 5 percent in its third quarter and that growth would be flat in the fourth quarter. But it still expected total revenue growth for the year to reach 40 percent. Cisco also said that it expected gross margins to decline to 60 percent from about 63 percent and that it would add 1,500 to 2,000 workers in the next quarter based on job offers that have already been made. The company employs more than 40,000 workers worldwide.
Despite concerns about the American market, Mr. Chambers said Cisco was having robust growth in almost all the other areas of the world. He said that he had visited or spoken with 75 percent of the chief executives of the world's largest 500 companies and that they generally had expressed confidence in their spending expectations.
He also noted that he was pleased with the progress Cisco has made in China, where it has revenue of about $1 billion a year.
"We got a very strong endorsement from the president of China, which is very unusual," Mr. Chambers said. China is one of the most stable economies in Asia, he said, and with a growth rate expected to be 5 percent to 8 percent, China could become Cisco's second-largest market in the next three to five years.
During the conference call this afternoon, Cisco executives suggested that trends in the marketplace were favorable to the company, which supplies corporations with the basic equipment for high-speed data traffic. In particular, the company said, corporate buyers were leaning toward large suppliers who could create so-called "end to end" equipment systems.
The company said that it was beginning to see growth in the market for Internet telephony, where routing gear is used to carry voice telephone conversations.
Executives of Cisco pointed to several examples of large purchases of such equipment: a New Zealand government agency that had purchased 8,000 of the new Internet telephone handsets and associated switching gear and the Dow Chemical Company, which has purchased 40,000 phones.
Mr. Chambers said Cisco was now selling 2,000 Internet voice phones a day.

HEADLINE: Bush Urges Airlines to Reach Labor Pacts 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
President Bush urged the nation's four largest airlines and their workers today to avoid strikes this spring and said he would "explore all options" if they were unable to settle their differences.
 "I am worried about strikes at airlines," Mr. 
Bush said. "It could have a harmful effect on our economy." 
 In the next few months, Delta is expected to reach agreement with its pilots, American with its flight attendants and United and Northwest with their mechanics. The airlines carry more than two-thirds of the 588 million domestic passengers traveling on United States airlines annually.
The prospect of disruptions in spring break travel and summer vacations has attracted the attention of the White House, which last week began conferring with the National Mediation Board, the government agency that oversees labor relations in the airline and railroad industries, The Washington Post reported today.
The first potential strike could come as early as next month if an agreement is not reached between Northwest Airlines and the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association.

HEADLINE: Pardoned Fugitive Said to Be in Talks on Russian Deal 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 6 

 BODY:
In what appears to be the culmination of a long history of business dealings in Russia, Marc Rich, the billionaire fugitive pardoned by President Bill Clinton before he left office, may sell his global commodity trading empire to a Russian group. 
 Marc Rich & Company Investment, which has offices in England and Switzerland, is in talks with Crown Trade and Finance, owned by the Alfa Group of Russia, to sell all or part of the trading company, people close to the talks said. 
 It is not yet clear how likely it is that the talks, which began late last year, will lead to a sale. Mr. Rich held negotiations with other buyers last year that came to nothing, these people said. But people who have met recently with Mr. Rich, who is 66, say that there is some urgency to the talks because he appears to be in poor health and wants to retire. 
The rises and falls of Mr. Rich's business dealings in Russia trace the evolution both of the global commodities trading business he helped create, and of the market economy in Russia, where he was the dominant player in the early 1990's.
Mr. Rich fled the United States in 1983 when federal prosecutors accused him of tax fraud and other illegal dealings, and now lives in Switzerland. The government said he and his partners exploited government price controls in the wake of the 1973 oil shock through a complex series of transactions that allowed him to reap excess trading profits and illegally move them offshore to avoid taxation. 
He later used a similar approach even more profitably in Russia in the early 1990's as the Soviet Union was collapsing. In the turmoil of the times, traders like Mr. Rich were able to buy oil at prices that were sometimes less than 1 percent of the prevailing world price, and then export it. Though officials who helped him may have acted improperly, it is not clear whether Mr. Rich's dealings themselves ever broke Russian law. 
"Russia was a Klondike for Mr. Rich," said Vladimir Lopukhin, who served briefly as Minister of Fuel and Energy in 1991 and 1992. "It was a time of complete confusion. There were so many administrative controls, and there were just as many special privileges. He felt like a fish in water here."
Opportunities abounded. Joint ventures with foreign companies gave Russian refineries special tax breaks and the right to export in unlimited quantities and ignore export quotas. Mr. Rich had at least four such joint ventures. 
Early economic changes in Russia gave directors freedom to conclude contracts, but did not give them an ownership stake in the companies or much accountability for their assets. That created strong incentives to siphon off assets and profits that theoretically belonged to the state. Traders like Mr. Rich, who had access to foreign capital and markets, eased the process, which continued until Russia began to sell its oil and gas companies to private investors in 1995. 
"Can I say that what he was doing was illegal? No," Mr. Lopukhin said. "He was always walking the fault line between legal and breaking the law." 
Russia, just after the fall of the Soviet Union, was a trader's paradise, especially for people like Mr. Rich and his partners, who had the experience to profit from the chaotic atmosphere and the ever-shifting legal climate. Former employees of the Rich firm describe unlimited expense accounts, extravagant spending and lavish coddling of the directors of Russian client companies. Flying a client company's director to London with a credit card, or treating him to a new set of teeth, could seal a deal; personal relationships meant everything, and prices meant little. 
At its peak, Mr. Rich's company occupied two floors in Moscow's high-rise international trade center. But in 1994, Mr. Rich was bought out by his partners, who renamed the venture Glencore International, and now occupy that space. Mr. Rich later founded a new company and opened a new office in Moscow in 1996, though he was never able to return to the old scale of operations. He had lost most of his crucial employees, and appeared to have had little success in choosing new ones. This second trading company is the one he is negotiating to sell.
And Russia's economy had changed in the meantime. Russian company owners had learned how to secure international financing on their own and sell to foreign buyers through their own trading companies. Gradually, the exporting business became more transparent, and oil companies have even begun holding auctions to choose the trader with the best price, an unheard-of practice five years ago.
Traders like Mr. Rich have also lost ground globally because so many more market participants have access to instant information through the Internet, leaving fewer opportunities for middlemen to profit.

HEADLINE: Disney Posts First-Quarter Drop in Net 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said yesterday that net income fell in its fiscal first quarter but operating income rose as profits from hit films and theme parks more than offset soft advertising revenue at its ABC and cable television networks and weaker sales at Disney stores.
 Over all, Disney reported net income of $63 million or 3 cents a share, in the quarter, which ended Dec. 31. That is down from $356 million for the quarter a year earleir; revenue rose 7 percent, to $7.3 billion. 
 The drop in net income was primarily attributable to a $253 million loss related to its 72 percent interest in the Internet Group, compared with a $161 million loss for the prior quarter. The company also suffered from a $228 million noncash accounting charge related to film advertising and $50 million charge related to derivative accounting. After stripping out those one-time costs, operating income rose 6 percent, to $1.3 billion.
Some analysts use operating income before Internet expenses and one-time charges to evaluate the health of the operating businesses. Disney's earnings per share before those costs were roughly 28 cents, beating a number of analysts' expectations. Still, at least two analysts said that softness in the ad market was already factored into the stock.
Several analysts said that much would depend on how the economy affected advertising spending in subsequent quarters. Disney's chief financial officer, Thomas Staggs, said the company anticipated single-digit growth in earnings per share for 2001; beyond that, he said that earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization would grow 13 percent to 15 percent, starting in 2002.
Because the consensus among analysts has been that Disney will earn 99 cents a share this year -- 10 percent more than last year -- a single-digit rise would lead them to reduce earnings estimates, one analyst said yesterday.
Operating income at the media networks, which accounted for 45 percent of Disney's operating income, fell 8 percent, to $590 million, the company said. The decline was a result of a soft first-quarter advertising market, lower ratings and higher programming costs. 
Shares of Disney rose $1.18, to $31.61.
Disney had warned investors that it faced problems at its Disney stores and said in its earnings statement that income at the consumer products division fell 13 percent, to $177 million. The declines at the Disney stores stemmed from lower comparative-store sales and decreased margins as a result of product markdowns because of a weak holiday market. Profits at the parks and resorts division rose 6 percent, to $385 million, as attendance reached new highs at attractions like Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla.
The company noted that the division's profits were crimped by increased spending at Disney's California Adventure, which is scheduled to open Thursday. The new park, adjacent to Disneyland, is intended in part to lure visitors for longer visits to the California theme park.

HEADLINE: Wachovia Bank Weighs Sale Of Its CreditCard Business 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
The Wachovia Corporation said yesterday that it might join a growing list of banks getting out of the credit card business, rather than compete with companies spending heavily to woo fickle consumers with promotions.
 With about $8 billion in receivables, Wachovia ranks as the 12th-largest issuer of bank credit cards, according to The Nilson Report, a publication in Oxnard, Calif., that tracks the credit card industry. 
 Wachovia, which has headquarters in Atlanta and Winston-Salem, N.C., said yesterday that it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to evaluate "strategic alternatives" for its credit card business, including keeping it, selling it or forming a joint venture. 
Stock analysts said yesterday that they expected Wachovia to sell the operation. Richard Bove, an analyst at Raymond James & Associates, estimated that a sale could bring $8.6 billion. Mr. Bove upgraded the bank's stock to a "buy" yesterday.
Wachovia's shares, which have rallied 14 percent this year in part because of the Federal Reserve's decision to lower interest rates, fell 55 cents a share yesterday, to $66.15, amid a poor performance for bank stocks over all.
Credit cards accounted for 15 percent of the bank company's net income of $832 million last year.
With the credit card industry growing more competitive, Wachovia faced the possibility of falling behind unless it was willing to spend heavily on acquisitions and marketing. 
"We've been able to achieve 10 to 12 percent growth in receivables, but what we were forecasting going forward was in the single digits," said Beverly Wells, manager of retail financial services at Wachovia. "The amount of money it is taking to acquire and retain customers is getting higher, and that was threatening to erode the profitability of the business."
A number of banks and other card issuers have been exiting the business. Last year, $18 billion in Visa and MasterCard receivables were sold, with Citigroup and the MBNA Corporation acquiring 80 percent of the amount, according to Nilson. 
Ms. Wells declined to say yesterday what Wachovia would do with the proceeds of any sale. But Ruchi Madan, a stock analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said the banking company could buy back stock or bolster reserves against potential loan losses.
In a research report published last week, Ms. Madan ranked Wachovia's adjusted reserves toward the bottom of the 30 largest banks in the United States. If, as she predicts, the bank applies some $200 million in proceeds from the credit card sale to its reserves, "Wachovia would fall smack in the middle of the pack."
A higher level of reserves would help Wachovia deal with a portfolio that included loans to several troubled companies facing asbestos litigation. Wachovia has made loans to Federal-Mogul, W. R. Grace, Owens-Illinois, Armstrong World Industries and Owens Corning, according to research by Lori Appelbaum, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Company.

HEADLINE: Machines Let Resorts Please Skiers When Nature Won't 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY SELINGO 

 BODY:
IN the past, when dry weather lingered in the Northeast in mid-February, that would have meant the cancellation of many a ski trip. But later this month, even if there is no hint of snow in the forecast, thousands of skiers will make their way to mountain resorts, comforted by ski reports on the radio announcing that all the trails are open. 
 They have snow-making to thank. 
 Mild winters with little snow once meant financial disaster for the ski industry. But in the past 30 years, the widespread use of snow-making equipment has provided so much stability to a ski resort's season that even traditionalists in the Swiss Alps and British Columbia have decided to install it. 
While natural snow is preferable for most resort owners, Mother Nature doesn't provide enough of it in many parts of the world for resorts to open early in the season and survive to early spring. "It used to be that the ski industry was satisfied with the economic performance of natural snow," said Curt Bender, a professor of ski area operations at Colorado Mountain College in Leadville, Colo. "But staying open 70 days a season is no longer acceptable. Nowadays, skiing is more of a business, and resorts are required to have that guarantee that they'll perform." 
Fake snow has become so popular among some resort owners that they sometimes look at nature as getting in the way, especially when it keeps skiers from getting to the mountain. "There's no question that a few inches of snow in Boston is a huge shot in the arm for resorts in Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont," said Skip King, a vice president at American Skiing Company, the largest operator of ski resorts in the country. "But it's less critical than it once was. People know we can make snow."
Still, making snow is not cheap. It is typically the second-largest cost, after labor, for resorts. New systems can cost upward of $40,000 per acre to install and $1,700 per hour to operate. 
The earliest snow-making machines used leftovers from household plumbing supplies and irrigation equipment. Although the technology has improved, the basic concept of snow-making has remained the same. Making artificial snow mimics what happens in nature, but the snow is produced much more quickly: In one method, water is pumped to a snow gun, where compressed air blows the stream of water into tiny particles that are then shot out into the air, where they crystallize and fall to the ground as snow. 
Walter R. Schoenknecht, owner of Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall, Conn., was one of the first to turn to technology to make an end run around nature in the winter of 1949-50. With no natural snow in early January, Mr. Schoenknecht trucked in blocks of ice, broke it up with an ice-crusher and spread the chips over one slope. "We spent about $3,500, used nearly 500 tons of ice, but the important thing was that there was good skiing, and that the skiers were happy," he wrote in The American Ski Annual and Skiing Journal a year later. 
Machine-made snow was first mass-produced by three engineers -- Art Hunt, Dave Richey and Wayne Pierce -- on March 14, 1950, in Milford, Conn. Using a garden hose, a 10-horsepower compressor and a spray-gun nozzle, they produced about 20 inches of snow. They later patented their invention. 
"The first attempts in snow-making were oddball solutions to a lack of snow," said Jeffrey R. Leich, executive director of the New England Ski Museum in Franconia, N.H. Despite those early efforts, the widespread installation of snow-making machines did not start until the 1970's, he added. 
"For the most part, there was enough snow," Mr. Leich said, "and it wasn't seen as a competitive advantage to have snow-making machines. Now, it's unthinkable that you operate without snow-making." 
But there are more than financial costs to snow-making. In some states, environmental advocates have complained about power consumption and the reduction of water levels in lakes and rivers. A few state environmental agencies have required ski resorts to build large holding ponds to furnish water during parts of the season when natural water levels are low. 
Making snow is not as simple as running water through a hose. A lot depends on the weather, and it is not the temperature on your outside thermometer -- known as the dry bulb temperature -- that is important. What snow-making operators look at is the wet-bulb temperature, which is adjusted for humidity. 
When the humidity is high, water may not freeze even at temperatures lower than 32 degrees. And when the air is extremely dry, water can freeze even at temperatures higher than 32 degrees. So low air temperatures and low humidity are the optimal conditions for making snow. But the weather can change from one place on the mountain to the next. Until recently, when computers became better able to monitor and adjust snow-making machines, changes in temperature and humidity caused extra-wet or extra-fluffy snow to stream from the machines. Such problems gave machine-made snow a bad name, said Mr. King.
Today, ski resort operators like to say that there is virtually no difference between artificial and real snow -- and that machine-made snow is better in some cases. But experienced skiers say they can still tell the difference. 
"What man cannot create," said Craig Bury, of Washington, who has been skiing for 41 years, "is the champagne of snow for the advanced or expert skier, and that is light, dry, big, fluffy flakes."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Just Add Air and Water"Machine-made snow is just like the real thing -- it just costs more. There are two types of snow-making machines, air guns that use compressed air to break a stream of water into droplets, and fan guns that rely on a high-powered fan for most of the air supply. Air guns require that water and air lines be run along ski slopes, and use large (and costly) compressors and pumps. Fan guns require only water lines, but the guns themselves are more costly -- about $50,000 for a top of the line model. Here's a look at how a fan gun works. THE WEATHERAir temperature and humidity are critical factors in snowmaking. Generally, the lower the temperature and the drier the air, the more snow can be made. A top-of-the-line fan gun can use up to 10,000 gallons of water an hour in optimal conditions. MANIFOLD AND REGULATORControls the water pressure and nozzle rings, opening more or fewer rings depending upon weather conditions. NOZZLESA ring of atomizer nozzles produces a mist of very fine water droplets, using air supplied by the small compressor at the base of the gun. Larger droplets from the other nozzle rings freeze onto these smaller droplets, forming snow. CONTROL PANELFor adjusting snow quality and amount and coverage area. The gun can also be controlled wirelessly from a central computer using software that constantly adjusts for changing weather conditions. COVERING A SLOPEBarrel can rotate completely and tilt upward. Generally the longer and higher the throw the better, as it allows more time for snowflakes to form. MAKING SNOWSnowflakes start with nuclei, a particle or extremely fine droplet on which other droplets can freeze. But flake formation is affected by humidity -- droplets won't freeze as fast, or may not freeze at all, in very humid air. Snow gun produces atomized water droplets. Other droplets freeze around these nuclei. Cold, dry air, and a long throw, make for bigger flakes. Drawings (Frank O'Connell/The New York Times)(Source: Lenko)

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
Sharecroppers' Promised Land

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
A jaunty newsreel from the 1940's describes a mechanical "robot" that could pick as much cotton in an hour as a family could pick in a day. The commentator suggests, enthusiastically, that perhaps sharecropper families could move to Chicago and work for International Harvester, the manufacturer whose invention had destroyed their livelihood. The farm family staring grimly at the camera does not seem to find the prospects ahead quite so cheerful.
 The newsreel appears in "Goin' to Chicago," a documentary tonight on PBS that tells the story of more than five million Southern blacks who headed North between 1940 and 1970. That was the second wave of migration. The first wave took place from 1915 to 1925 and was motivated by racial segregation, vote deprivation, terrible poverty and crop-destroying boll weevils. The catalyst for the second was the automatic cotton picker. It virtually nullified the sharecropper system that kept the descendants of slaves in a state of semislavery -- though it also deprived them of a living. 
 For many, relocation would prove fruitful and then frustrating. The industries that offered opportunity for a time would eventually move to where labor was cheap -- paradoxically, often to the South. The ensuing poverty and unemployment seemed a double blow, because African-Americans had looked to the North as a hopeful destination. Now grandchildren of those migrants speak wistfully of the place their families came from. "People get hurt around here too much," says a boy living in Chicago's Cabrini-Green housing project.
"Goin' to Chicago" moves briskly through this large and important piece of history, which for years had largely been ignored. There isn't time in an hour to explain fully the complex economic and social forces that stymied the transplanted Southerners and their children after a buoyant beginning. For that, Nicholas Lemann's 1991 book, "The Promised Land," is an excellent resource. (His book was the basis for a five-hour series produced by BBC and Discovery Productions that appeared on the Discovery Channel in 1995.) So "Goin' to Chicago" isn't the first time the story has been told, or the most complete version, but it's illuminating all the same.
The documentary touches on the big themes but focuses on individual stories -- many of them told by a group of elderly people who return to Greenville, Miss., from Chicago for a reunion. These stories remind us that this may be history, but it lives. The reunion segments, which have the informal feeling of a home movie, remind us that the migration also produced optimism and accomplishment. The promised land may not have ended up flowing with milk and honey, but many people did manage to find a good life (as did many who stayed behind).
The producers rely on standard techniques like interviews and archival film. That's just fine, because the witnesses have strong stories to tell, and so do the pictures. The old people know how to use language to conjure a memory. A woman who grew up in a place called Sunflower County, Miss., gives a succinct definition of sharecropping: "It means you work 20 years for yourself and 20 years for somebody else." Another woman weeps remembering how hungry she was as a child, half a century earlier. Triggering her tears are Proustian recollections -- not of sweet cakes but of skimpy meals of turnips and beans. 
People moved all over the North, but this documentary focuses on Chicago, which took on mythological meaning to those who moved there. "Chicago was the heaven that you fantasized about," says one man. The city offered jobs in its stockyards and manufacturing plants. It had a black newspaper, The Chicago Defender, and lots of music played by great black musicians. While Chicago's industries prospered, so did its black community, though one man admits that the good life may have been exaggerated. "It was the kind of exaggeration people needed to maintain hope," he says.
The city was less welcoming when black people started to integrate neighborhoods. The documentary recalls those ugly moments with film showing hostile whites staring at their new black neighbors unloading their belongings. Old women describe how frightened they were as young girls to discover that their families' upward mobility was an affront to angry white people.
"Goin' to Chicago" is also filled with music, another vital tributary in this particular stream of history. Eventually, the blues, reflecting one kind of misery, gave way to rap, reflecting another. But there's much more to the story than misery-like resilience, bravado, humor, and the documentary reflects that, too.

HEADLINE: New Increases in Worker Output 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
Despite the slowing economy, American workers increased their productivity at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in the last three months of 2000, a gain that was higher than expected, the government reported yesterday.
 At the same time, workers' hourly compensation, adjusted for inflation, rose at an annual rate of 3.8 percent, its fastest growth since the first quarter of 1998. 
 Growth in productivity, a measure of the hourly output of goods and services per worker, has been remarkable for its robustness through much of the expansion over the last decade. The rate in the fourth quarter actually eased, for the second consecutive quarter. Still, the Labor Department said the rate remained high enough to complete a year of 4.3 percent growth over all, the strongest since 1983 and evidence that the productivity gains are lasting. 
"We have a structural improvement in productivity," Bruce Steinberg, chief economist for Merrill Lynch, said, crediting technological advances for the gains. The rise 17 years before was less meaningful, he said, explaining, "It's not at all a comparable year; 1983 is a recovery year from a recession, when productivity is artificially pumped."
The annual productivity growth rate in 2000 peaked in the second quarter at 6.3 percent. The growth rate slowed to 3 percent in the third quarter before dropping off to a gain of 2.4 percent in the last quarter.
Still, economists had expected productivity growth of only about 1.5 percent in the fourth quarter. Many said they were surprised by the stronger figure, which came in part because of the unexpectedly rapid decline in the number of hours worked, said Kathleen Stephansen, director of economic research at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Companies put their employees to work for 1.1 percent fewer hours than in the third quarter, the second consecutive quarterly drop in the number of hours. For the full year, growth in the number of hours worked was the lowest since 1992, as companies reduced workers' hours before resorting to layoffs.
Output of goods and services outside the farm sector grew only 1.2 percent in the fourth quarter, the slowest since the second quarter of 1995.
Viewed in the context of high energy costs, falling consumer confidence and disappointing corporate earnings, the productivity growth numbers tell of a squeeze as employers continued to push for more output in fewer hours, economists said.
"There was bad news for businesses in the compensation costs," said John Youngdahl, at Goldman, Sachs. "Their cost structures were moving up very rapidly."
On the topic of consumer spending, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that in December Americans slowed their pace of increased use of installment credit, defined as borrowing meant to be repaid in four or more installments. Consumers put $3 billion, or 2.4 percent, more on such credit that they did in December 1999. In November, consumer credit had grown $13.9 billion, 11.1 percent more than in November 1999.

HEADLINE: Want a Tax Cut? You Bet. Well, Maybe Not. 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: GRIFFIN, Ga., Feb. 6 

 BODY:
Not a single customer brightened the doorway today during a half-hour conversation with Marion C. Godard in the clothing store he has owned since 1949 in Griffin's seen-better-days downtown.
 Admittedly, Mr. Godard, 76, explained, Tuesdays are often slow. And, yes, a lot of the traffic that once kept North Hill Street bustling has moved out to the strip malls along the highways, where Kmart and Wal-Mart now effortlessly undercut mom and pop stores. 
 But Mr. Godard also senses some nervousness among his customers, senses that they might just be waiting to see whether the economy really flattens before they splurge on a new gray fedora. His January sales were down 15 percent from the previous January. And that is why Mr. Godard, like many of the other proprietors in this small city 45 miles south of Atlanta, is eager to see President Bush push for a hefty tax cut that will put some cash back in their customers' pockets.
"I know exactly where they could spend it," Mr. Godard said, stroking his thin brown tie.
A dozen interviews here, conducted just before Mr. Bush was to send his package to Congress on Thursday, produced a broad consensus about tax cuts: everyone wants one. And any lingering concern about the $1.6 trillion, 10-year cost of the Bush plan, or about its equity, seemed to have been subsumed by Mr. Bush's argument -- echoed last week by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan -- that the slowing economy demanded stimulation. 
Many have already thought about how they would spend the money produced by Mr. Bush's plan to cut income tax rates across the board, double the per-child credit, repeal the tax on large estates and give a break to many two-income couples, among other provisions. 
Tim C. Cramer, a lawyer, would put some of his savings into an individual retirement account, some into a college fund and some into a new bag of golf clubs. Larry W. Lillard, a property tax appraiser for Spalding County, would pay off some of his mortgage. April S. Crawley, a 21-year-old mill worker, would buy new clothes for her two children.
"They take $50 or $100 out of my $500 paycheck," Ms. Crawley said. "It's just like taking my children's livelihood, but I make sure all my bills are paid first before I buy them new clothes." 
Neal Boortz, a conservative talk radio host on WSB-AM in Atlanta, spent nearly his entire four-and-a-half-hour show today fielding calls about Mr. Bush's tax cut. Many callers, Mr. Boortz said, were skeptical that the surplus really existed, and many were also skeptical that Mr. Bush and the Republican majority in Congress would have the fortitude to enact a meaningful reduction.
But there was no lack of desire for a tax cut, Mr. Boortz said.
"I can honestly tell you," he said, "I haven't had one strong phone call from a person who thinks that a tax cut is not needed." 
And yet, when pressed, some of those interviewed here, even those who voted for Mr. Bush and who said they would gladly accept a tax cut, also said it might ultimately be more important to spend the federal surplus on other priorities. They listed paying down the national debt, investing in schools, rebuilding the military, shoring up Social Security and expanding Medicare coverage to include prescription drugs. 
That ambivalence -- the desire to dedicate the estimated $5.6 trillion surplus to both a tax cut and to new spending -- helped make the 2000 presidential election one of the closest in history. And both before and after Election Day, public opinion polls reinforced the sense of North Hill Street, that Americans wanted a tax cut and thought it would help the economy even as they admitted that other priorities should perhaps have taken precedence. 
Polls by CBS News, for instance, found consistently over the last three years that tax cuts were viewed as less important than other priorities. The most recent poll, taken in December, found that 15 percent of those surveyed said they would prefer a tax cut when asked to choose among various ways to spend the surplus. Nearly half said the money should be spent on Social Security and Medicare, as former President Bill Clinton had proposed, while 17 percent favored deficit reduction and 18 percent chose other options.
It is an age-old struggle between personal benefit and community benefit, and many Americans seemingly perceive that the economy today is neither sick enough nor well enough for either imperative to prevail. 
Jimmy G. Jackson left his job with United Parcel Service last year to open the Neighbor's Grill just down the block from Godard's clothing store. Business has been good enough so far, Mr. Jackson said, but he would love a tax cut so he could invest some money in advertising.
"Don't they have like a $5 trillion surplus?" he asked, his brawny arms planted on a well-sheened bar. "I think it should be put back into people's pockets rather than sent off to other countries. I'm a firm believer that you sweep off your own porch first."
So what about America's own porch? What about the needs at home? It makes Mr. Jackson wonder. "Is he going to cut Social Security, Medicaid, school lunches?" he asked. "Where's the money going to come from? Maybe he needs to pay off our bills. I'd be stupid to say I don't want the money, because everybody could use a little extra money. But maybe if he paid off the debt it would be better for the country."
J. Edward Bagby, an interior designer, said he certainly could use a tax cut given that he was still paying the Internal Revenue Service for his tax liability in 1995, 1996 and 1997.
"It's horrible when you're self-employed," Mr. Bagby said, standing among the ornate frames and fabrics in his shop. "One year, right at 60 percent of my income went for taxes."
And after a decade when even middle-class homeowners could afford his $3,500 consulting fees, Mr. Bagby said that he, like Mr. Godard, sensed that the warnings of a slowdown were taking root in consumer psychology. That, too, would seem to make him receptive to a tax cut.
"I'm a little worried that confidence is going to go down, that we're hearing about recession and the economy going down and that people are going to start holding on to their money," Mr. Bagby said.
And yet, he said he worried that Mr. Bush was moving too fast, and that his tax cut would be too large and weighted too heavily toward high earners. "I think that $1.6 trillion is an outrageous figure," Mr. Bagby said. "And maybe he should target more to middle-class Americans. I really think at this point it may be the wrong priority."

HEADLINE: Insurers Push Rates Higher For Medigap 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
The rising costs of prescription drugs are driving up the premiums of insurance plans that supplement traditional Medicare and include drug coverage. The high costs of these so-called Medigap policies are forcing many elderly and disabled people out of the programs even as Medicare managed care plans and employers are retreating from providing drug coverage. 
 While there are wide variations among states and even insurance companies, officials in New York, Illinois and Wisconsin report big increases. 
 Medigap plans cover more than just drugs, helping pay for hospital and doctor charges not covered by Medicare. But it is the drug component of some of these policies that is driving the increase in premiums. For most of the dwindling numbers with Medigap drug coverage, there is no other available option. Michael Metzler, 44, who lives with his parents in Sullivan County, N.Y., on a $1,600 monthly disability stipend, said the increase would absorb 14 percent of his income. "I have no way to make it up," he said. 
How to provide new forms of government help with rising drug costs was an issue in the presidential campaign and is expected to attract renewed attention in Congress. In New York, Empire HealthChoice, the largest Medigap drug insurer, said it would raise premiums 31 percent on March 1 on Medigap policies with drug coverage. In letters to policyholders, Empire said it had underestimated rising medical costs even after 10 percent premium increases in each of the last two years.
"We anticipate that the increases may reduce enrollment somewhat," said Deborah Bohren, a spokeswoman for Empire HealthChoice, formerly called Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
Deborah Chollet, a health insurance economist with Mathematica, a nonprofit research firm, added, "These drug plans will become more and more expensive and less and less available."
The new Empire rates will range from $222 a month, or $2,664 a year, in Albany to $275 a month, or $3,300 a year, in New York City for a plan that pays half of drug costs after the first $250, up to $1,250 a year. 
Ms. Bohren said Empire lost $18 million on Medigap drug policies last year as Medigap policyholders increasingly reached the $1,250 maximum.
Medigap coverage is offered in 10 standard varieties. Two of the Medigap plans cover drugs up to $1,250 a year and one, typically the most expensive, covers drugs up to $3,000. 
About 12 million Americans older than 65 have drug coverage through employer retiree plans, 4 million are covered by Medicaid programs for low-income people, 560,000 have Medigap policies and 12 million more have no drug insurance. In 1999, about 58,000 had Medigap drug coverage in New York; 42,000 had such coverage in New Jersey.
Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee and Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana are planning to reintroduce a bipartisan proposal to give private insurers more responsibility for Medicare with a requirement for drug coverage. President Bush indicated approval for the Frist-Breaux approach during the campaign. 
Revising Medigap is already being studied by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, which helped draft the existing Medigap categories under a mandate from Congress. "One proposal on the table would make all Medigap plans include drugs," said Kathleen Sebelius, the Kansas insurance commissioner and president of the association. 
But Mark Bartorelli, chief actuary of the AARP Medigap unit of the United Healthcare Insurance Company, said "seniors need to have reasonable choices." AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, raised premiums for Medigap drug coverage 10 percent in New York on Jan. 1.
Ms. Bohren said requiring drug coverage would "put Medigap out of the reach of more seniors by raising the cost of the other plans." 
Empire cut the price of a popular Medigap option that does not include drugs by 2 percent. New York regulations limit the percentage of Medigap premiums that a company may retain after paying for health care costs. But Diane Archer, president of the Medicare Rights Center in New York, a national nonprofit advocacy group, said it was "increasingly clear that private health insurers cannot offer affordable prescription drug coverage even to middle-income older and disabled Americans."
"Congress needs to expand Medicare to cover prescription drugs and leverage the government's purchasing power to negotiate fair prices," she said. 
In Wisconsin, which has its own formula for Medigap, the GE Life and Annuity Assurance Company has raised the annual premium for comprehensive coverage, including prescription drugs, 24 percent, to $2,339. In that total, drug coverage rose 35 percent, to $922. All Medigap insurers in Wisconsin must pay 80 percent of catastrophic drug costs of more than $6,200.
Medigap drug coverage increased 16 percent late last year in Arizona and 14.2 percent in Ohio, according to a telephone survey by the Medicare Rights Center. 
In Illinois, Life Investors raised Medigap drug rates by 20 percent and Monumental Life increased drug rates by 26 percent, said Gerald Lucht, an actuary with the state insurance department. AARP rates for drug coverage rose 7 percent, but AARP increased charges 17 percent for a new category covering "the worst risks," he said.
Mr. Bartorelli said AARP was the only insurer that offered a Medigap drug plan in every state, covering about 200,000 people.
The AARP plans have managed to hold down the cost increases to 10 percent or less. Except in New York, which does not permit denial of Medigap coverage, insurers can turn away applicants who are thought likely to have high drug costs.
A recent Towers survey found that costs had increased 14 percent this year in Medigap programs provided to retirees by large employers. Towers negotiates for 40 big employers with 1.5 million retirees and spouses. 
Almost all companies are shifting more drug costs to employees. Payments for drugs by employees rose 14 percent, to $16, on average, for each brand-name drug and $7 for each generic drug last year, according to a survey by William M. Mercer, the benefits consultant. Employees of one in four companies, which required higher payments for drugs not on a preferred list, paid $28 for each drug. 
"Almost everybody over 65 is using medication to a large degree," said Bob Eicher, a principal at the Towers Perrin benefits consulting firm. "It is not unusual to have over $10,000 a year of medication expense for people who are taking eight or nine medications in a given month."

HEADLINE: Bristol-Myers Squibb Names Marketing Official as Chief Executive 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
Peter R. Dolan first made his mark by getting consumers to buy more Jello at General Foods. Now, after 13 years at Bristol-Myers Squibb, the pharmaceutical company, he has been named chief executive, becoming the latest marketing executive to run a major drug company.
 At 45, Mr. Dolan also becomes one of the youngest chief executives of any of the large drug makers. 
 The board of Bristol-Myers voted to promote Mr. Dolan, who is now the company's president, on Tuesday night. He will take over for Charles A. Heimbold Jr., the company's current chief executive and chairman, on May 1.
"This is pretty terrific," Mr. Dolan said in an interview yesterday morning.
He said he was both honored and humbled to be picked to run Bristol-Myers, the nation's fourth-largest pharmaceutical company. Bristol-Myers, based in Manhattan, sold $9 billion in prescription drugs in the United States last year, just behind Pfizer, Glaxo-SmithKline and Merck, said IMS Health, a company that tracks prescription drug information.
Mr. Dolan joins Jean-Pierre Garnier at GlaxoSmithKline and Sidney Taurel at Eli Lilly in being made chief executive after working their way up the corporate ranks mostly through sales and marketing.
And last summer, Novartis promoted Thomas Ebeling, a former marketing executive at Pepsi-Cola, to be global head of pharmaceuticals.
Mr. Dolan said his consumer marketing experience was important because drug companies could no longer rely on selling their drugs only by having their sales representatives visit physicians. Instead, companies must also reach out to consumers through advertising, he said, and to the governments and the managed care companies that pay for most drugs.
Already, Mr. Dolan has shown that he can convert his marketing expertise into higher sales. As president of the Mead Johnson Nutritional Group of Bristol-Myers in 1995, he made Enfamil the top-selling infant formula in the country by advertising the product to mothers in addition to promoting it to pediatricians.
Mr. Dolan is taking over at Bristol-Myers as the drug industry faces increasing criticism over the rising cost of medicines.
Senior citizens are pressing Congress to have Medicare help pay for prescription drugs. And some states, which now pay for drugs for the poor through the Medicaid program, are calling for drug companies to reduce their prices.
Bristol-Myers and other companies are also being pressed to make significant reductions in the prices of drugs that are needed to fight AIDS in Africa and other areas of the world.
At the same time, several of the company's drugs face possible competition from lower-priced generics. Its diabetes drug, Glucophage, and an anti-anxiety drug, BuSpar, could soon face competition. And sales of its cancer drug, Taxol, are falling after Ivax, a company that produces generic drugs, began selling a lower-cost version of that drug last year. 
Bristol-Myers has been one of the most aggressive drug companies in filing lawsuits and using other legal maneuvers to try to add months or years to the dates that the patents on its medicines are set to expire. The Federal Trade Commission said last year that it was investigating whether Bristol-Myers broke any federal laws as it tried to keep Ivax from selling its generic version of Taxol.
Mr. Dolan said the company had to take whatever legal actions were available to it to extend its patent rights or it would face the wrath of shareholders.
"We feel we're doing the right thing," he said.
Analysts had expected Mr. Dolan to be named chief executive, and generally praised the choice. "He has experience, youth and energy on his side," said Neil B. Sweig, an analyst at Ryan, Beck & Company. "But there's no denying that Bristol has problems to solve. He'll have no honeymoon." 
Bristol-Myers hired Mr. Dolan in 1988 as vice president for marketing at its Bristol-Myers Products division, after General Foods was acquired by Philip Morris.
"I decided I wanted to work at a health care company," he said, "rather than a tobacco company."
Mr. Dolan served as president of the Bristol-Myers European pharmaceutical business in 1997, and became the president of the company last year.
Recently, he was the creative force behind the advertisements for Taxol that featured Lance Armstrong, the cyclist who won the Tour de France after a battle with cancer, company executives say.
Mr. Dolan said his mother had died of ovarian cancer and his sister had ovarian and colon cancer, which were now in remission.
"The company's mission of extending and enhancing life is very personal to me," he said.
An avid cyclist himself, Mr. Dolan and his wife have ridden in the two-day 192-mile Pan-Massachusetts Challenge, a fund-raiser for the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, for the last five years.
In his spare time, Mr. Dolan skis, dives and plays tennis with his wife and two sons, ages 12 and 14. The family lives in Larchmont, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Book Calling Holocaust a Shakedown Starts a German Storm 

BYLINE:  By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Feb. 7 

 BODY:
The publication of a book here today by an American historian declaring that the Holocaust has become an "extortion racket" through which some Jews blackmail Germany has ignited a stormy debate.
 A television documentary on the author, Norman Finkelstein, that was to have been carried on Monday was canceled at the last moment, and newspapers have been full of virulent discussion over whether the book is a "breath of fresh air," as one has put it, or a dangerous invitation to anti-Semitism. 
 "Germany is right to reject the use of the Nazi Holocaust as a weapon for political and economic gain," Mr. Finkelstein said at a packed news conference. "The Holocaust has long since ceased to be a source of moral and historical enlightenment. It has become a straight-out extortion racket." 
The author, whose parents were Holocaust survivors, was presenting the German translation of his book, "The Holocaust Industry" (Verso), published last year in the United States to a generally hostile reception. It was also published in Britain. Its central argument is that what he calls an "American-Jewish elite" has appropriated the Holocaust and debased it for financial gain.
The book's publication here comes at a particularly sensitive time. Long negotiations that culminated last year with an agreement for the German government to pay $4.8 billion to people coerced into working for the Nazis revealed growing impatience here with such quests for compensation.
Germany has also suffered a wave of anti-Semitic and xenophobic attacks over the past year. 
In this context, Piper Verlag, the publishers of Mr. Finkelstein's book, came under pressure to refrain from publication.
Ignoring the pressure, and sensing a commercial success, Piper Verlag has published 50,000 copies -- a large initial printing. It has come to the accompaniment of bitter criticism from leading German historians, including Michael Brenner of Ludwig-Maximilian University in Munich, who has described the book as the work of a pathological anti-Zionist who sees "Israel's conspiratorial influence everywhere."
Mr. Finkelstein, protected by security guards, and looking tense, said he was "concerned about the enthusiastic reception of my book that may occur in right-wing circles." His message is certain to be seized upon by rightists and other Germans simply impatient with the reduction of German history to the 12 Nazi years.
But the author, who teaches at Hunter College, said his worries about how the German right would use his book were outweighed by his determination to put "the Holocaust industry out of business" and so end what he called the "exploitation of my parents' memory."
By "Holocaust industry," Mr. Finkelstein appeared to be referring essentially to the World Jewish Congress and the Jewish Claims Conference, whose roles have been prominent in securing the latest compensation from the German government. 
Gideon Taylor, the executive vice president of the claims conference, rejected Mr. Finkelstein's accusations as "reckless and unsubstantiated allegations."
While some leading American historians have welcomed Mr. Finkelstein's determination to open up the subject of how the Holocaust is remembered for debate, they have generally been fiercely critical of his conspiracy theories about American Jews and contested the accuracy of the book.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Rivera's Agent Is Fired, Setting Back Negotiations

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Mariano Rivera salary arbitration hearing, scheduled for today, was postponed yesterday amid a corporate confrontation that resulted in the dismissal of the pitcher's agent. Rivera, the Yankees' premier reliever, is the player most immediately affected by the dispute, but it is a far-ranging conflict that touches the owner of the Texas Rangers and other agents.
 The hearing, which was tentatively rescheduled for next week, was postponed several hours before the SFX Sports Group announced that Jim Bronner, Rivera's primary agent, and Bob Gilhooley, Bronner's partner, had been fired "for cause." 
 A company spokesman declined to say what the cause was, but a lawyer close to SFX said it stemmed from an attempt by the agents to restructure their deals with SFX because of the position of Tom Hicks, the Rangers' owner, with the entertainment company's parent company. Hicks is vice chairman and a director of Clear Channel Communications. Bronner and Gilhooley had been concerned about the possible conflict his position presented. 
Another lawyer said it was more an economic issue. SFX was willing to give its baseball agents additional money as a result of its purchase by Clear Channel, the lawyer said, but Bronner and Gilhooley wanted more. "They overplayed their hand," he said.
SFX, the first lawyer said, tired of the agents' efforts and fired them. Bronner and Gilhooley, the company acknowledged, filed a lawsuit against it in Chicago. Bronner and Gilhooley did not return telephone calls seeking comment.
Rivera will continue to be represented by Speakers of Sport, the Chicago area agency that Bronner and Gilhooley began 25 years ago, then sold to SFX a year ago. His designated agent is Fernando Cuza, who along with four other agents of the firm, SFX said, had agreed to remain with SFX and represent the Bronner-Gilhooley clients.
If the Yankees and their closer go to a hearing, at which Rivera would seek a $10.25 million salary against the Yankees' bid of $9 million, Cuza said he would participate in it. But Rivera's case would be argued by Randy Hendricks, who is the head of SFX's baseball business and has vast arbitration experience. SFX bought the agency operated by Hendricks and his brother, Alan, in 1999. 
Cuza said yesterday that he hoped to conclude a deal with the Yankees before the hearing, which would most likely be held next Wednesday or Thursday.
"I've been talking with the Yankees since yesterday," Cuza said in a telephone interview. "We'd like to work something out before the hearing. I like our chances."
Although there was at least the possibility that Randy Hendricks would become involved in negotiations because he and his brother have a good relationship with the Yankees, Cuza said he expected to continue in the negotiating role.
The Yankees had developed a testy relationship with Bronner. They were unable to conclude a multiyear deal for Rivera a year ago, and they have had difficulty again this time. The Yankees had offered Rivera $36 million for four years, while Bronner, at Rivera's direction, had proposed a four-year deal in the $43 million area.
Bronner said this week that the Yankees had said they would make another offer but had not done so. "It's hard to resolve anything if they're not willing to negotiate," Bronner said.
SFX did not say what the crux of the agents' lawsuit against it was. At the time Clear Channel purchased SFX Entertainment, less than a month after SFX bought Speakers of Sport, Bronner and Gilhooley expressed concern about the conflict that Hicks's position with Clear Channel represented -- a team owner with agents as his employees. 
Bronner and Gilhooley would very likely seek to show that SFX breached its contract with them by selling to Clear Channel and attempt to void a clause in their sale agreement that prohibits them from competing with SFX for a designated period, most likely five years.
In its news release, SFX said it would move to dismiss the lawsuit.
